Draught @ Some pub in San Francisco. Rated on 20.10.2012.

Pours a golden amber colour with a white head. Aroma of strong floral hops, grass and peach. Flavour of floral hops, strong bread-like maltiness, grapefruit, lemon zest, pine and oh so sweet caramel. Medium bodied, slick mouthfeel and high carbonation. Too sweet and lacks bitterness.

Pours clear amber with long-lasting head, good fizzy lacing, and small sediment.  Aroma is citrus, some grass, but pretty subdued for a DIPA,  Taste is very balanced between a tasteful hop bitterness and a healthy dose of sweet malts and bread to balance.  Palate is lively with plenty of lasting carbonation.  Aftertaste is subtle in bitterness, balanced.  No glaring flaws, but seems to be missing something I can’t put my finger on to propel it into world-class.

Aroma is peaches, some pine, and very citrusy hops.  Taste feels very sweet on the tip of your tongue, moving right into tart hops on the sides of mouth into the finish.  Not overly bitter for how strong the flavor is.  Very thick and full palate.  Feel the ABV without any obvious taste.  Very good IPA!  7+4+8+4+17=4.0

Golden to orange color with a head that faded quick.  Good lacing.  Aroma of pine, citrus and sugar.  Mouth is full.  Taste is sugary and tropical fruit like.  Huge citrus content along with some pine.  This is a very nice beer but maybe a little too boozy.
Loses a bit of character as it gets soapier and boozier, but still a decent drink. Good malt character and little to no aftertaste.
Bottle. Pours a clear amber color with a moderately thick white head. Nice hoppy nose with some great malty and hoppy bitter flavors to it. A little thick, but a fun drink.
355ml bottle. Clear amber color, nice white head. Sweet, bready, malty, hops in aroma. Malty, hoppy, sweet, caramel, fruity flavor. Very fruity brew. Quite nice.

355ml bottle (Systembolaget, Stockholm)

Sweet caramelly biscuity malts in the aroma, and lots of fruity hops too. Smooth slick palate, but crisp carbonation cuts through that well. In the mouth it’s full of sugars, tons of caramel, and loads of fleshy fruit flavours too. Some alcohol wafts over too. Too much sugar, and it fails to cover the alcohol. However, despite those negatives, there is a hedonistic aspect, the sticky juicy friuts just tempt you in. One only for the end of the evening, I’d think.

Bottle. Clear, amber colour with medium off-white frothy head, that sits down slowly and became creamy with nice lacing. Strong, gorgeous hoppy aroma, also cactus, nettle, grass, herbs, grapefruit. Flavor is heavy bitter with some liquor notices. Outstanding beer!

Bottled from Systembolaget
Clear amber with a medium head.
Sweet and creamy aroma with grassy hops.
Fukk-bodied sweetness in the flavour. Tropical fruits and toffee. Medium bitterness.

Not sure if I got a bad bottle, but found this to be a step back from their ipa in both hop presence and mouthfeel. A strange beer without much bite and just not very good. Could mistake this for a pilsner.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle.
Amber with an off-white to beige head leaving lacing.
Aroma: peaches, ripe pineapple, butterscotch, pine.
Taste: pineapple, butterscotch, some salt, orange and blood grapefruit, pine, some salt, medium bitter.
Medium-bodied.

Botte @Lagunitas tasting at Artisan Wine Depot. Pours clear light amber with a small white head that dissipates with some lacing. Aroma is surprisingly malty with forward notes of caramel and bread with a pine/citrus backing. Flavor is about the same, medium to quite sweet, light to medium bitter and a bit grassy on the finish. Way to malty for me.

Bottle: Thanks Soren:
Medium sized sticky vast creamy white head, changes slowly into a closed creamy white lacing on top of an almost clear orange amber colored beer.
Smell hops, hop fruit, citrus, grapefruit, nettle, cornflakes, oatmeal, some hay, cream.
Taste hops, barleys, corn, hopfruit tints, light grapefruit, orange, peach, mango, honey, nettle, light bitter, creamy, some vanilla, floral.
Aftertaste honey, grass, cream, barley and of course hop, hop fruits and light hop bitters.
Low carbo, soft mouthfeel, good medium to lightly fuller body and a creamy texture.

Bottle from Systembolaget, Sweden. Pours amber. Lots of slightly orange head. Hop and alcohol nose. Hop, resin, malt, citrus, pineapple aroma. Very bitter. Lots of malt and fruit sweetness. A good IIPA.
Ganska söt ipa, mycket humle. Gräs. Malt. Fruktighet så det smäller om det. Medelbeska som blir uttalad först i eftersmaken som är ganska kort. En aning punsch? Trevlig ipa, men inte fantastisch. 3.5

Bärnstens färgad, klar med stort skum. Humle, gran, jord, söt malt och lite spritig doft. Söt maltig smak med beska som nästan väger upp det söta. Smaken är som doften men mer fruktig och mindre spritig. Smakerna åker upp och ner, kommer, går och kommer igen. Först söt sen besk när man sväljer sen söt igen och besk eftersmak. Mysko, första ölen jag dricker som är så här, kanske därför jag fastnat lite.

Light amber colour with a light fluffy head at 2 fingers. Aroma of grass and citrus. A lovely taste with much flavour to it. Taste of caramell (or something smooth like vanilla) in background, hops, sweet/smooth malts and hints of grass and citrus. Some fruits and hints of whisky. A nice hoppy bitterness which is just enough and not overwelming. Although not quite as strong as other imperial/double IPAs.

From notes, 9/29/11:
Poured a 12oz bottle into a Sam Adams perfect pint.

A: Light amber, clear with medium amount of carbonation bubbles. 2 finger white head that dissipates slowly; no lacing.

S: Piney hops, some sweetness.

T: Again, the piney hops, but not overpowering. Malty sweetness to keep the hops in check. Grapefruit in the finish.

M: Medium and very nice. Makes for a very drinkable DIPA.

O: I liked this one; serves as a good weekly hop fix for a non-hophead.
Bottle. Amber colour with a white head. Strong hoppy aroma. Strong floral flavour.

Strong aroma of pine and hops.  Copper amber in color...head holds up nicely.  Heavy hops in front, with a surprising sweet note,,,,followed by spices, and some citrus.  Finishes with a lot of bitterness with a little too much aftertase.

Draught.  Orange gold beer with creamy head.  The aroma is a blast strong ripe fruity and spicy hops.  The flavor is way too sugary fruit juice sweet and that coats the palate while overwhelming most of the hops.  Not into it at all.
Amber with a medium white head. Sweet and fruity tones. Malt, fruit, sweet and bitter. Full body with a nice, bitter sweet finish.
Pours golden orange with medium head. Sweet and sour aroma. A real hop juice, lot of taste, grapefruit and tropical fruit.
Ett öl som dryper av smaker. Skikten är så många och täta att det enda sättet att njuta av ölet är att bara ge sig hän. Analyser är endast smolk i den här glädjebägaren.
Pretty much everything I love in an imperial ipa. Very drinkable, but not too overwhelming.

355 ml bottle bought @ Systembolaget. Pours tiny hazy deep golden with a frothy and slightly fizzy white head that slowly dissipates while leaving some sticky trace on the glass. Smell is slightly sweet, tiny sour and hoppy with orange peal marmalade, bread, dried apricots, caramel, alcohol, overripe plums, resinous wood, raisins, grapefruit juice and moist grass. Taste is tiny sweet, bitter, tiny sour and slightly fruity with bread, grapefruit juice, orange peal, lemon peal, orange peal marmalade, raisins, prunes, golden syrup, caramelized apples, pine, alcohol,  apricot marmalade and dried peaches. Mouthfeel is tiny dry, tiny astringent, round, tiny sticky sweet and medium bodied. Finish is tiny sweet and bitter with bread, orange peal, marmalade, moist grass, pine, dried apricots and hints of caramel. Feels stale hop-wise. Probably not very fresh…
Copper-gold pour with decent head and nice lacing. Mild pine-fruity hops. A  somewhat hearty DIPA.

Served from a bottle at Lockview on 06/04/12.

A: orange-ish amber color with a beautiful cream finger head. pretty good lacing along the glass.

S: strong tangerine-citrus scent with malts. Little to no hop tones.

T: pretty good alcohol kick, hints of hops and malts. Finishes pretty bitter.

M: pretty easy to drink, the alcoholic taste doesn’t deter from the taste.

O: not too bad to drink. I could easily get this one again, but I wouldn’t put it on my favorites list.

One of my first "favorites". A very strong, hop forward brew with excellent balance. The abv is well hidden but you definitely know its a strong beer. Great hop flavors without a really bitter finish. I love this beer.
355ml Bottle - Amber with a foamy head. Pine, peach, grapefruit and toffee in the aroma. Hoppy taste with notes of tangy grapefruit, peach, toffee and dried fruit. Enjoyable.

Bomber. Pours a golden-orange-amber color with a nice white head that leaves little lacing. Aroma is citrus, and really piney hops. The flavor is of pine resin, caramel malts, and some citrus. The alcohol is still present at 70 IBU, though not too overpowering. Medium body malty mouthfeel with a nice dry finish. I would like a little more bitterness and a little less sweetness; just like Lagunitas Hop Stoopid!
Flaska systembolaget. Fin färg, mycket smak. Omvärderar denna, bättre bedömning idag!

Bottle: Red/cobbery colour, with a nice big head. Aroma was dominated of sweetmaltynes, mixed with a nice frech citrus, flowery nose, and some vanilla and caramelly! Flavor had a nice fruity citrus mouthfeeling, mixed with a nice maltynes balanced. Medium body, and a long fruity,cuitrus finish. Well done!!

Det är alltid lika roligt att upptäcka riktigt god öl, och det här är en sådan öl. Smaken präglas främst av grape, äpple och gräs, beskan är dov, ihängande och balanserad. Slutsats: en riktigt bra öl.
Clear amber with small head. Resin, caramel and citrus peel. Ending with a good bitterness. It’s really hoppy.

Pours clear amber with a small white head. Aroma has light hop cues, pine, spruce, a touch of resin. Thereâ€™s also a lot of caramel malt in there, with a hint of vanilla and butterscotch. Taste is sweet at first, before turning into a balanced, almost held back bitterness. Body is a tad too light for the style, and the finish, while long, is very elusive. Low carbonation.

Bottle from Systembolaget.
Pours amber with a 2 finger frothy head that leaves nice lacing on the glass.
Aroma is pretty sweet, malts, flowers, some chewing gum/candy sweetness and some bitterness at the end.
Taste is quite bready and sweet at first, quite a lot of alcohol shines through, tangerine and hop bitterness in the after taste. 
Medium bodied, medium carbonation. Mouth feel is quite sticky.
Too sweet for me and the alcohol is to prominent. Perhaps the bottle is not that fresh as the hoppiness is not straight forward at all.

Update: Had another bottle, not as tired as the one I tried first. Much better this time. More hops which added a bitter marmalade touch, not that much alcohol that shone through.

Aroma: Smelling toffee, pine needles and resin, tropical fruits, very neat.
Appearance: The ale is clear amber with small bubbles, a warm off-white head leaving good lacing, medium curtains.
Taste: Starting sweet, sultanas, peaches, mango, pine-apple, bitter orange peel (reminds me of Loranga soda (approx. Fanta)).
Palate: Medium carbonation, soft and oily, slightly sticky, a medium body and a slightly dry finish.
Overall: A very fruity DIPA, not bad, but no real groove.
Note: Bottle 355 ml. Reviewed 2012-09-10.

Bottle from Systembolaget. Pours hazy amber with a thin lasting head. Piney full aroma, typical of american pale ales. The taste is a let down, more piney bitterness, hardly any malt at all.  Too bad, the beer is a looker but it tastes like a hop concentrate. I have higher requirements for a beer.

12oz. Deep golden pour with a towering head. "Smack in the face" says piney hops! A hefty caramel malt note and some grapefruit linger. Damn can you taste the hops throught this. More and more piney/citrusy hops dominate the palate. A hoplovers dream here. Slightly heavy body and maybe a "one and done" for the night beer.

Bottle, pours clear copper with small-medium off white head. Aroma is sticky sweet hops with citrus, sweet orange, some peach. Taste is sweet with sticky resin hops. Medium bitteness. Oily mouthfeel. 
Ok, little bit to sweet for my taste.

Ar: jam, honey, alcohol, solvents, can’t detect the hops at all at first, after a while I find some grapefruit and resin, but very subdued. 
Ap: Amber colour, no head.
F: boozy, very boozy, medicinal bitterness, not at all pleasant?
M: flat almost no carbonation.
T: have I got a faulty bottle? Will need to try Another one to be sure, but this was horrible.

Rerate: malty, but noticable hoppiness, grapefruit, bread, caramel, citric, resinous, tropical fruits, amber colour, medium white head, lacing. Medium bite for the style, pronounced maltiness, ABV noticable. 
Medium/fullbodied, average carbonation, sweet and bitter finish.
Too malty, but obviously the first bottle I ratead was faulty in some way.

Bottle from Systembolaget. Clear copper with a frothy one inch head,  Quite sweet aroma, resin, caramel some dried fruit as well, grapefruits, oranges. Taste is sweet (molasses, dark sugar) balanced by a non-overpowering bitterness. The maltiness makes it almost Barley wineish. Medium body.
Bottled. Pours copper with a white head. Smells nutty fresh hoppy. Tastes creamy sweet hoppy, abit candy malt with a similar finish.
Flaska från SB. KLar bärnsten med fin "mörkvit" skumkrona. Hyggligt med humle och tydlig beska, inslag av apelsin

Poured into a pint glass ...the color on this beer is perfect a nice hazy orange/amber,lots of citrus on the nose very juicy grapefruit, oranges,mango and pineapple are all mixed in here ,nice 2 finger off white head with decent lacing,taste is actually  sweet for a IIPA but is very refreshing with a heavy malt backbone to level out the hops up front and a nice bitter finish, a damn good brew...cheersl

Bottle from Systembolaget.
Pours clear amber with a huge firm white head, leaves lots of lacing.
Taste of biscuits, fudge and lemon, lots of lemon. Lots of alcohol and over all a very divert taste.
Helt okej IPA. Aningen för söt och sedan saknar jag friskheten från humlen. Maltigheten tar över. Liten beska med apelsintoner.

@ Basunen: ganska brödig doft. Smaken är helt ok men lite söt. Mycket malt. Ganska tunn kropp. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

0,355 flaske i København, innkjøpt på Thørst i juli-10: Litt mørkere enn  Lagunitas IPA, og mer av alt i forhold til denne; grapefrukt, florale antydninger og god maltsødme i aroma og smak. God munnfylde. Meget drikkbar, må prøves igjen. Og heldigvis bød anledningen seg på Cardinaltreff i juni-13: aromaen følges opp av smaken. Så godt humlet at den fjerner caries. Oppfra 3.8 til 4 - libvet er godt på mandager!

355ml bottle. A little darker colour than the standard Lagunitas IPA, looks a little filtered. Full grapefruit and sweet bread malt aromas. Taste has grapefruit, floral and herbal tea qualities. The malt is strong with some rich molasses flavours and well balances the hops. Nice thick body. Overall, a very tasty beer. The malts really stood out here and made it very drinkable.

This is a very balanced ipa. You get a bit of everything. Hops, bitterness, citrus, floral lightness, malt and body. The only bad thing is that none of it really stands out. Also, the overall "taste" of the maltiness may not appeal to everyone.

Tap @ Lagunitas: clear bright orange with a thin head and short lacing. Aroma is predominant orange, citrus, all hops up front, Taste of sweet citrus, some maltyness, floral. Good bright clean mouth feel, good lasting bitter finish. Good balanced brew!

Sample at BrewPub



A - Burnt caramel appearance. 2 finger head, okay lacing. head fades fast.



S - Some pine and sugars. Smelling tangerine as well



T - Very biter taste with a heavy malt backbone. Loads of pine and oranges.



M - Medium carbonation and body with big malt finish.



O - Standard in taste. Nothing too exciting.
35 cl bottle @ home. Pours clear amber with a white head that leaves some lacing. Aroma is fruity and resinous hops as well as a little malt. Flavour is quite similar to the aroma.

Poured into a Samuel Smith pint glass.

A: Pours a golden copper color with solid clarity and tiny trails of carbonation. The head is a two finger offwhite color with decent frothiness and average retention, leaving spotty clumps of lacing on the glass.

S: This has a strong herbal component, along with grapefruit rind, and the typical caramel maltiness I normally smell/taste from Lagunitas.

T: Quite sweet, in fact it might be a bit too sweet. Hops are very hard to find in the flavor, meaning this could be an older bottle (y’know, Total Wine, and whatnot...) After a bit, a nice grapefruit flavor finally appears on the aftertaste. But there is good news - the malt backbone is well executed, with notes of caramel, honey, brown sugar, and a hint of finishing booze. It falls short as a DIPA, but wow it’s a great strong ale, albeit one that’s a bit cloying after a while.

M: There’s an excellent silky creaminess to the texture, along with subtle hop oil lingering on the aftertaste. The body has a medium to heavy feel on the tongue and slight dryness. Average carbonation.

O: If it had a bit more hoppiness to balance things out, this would be flat-out fantastic. As it stands, it’s still a great no-frills DIPA. Highly recommended for those who like sweet DIPAs.
Dark amber with a thick white head. Fresh green hops on the nose. Medium to full bodied IPA with high carbonation. Crisp, bright and full of hops. Bitter, yet clean and refreshing on the finish.

Clear deep golden orange with white head. Farm dirt, with orange and other citrus aroma. Orange flavor with grassy subtleties. Bitter finish blends well with a bready malt and the citrus again dominates late palate.
If you dig ipas, you’ve prolly had it.  I was sold on lagunitas after i toured the brewery and im still partial to hopstupid, but my 2nd fav.... Drank it

12 oz. bottle from SoHo Organic Market in Elizabeth City, NC.  Dark orange pour with a frothy off-white head.  Aroma of peach, mango, and grapefruit rind.  Very nice citrus hop flavor of pineapple and grapefruit with an assertive malt backbone that adds to the balance more than it makes it too sweet.  A nice DIPA!

Shared at a tasting at my place, Pours orange to yellow with a small head, aroma of honey, caramel, malt, orange, flavor is bitter with some orange and hoppy notes and malty backbone, medium bodied, way over its peak

Semi-clear orangish color with one finger of head with good retention.  Smell of citrus with earthy pine.  Earthy taste of orange with yeast and grass detectable.  Bitter as IPAs usually are but not overbearing.   Warm alcohol feel.  Good for the style but not to my taste.

Poured this beer from the bottle into a trumpet glass to drink.  The beer had a semi-cloudy amber-orange color with a good-sized foamy white head with average retention, but great lacing and cling.  It had a big citrus and pine hops aroma with some sugar and spices, along with touches of lemon and wheat, and some lighter yeast and barley.  The taste was of somewhat bitter citrus and slight sour grainy undertones, along with a touch of lemon.  The beer had some decent life and fizz, good carbonation, and was not too dry, with a filling mouthfeel.

Bottle sample, thanks zvikar, small head, clear rusty orange colour, flavour of orange and strawberry jam, tobbaco and just a hint of orange blossom, flavour of orange marmalade, tobbaco and  biscuity malt. a bit too sweet, strong pleasant bittersweet. long bittersweet aftertaste. Too sweet, probably  past its prime.

#IPADay, my after work treat.  Bottle poured into snifter glass, copper color with wheat head that disappears.  Aroma is pineapple and grapefruit citrus hops.  Taste is sweet, floral, very hoppy and a little caramel.  Alcohol well hidden, aftertaste is surprisingly short lived.  Enjoyed.

Copper color out of bottle. Soft nose. Grapefruit and faint hops. Citrus hops cascade down your throat. Super hoppy but very drinkable. Good good good  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Appearance: beautiful orange and copper under a meringue bready white head which fades bubbly and patchy. Fades with clumps and random spots of lace.


Nose: mint and leafy herbs, fir trees and grapefruit. Very zesty and alive. White crackers in the back.


Palate: fresh mint leaf, fir trees, and ferns. Oak and rind finish – grapefruit and pine. Raw hop resins of the forest and grapefruit groves. Full sticky mouthfeel – hops, oranges, and grapefruit oils. Mint and herbs weave in and out. Tickle of sweet spiced heat in the back – oak and orange liquor. Sticky. Orange and sweetness comes forward while pine and grapefruit falls into the back as it warms up.


Final Thoughts: I wasn’t expecting much but wow, did I get a happy surprise in the Maximus Imperial IPA from Lagunitas Brewing. Delicious! Fresh, lively, playful, and a welcome addition to my fridge any day.
Bottle pour with a solid head. Mild citrus aroma. Very smooth for a DIPA, not a lot of bite. Overall a very good beer.
Poured from a bottle with a nice head.  Hop lovers rally!  Great beer, not to be missed.

Poured from a 12oz bottle into a snifter. Pours with a moderate amount of fluffy white head and just a little lacing. Both are less than I thought. Dark gold, just a shade over auburn, color. Mouthfeel is light to medium. Too much carbonation. Aroma is very flowery with some mango. Taste is sweet and flowery. Lots of tropical fruit and some all-spice. Very good beer. Not really an IIPA but bigger than a regular IPA. Very tasty. A good combination and a very drinkable beer!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Could Lagunitas possibly improve their IPA?  The company’s description says it right; Lagunitas IPA pumped up 30%.  If you are an IPA fan you will like this one.  Grapfruity citrus and a hint of grassy sumpin’ sumpin’ blend with the decent a/c to make this a highly enjoyable brew.  I like these after a large meal, two or more at a time.

I'm smelling pineapple and marmalade. Tasting some caramel, marmalade. Sweet with slight hoppy aftertaste. 

22 from Mesa gas station

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a clear amber color.  Aroma is mostly citrus.  The body is medium.  The alcohol is subdued considering the high ABV.  The taste is hops with a nice amount of sweetness.  It is well balanced, smooth and has a clean finish with little lingering bitterness.   A very nice DIPA.

Pours an bright golden/orange with a thinner white head.  Aroma consists of grapefruit, orange, apple, and grass.  Taste is very similar to the aroma, with the orange and grapefruit being more pronounced.  Nice hoppy bite.  Drinking is pretty clean and more crisp than others of this style.  Aftertaste is short and citrus.  Overall, this is pretty good, but isn't anything amazingly special.

Pours an orange amber color with a small off white head. Aromas are citrus, grass and ripe nectarine. On the palate its more of the same but with a nice sweet apricot malt backbone that is very refreshing and not syrupy in mouthfeel.

Purse hazy tangerine, aromas of sweet rich marmalade malt with a subtle hop citrus highlight. Flavour is immense: so much aggressive hop bitterness, complimented by an almost fruity, estery malt backbone, and rounded out with a lovely candied orange finish. Seriously one to hunt down.
Hop Stoopid is correct.  Outstanding bitterness.  Color,  aroma and taste all good. Love it

Pours a hazy greyish-green with a cumulonimbus head. Heavy lacing. Sexy herbal scent, laced with a touch of tartness and vanilla. Thick lemony flavor, with overtones of chocolate and sherry. Non-descript mouthfeel and delicate finish.

Small half finger head, golden brown, minimal lace. Nose is very sweet with some earthy and hoppy accents. Taste up front has some citrus and biscuit, followed by a little sugary hop kick. Goes down easy. I’m intrigued because it does not taste even in the ballpark of 72 IBUs. Good beer but wouldn’t think it was a DIPA from the taste. Alcohol hidden well.
Out of the bottle so color is hard to judge. Smell is sweet without much hoppiness. Taste is much sweeter than I expected or would have liked. Not too bad, but not my favorite.

Poured from a bottle. Nice medium copper color, decent head with good lacing. Nose is a spicy yeast and a bit malty for a DIPA, but it’s deceiving. In the mouth it’s  all tropical fruit and floral hops. Slight lingering hop bitterness. Clean finish like most brews from LBC. An excellent example of the style.

From a bottle to a duvel tulip. Pours a clear orange amber with an inch of white head that shrinks to cover the top and leaves ok lacing. Aroma is tropical fruit up front. Pineapple, mango, and orange. Theres also caramel and a bit of pepper. Taste is a bit piney with more mild tropical fruits. There’s also a good caramel malt balance. This is well balanced and nowhere near as bitter as I expected. There is some alcohol burn. Mouthfeel is thin to medium with higher carbonation. Pretty good.

Pours orange-gold with small head and some top lacing.  Smell is potent orange citrus - very, very sweet-smelling - and some pine.  Taste is orange juice, pine, alcohol, and more orange juice.  Teeny bit sour, but not enough to offend.  Pretty unusual DIPA - would like a little more to the smell and flavor other than the big orange profile - but not bad.  ABV well-hidden.  Good mouthfeel for a DIPA.  Might convert fans of screwdrivers.

Pours copper with a thin head and virtually no lacing. Aroma is malty caramel and the taste is the same on the front end. For an 8.2% ABV, this doesn’t taste very alcoholic. At the back end on the tongue, the caramel and maltiness dissipates and a nice grapefruit with small amounts of citrus finishes the beer. Very enjoyable.

Clear bright orange yellow, fine rocky white head lasts, leaving definitive stepped lacing. Strong piney citrus hoppy aroma and taste, with a subdued sweet caramel malt background. Average carbonation, medium bodied, moderately hopped. Alcohol well hidden. Dry hoppy finish. Very good. LBW (Lagerboys Be Wary)
Pours hazy orange..big head...aroma is caramel hopps fruit..  Taste us similar ..awesome taste..well balanced with smooth finish

Aroma rich bready malt caramel..hidden under big citrus...expected bigger hop aroma.  Pours golden amber crystal clear with white head that goes away quickly.  Big piny hop flavor with malty richness and alcohol finish..sweeter than expected...balanced toward malt, finish has sweet the lingers in palate.

Pours a nice copper with a great two finger head that dissipates and leaves solid lacing. Aroma is citrus and pine, all hops. Taste is also pretty much all hops, a bit of alcohol burn. Nice california	DIPA.

Pours copper with low head.
Aromas of caramel malts, brown sugar, toffee, hoppyness of some tropical fruits
Very nice palate that starts out sweet almost vanilla fudgy like and moves over to a medium bitter ending. Some oakyness there as well. Really good!
Lucious, one of the better IPA’s I’ve ever tasted.  My wife normally doesn’t care for IPA’s, and she loved this one.
Hops don’t overwhelm the flavor. Alcohol is smooth. Light on the palate. Clean finish. Great with spicy food--just had mine with jerk chicken.
Thick white head covered a golden body. A great beer..slightly on the bitter side. Hoppy and citrusy. All Lgunitas IPA’s has an orange taste to it, this one is no exception.
Bright orange in color with a good sized white head. Aroma is of grapefruit, floral, light grass. Taste is of caramel, grapefruit, lemon, light pine.

Bottle. Orange colored, clear, inviting, nice lacing white head. The smell is citrus, grapefruits, floral, sweet, hops, and caramel. The taste is hops, grapefruits, citrus, slight bitterness bite but not too much. Good.

Poured form a 12 oz. bottle into a tulip glass. Pours a hazy copper color with a light tan head that leaves decent lacing. Aroma is of light malt, caramel, grape, and citrus/pine. Taste is sweet, malty, with a hint of citrus, and an undertone of bitterness. The bitterness becomes apparent with alcohol on the backend. Decent mouthfeel with a light carbonation. Overall a good beer but not very reminiscent of the D-IPA style.
12 oz bottle pours a orange/amber color with a nice white head.  Aromas of grapefruit rind, citrus, pine and sweet malt.  Medium bodied, nicely balanced, alcohol well hidden with a nice bitter finish

From bottle to tulip. Pours a hazy amber with a two finger beige head. Smells of bread, caramel, and hops but also slightly sour. Tastes much of the same with the hops more predominant but the sour sweet malts coming through. MF is lighter with soft carbonation. Overall this is a decent DIPA that is definitely worth a try.
Dark amber with fluffy white head. Pithy pink grapefruit nose. Sweet sticky malt with dry bitter finish and light carbonation.

Firkin at Blind Tiger.  Hazy orange with a small white head.  Sugary, malty, light grapefruit and pine nose.  Flavor is equally not hoppy.  Some bitterness and more sweetness but not much actual flavor.   Typical of this brewery.
Very pale in colour, light fizz.  A little lacking on the hop front, but nonetheless a pretty tasty IPA.  Could do with a slightly bolder flavour perhaps.

Appearance: Orange golden brown, clear, some white head.
Aroma: Lots of fruit, not much hops.
Taste: Hops, quite sweet, some fruit.
Info: 650ml bottle, 18/4-2012
we felt that the only cure was a raging mouthful of fresh hops and malt. Caution: May remove enamel from teeth. This is Lagunitas IPA pumped up by about 30%!

Pours a clear orange color with a small off-white head. The aroma is of sweet malts, caramel and citrus and pine hops.  The taste is more of the same with a malty back bone and citrus/pine hoppy bitterness. Medium bodied.

pours a dark golden to light amber color with a white frothy head.  The aroma is strong in grape fruilt, and citrus. there is litlte malt smell and other aromas. The flavor is grapefruit throughout with small amounts of citrus. This has a good malt backbone with caramel flavors and sweetness.  The body palate and body feel heavy comparable to other IIPAs that i have had.  I would recommend this. They did a nice job to this but i truly think that it needs just something to finalize the taste and make given components to stand out much more.

Good, but missing something. Aroma and taste is just O.K. Nice appearance though. Don't think I would buy again. There are better ones out there. Green Flash's Imperial IIPA comes to mind.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Deep copper body, white head. Exotic fruits, resiny hops, bitter and bit alcoholic. Very intense and enjoyable.

Poured from bottle, copper, thick head and good lacing.  Aroma is light, taste is sweet and malty, then followed by bitter.  Very complex and delicious IPA.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours light copper with thin white head and little lacing.  Aromas of pine, spruce, and lemons.  Malty light sweetness turns to light bitterness, then finishes with a dry bitter bite.  Very well done, smooth IPA that leaves wanting more.
Nice hoppy aroma with hints of rich malt. Good looking pour/head retention. Taste is well balanced and hoppy with good malt backbone. Good strong IPA but stays refreshing.
roasty, toast, herbs, Light color, small bitter taste. Very nice knick at the on palate. Sneeks by with a wondeful flow .
Pours clear orange with a nice white head and good lacing. Aroma is mango, peach, and pine. Taste is very sweet with some earthiness and bitterness at the finish.

Poured into a Duvel tulip glass from a 12 ounce bottle with no date.



A: Slightly hazy amber with a thin white head with poor retention.



S: Semi-sweet citrus.



T: Grapefruit throughout over a sweet malt base, a bit too sweet.



M: Full-bodied with fizzy carbonation.



O: Too thick and sweet for my liking, not very drinkable.
ambrato scarico discreta schiuma media persistenza sentiori agrumati malto caramello un tocco resinoso contrasto dolce amaro  buon finale

Bottle from Ølkonsortiet, Ålborg. Pours clear dark golden with a big frothy off-white head. Aroma of oranges, sweet marmelade and piney hops. Taste is very sweet malty, sirupy and thick mouthfeel, ends with a solid bitter sweet hoppy bite. A bit on the sweet side for my likings, still some may like this better than me.
Pours mostly clear orange color with a small white head. Aroma is of citrus and pine hops with and malty sweetness. Taste is very similar with sweet start and a bitter finish. Medium bodied.

aroma is a hop fest very floral and citrusy maybe a little pineyness and faint caramel maltiness.. real nice looking amber orange clear with sudsy white head lots of lacing...tastes grapefruit,sour,bitter,pine and candy-ish malt background..warming tingly and a bit sticky on the palate dry finish..overall i like it good bargain at 10 bucks a six not a top favorite ipa of mine but still very good

Style et résumé: Double IPA américaine.  


Comment: Bouteille de 12oz.  encore une fois merci Patrick. 


Description: Bière cuivrée avec une mousse beige. Le nez est de caramel, sucre d’orge,  avec de la résine de pin. L’alcool transpire au nez. La bouche est tout en caramel, ce caramel est agréable. Cette bière est de moyenne longueur et l’alcool est présent en fin de bouche. Elle est quelque peu vieille et demanderait à être redécouverte sous des jours meilleurs. 


Note:  6+/10

12oz bottle. Pours a copper color with a big off-white head. Almost clear. Lasting foam. Aroma is hop forward with not much malt action. Tons of citrus and grapefruit, peaches too. Taste is a bit more balanced with some nuances of caramely malts and a ton of fruity and piney hops. Mostly fruity with peach, mango and grapefruit again. Medium+ body with good carbonation. Overall, this is a midway between a classic IPA and the latest high-ABV DIPAs. It’s a true showcase for hops and I fully enjoyed it.
Burnt orange / coppery color. Smells like caramel and roasted oranges. Akin to the smell, lots of sweet fruit, understated bitterness, some malty sweetness as well.

12oz bottle, at an awesome restaurant in siesta key over my 2012 spring break, the treat of my hosts. Nice, foamy off-white head. Clear amber / orange color. Lighter, smoother carbonation. Bigger body. Nice, substantial hoppy taste. Nice and piney, some citrus. Nice to sip, yet easy to drink. Good, but it’s lacking something that would have made it fantastic.. 7/4/7/4/14 

Re-rate, 1/22/16: 12oz bottle, acquired this week from a rep. Coded 351 5 2, indicating that it was bottled 12/17/15. Pours a mostly clear orange color, with a bigger off-white head, leaving great thicker lace. Kind of a sweeter, caramel bready malty flavor up front, little musty funkiness, touch of vegetable. Bigger bitterness, but not much hop flavor aside from a brief sharp pine character up front. It quickly subsides to the sweet malt, overall it’s a moderate to bigger sweet taste. Mild slick finish. Bigger body. Lighter carbonation. Not terrible, but very subpar compared to your typical DIPA. Too much lingering sweet maltiness here, it dominates the flavor and makes drinking this a chore.

12oz bottle poured into tulip glass.  Julian code bottle date puts this at January 3rd.
Aroma:  Wow, lots of aromas packed into this one:  Peaches, mango, cherries, floral hops, resin, raisins. 
Appearance:  amber, clear, very little head that faded quickly.  laces glass nicely.
Taste:  Medium sweet and medium sour.  very little bitter.  sour aftertaste
Palate:  Medium body and slick/thin texture.  Carbonation is average.  FInish is sour and hardly bitter.  Aftertaste fades quickly.
Overall:  Expected more from the flavor because of the amazing aromas.  Still very tasty though.  Aftertaste is almost non-existent.  Feels like its missing something.  Definitely can drink this faster than most other 8.4% beers.  Will pick this up again in the future.  Not as good as the Bells Two Hearted or Hop Stoopid but still enjoyed this one.

Bottle.  Aroma is of oranges, pineapple, dark grapes.  Taste is biting hops that linger toward the back of the tongue and throat.  Leaves a dry, bready finish.  Flavors are some citrus with a bold bready chewiness; resiny.  Some sourness.  This is more complex than the standard IPA, yet not as bitter as I expected for 72 IBUs.  Great choice!

really great orange appearance, big huge resinous hop nose. loved it. flavor is grassy and sweet, with a big hoppy finish and some alcohol warmth.  velvety texture.  very good but a little on the sweet side for me

Color:Orange Amber
Aroma:Floral, grass and citrus
Body:Dominated by hoppy citrus, grapefruit, light malty sweetness
Finish:Long bitter dryness
Mouth-feel/Over-all:Medium mouth-feel

Hazy amber in color with a creamy off-white head and lacing. notable aromas of citrus and resiny pine. taste was a moderate sweetness with a long, bitter finish. medium to full-bodied.  Good drinkability.

Small half finger head, golden brown, minimal lace. Nose is very sweet with some earthy and hoppy accents. Taste up front has some citrus and biscuit, followed by a little sugary hop kick. Goes down easy. I'm intrigued because it does not taste even in the ballpark of 72 IBUs. Good beer but wouldn't think it was a DIPA from the taste. Alcohol hidden well.

Bottled and delicious. A red-orange toned beer with minimal head. Aroma and taste share similar characteristics: sweet citrus, a bit bready, and blatant hops. Healthy carbonation. The 8.2% really starts showing its true colors after it spends some time warming up. Great DIPA!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle:  Almost all IPAs and almost all DIPAs are very good.  This is no exception.

Bottle.  Transparent orange pour.  Thick off white head.  Aroma is floral, pine pineapple and guava.  Taste is guava, mango, resin, and a good amount of sweet malt.  Aftertaste is bitterness and alcohol.  Medium to heavy body and lower carbonation.

such a drinkable IPA, but with a knockout high abv %. Cloudy orange pour with a medium, lacy white head that dissipates quickly. Powerful citrus notes backed with solid malts and a lingering mouthfeel. Tingly and slick. Purchased as a 6 for around ten bucks you really cannot beat the value. Definitely worth your evening!
Hops presence from start to finnish, aroma is passion fruit, resin, grapefruit. Taste is a explosion of bitterness that linger for a long time. Nice beer

Almost an imperial ipa. Very hoppy to the point of overwhelming,and I am a hophead. Nice hoppy aroma, not much of a head with little lacing. Probably not one I would return to often.

Sweet citrus hops explode on the tongue balanced with the caramel malt base. Grapefruit and bright tropical fruit flavor dominate much of the palate with only a slight caramel flavor peaking through.

Great smell after the pour. Nice flavor and right amount of hops. Nice finish.

12 oz Bottle, poured into a tulip glass

a: clear orangy amber color with a silkey 1/2" head. Ok retention does reduce to a light lacing cap and rings around the glass

s: floral and citrus aroma profile, nice

t: Malt sweetness quickly dominated by citrus hops, mostly orange and grapefruit hop profile.

m&d: medium body and dryness,

12oz bottle) Pour is a copper with nice white head..Nose is pine, citrus hops,...Taste is citrus, bubblegum,hoppy..Gives a nice tingle feeling on palate..very hoppy, with some cirtus, not much bitter...i super solid and easy drinking double IPA

(12 oz)  Une robe orange finement voilée.  Une petite tête qui flotte pour quelques minutes.  Un nez peu explosif de houblons fruités avec des fleurs douces qui sont attaqués par une bonne base caramélisée.  Des saveurs de DIPA qui privilégient les céréales sucrées au détriment de houblons fruités et floraux qui manquent définitivement de vigueur.  Une bouche assez costaude avec un pétillement modérément bas et une texture assez riche.  Une finale qui permet une certaine éclosion de notes amères fruitées et florales.

From notes.  First reviewed 5/18/2010.  "oured from a 12 oz. bottle into a pint glass.

Somewhat light clear copper color, with a thick, rocky off-white head. Tons of great lacing sticking everywhere on the glass.

Strong grapefruit and citrus hop notes in the nose. A bit of alcohol. Piney hop resin at the finish.

A strong hop flavor, but the balance is what I really like about this beer. Grapefruit citrus up front, and the pale and caramel malt sneaks through midway through. Pine notes blend with more citrus at the end. Wraps up clean, with nearly no aftertaste.

Mostly creamy feel, with the carbonation giving it a slight bubbly pop. Medium body. Slightly sticky and puckering on the finish. Pleasant. 

The hop flavor is round and robust, making it a very drinkable brew.

Pours a clear medium amber with a perfect thin head. Aroma is fairly sharp hops, and the flavor follows.  Good brew, strong and hoppy.  It’s a good flavor too - a bit bitter on the back of the throat but I’m not complaining.
Pours clear gold with a medium head of white bubbles.  Aroma smells like a field of hops. Medium in body with nice carbonation. Flavor is dry with a ltr its floral and grapefruit.

Nice copper pour with a half-finger head that leaves an ok lace throughout. The hop aroma is apparent as well as well as some candyish sweetness. The taste is a pretty nice citrus hoppiness with a sticky malt sweetness. The hop flavor is pretty basic not a whole lot of depth and/or variation. The mouthfeel is sticky and a little slick. I really can’t stand a slick on my pallet. The slickness detracts from any potential for crispness and "refreshing or quenching" attributes. Overall this is a good flavored and bodied brew with a slick mouthfeel.

Strong, leafy/piney hops on the nose with a subtle fruity background.Pours a dark shade of gold with a moderate size foam top. Taste buds are immediatly greeted by bitter hops with slight caramel malts. Nice grapefruit undertones are noticable with a spicey bitter hop finish. Overall, a pretty solid IPA with a nice bitter hop flavor. I’d give this a B+ rating.

Bottle.  Pours copper with a two finger white head, plenty of lacing, and some light carbonation.  Smells of pine, minor grapefruit.  Taste is medium bitter with a semi-dry finish.  Mouthfeel is a little lighter than i’d like in a DIPA but pretty darn good.
Unclear orange. Strong cascade hop citrus/pine aroma tells you what to expect. Quite dry. Taste leans towards lingering resin over the more typical citrus/grapefruit notes.

Location/Date:



Appearance: Pours a nice copper. 
 

Aroma: Aroma is of piney hops.
 

Taste: Medium bitterness, nice amount of citrus.
   

Palate:Medium slick, medium aftertaste.



Summary: Two consecutive ratings on a beer I’ve had before but not rated - last time I had this was at Rattle & Hum with Ben while watching the lousy Redskins play the Panthers.  This beer is really enjoyable, as are all of the variants of IPAs from Lagunitas.
golden amber color, aroma is sweet citrus pine hops, slight caramel malt, flavor is citrus, pine, caramel, very balanced nice dry finish, I drink this one a lot, very good and not to hard to find

Bottled. Pours clear amber with a medium sized off-white head. Fai lacing. Clean hop nose of citrus, pine needles and caramel notes. Sweet fruity flavor with grapefruit, pine and caramel. Medium bodied oily texture and soft carbonation. More dry and nice bitter finish. A fresh and enjoyable IPA.

Nice amber-copper color.  Head dissipates quickly.  Very little lace on the side, perhaps due to the large amount of hops.  Very floral and piney notes, with some butterscotch. First apparent is the sweetness of the malt.  Honey and some licorice.  Nice bitter finish from the hops.  Solid beer.  Not much carbonation.  Oily and resiny due to the hops.  Very enjoyable beer.  It’s really a pleasure to drink and remarkably refreshing given the amount of hops.

Solid pour, lots of suds, smells fruity.  Very fruity and sweet, with a nice hop kick and bitter finish.  Tastes similar to other lagunitas ipas, abv not detectable.  I think this is solid, basically a souped up abv of their standard IPA but very solid for sure.  Not quite a top tier dipa but close.
Fresh and non-imposing, meaning it didn’t bomb my tastebuds.  It has a heavy-hopped flavor with a nice floral smell and a bit of an abv kick.  This was some great stuff.

Amber pour with thick white head.  Moderate skunky pine and caramel malt.  Sweet caramel malt and some biscuit followed by solid pine bitterness.  Lightly dry finish.  Solid beer just no wow factor here.  Would love to try fresh.
Poured a clear golden with a nice head. Some sweet malts followed by a nice punch of hops with a slight bitter finish. Quite a beer, tasty.

Dark golden  coloured and clear. Has a white head, medium duration. Aroma has malty, sweet notes and heavy hoppy too. Faint citrus, herbs, harmonic. Flavor starts moderate sweet and finish heavy bitter. Dry texture, creamy too. Moderate carbonation.
sweet hoppy aroma,orange/golden, clear, off white foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, light body, oily feel, bitter, long finish,

Pours a murky, unfiltered gold with a white foam head that head that stays on the top of the glass and a decent amount of carbonation, looks good. Smells sweet in hoppy, with some spicy fruit making up the sweetness. Taste actually is lacking on hops and is more malty. Bitter, but also with a sweet and yet spicy cherry flavor. I can taste the alcohol and as well and the boozy taste really is prominent and finishes on the palate. Not so great, but not horrible.

As I explore the world of beer (and my new-found taste for the hops) I thought another double IPA from Lagunitas Brewing Company "Maximus" was in order. Plenty of quality bars have this monster on tap and it has been bottled in 22oz bottles in the past, but currently the 12oz bottle in 6-packs has become the standard. At about 8% abv, a 6-pack of Maximus probably has as much alcohol as a 12-pack of the Silver Bullet, so light beer drinkers beware!

The Maximus pours out a nice reddish-orange hue, crystal clear, with a nice full one-finger foam on top.  Bright ivory in color, the foam is lively and leaves behind a nice sticky lacing. The aromas are bright and zesty, full of citrus, floral and grapefruity hops. The aromas are bountiful, but very soft in nature; this is one of the sweetest/most pleasant smelling IPAs I’ve ever put my nose in.

On the palate the Lagunitas Maximus is very similar to the aromas. Very bright and flavorful hops are dominated by a very soft, smooth, and citrusy style of hops. There’s a slight hint of spice in the mid-palate, with a touch of malty sweetness on the back-end.  Much the same way that DFH 90 Min is a hoppy yet sweeter style IPA than the 60 Min, this Maximus brew is a little bit on the sweet side.  Despite being rated at over 70 IBUs, the Lagunitas Maximus DIPA is quite easy to drink, and verges on refreshing.

Segunda Imperial IPA que probe, y la que empezo a determinar que este estilo se convirtiera en mi favorito, tiene un intenso aroma, con notas de malta y citricas de lupulo mezcladas en un gran balance. Es una cerveza color ambar claro con buena cabeza que presenta buena retencion. Al igual que el aroma, el sabor tiene un gran balance entre malta y lupulo, anque esta dominado por este ultimo. Una gran Imperial IPA.

Fresh green hop aroma coming out of the bottle.   Crystal clear light copper/brass color with a frothy white head.   Sweet candy aromas along with the hops come out of the glass.  There’s a good bitter earthy/pine bite up front, but this is quickly followed and nearly overwhelmed with a caramel sweetness with a slight cherry fruitiness.  This is all transported around the mouth by a good dose of alcohol that makes itself known without getting boozy.  Kind of like a semi-Imperial British IPA.  Good stuff.

Clear copper-amber with a small off-white head. Aroma full of citrus, apricot, pine and light bready malt. Taste is sweet with a surprisingly mild bitterness. Medium bodied and a touch dry with mild carbonation and a slightly syrupy texture.

Bottle into shaker. Aroma is great, lots of apricot and peach sweetness.  The taste is a bit strange to me though.  It’s quite sour actually, with a lingering bitterness.  I much prefer the single IPA.

Keg at Brewdog Camden. Amber orange colour with big creamy beige head. Aroma is toffee, apple, creamy maltiness. Taste quite bread malty, quite a spike of bitterness, but much more malt. Maybe bit of biscuit. Caramel and dark fruits. Very smooth in the mouth, and maybe a bit of treacle or golden syrup in there.

Thanks, James! Tasted from bottle into shaker. Poured a orange-amber color with some chill haze and moderate white foam, somewhat lasting with a little lace. Intense American hops aroma: grapefruit and other citrus rinds, earthy, cedary, slightly spicy. Faint aromas of bread, caramel and fruity ale yeast esters. Strong malt flavor overcome by an even stronger tangy hops bitterness. Medium body, strong carbonation, no hint of the high alcohol, lingering bittersweet aftertaste. A classic example of American Imperial IPA.
Amber orange with a good lick of white foam. Very hoppy  smell and taste.  Goes down easy with piney after taste. Very enjoyable
Bomber. Since this is basically the same brew as their normal IPA I shall give it the same rating. Although I’m tempted to rate higher for the increased ABV and IBU’s. Nice double.

12 oz bottle. Pours a clear orange/amber with a 1 finger  off white head.  Grapefruit aroma with a touch of caramel sweetness.  Grapefruit follows through in the taste with some breadlike qualities. medium bodied palate with a bitter finish.
Well rounded DIPA and one that I would drink again.  Very bold with lots of citrus and hops.  Smooth and easy to drink for the ABV.
Pours an amber colour with a big white head and an aroma of toffee and hop resin. Has a big grassey flavour and appears very well balanced not a bad DIPA.

A delightful beer all round.  Rich full flavoured with hints of sweet toffee. 

Moreish!

bottle picked up at brewery: pours clear, light orange, nice off white head. fruity pineapple, grapefruit, pine, resin, caramel malts. more resin and fruit on the palate. velvety, mild bitterness. soft bodied. balanced and drinkable.

12 oz bottle, thanks to Adam. Served in tulip.  Grapefruit and pineapple nose. Taste is a well blended mix of fruit, pine and flowers. Mild bitter, lingering bite. Body is clean. Lots of resin as it warms and gets more bitter as well, good stuff.

Purchased at Armanetti’s in Chicago, IL; enjoyed during the day on New Years Eve while making some chili for a party tonight.  Appearance a nice slightly dark gold with a rich white head, tiny carbonation bubbles rising to the top that make it look like some sort of champagne.  Aroma of rich caramel malts, citrusy/acidic hops, a touch of pine, nice smell.  Taste is fantastic, more of the naturey/pine hops come out in the flavor, along with the caramel malt.  It’s pretty smooth for a DIPA, has a nice full backing with medium carbonation.  Nicely done.

Pour light amber, with a one-finger white head. 
Nice fruity hoppy aroma. Peach, sweet fruits. A bit of caramel. Quite Nice and balance. 
Medium body, with a lively carbonation. Well balanced.
Strong apricot taste. Absolutely beautiful in the glass. A little spicy on the back end. Comes off as a little boozy. Maybe it could be a little more balanced?
Bottle. Orange with white head. Hoppy as all get out. Bitter too. A pretty good IIPA.
From bottle. Orange with small ring of head. Nice fruity hop aroma with a caramel malt backbone. Taste is similar, well balanced. Decent

12-oz bottle from Bev Max in Manford w Andy, Maggi, Massimo and Nick. Pours dark gold with a big, somewhat uneven head and leaves a random, splotchy lacing on the glass. Appearance is only downside. Nose is huge grapefruit and piney hops. Mouthfeel is smooth and a little viscous. Palate is fresh, fresh grapefruit and not very much bitterness despite a good hop profile. Cool.

Amber beauty with a soft quickly dissipating big bubble one-finger head. Rich hops aroma with a touch of warm brown sugar smell in there - no fuel smell despite a nice heat-rich 8+ abv. Rich hoppy flavor without a ton of IBU smack in the mouth. I’m tasting it right now next to Dogfish 90, and it’s less bitter than DF90 as well as richer in flavor. I’m overall very pleased with this double IPA as it’s got notes of pine, sugar, oak, and honey in the mouth. The finish is much smoother than most IPA’s and this beer has made my top 20 for sure.

Bottle Ölkonsortiet cons 2011-12-12 Göteborg
Ar: rich hoppy, rich apricot marmelade sweetness and some herbal tee
Some plums and caramel is reveled when poured
Ap:  orange copper colored body,high frothy of beige head
F: heavy apricots marmalade sweetness, pine, grape fruit, finish is dry and sweet, warming feeling, some white peppar,

Bottle 33 cl, ØlKonsortiet. Pours clear copper amber with a creamy and bubbly beige head leaving lace. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel, fruity, piny and grapefruit. Flavor is sweet, pungent, bitter, caramel, fruity, citric, tropical fruits and has a very nice malty base. Finishes dry, malty and bitter.

Bottle/12oz - Pours a darkish amber in color with a very small white head that quickly fades to nearly nothing.  Aroma is heavy with resinous hops and toffee/caramel.  Flavor is similar with plenty of hop bitterness offset by the malty understructure.  Slightly sweet initially, but the hop bitterness wins over in the end.  Lingering strong pine resin hop flavor and slightly sweet...  Well constructed and very enjoyable!

Poured from bottle.  Aroma of burnt sugar and hops. Copper, white head, lacing.  Big pine/floral hops lead the flavor, followed with a burnt caramel with a creamy malt base.  Not noticing the alcohol at all.  About midway thru I really start to realize the amazing amount of hops in this.  This beer gets better as I drink, leading to a great finish.  A classic.
Little head, cloudy deep yellow. Heavy hoppy caramel nose.fullbody and some length. Fresh caramel with hops. Quite sweet and heavy. Pleasant but saturating.

Another solid hit by the Lagunitas people. Served at a good temperature and with a nice cream colored, foamy, fine head that settled out after a while and good lacing. Color is a clear red honey amber with lots of tiny bubble trails. Aroma is hops, malt, caramel, toffe, bread dough. Flavor is much like nose and has slight sweetness, good carbonic tang, yeast, some citrus, and resin. Body n carbonation are nailed. Finish is like flavor, of good length, and slightly boozy. These guys make the beer.

Dark golden poor, good head That lingers.  Clean scent of pine and grapefruit.  Initially bitter, but lightens to good hoppy flavor.  The flavor continues to change over time, passing through citrus on its way to a faint and surprising bubblegum at the end.  Very nice.

Don’t mistake this rating as not liking the beer, it just had ZERO aroma.  I swear, I thought I was smelling water. Palate and finish were awesomely bitter with a good west coast hop profile and not too much body or sweetness, which I hate in double IPAs.  Good!
Real nice blend of citrus, hops and booze, without being overpowering.  Another winner from Lagunitas.

I always know my head will be blown off with hop bitterness when the head of a beer has a greenish tinge, and oddly enough this is peculiar to Pacific Coast IPAs. This one fits fairly and squarely into that category. Gorgeous amber colour with an enduring rocky head that leaves excellent lace on the glass. The nose is pungent spruce hoppiness with lovely creamy biscuity malt underneath. Smells good.
Full on hop resin and pine characters at the fore and then sweet malt glides in hand in hand, it’s neither one ’nor the other, but both at the same time. The bitterness doesn’t wring out the sides of tongue, but you definitely know it’s there. I believe that’s calledf balance and it shows the brewer hasn’t just attempted to make some overly hoppy monster without restraint. Big like actually, big like.

Purchased as a 12oz bottle from Baruni’s Bar and Hotel in Baden, PA.  Everything is very pleasing in this IPA.  From it’s full-bodied taste to the smooth and creamy feel on the tongue, this is an exceptional beverage.  One other nice thing is the hop level which seems perfect, not overdone, nor does it cause the beer to become dry.

22 oz bottle from Whole Foods.  This DIPA poured a clear copper in color with a white frothy head and lacing.  The medium body ale had a lively carbonation.  The sweet ale has a taste of pinapple and citrus.  The DIPA finished smooth  with decetive abv.  The ale lacked some kind of punch that separates it from the pack.
Bottle. Smooth drinking Double India Pale Ale. Well balanced with the malty sweetness almost dominating the hops. Finish is more citrus than bitter.

bottle pour. comes out a transparent amber color. citrus/floral hops punch you in the nose! medium bodied when it hits your tongue with a nice mix of malt / hop flavor going down. slightly harsh but definitely some great hop flavor here...

22oz bottle from the haus, poured a nice copper head with a very nice citrus mango aroma. Great balance hops with a medium body and a lip smacking finish. One of the better IPA’s I’ve had recently but still not my favorite Lagunitas which shows you how good these guys are.
On tap at Blackthorn Pub in Holly,MI. Outstanding IPA2 - hits the high hop notes and tastes much cleaner and greener than most in the style - a crispness about it that is rare and welcome.

This snarky beer lists hops as every other ingredient, and as might be expected it smells like a pine tree. The color is almost orange with a collapsing head. The taste is bitter pacific tree fruits, followed by more bittersweet.  This has killed my palate so I can’t rate anymore beers tonight. Highly recommended. Not Ruination, but close.

Bottle @mondial de la bière. A golden beer with medium head. Nose is on agrumes and sweet like. Aroma is on resin, honey and hops, quite bitter but with dry fruit notes, light acidity at the finish, lemon and mangoo notes.

Bottle. Shimmering autumn auburn pour with plenty of carb. Average nose for the style - some tropical fruit and citrus rind. Big bodied beer with a solid lingering bitterness. Not overly tasty, but a well rounded IPA she is. Might be a little dated too as it lacked some punch.

A - Served a super hazy copper-orange color with a half finger of frothy white head. The head fades down fairly quickly leaving behind some nice lacing.

S - Aroma is bursting with tons of fresh citrus hops. Lots of orange and grapefruit. There is also some piney hops mixed in as well as some rich caramel malts.

T - Starts off with a huge kick of fresh citrus hops with plenty of bitterness. Again, lots of orange and grapefruit flavor. some rich sweet caramel malts in the background. Through the middle, more citrus hop and bitterness come through alongside some more grassy hops joining in. The finish is a mix of lots of fresh hop and bitterness and a bit of sweet malt that linger.

M - Medium-full bodied with moderate carbonation. Feels smooth with a fairly dry and resiny finish from the hops.

D - Very drinkable. Amazed as to how big and fresh the hop flavor was. Not really all that balanced, but this beer was made to showcase the hops and it nailed it.

4/10/2011 on tap @ Rattle ’n Hum, NYC (2011-519)


Clear deep orange to light copper red beer, small off-white head, unstable, dissipates completely. Aroma: passion fruits, sweet pineapple, pretty much the same again. MF: ok carbon, medium to full body. Taste: very fruity start, sweet pineapple and passion fruits, canned peaches with syrup, little sugary but not cloying. Aftertaste: citrus touches, bitter hops, sweet still. Way better balanced than the other hop boms.
Bottle 12 oz. Clear amber with a medium off white head. Aroma of sweet with grassy hops and hints of dark fruit. The taste is sweet and hoppy with a dry finish

Bottle 355ml @ home

Pours cloudy amber with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel, citrus and pine. Taste is medium sweet and medium bitter. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

Aroma - Floral hops
Appearance - Clear medium amber, very light head
Taste - Medium malt and hops.  Smooth  but not light
Palate - Medium body; slight bitter finish
Overall - Not quite as smooth and as malty as most Imperial IPAs, but smoother and lighter than a typical IPA. Could get into trouble with this one...

A: Orange-amber body with a thick lasting offwhite head.. not much lacing..

S: Mostly citric and piney hops.. standard western ipa aroma.. not too strong of a malt background comes through the nose..

T: Suprisingly the malt seems to outshine the hops... a bit soft for a dIPA.. bready malts are tasty though.

M: Nice medium body.. smooth consistancy.. moderate carbonation..

O: Good all around.. just not quite as much of a hop barrage one would expect... might be a great introduction to the dIPA for someone who is a bit hesitant with the hoppy hops :)
Pours a clear golden orange.  Aroma is full of hoppy goodness.  Taste has a nice bit of malt to balance the hoppyness.  A nice IPA! Better than their actual "IPA" by a long shot.

A very floral and piney scent with a medium off-white head and lots of lacing.  The color is a deep orange, and the taste is full-bodied with lots of sweet citrus, grass, and hint of malt, and a long pine and citrus aftertaste.  One of my favorite IPAs.

Poured from a bottle into a 24-oz. Steeler plastic glass. Color was caramel amber. Maybe ¾ inches of head. Light lacing. Film stayed throughout. 

Smell was caramel citrus, along with some hoppy pine.

Nice balance of taste between citrus, caramel and pine. Bitter finish, but not too much of a bite. Smooth taste.

Medium body. Average carbonation. Smooth. Not as much alcohol as I thought.

Thought it would be better, but overall it was decent beer.

(33 cl bottle from Gunnar Madsen Vinhandel) Pours a clear amber with little, off-white head and lace. Some retention. Aroma is of the classic hop bite variety - more bitter and piney than grassy, floral or fruity with some malty sweetness for good measure. Oily texture, full-bodied with medium carbonation and a long, bitter finish. Taste is quite bitter. Girlfriend says: "I thought it would be flowery but it’s only the bitterness that stands out."

Bottle. Clear orange body, small white head. Nuts, pine, hints of licorice and strawberries in the nose. Very smooth. Taste is even smoother: nutty pine tones, and hints of strawberry again, pretty much like taste but highly integrated. A solid West Coast IPA, despite the smooth and slightly sweet profile.

35,5 cl bottle @ hotel room, Tokyo. Bottled 11094010, BBE 06/2012

Aroma has sweet, sugary exotic fruits. Flavour is rather sweet with hops and exotic fruits, especially mango. Surprisingly thin palate. Yet another a-bit-too-sweet american DIPA.

Clear Amber-copper pour with tight eggy head. Piney hop nose. Sharp pine taste. medium body Long resiny bitter finish. A winner for hop heads but might be so piney that it is difficult drinker for non-hop heads. Pinier than Pliney, Racer 5, 10 15.

13 Sept 2011, bottle. honey gold, clear, no bubbles, thin lacing. nose is a sharp grassy hop with sweetness that comes from alcohol but doesn’t smell like alcohol really. just sweet malt. full/med body and a bit fizzy. tastes really good. sweet pink grapefruit and bitter grapefruit rind with lingering bitterness. alcohol is balanced well, not contributing a big or dominant flavor.

Pours translucent ruby orange, with very light tan head.  Bright and fresh floral nose.  Sweet herbal taste with just the right amount of hops.  Mild carbonation, full mouthfeel, and a refreshing finish.  Quite delicious.  Taste like California.

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into Nonic Imperial Pint. 

Appearance: Clear golden-amber with thin white head and little lacing.

Aroma: Pungent sweet grapefruit, with light notes of orange and pine.

Taste: Grapefruit is the highlight here as well. However, the grapefruit is a little too sweet, candy-like and almost sickly. Light toasted malts offset the hops, but only serve to keep the beer in somewhat sweet territory. Slightly more dry and bitter on the finish with light accents of pine.

Palate: Smooth body with moderate levels of carbonation. However, the finish is not as dry as I would like an IPA or DIPA to be.

Overall: Based on the candy-like sweetness, I was going to post lower scores, but after warming a little, the sweetness dies off a little, probably because the sweetness strangely resides more with the hops than the malts. After some warming, it is a nicely balanced, enjoyable beer, but still not quite what I want in a DIPA.

Good IPA. Pours amber with light tan head. Aroma of spruce, resin, some citrus and leaves.  Slightly salty with bitter bite, but not overwhelming and smooth nonetheless. Lively carbonation, slick texture, astringent finish.  This is a medium to full bodied beer that is very drinkable.  Very flavorful IPA.

Bottle @ Voldby beerfest. Pours golden with a white head. Aroma of malt, caramel, bread, loads of hops, grapefruit, pine. Taste is malt, caramel, bread, grassy and floral hops, grapefruit, pine. Medium body, soft carbonation, bitter finish. 270811
Bottle. Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Orange colour. Moderate malty and hoppy aroma. Moderate bitter flavior. Average moderate bitter finish. Creamy palate.

Bottle from Ölbutikken, Copenhagen, Denmark. Aroma has a lot of bread and caramel from the malt and just a hint of floral notes from the hops. Pours a dark amber, almost brown, with a thick white foam. Taste is medium sweet, a little sour and slightly bitter. The bottle I had was probably too old to be enjoyed properly though. Medium carbonation and a slight oily feel on the palate.

It poured a golden color with an off-white head. The aroma was hoppy with some citrus and herbal notes, along with some pine. The flavor, fairly thick, decent amount of bitterness. Well balanced with a decent amount of malt character that comes out on the palate. Medium bodied. A very solid, flavorful IPA.

A very good IPA.  Lagunitas is fast becoming one of my favorite breweries.  The color is light amber and it has very little head.  It smells piney, but not overwhelmingly so.  The beer has a very strong hoppy flavor, but the bitterness is not as overwhelming as the label would have you believe.  In fact, this beer is very palatable.  If it wasn’t for the extraordinarily high alcohol content (for a beer), I could put quite a few away. The flavor will overwhelm bland foods, so don’t pair it with something bland.

Good beer, decent double IPA.  Excellent balance, slight hoppy aroma, mild hoppy start, medium malt balance, with bitter finish.  My only complaint is that I would like it to have a hoppier taste. Some complexity going on here, good CO2.  Overall, good brew, worth the try.

Pours clear amber with a tiny white head. Aroma is juicy hops, sweet caramel malts, peach, orange, pine, toasted bread and light citrus. Taste is hoppy along with alot of caramel malts. some fruity notes from the Aroma leading to a piney bitter end.

Clear red orange with no lacing. Medium yeasty aroma and grass/flowers with notes of corriander. Flavor is great hoppiness and the bitters are a great accompianment. Fun warm weather beer that will warm you up inside.

A copper colored beer with a small white head.  The aroma is very nice, with notes of pine, citrus, and peach.  The flavor is medium bitter, with lemon, grass, and pine notes.  Not so pronounced on the alcohol, which is nice for a double, just lots of big hops characteristics.
Love this beer! Great initial hop bite, then some beautiful sweet balance (vanilla?). Long bitter finish. Refreshing carbonation, and medium body in the mouth.

Pours a very slightly hazy light copper, with an effevescent off white head.  Hoppy grapefruit citrus - including peel - and malt aroma, with spice notes and... vanilla?  Nice robust bitter and light caramel sweetness, with the malt coming through a bit more than through just the aroma. Lingering bitter finish.  Low carbonation, but really helps amplify this beer.  I’m loving this one.
Great beer. This IPA is amazing.  I love the bitter start middle and finish of this beer.

12 oz bottle: Aroma is a nice caramel malt with a floral and a bit of herbal hops. Appearance is a nice golden orange with a nice white head. Taste is very nice and complex with a hop front end and a nice mellow malt flavor on the back. Palate is very smooth but complex enough to keep it very interesting. Pairs well with food.
Bottle (dmg notes). Nice yellow head. Flowery hoppy aroma with some malts still present. Bitter and hoppy yet very malty. All that was readable on the note...

Pours a mostly transparent orange, with a good amount of dense yellowish foam. Aroma is grassy and hoppy, a bit of citrus fruit. Taste is a bit piney and sweet, noticable alcohol burn, but not as strong on the hops as I was expecting.
Pours hazy amber with a nice white head. Aroma is grassy and malty. Sweetish with some bitternes.
Härlig orange öl med ett livligt vitt skumm. Mycket tallbarr i doften. I smaken går humlebeskan mer åt citrushållet. En trevlig sötma balanserar upp humlebeskan

Bottle. Pours a nice orange color with a frothy off white head. Aroma is qutie nice, filled with hoppy aromas of grapefruit, pineapple juice, orange, floral notes, a touch of breadiness and caramel malts. The flavor is equally hoppy, and not that bitter actually for a DIPA, this is more on the hop fruity side, with loads of pineapple juice, grapefruit, some pine, some floral notes, the sweeter citrus fruits like orange and tangerine, the breadiness and also some caramel malts. The body is medium with a lightly dry mouthfeel. Overall a really tasty DIPA, it litteraly almost smells like tropical multifruit juice!

I actually didn’t realize this was an Imperial/Double until I just read the description on this site.  They claim 72 IBUs, and if that’s the case it’s very well masked behind a malty smoothness not usually found in stronger IPAs.  A very drinkable summer beer.

22 oz. bottle- Pours a nice deep golden with a 1 finger fluffy white head, aroma is citrusy grapefruit, floral and melon. The flavor is the same, strong citrus grapefruit, kind of a tropical fruit vibe goin’ on. Very tasty, smooth, sessionable, could use a more bitter kick. The body is medium to kind of light (hence the sessionability), carbonation is medium, finish is sticky and little bitterness. Overall a different kind of a double IPA, especially for the west coast, which is known for their huge hop bombs, I was expecting a little more, but for what it is, pretty tasty stuff.

I rate this IPA very high. Nice aroma, good appearance and the taste is different than any other IPA I have tried. Just an excellent IPA. The IBU is 72. I had a friend try it and he too thought they are putting more malt or something in the beer to give it a different, great taste.

One issue I have though. I called the brewery in Petaluma, CA to complain about the white stuff floating in the bottom. The beer was about 4 or 5 months old. The person I spoke to said the owner (he was reading it off something) claimed it was nothing other than protein and it was good for you. My son and I think that is a bunch of B S - this beer is 7.5% and after 120 to 150 days it should not exhibit white matter floating in the bottom of the bottle. It was kept in a closest in my basement. 

So try this great IPA - but don’t let it sit around too long unless you want to drink some floating "protein".

Bottle. Glowing sunburst, predominantly orange. Heavy pine aroma, plus pineapple and white grapefruit. A wallop of flavour, very rich, with good bitter grapefruit and pine, plus a unique strawberry accent. A big beer that still has subtle nuances. Highly enjoyable.

Nice amber/orange color; Medium creamy body; Aroma of floral hops, caramel malt, & citrus; Flavor of sweet malt, caramel, pine hops, and citrus (notably orange & grapefruit); Finish is bitter; Nicely balanced; Overall, middle of the road - but solid DIPA.
Sampled at tasting room. Amber with light biege head. Muted hops, citrus, marijuana, some malts. Well balanced bitterness and smooth, nice hops, bit of sweet at the end. Good.

Pours a hazy golden amber with a thin white head. Plenty of sediment floating about. 
Aroma is citrus, caramel, toasted malts. 
Taste is lightly sweet and bitter. 
Palate - well carbonated, sticky, long bitter finish.
Humle, korn, halm, malt, grape, fyrrenåle, træ, gylden rød, klar, hvidt, tæt, skum, sød og meget bitter, tør,livlig, Meget blomster, bitter boch.

12 fl oz bottle from Kihoskh, Copenhagen. My bottle says 7,5% ABV? Clear, golden/light amber liquid with small-medium, fluffy off-white head. Nice lacing. Hoppy aroma with notes of citrus, pine, hops and a nice caramely, almost burnt base. Very nice aroma indeed! Taste is quite malty with lots of bready, toasty, biscuity notes and medium-high bitterness. Also slightly higher sweetness than your average DIPA. Nice balance! Some alcohol as well, but not too disturbing. Medium bodied with maybe a bit low carbonation and lingering finish. Overall, well performed DIPA but considering the ABV it’s possibly not that style accurate. Well, well it’s good anyway!
Big bold hop and citrus nose. Big fluffy head. Attack is very fruity, notes of sweet grapefruit? Ends a little too sweet for me. Still dang good.

Bottle from a hole in the wall liquor store in Lendrum strip mall, Edmonton. 8.2%.  Pours a darker amber, with a bubbly tan head. Aroma is citrusy, grapefruit hops predominant. Taste is extremely hoppy, tempered with a pleasant citrusy sweetness that disguises the higher abv quite well. Exquisite.

12 ounce bottle at the Bayou. Pours a clear copper color with a medium white head. The aroma is sticky sweet caramel and hops. A rich fruity flavor, resin, caramel, light bitterness. Quite nice, smooth and drinkable.
Yummy, but expecting a little more. Would drink again, but not as hoppy as I would have expected and a little light on the tongue.
12 oz bottle.  Pours a beautiful copper color.  Aroma of pineapple, tangerine, pine, dried cherries, brown sugar, lavender.  Flavor is pineapple, caramel, pine.  An absolute drinking delight.

(bottle, alcohol 7,5 %) Beautiful clear and extremely orange with huge thick head. Overwhelming aroma of malty biscuits and ripe citrusy hops. Taste is malty sweetness and hoppy bitterness, impressions of mandarine, peach, orange, grapefruit and biscuits. The alcohol is evident. Dry and bitter finish. Not bad, but body is too bold and massively malty to my palate. I prefer my IPAs to be lighter, rather dry and more astringent bitter.

355ml bottle from Firefly Liqour Store, Vancouver, BC



Pours light orange with a minimal head. Aroma is strong with notes of malts and pine. Taste is quite malty with notes of grass and hops. Long lasting, bitter and sticky finish. Okay, but quite malty IIPA.

Drank just on cool, but not cold. It shimmers in the light, not quite bright with very minute particles caught in suspension. A deep amber-tinged orange with very fine, slow to rise, carbonation. Head forms late into the pour, a messy, sloppy, foamy mass of white that holds well and laces rings down the glass. Smells predominately of ‘Ovaltines’ and ‘Milo’ with an edge of burnt sugar and savoury plums and raisins. Marmalade and caramelised fruit undertones.  It has a good level of alcohol spice that tickles the olfactories, nice and penetrating nose. The first mouthful is full-ball; lots of chewy, biscuity, grainy sweet malt and juicy fruit esters - tangerines, lychee, blood orange, plums  and apricots – just draw out saliva in a fluster of all-tingling flavour. Smooth, silky, well-rounded, a mild spritz of carbonation teases the tip of the tongue. Good apex of woody, piney, vine-like and earthy hop nastiness at the rear perfectly in-sync with the meaty palate. Finish is smooth as silk, a tangy, juicy continuation of the palate with alcohol well hidden, fades out clean. This is absolutely delicious. Might even bring me back around to loving Pale ales again. Really good stuff! (12fl/oz, no date stamp, Cellarbrations Carlisle)
This will not remove enamal from anyone’s teeth. It’s not that hoppy, quite balanced. Herbal hops. Nice beer, but nothing amazing.

bottled. pours orangy amber with a minimal head. aromas of citrus, spruce and caramel. flavor are smooth. it is relatively sweet with a touch of bitterness. medium bodied with a smooth lasting bitter finish. Good beer

Getting to the point where all the Lagunitas IPA variations sort of run together in my mouth and head. That’s not a negative--I just wonder whether they all come from the same barrels. This one goes great with a full-bodied pizza.
Hazy orange with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, caramel and rather hoppy - grapefruit and pine. Flavor is quite sweet and rather bitter. Dry and rather bitter finish. 170609

Bottle from Kihosk.
Clear amber with a white head. Aroma moderate malty (caramel), heavy hoppy. Flavor  moderate sweet, heavy bitter. Medium to full body.

Bottle at home, scored against my interpretation of 2004 BJCP Guidelines.  Aroma:  hops, floral, hint of resin.  Appearance:  clear, dark gold, lacking in head.  Taste:  very hoppy, hint of caramel?  Palate:  smooth, medium-high carbonation, long dry finish, seems to be lacking the warming alcohol sensation.  Overall:  Seems to be a great example of the style, very hoppy, light on maltiness, smooth and enjoyable.
Amberish orange pour with little to no white head. Nose is of pure hops. Taste is a bit more complex with a ever changing hop flavor from floral to citrus.

22 oz. bomber. Sunburst orange fading to a bright yellow at the bottom of a goblet. Very smooth when cold, creamy malty mouth feel but the hops are what this is about. Clean hop finish, its sweeter up front and crisp with a fresh grassy hop after taste. Not much alc. taste for 8% but it does the job. Highly drinkable, kinda seems like their attempt at a high strength Sierra Nevada Pale Ale, but they did it well. Only draw back is their yeast tastes the same in every beer and i sometimes lose interest in it, enjoyed this one though.

A beautiful beer. Honey/amber/orange in color with a nice white head that leaves a good fading lace. First sniff is piney hops, but over time that smell gives in to citrus and peppermint. Taste is hops with a solid malt backbone. Medium bodied. Pleasantly surprised.

Pours a dark straw color with a fluffy white head. Good lacing. Aroma is fresh floral and hoppy. When you first take a sip it is silky and hoppy. Medium mouth feel. The aroma is just full of hops.  I don’t know what hops where used but they are awesome!  A little too bitter bite at the ending.
