ho hum at best imo. definitely a imperial and not a dipa, but not a strong imperial at all. why would you rate this so high? whoever does has missed out on great dipa’s and imperial’s out there because this nothing to write home about. more like a slightly above average ipa.

Small head, no lacing. Smells like... not much, actually - subtle caramel and citrus. Yellow amber color. Lots of malt, hides the booze well. Not very impressed with the hop presence here. Meh. Too thin - goes down like water. Very bitter on the finish but doesn’t linger. Overall disappointing but generally what I expected from Lagunitas. Price is nice though!

This beer strikes me more as an IPA-and-a-Half than a DIPA.  Pours a hazy golden amber, with almost no head and little lacing.  Smells like orange hoppy madness, but with ’roided-out malts goading them on.  First sip brings on toffee and orange honey.  The thick, chewy, dense front coats your palate in sweetness, but the hops quickly rush is with a citric tang and firm bitterness.  I can see why this beer doesn’t tickle the fancy of serious hopheads;  it’s more of a hoppy malt-bomb.  Still, does the trick for me, judging at how fast my bottles have disappeared.  (6/8/09)

Bottle.  Pours orange with a bit of brown.  Head is white, creamy, with a tinge of yellow.  The head dissipates quickly.  Aroma is soft hops, a bit of citrusy pineapple.  Not too pronounced.  Taste is a nice bitter citrus.  There is a bit of caramely malty sweetness too thats not too strong.  I would like to see more bold hops going on.
A little too malty for a double IPA, I wish when breweries would make a double IPA they would keep a high hop to malt ratio like the regular IPAs.
Pours orangish brown, medium head. Citrus, floral, leaves. Somewhat heavy and sweet. Plenty of bitterness. A nice IPA
Pours light copper with a thick white head and a little lace.  Lots of fruit and some hops in the aroma.  Great hoppiness with a nice price tag.

Bought at Barley wine in Copenhagen. A wonderful nose full of over ripe pineapple, mango and grape. My guess is that the malt has overcome the hops due to shipping to Denmark. Sweet, sweet mouthfeel. Lots of fruit, wonderful to sip but maybe sweet to the nose than to the tongue. Medium bitter. Very good.

Bottle.  Poured an golden orange with a bubbly white head that wa poured rigorously to achieve. Very grapefruity nose with pine and a nice sweetness.  Flavour was pretty in your face, but it smelled better than tasted but still was quite nice.  Citrusy/piney flavor that had a very bitter finish.  Wasn’t that balanced but what do you expect for this category.  Mouth was medium high for this style for me.  Overall, really nice brew that I hope to have again soon.

12 oz. pours brownish yellowwith very little head. Not a lot on the nose some caramel, pine and grapefruit. Very malty, some pine but it’s not ripping the enamel from my teeth. Mouthfeel is thin for an Imp IPA  and the finish is bitter but not long.
Had it many times. Love it. Still love how Lagunitas does NOT raise their prices in this epic game of charging more for beer!

clear copper white head med carbonation A: Citrusy, caramel a bit of bread in there as well. F: med body finish it bitter and medium long. O: Was expecting a bit more hoppy aroma on that one like a big giant punch.
Tried this beer at the Casanova Beer Cave Festival (2011), had a nice hop flavor.

Bottle @ home. Orange amber appearance with an orange tan head. Quite piney, light earthy hoppy nose over a fairly strong malty nose. Very hoppy- grapefruit, pine, green, organic- and sweet and fairly strong pale malty flavor. Big flavor but well done.

Pourd from 12oz bottle, pours a clear copper with a thin white dinimishing head, aroma is of subtle pine and hops, I was actually hoping for a little more on the nose, the flavor has a nice mix of hops mixed in with the malt and a decent bitterness bite to it, nothing out of this world but a solid all around DIPA.

Pours a clear copper color with a white creamy head. Strong smell of piney citrus aroma. Strong flavorful hops, right down a hopheads alley. A slight piney hop taste with a smooth bite at the finish. Nice after taste. Very drinkable.

bottle; amber clear with small off-white head; aroma-pine and floral, some citrus, sweet malt; taste-mild sweetness and carbonation, very good bitterness without overdoing it. Very good double IPA, accessible to all

Reviewed from notes.

Served in a tulip glass. Pours a nice orange color that is just ever-so-slightly darkened by a bit of bronze. Nose is strong citrus hops with loads of orange and grapefruit. A bit of rind. The taste is quite hoppy, but doesn’t hit quite the level of the nose. Nice bitter and resinous feel. Drinks quite well and is a solid DIPA.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-14-2010
Bottle. Copper, gold color smells or fruit, hope and lemon zest. Taste is strong with a sticky syrupy presence. Really drinkable and good. Enjoyed this very much

Poured a clear, light copper color.  Almost no head, not sure why.  Bad bottling?  Anyway, aroma was of grassy hops and malts.  Taste was a medium bitterness.  Medium body, slick texture.  Almost no carbonation (see above).  Will have to try another bottle sometime and see if carbonation is better.

a rather boring looking clear copper body, a nice white head that forms a great cap... balanced nose with some pineapple, caramel and grass hops, a touch sweet for a dipa... something off about the taste, really blah, front is chemical hops with an alcohol finish... really rough to drink, pass

There is something fairly comical that this beer advertises itself as being an extreme version of anything...this is not an extreme beer.  There is pleasant aromas of citrus, lemon zest, and pine...the malts are present, and well balanced, in the flavor with citrus and pine from the hops. This is a great IPA, but definitely not an IIPA in my opinion, and I am not just talking by Pacific Northwest hop monster standards.

Poured into a shaker glass. Aroma is really hoppy, and pleasant. Appearance is clear amber, with a thin head. Pretty typical looking for a IPA. Flavour is very floral hoppy. Not to bitter for the high IBU rating. Mouth feel is medium bodied, and kind of watery. Carbonation is normal. For me this is a good IPA that didn’t have much flair, but its good!

Deep reddish gold pour with a thin, sticky white head. Rich orange and grapefruit aroma, with a sharp hop bite. Caramel, estery sweetness. Taste is malty, bready sweetness up front. Somewhat bitter piney finish, but the hops are largely balanced by the hefty malt bull. Mouthfeel is fizzy and well carbonated. Not my favorite Lagunitas offering, but not bad.

12 oz bottle - Pours an murky orange color with a nice foamy white head. Nose of intesne floral hops, pine and citrus. The taste had the same intensity - with grapefruit, pine, resiny hops and some caramel - a solid  Imperial IPA.  Lagunitas is never one to disappoint!

A- Beautiful golden/golden hue, that pours great white lacing.

S- great hop aroma that reminds me of Chico, CA, screams cascade and I am diggin this aroma. Fruity yet bitter, but the fruits come out a lot stronger.

T- I love Lagunitas! I have yet to be disappointed by the brewery. Great hop flavors with a well-balanced malt structure. Tastes like Sierra Nevada on crack. This is a great example of a TRUE double IPA. Very floral, and I cant describe how well the malts are balance right now, but it is b-e-a-u-tiful.

M- the hops come straight out in this one, hitting the palate perfectly. leaves the mouth with a dry feeling that is expected with the style, yet the malts mellow it out. everytime I take a sip, I want another one just to feel it again.

D- Great beer to have a couple of but like all double IPAs, it should be consumed with caution due to the higher alcohol content. I love this beer to finish my night, but even better to start it off when drinking IPAs all night. Support this brewery, Lagunitas isn’t as pretentious as Stone, makes better beer and cost substantially less.

Bottle pours orange/gold with a white head.  Aroma shows notes of caramel, citrus, pine, and light florals. Flavor shows the same with defined notes of tangerine, candied orange, and lemongrass.  Overall body is moderate and sticky with a somewhat aggresively bitter finish.
Bottle thanks to Phaleslu. Clear golden orange. Aroma of grapefruit, pine, lots of citrus. Taste is great, bitter but not one dimensional. Good malt balance, excellent beer.

Hazy golden beer with a frothy, white head. Hoppy/grassy aromas. Expecting something pretty awesome here. Tastes of fresh lawn clippings, pine needles, and some hints of assorted, tangy fruits. A bit flat, and one dimensional. Bitter hop finish. Delivers on what one expects from the style, but doesn’t do much to set itself apart from other beers in this style. Their regular IPA is a better brew.

I’ll preface this by saying that I rated Lagunitas IPA earlier today so my palate maybe trained to the IPA flavor.  This beer poured a golden honey orange with a white one finger head which showed nice lacing.  Hints of aromatic hops and citrus sweetness on the nose.  There was a malty sweetness in the center of the mouth and some bitterness on the finish, but not what I expected.  I feel like I got more hop bitterness from the IPA than this one.  It also lacked the carmel notes that the regular IPA had.  Overall and very enjoyable and well balanced beer.

12oz bottle.  Pours a hazy amber orange color with a two finger off white head that dropped down to a thin layer.   Its aroma is piney, floral hops with some citrus notes and some light malt.  Taste is primarily big bitter, spicy hops with a solid malt overlay that has hints of citrus and tangy tangerine. Smooth, spicy mouthfeel.  A decent DIPA.
This should be a double IPA, it’s not so bitter as it says on the bottle, but is a fantastic tasty American summer IPA / Pale Ale.

12oz bottle. Pours a darker orange reminiscent of newly stained hardwood floors.  Aroma of orange rind, with a earthy, grassy scent in the background covering just a hint of booze.  The beer flows from slightly orange citrus upfront into a sweet malt profile into a bitter astringent finish. The finish is what I can’t get onboard it.  It has similarities to some DIPAs, but I technically wouldn’t consider it one.  Its just a real hopped up, bitter-ass, IPA.  If you like west coast IPAs, this one is for you.

Small white head with minimal lacing. light amber hue in the glass. Aromas of slightly sweet hops. Some floral/perfume notes in there as well. Mouth-feel is sufficiently carbonated. Initially the hops are soft then expand as it moves over the palate. Great balance overall. At 72 IBU I expected more bitterness. This was surprisingly smooth.
hops hops hops....  awesome aroma, not too bitter, and loaded with hops.  Huge mouth feel, and very very drinkable

Pours caramel amber into the glass, with a wispy fluff head that leaves chunky lace.  The nose is of fresh spruce and pine.  An assertive caramel malt backbone doesn’t get in the way of the cleansing spruce and citrusy grapefruit and orange peel.  It finishes with a healthy dose of pine hops, alongside some alcohol.  It feels very full, yet very refreshing.  Nice, clean on the palate, but of definite substance.  A nice offering here.

A very underrated IIPA.  Forgot about this one and then recently had what seemed to be a very fresh bottle.  I put it right up there w/ Pliny and some of the others with high ratings.  If you want a great all-around solid Imperial IPA grab one of these.  Lagunitas continues to please the taste buds!

Comes in a somewhat interesting 12 fluid ounce bottle with some ramblings about its high intensity. apparently it is 72.41 IBU’s. Has an indecypherable freshness code.

Pours a clear copper with a 1 and a half finger slightly off white head with large bubbles. Leaves some slightly intricate lacing behind.

Smell is of hops, not that intense though, I expect more from a DIPA. Has a sweet/earthy characteristic. 

Body is smooth, with a small amount of carbonation. A bit of biscuity malt and a hint of watermelon and apple. Hops are present in the form of pine sap, honey, a spritz of lemon, and intense bitterness. The aftertaste bittersweet. The alcohol is well hidden. This isn’t too pungent considering it is a DIPA, maybe I need to get it fresher.

Overall its a pretty average selection in the DIPA category. It just seems very pedestrian considering the IBU’s and the somewhat of hype it gets.
Pours a pure gold with quickly dispersing foam. Smells sweet of lupulin. Tastes primarily of floral hops, though quite sweet and lightly bitter.

12oz bottle.
Somewhere between amber and orange with some frothy white head.  Lots of delicious pine and tropical fruit hop aromas - very balanced with a great malt backbone.  Resiny and chewy - reminds me of why I love this style so much, especially when done this well.  One I keep coming back to year after year.

Had the wet hop version of this on tap at The Common Table and it was incredible.  The resiny wet hops made this already great brew even better.

I had this from a bottle poured into a pint glass.  There is a light very small head.  It is medium amber color with strong hop flavor and taste.  A little citrus but that is mostly overwhelmed by the hops.  Good Beer, not sure I can drink too many though.

Pours deep amber with one-finger white head that laces pretty well. Hops aren’t too strong on the nose for the style, with some stickiness and lots of malt character. Some tropical fruit citrus, perhaps pineapple, lurking in the background. Taste is hoppy, but with much more malt than expected. Very coarse beginning, with initial hop bitterness quickly countered by fruity sweet malt. Pine is evident mid-sip as well which is nice. Sticky finish that lingers on the tongue. Drinkability is decent, nothing incredible for the style, but still solid. Lagunitas cranks out affordable, good beers and I laud them for that.
Good IPA. Nice aroma. Tastes of citrus in the beginning and ends with good hops flavor and bitterness. Crisp. Great summer beer.

A pretty solid beer. Aroma of pineapple, sweet grapefruit juice and resinous pine. A beautiful bright golden orange body with a moderate finger of whitish head. A sweet highly hopped beer with tangy mango and pineapple flavours. A wonderful beer, but not as good as other IIPA’s from Lagunitas.
(bottle)  Light copper color with long-lasting head and lacing.  Refreshing and distinctively hoppy, without being overwhelming.  Mellow and smooth.  Could easily session this.

Pours a copper orange with a medium white head. lots of lacing. nose is sweet citrus and orange. grapefruit, honey and herbs. taste is really sweet, with a bitter orange peel on the back end. palate is decent but mouthfeel is a little on the light side. overall a pretty good DIPA

On cask at Max’s in Baltimore. Opaque tawny gold with one finger white head. Brilliant nose on this beer. Big citrus and tropical hop aromas. I can identify tangerine, grapefruit, mango and pineapple. Amarillo and Columbus hops? Great nose...unfortunately, the enjoyment ended there. I’m guessing this was the end of the cask or the cask had been mishandled. The beer had a cardboard and soapy flavor. Not enjoyable at all. Some  sweet malt and some hop flavors, but they in the background compared to the soap. Bummer.

Golden amber color. Aroma is of hops. Maybe I am drinking an old bottle, but I do not get much of a taste of citrus. Instead I got a tolerable toffee taste, and also a hint of alcohol. In the end an unpleasant bitter taste lingered in my mouth.

Bottle. Punchy hop perfume aroma, good copper colour but not much head retention. Quite sweet up front then as the sweetness turns a bit stcky, then hop bitterness kicks in. Some sweeter citrus - orange and tangerine. Not bad at all
Bottle. Amber red color, small white head. Nose of grass, pine, and alcohol. Sharp hop bite and crisp carbonation with a sticky finish. A good, if unmemorable, strong IPA.

18th April 2009 
Beautifully coloured amber goldbeer. Soft silky palate. No bitterness - deep rich hops mixed with a toffee like sweetness. Lovely palate, lovely flavour.

Great huge hop aroma with a quite a complex fruity aroma. The aroma on this is fantastic! The mouthfeel is quite full with a good supporting malt flavour but its ALL about the hops with this beer. Bitterness is definately there but the malt does balance it out. Great beer!

Lucent amber, thin but lasting beige head, sticky medium-full body, medium-high carbonation.



Aroma: bright resinous juicey piney hops, sweet bready malt.



Taste: lots of bitter resinous herbal piney hops, bready pale malt sweetness.



Very hop-focused, with good hop character. Not much toffee, caramel, or nutty malt flavor. Unbalanced toward bitter, but the hop profile is clean and bright, and the bitterness does not accumulate, or overwhelm an accustomed palate.

golden pour.  exceptional aroma...sweet citrus, pine, very nice.  complex hoppy flavor but not too bitter.  love the caramel malty backbone to this one.  Lagunitas is quickly becoming one of my favorite brewers.

Bottle. Aromas full of flowers, malts and citrus hops. Taste is lots of citrus hop,some pine and more floral notes. Also getting plenty of caramel and a nice malt backbone to round this out. Wish I could buy it here!

Bottle 330ml. Masterpiece. Aromas of caramel, grass, butter, a bit of citrus, and a touch of alcohol. Taste is bitter, with balancing maltiness, and very long length. Palate is creamy, and full bodied. Orange, with a frothy white head.
NIc eone,  little bitter and nci ebrewed. A little dusty and grapsy but fine one.

355mL bottle.  Pours hazy gold that clarifies with temperature and a wispy head.  Aroma of citrus, tropical fruit, berries, malt and alcohol.  Pretty mild but harsh bitterness, medium sweetness, a little fruity.  Medium bodied, soft carbonation, fairly sticky without much of a finish.

Crystal clear deep bronze color, with substantial head which leaves great intricate lacing. Aroma is citrus hops and malt. Flavor profile is hop forward, but the sweet maltiness was taken too far. It takes away from the bitterness and complexity of the hops. If I buy an IPA with 72 IBUs I want to be knocked over by the hops, not get a toothache from the sweetness.

Pours brilliantly clear deep golden to light copper with a sizable off-white head.  Lots of floral hop aroma with a good amount of malty sweetness as well.  Hops dominate, but a sweet caramel malt flavor provides a very nice background for this beer.  Carbonation is moderate and creamy, and the hop bitterness leave no astringency in the finish.  Excellent beer, will definitely be drinking more of this in the future.

A good super-hopped IPA, but not a great super-hopped IPA. This one dispenses of the subtleties and hits you with the hops. Which is enjoyable, but also leaves you glad you only had a small bottle of it.

Oily clean pour.  Pine resin and orange peel aroma.  Caramel backing.  Tastes like pine needles, grass.  Heavy-medium body.  Chewy and sticky.  A cold IPA, lacking significant floral or spice character.  Strictly summer.
What can I say, Lagunitas has got a good roster.  From Stouts to Ales they make great beer...
This is by far the best IPA I have ever tasted. Fruity aroma and fruity taste which compliments this IPA and makes it its own.

Pours a beautiful golden hue with a almost non existant head. Aroma is sweet hits the nose with a berry like smell. Taste is out of this world  with a smooth blend of citrus flavor and hoppy a very very small hint of alchohol. This is a great beer, goes on my highly recommended list for IPA lovers. Hard to beat.

Burnt orange / coppery color. Very clear with some light carbonation.  Nice aroma. Mostly all hops here. Right up front I got some citrusy Grapefruit and fresh Pear & Apricot  Tart hoppiness.Malts recede to the hop character.  Medium to fuller body. Very enjoyable.

Pours a mostly clear amber with sizable head.  Very aromatic - citrus hops - grapefruit, orange - very nice.   Very flavorful, and like many IIPAs - very dry and bitter at the end.  Quite enjoyable - would gladly purchase as often as I can - cheers!

Lemons and citrus in the nose.  Hoppy, floral aroma.  Pours a deep golden color.  Not as bitter as I expected.  I wouldn’t go as far as to call this a double IPA.  Maybe like a 1.5x IPA.  Good session beer.  Yeah, I said it.  Sessionable.  A 6 pack of this stuff goes down smooth and will set you straight.  Good beer.

A fine IPA tasting at Uncle Steve’s abode, with Brian the Beer Pimp, the Doctor of Beerology, Drbayern, the notorious Celticbrew, and Bobster.
Poured yellow with a nice creamy head, sweet floral aroma. Nice esy hop taste, with a note of sweet blossomy flavor.  Nice bittering on the aftertaste.
Pours light crystal clear copper color. Strong floral aroma. Sweet taste well balances by tons of  sticky hops.  Medium  body and citrus aftertaste. Another very good Lagunitas brew.

12oz bottle.  Filtered orange-tan.  Soapy, glass-lacing, off-white head.  Steady hop aroma, solid west coast feel.  Quite a resiny, syrupy mouthfeel.  The hops really stick around in the aftertaste.  Lots of orange flavor.  Clean, doughy malt backbone covered in hops.  Rather mellow mouthfeel.  Pretty solid beer overall, maybe a little underwhelming.

Pours a dark straw color with a fluffy white head.  Good lacing.  Aroma is fresh floral and hoppy.  When you first take a sip it is silky and hoppy.  Medium mouth feel.  The aroma is just amazing, this is one damn good beer!  I don’t know what hops where used but they are awesome!

Bottle served in a tulip. Pours near-clear polished oiled copper. Medium size off-white head. Good retention and lace. Nose is mostly malty, but also bitter. Caramel, nuts, bread, and resin. Very sweet flavor. Medium-full body, s-thick-y texture, mild carbonation, bitter finish but the big sweetness lingers as well. I would guess this is a Lagu brew, blind. Almost cloyingly sweet.
Strong but not over powering hop flavor with a smooth finish. Deep amber color and hoppy aroma.

Bottle from Breeze Thru.  Pours a golden orange with a lot of activity under a 1/4 inch head.  Aroma is lemony grapefruit and pine.  That carries into the flavor, which carries a nice bitterness throughout.  Some overriped fruitiness in the mouthfeel, but I would characterize as an ipa not a double.  A good ipa, better certainly than their regular one as this carries through on the promise of the aroma.

Drinks much lighter (and indeed easier) for a DIPA. Hops are fresh on both the nose and palate, and there’s plenty of resin sweetness and malt power coming through the aromas as well. Holds the sweetness in the mouth but for the most part enough bitterness to cut through. Some aniseed to finish. Very solid.
12oz bottle pours clear copper with thick bubbly off-white head. Aroma is sweet caramel, citrus, and pine. Taste is very sweet, honey and citrus. Sticky syrup texture.

Really mean IPA and one of my old favorites. Always nice to see it pop up around here, not something that happens very often. This is absolutely as good as mid-grade IPAs come in general, and I tend to gravitate toward those that toe the line between regular and imperial (such as this), so it’s right up my alley. Awesome copper semi-transparent color and dense beige head. Nose and flavor are identical: big time resin bomb, medium-heavy hop presence. Extremely robust flavor that keys the hops in perfectly. Outstanding brew and a great value as well especially if you’re on the west coast.

Pours amber with a small head.
Nose shows rich caramel, hoppy resin and orange marmalde.
Flavours are very similar; huge amounts of malt, lots of caramel and golden syrup with more marmalade, pine and grassy hops. Bitterness is hardly aggressive for a DIPA, or even an IPA for that matter. Or maybe its just that insane malt overshadowing it.
Carbonation should be higher to cut through the sweetness.
Very easy to drink, especially for a DIPA.

355ml bottle. Looks great in the glass with a strong body and a nice cracking head that hangs around. Once those piney floral hop aromas get into your nose they take over your body. Full mouthfeel with a silky texture and a flavour that makes your throat glow. Definitely one to be savoured.

Bottle.  Poured a clear amber with a dense beige head.  Aroma is driven by intense hop esters of pine resin and grapefruit.  Medium body, mouth feel is sticky with good carbonation.  Big hop extract notes of pine, grass, and citrus and light pineapple, however, there is a strong enough caramel, sweet malt foundation to support the bitterness.  Flavor is distinctly Lagunitas.  Finishes slightly sweet with a good dose of lingering bitterness.

Bottle from Total Wine, Las Vegas. Pours a brilliant, almost Lucozade-hued orange with a slim, tenacious white foam. Aroma a pot pourri of Peach Soothers, rose, grapefruit and honey. Well-balanced with a slippery, lemon mousse palate, chalky alkalinity, notes of grapefruit, tinned peach and lemon zest and a firm, honeyed digestive biscuit malt base. Sweeter and more balanced than the pale ale and pils; a mellow, flowery, gently humming IPA with a big lovely cuddle of honey-cushioned bitterness. Just a slice less of tinned peach sweetness would, for me, nudge it from good to great.

Bottle. Clear orangeish amber pour with afoamy white head that doesn’t last long. Aroma has lots of nutty, caramely malt and hoppy notes of passionfruit, apricot, orange, lime, mango and grapefruit. The hops dominate the flavour a little more than the aroma but there is still a nice balancing malt profile. Moderately thick, oily mouthfeel with soft, tingly carbonation and a long bitter finish. Maybe not the most remarkable or original DIPA but still quite nice, easy to drink and kinda sessionable. A good choice for when you want something worthwhile without being challenged too much.

Pours a decent golden orange with a billowy cream coloured head. Plenty of lacing. Aromas are very malt forward with plenty or brown sugar and light caramel. Some citrus hop character in the background. Flavours are once againdominated by the malt. Plenty of sweetness and a slight toast. Hops come through near the end, Medium mouthfeel. No where near as hoopy as anticipated. Have definately had better DIPA’s.

Poured a Hazy copper Orange, Foamy white head and excellent lacing along the side of the glass. Aroma is hoppy with notes of honey, grapefruit and and something else sweet. Flavor is sweet and malty up front and bitter and hoppy on the back end. Nice balance, the sweetness has a taste of fruit....Banana or Pineapple? Whatever it is I like it. I would like to try this fresh next summer, maybe it will have a more "Hop" presence. Solid 2IPA

Aromas are big toffee and brown sugar, hops of citrus and pine. Flavour is heavy up front malt of toffee, buscuit and carame. Hops are strong citrus and leave a long bitter finnish. Full mouthfeel and slightly sticky.
From a 12ox bottle....pours a light amber.  Toasty malt with pronounced hops. Citrus.  A nice, solid IPA.  Not overwhelmingly hoppy.
From bottle at bierbistro. Dark copper with resin and citrus hops. I down graded the palate a bit because I found it a bit syrupy.  However, all that malt definitely makes this an interesting beer.

From bottle. Pours gold with a touch of haze and some off-white head. Nice hoppy aroma with some citrus and herbal notes, along with some pine. Lots of flavor, fairly thick, decent amount of bitterness. Well balanced with a decent amount of malt character that comes out on the palate. Medium bodied. A very solid, flavorful IPA.

Clear copper coloured pour medium carbonation aromas caramel floral fruit honey flavours very sweet caramel honey bitter not strong but works in well grapefruit apricot nutty taste bright malty tastes a real plus at the finish with fruity hop tastes they leave a pleasing aftertaste

This is a curious beer that is not really big enough to be a dipa, but is a bit too big to be an ipa. I can see why it is classified as a dipa, though, because the malt profile is what really stands out. This gave the beer a pleasant reddish color when poured from a 12 oz bottle into a snifter. It is sufficiently hopped to raise an appetizing aroma even through a 1 1/2 finger head, yet the primary flavor is of caramel complexity. Smooth and light in the mouth, it’s much easier to drink 2 (or more!) of these relative to most dipas. The price ($11/6) also helps in that regard. Overall, this is a strong ipa or a weak dipa, as you prefer ... but is tasty and reasonably priced either way.
Doesn’t have the hops power I expected. The hops is balanced with malts with a nice caramel flavour on the taste. Hops are more on the grassy side than fruity. Nice thickness in the mouth.
Well balanced with the hops and malts. Impressive but not quite my favorite imperial IPA.

Bottle. Poured a very nice amber color with a smaller white head, left some lacing on the glass. Aroma was caramel, citrus, and spruce. Malty backbone with a hop aftertaste. More well balanced IPA. Good though.

Bottle at Wachi. Big, fruity, earthy aroma with caramel and great hops. Bright, shiny, amber color. Sweet caramel flavor, very fruity with cherry, plus nice grass and citrus hops. Strong bitterness. Rather high carbonation. A bit too sweet, though bitterness in the finish balances well. A pedestrian, but very well done IPA.

Bottle. Clear amber with an off-white head. Aroma has kumquat, peach, caramel, a little cheese. Taste has caramel, stone fruits, bread and again a little cheese. Not that much bitterness apparent at the rather muddled finish. A nice enough fruity ale, but needed either more finishing bitterness or aromatics. I was expecting that this would be what I liked about the Hop Stoopid and the normal IPA, but it’s lesser than either despite the more charming malt side. Maybe the aromatic hops didn’t make the journey. A tad disappointing.

Clear lite amber with 1 finger off-white head. leaves nice sparse lacing. Smell is floral sweet hops Hops, fruit and citrus. Taste is Hops up front, mild fruit and citrus sweet notes and nice mildly creamy malts. Hits your tongue with hop bite and dryness, moderate zesty carbonation, feels clean and refreshing. A good brew...Hops up front but not overdone, a pretty nice balance. I’d buy again, and again!
(12oz bottle thanks to mar) clear golden orange with a film of white bubbles. Nose of weed, dank, orange, spicy marmalade. Taste of weed, bong water, citrus, and candied fruit.

355 ml bottle. From København, Denmark.

Hazy amber colour with small white head.
Fruity and floral hoppy aroma with some caramel notes.
Flavour is tropical fruity hoppy with bitterness but not that extensive. Maltiness and citrus in this delicious and highly drinkable beer.
Bottled at Stockholm Beer Festival 2010. Copper color. Strong hop aroma and flavor with mango, lemon and toffee. Strong yet smooth bitterness. Good smooth and firm IPA.

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a Cigar City snifter.

Appearance: Pours a clear orange-copper with a very small foamy white head which dissipates quickly. Minimal lacing.

Smell: Sweet floral and citrus hops, caramel and a hint of alcohol in the background.

Taste: Mildly sweet citrus up front followed by a mix of spicy hops and earthy malts in the middle then an explosion of lemon rind bitterness and a subdued hint of alcohol at the finish. Aftertaste is very bitter. I’m surprised that this is only 72 IBUs.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied with a moderate amount of carbonation.

Drinkability: Fairly high drinkability. You could down a couple without much trouble.

Overall: Good beer overall. While I guess it’s technically an Imperial IPA, I consider this more of a strong IPA. It’s not the best in the world but you can do much worse.

Bottle consumed during Online Birthday Party, October 16th, 2010. Gold with a white head. Leafy, hoppy aroma with a hint of creamy caramel developing. Sweet taste with leafy coriander and a sharp bitter finish. Full and exhilarating, yet very drinkable.

Mine is a lot maltier than the other reviews that I read.  Maybe a bit old?  The bitterness is there,  but the malt aroma and malt flavors are very strong on the front and the bitterness kicks in after the malt.  Maybe mine is a bit old?  Still pretty good though.

Bottle at home for Hugie and IrishBoys 60th Online Birthday Bash ... golden amber ... thin white head ... light malt ... soft pine hop nose ... some of that malt i dont like  ... big hop ... some hop resins ... decent enough

Thanks to mar for sharing this bottle.

The beer pours a yellow color with a white head. The aroma is not near as strong as I remembered it being. I get some pine and citrus notes, as well as a little bit of toffee. Still, it is not the big strong aroma that I remember from this beer. The flavor is similar, but more pronounced. I get some tropical fruit and pine hop notes, as well as some alcohol. There is also some toffee. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

Yellowish amber, not a lot of head.  Tons of hop aroma along with smells of pineapple.  Taste is seemingly of fresh, green hops, some malt behind it, but not too much sweetness or alcohol feel.  I’ve always thought I liked IPA, but perhaps I’m tasting some really good ones thats making me like IPAs a lot more.

Pours brilliant and pure copper.  Medium, foamy white head.  Nose drips of caramel malt and spicy hops.  Nice carbonation level, lot of crispness on the palate.  Good amount of malt character underlying a solid bitterness on the finish.  More resiny than floral or citrus.  Despite similar bittering to the "Sumpin’ Extra" Ale I had last night, this one is much better balanced and drinkable.  Good stuff, but still not remotely solid enough to become a favorite in this style.

12oz bottle thanks to TheSevenDuffs.


Appearance : Clear amber with medium creamy head. Extensive lacing.


Aroma : Nice fruity and piny. Lots of malt, a bit spicy. Very fresh and fruity. A bit sugary.


Taste : Nice fruity and malty. A bit piny and resinous. Finish is fruity, piny and quite malty. Rather bitter and a bit resinous. Citrusy finish. A bit sugary on finish.


Overall : Quite drinkable. Nice balance between hops and malt. Soft and enjoyable carbonation. Very nice IPA. I like Lagunitas !!

Maybe this would be better on tap. Lagunitas makes some great IPAs but this is not one of them. The hops just aren’t there, they don’t have the intense citrus kick that a good California ipa should have.

Orange color with some head.  Aroma mostly citrus and some floral.  Medium full body with lots of moderately bitter hops, some spices, some citrus, a touch of sweetness, some pine.  Kind of between an IPA and DIPA, whatever, it’s good.

Aroma of grapefruit, hard candy, lemon zest and earthy hops. Appearance is dark reddish gold with off white head. Flavor matches the nose, and for the IBUs, this beer is very smooth and drinkable for the style. Palate is bubbly.  Very nice IPA.

Have to echo others- nice appearance and aroma, but strange dominance of malt on the palate.  Kind of reminds me of Paddockwood Loki, another (Canadian) not entirely disagreeable but slightly "off" double IPA dominated by malt rather than hops.

Amber orange pour with a fluffy white head.  Brown sugar and caramel aroma with pronounced citrus peaking through.  Has that brown sugar and caramel flavor up front, but it’s sufficiently pounded into submission by orangey citrus and an aggressive resinous bitter finish.  I’m generally not a fan of a lot of sweetness in my double IPAs, but this does it better than most.
Very nice deep hop aroma, quickly fading head, orangish - copper pour...not too floral, not overly hoppy - nice delicate balance and delicious.
bottle pours light amber with a medium white head.  Aroma is all hops, pine, some floral.  Flavor is sweet grassy malts, hay, and ending with a grassy, leafy hop finish.

pours a nice clear amber with a small creamy off-white head.  Foe a small head, it sure persists and laces.  The aroma hits you with citrus and pine with some sweet malts, caramel, in the background.  The beer has a medium-light body and dry bitter finish, big on the bitterness.  The taste is more of the same, citrus and pine hops dominate, there is some sweet malt in the bckground.  This is a very hoppy/bitter beer.

Saturated orange color with a frothy white head. Aroma is sweet and earthy, and reminds me of snus (Swedish snuff). Taste is earthy and hoppy with some muscovado sugar. Nice balance betweet swetness and hops.

I’ll agree with many out there who say that this brew has too much malt character. There’s too much sweetness which can be a huge problem if enough of your carbonation and bubbles are gone. As it warms this beer becomes too heavy and doesn’t  resemble the great beer it can be. Not a favorite of mine.

Enjoyed a six-pack of this. Pours rich orange with nice clarity. Aroma is all pine and caramel malt. Flavor packs a orange, lightly caramel punch with nice bitterness and relatively high carbonation. Drinks nicely.
Poured copper yellow color and an off-white lacing head. Fairly light aroma, some floral notes with grapefruit and caramel. Medium dense body and carbonation. Sweet taste with a dry, hoppy finish.

There are some who would say this is not a IIPA because it is only 7.5% alcohol. I think that says something about where the beer scene in the United States is. I don’t think what it says is bad; I just think it says something. Anyway, this IIPA is on the light side alcohol wise but has plenty of hops and more than enough malt to earn its style designation if you ask me. It might even have too much malt character, not that that’s a bad thing. It’s a clear orange color, head is small and of mostly large bubbles--not really what I look for but not entirely unappealing. Big pine hops dominate the nose. I am more of a citrus hop kind of guy but this is still good. It also has a fruity melon malt and ale yeast quality that I generally associate w/ barleywines. This is definitely not a one dimensional beer. There is real malt character here. Whether or not that is appropriate to the style is up to personal taste but I like it just fine. The fine carbonation cuts it and keeps it from cloying, allowing the hops to shine just as much. It all works rather well and while I do think the best IIPAs have that "oops, I just drank a half gallon of really strong ale like it was Sierra Nevada pale ale" quality, I can appreciate one like this that makes you take your time on it. I feel like it tastes bigger than it actually is and that is always a worthy accomplishment in my book.

Pours a nice clear amber with a quickly disappearing white foam.  Aroma is grapefruit and pine hop.  Taste is a blast of hop bitterness, followed by citrus and mild malt mouthfeel.  Tastes like an IPA on roids, which I suppose it’s meant to me.  Good beer but not the best DIPA I’ve had.
Great IPA.  Complex malty start moving into a resiny/grassy hop finish/.  High gravity with excellent mouthfeel.  All the complexity I expect from such a brewery.

$10.99/6 pack. Whole Foods. San Antonio, TX. A golden-orange beer with an average 1 finger head. The aroma is sweet, very nice and piney, citrus-orange, peach, grapefruit. A nice and pleasant aroma. A nice malt taste that can be sweet at the front but at the end of the drink the hop flavors come in with peach, pine, and orange. Reminds me somewhat of Modus just a little more sweet and bitter.

Bottle at Block Party. Pours clear copper with a medium, white head. Bit hop aroma with sweet citrus and grass. Flavor has a nice, sweet malt profile followed by heavy, bitter hops. Medium bodied with average carbonation. Finishes with lip-smacking bitters and light, bready malts. Solid.
Copper, big citrus hop aroma, maybe some pine. Slight caramel sweetness with a huge hop presence, fairly bitter.

Bottle that Craig picked up for me from GBBF (cheers mate) consumed in a wet field at Fairports Cropredy Annual Reunion 12-07-10  The nose nose sweet malt & hops, taste is sweet, malty and with a good hoppy bite. Bi fresh green hops in mouth and surprisingly less bitter than expected though there is a noticeable furriness across the tongue.   A6 A4 T7 P4 Ov13  3.4

This poured a clear golden-orange, with some very fluffy foam, almost reminiscent of rising bread dough. Aroma has some floral hops, along with a faint sweetness. Up front, the floral and citrus-like hops are definitely more present, though they are dempered quite well by the sweet bready malts. Carbonation, while significant, is also very soft to the touch. All in all, this is actually an extremely well balanced double ipa. A sessionable double ipa that will not ruin your palate.

OK this is a fat-ass IPA. Dark blonde and clear with a pale tan dense cap. Fresh citrus aroma, candy fruit. Taste sweet candy fruit, apricot and lemon. Dense sweetness, lingering palate is very solid. Finish dry grassy hops.
Bottle. Pours orange, white head. Caramel maslt and citrus hop notes in the aroma. Sweet. Add some real bitterness in the end and you get the taste. Simple and inviting.
Bottle.  Pours mostly clear yellow-orange.  Smell of lemon and orange citrus hops with with piney hops and malty sweetness.  Medium body with a nice sweet taste balanced out with hoppy bitterness.

330 ml bottle from Premier Wine & Spirits (Halifax).  Pours a fairly clear rusty orange with a small white head.  Strong caramel malt backbone with citrus and herbal hops.  Taste is quite malty with decent citric/herbal/piney hopping.  Medium body.  Somewhat dry, moderately bitter finish.  Fairly easy drinking for a DIPA.  Nice.

12oz bottle: Appearance is amber brown with minimal off white head, Aroma is very dominate in citrus hops, Flavor is again dominate in citrus hops with a mildly malty pale malt backbone and hints of caramel. Pretty good DIPA.

Bottle bought at GBBF 2010. A beautiful orange coloured pour with a medium white head. Wonderful hoppy aroma that I could inhale forever. A superb balance of hops, malt and sweetness. This is so damn drinkable. If I could invent a perfect DIPA this is how it would taste. A beautifully balanced and quality DIPA, if only I could get a 6 pack in my local Tescos here in the UK. Bloody marvellous!
Pours orange amber.  Aroma is florals, citrus, pine and some cereal.  Taste is bitter with a sweet and resiny finish.  Very interesting IPA with the malts coming through more than usual.

Figured this must have been a double IPA when I got a whiff. Nice and malty sweet with the hops in the background. Very rich and full bodied mouth feel with a very sweet malty start followed by a nice hop balance. Finish was dry and refreshing despite the alcohol content.
Transparent copper in the glass.  Earthy hop aromas.  Strong hops on a caramel malt background.  Quite pleasant.

Bottle.  Pours a clear golden orange with a white head.  Nose is lots of piney hops, some citrus, sweet caramel malts.  Taste begins and finishes with the hops, again pine dominating, some citrus.  Fairly well-balanced with the malts.  Some sweetness up front, more bitter towards the finish.  Nice dry, bitter hoppy finish.  Pretty good IPA overall.

22 oz bottle at Bar Volo in Toronto (6/07). Poured clear light orange with a white foamy head. Aroma is my favorite in this, like putting your head in a hopsack, with pine being predominant. A little bit of bitterness at the end, but not what I would really expect of an imperial, but very nice.

12 oz. bottle from Blueberry Hill.  Pours an orange-amber color with a small off-white head.  Notes of piney hops, orange citrus, resinous pine tree sap, pineapple, sweet malts, and sugar.  Medium-bodied, with a sticky mouthfeel and active carbonation.  A little too sweet for my liking but a nice, piney DIPA.

Pours a slightly hazy orange amber with a thick, fine-bubbled, pale orange-tan head. Aroma is strongly hoppy and somewhat fruity. Strongly hoppy flavor is a little bitter and has tones of banana and apple as well as a whisper of sweetness that complements the bitterness rather than fighting it. Texture is smooth, edgy and tingly.

Bottle. Aroma is ruby red grapefruit, dried mango and resinous hops. Appearance is a translucent reddish golden color with a half inch of dense head. Taste starts off with assertive herbal hops and toasted malt flavors followed by grapefruit, caramel, tangerine and pine. Mouthfeel is slightly sticky with medium carbonation and a bitter, tangy finish. The overall flavor is much more aggressively hoppy and citrusy than their regular IPA. While it’s not quite as flavorful and balanced as Hop Stoopid, it’s still a quality DIPA that delivers a strong blast of hops to your taste buds.

12 oz bottle. 07.09.10.
Pours a deep golden honey color with a creamy head like melted whip cream. Taste is predominately pine with some mild citrus hops, pineapple, and a nice caramel malt backbone. The nose is spicy, piney hops, caramel malt, some citrus fruits (pineapple and lemon zest), and a hint of orange rhind. The mouthfeel is very creamy, bordering on being mildly chewy. A nice velvety texture. Great iipa for the price. Thanks Lagunitas.

12 Oz.  Pours a beautiful golden copper with solid fluffy head.  Aroma is of mild floral and citrus hops.   Taste is very broad and full bodied amazing citrus spicy hops.  Finish is clean and crisp with a full bodied malt and hop experience.  Excellent stuff!

355ml bottle. Pours golden orange with average off white head lacing the glass. Strong pine and citrus aromas on the nose, overshadowing anything else. Medium-light body, with moderately assertive, but not upfront bitterness. Flavours apart from those characterized by the hop aromas typically not standing out, however some malty sweetness combines with the lingering bitterness on the medium-dry finish. Alcohol hidden well, Not Bad, but there are better IPA’s out there.

335ml bottle. Pours a slightly hazy bright copper with little head and lace to speak of. Dominant hops on the nose, but not overpowering; kind of lacking I’d say. Very confused in the mouth with a sweet almost wheaty entry but a nice long bitter resiny hop finish. Overall mediocre. Do yourself a favour, drink their Hop Stoopid instead.

Location: Cask at Whole Foods-Bowery, 7/2/10




Aroma: It has an aroma of orange grass, and pine


Appearance: Hazy orange beer with a frothy white head


Flavor: The taste is both sweet and hoppy, pretty big and flavorful


Palate: Medium-full bodied beer with a creamy feel, and a sticky sweetness


Overall Impression: 
Pretty surprised I’ve never rated this one before, but somehow it has gone until now without a review from me.  That all changed when I wandered into the Bowery Beer room on Friday trying to stumble across one of their tastings, and lucking there was the guy from Lagunitas...
This is a really good beer, but I shouldn’t be surprised, these guys never really seem to disappoint.
Thick pillowy head. Golden color in appearance. Great hoppy taste with a sweet finish.

I trusted the ratings on this site, and it was accurate.  Great beer.  Bubbly and alive on the tongue.  Don’t know what they mean by "Unlimitied Release."  If we buy it, they will make more?  Drank mine with mesquite spiced, pan-fried salmon.

Caramel, with pine and pineapple accents. Orange with fine floaties, medium head, nice lacing. Overripe fruit and caramel flavor. Medium body, alcohol evident. It’s ok on an overall beer scale, but mediochre on a craft scale.

A Mes rate. Bottle by the fire on Black Rock beach in Wales.
Well, I’ll start with saying this. Bloody hell! Beautiful clean amber gold with a really good white head and lots of lace. Great looks. Utterly glorious hops backed up with an equally divine hit of candy sugar and fruity malt. Adorable floral character too. Close to perfect prickly bitterness, really good length. Just bloody stunning all round. Brilliant.

9 bucks for a six pack.  Poured a clear dark golden color with a big head, had to pour some off and I poured it lightly.  Aroma was better than I expected, very resiney, pine needles and goodness.  Taste followed suit.  I was expecting barley wine sweetness but didn’t get it, which was a great surprise.  Instead got some excellent hop goodness and a nice lasting bitterness.  A diamond is what I thought would be the rough.  Awesome.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a clear dark gold with a medium white head that dissipates quickly, but leaves a lot of lacing on the glass. The aroma is wonderfully citrusy. The initial taste is sweet, with a surprising bitter kick from the hops. Has a lingering bitter aftertaste. There is minimal carbonation and goes down smoothly, with just a little fizziness. Overall, this is a great IPA. Strong, balanced flavors and smooth drinking.

Bottle.  Pours an orange/copper color with a 1-finger beige head and some suspended debris.  Aroma of pine needles, sap, orange and pineapple, and brown sugar.  Flavor is candy sugar, soft juniper/pine, sweet alcohol, and a slight bitter finish; apricot aftertaste.  Medium carbonation, fairly sweet, and warming.  Very nice, a sweeter take on an IPA, but good.

At first glance, this appears to be an IPA made with slightly darker malts. Dark orange with a rocky white head. Aroma is more complex than the regular IPA. Orange peel, rosemary, pine and cream, plus some spices. Flavor is plenty bitter, and a bit caramely. This is a very rich IPA.

(bottle) A cloudy orange body with a small, creamy beige head.  Big citrus hop aroma (orange and grapefruit) with hints of other fruit (peach), and pine. Medium bodied; creamy - nice.  Hops are of course very strong in the flavor, but there is just a bit of underlying sweetness up front before it completely dries out in the finish. Lingering bitter aftertaste. The flavor profile includes grapefruit (but leaning a bit toward lemon) hops, caramel, pine/woody.
Bottle.  Aroma is strong with hops and a bit of malt.  Notes of pepper, pine, grass, and grapefruit stand out.  Very freshing for the hop level.  Flavor brings out some carmel notes.  Good ipa

a very nice imp ipa.  Pours orange/amber colour with moderate white head which dissipates quickly.  Grapefruit on the nose and in the taste.  Has an almost caramel component to it.  A nicely balanced beer where the hop bitterness actually gives rise to an almost sweet brew.  I would buy this again for sure.

Pours amber-orange with a large pearl head. Decent lacing. I get a lot of grapefuit hops in this. Very citrusy flavor, with a pine finish. Nice DIPA with a smooth finish.  Very drinkable and a re-buy.
Great appearance. Copper colour with a good frothy white head and lace. Lovely grapefruit hop aroma. Sweet but well balanced IPA. Nice beer

Poured from 12oz. bottle (no bottle date) into Sam Adams perfect pint.  Golden, orange/reddish color with good carbonation and good head retention.  Very nice citrus hop aroma.  Very good citrusy hop flavor with a hint of carmel in the backround.  Medium bodied with a little creaminess to it.  Not a bad IPA w/ a high ABV.

Rating #352, bottle from Lagersalget @ Grønjordskollegiet 
 


Cloudy golden-brown beer, really no head. Aroma of floral hops, citrus and a bit berries. Taste is marked by berries, tobacco-like hops, citrus and malts. Rather dry mouthfeel. Finish is bitter hopped and citrusy. Long bitter aftertaste, a bit alcohol. Medium body and carbonation.

12oz bottle in a snifter.  Pours ruby amber with a thick, off-white head.  Aroma very citrusy, with some slight earthy/grass notes.  Starts off with a nice citrus flavor, and finishes with a more full citrus flavor.  Lots of hops in this beer, if you can’t tell.  Very good.
Sample. Amber/orange with off-white head. Flavour is malt, fruit and lots of hops.

pours amber almost red in colour. This is a massively expressive and well hopped brew that meets a good balance with the malts as well. some pine cones and resin with a slight caramel note in there. It delivers on the palate with an explosion of hoppy goodness, green bitter notes and full rich flavours are in balance with the malted notes as well. A fanstastic finish and one that keeps on giving hoppy bitterness well after the last drop! Makes me want to move out to the west coast!

12 oz. bottle to favorite snifter. Pour is amber orange with creamy thick head that dissipates to a film on top. Aroma is rich sweet malt with strong grapefruit and pine. Taste is spice followed by pine and grapefruit, and alittle sweetness. Palate is creamy full and chaulky. This is a very nice bottle to keep on hand in the fridge for any hop head.

Wow, this is a damn good IPA. A sniff of the glass is like taking in a evergreen forest and not fresh cut grass like lesser IPA"s. The apearance matches the aroma. Nice copper color with a pretty generous head and nice lacing on the glass. On the palate those hops just hit like a ton of bricks. Just an explosion of flavor in my mouth. My palate is more in tune with the hops, but I do get the sweetness of the malt on the backside to balance out the finish. I’d rate it higher if the aftertaste lasted longer. I’ll buy this again for sure.

Kind of a copper coloring to it with little to no head on top. Bitter flavor with some malt characteristics to it. Good balance between the malt and hops. Had a lot of very similar beers like this one in the past. Not too bad for a standard IPA.

This is my go to beer!  Wonderful Pine hops upon opening and on the pour.  Clear dark gold with a creamy head and lots of secondary bubbles as the head fades.  Sweet caramel and burnt orange hops dominate the taste with a fairly bitter finish.  Very oily and yet creamy at the same time.  Very drinkable due to its 7.5 ABV.  One of the best values in beer, these guys prove that they are not just about the money.  Two thumbs up!

Although this beer is enjoyable it lacks the all-round greatness that I look for. When I popped the bottle top and took a whiff I set the bar too high... it smells wonderful! It pours a clean golden color without much of a head. Initially I was not a big fan.. a thick malty taste with a tangy mid and after taste was not on par for what I expected. After about a third of the bottle my tastebuds were "tuned" and enjoying the back end bitter. My only complaint at this point was the major malty rush in the initial taste... 

All and all a good beer, worth trying. Lagunitas has never REALLY impressed me beyond their ability to put out solid priced beers, but @ $11 per 6-pack it seems to be creeping higher... maybe its just my local store though.

Give it a try if you like matly beers.... give it a try if you like IPA’s. but dont give it a try if you want to drink it all night... 7.5% isnt much these days but I have a feeling the "thickness" and alcohol content will creep up on most people, myself included.

Bottle.  Golden yellow pour, thick fruity, syrupy hops aroma and a little head.  Flavor is also heavy syrup, burnt orange, plenty of sweet hops and finished a little hot.  Like most other Lagunitas brews, very good (not great), but amazingly solid for the price point.
Wow....excellent hop and malt balance. Starts out bitter, middle is sweet, ends bitter. Excellent clean and dry finish, fuzzy carbonated mouthfeel. Excellent beer.
Drank from a 12 oz. lightly  orange and clear. It is really bitter and hoppy. It’s a pretty good IPA.

12oz in mug.  Brilliant amber with minimal off-white head.  Enormous mango, kumquat, and bergamot aroma.   Tangy and juicy, brash but flawless.  Clean and balanced, intoxicating yet memorable.  America, fuck yeah!
from a 12oz bottle,this beer smells great,white head,gold,caramel, spruce,it just doesn’t taste as great as it smells.But neither the less it’s a decent IPA
Pours a dark golden brown color with a white head. Immeduately the smell of pine trees hits my nostrils and I am in heaven. Taste is bitter and heavily carbonated. Finish is even more bitterness.

12 oz. bottle, pours hazy golden with a white head. Grassy hops, pine and grapefruit on the nose. Much more hoppy than the single IPA, with less of a malt backbone - just the way I like IPAs. Beautiful body, albeit a tad thin - however, the palate is wonderful: pine hops, grapefruits, some citrus, good astringency. Great double IPA.

(bottle) Pours a clear light amber with a large white head that retains well and leaves good lacing.  Aroma is full of tangelo, Tang powder, crushed Daily Cs, and maybe a bit of cracked black pepper as well.  Citrus scents in many forms exhibited here, but they all retain that candy-like quality.  Taste is quite sweet with plenty of citrus, orange, tangelo, and a slight caramel undertone before rounding out into a fair dose of bitter grapefruit pith.  Not as potent as the aroma, and as it warms the alcohol turns up the heat and clashes with the other flavors.  Mouthfeel is medium and carbonation is spot-on.  A decent beer.

Pours a hazy golden with a small but well retained head with some good lace. The aroma is grapefruit, citrus rind, some caramel and lots of nice fresh hops. The flavor is grapefruit and mango primarily, and generally it’s a pretty damned fruity bbeer with some mild caramel like maltiness shining through.

(Old BA rate - bottle)
Nice amber/orange color in line with a lot of other DIPAs that I have sampled. Piney, cedary strong hop character in the aroma, with not even a hint malt. Sets you up for what you will be tasting. Strong hoppy, west coast style taste that really hits the spot. Malty texture to let the hops kick in big, but keep the mouthfeel smooth and coating. Certainly a strong beer on hops, but a very drinkable DIPA. Very great on the drinkability scale given the sometimes overwhelming nature of other beers in this style. Really good DIPA, and one that I will certainly return to.

A- Body is a completely transparent orange/amber that pours with a 1 finger off-white foamy head. Head fades pretty quickly to a thin collar and little lacing is left behind in the glass.

S-Sweet caramel malt is the first thing to come through. The hops are present-but very subtle and cirtusy. The balance is definitely tipped toward the malty side (more of an amber ale caramel malt than a barleywine malt).

T-Upfront is a citrusy hop flavor and a big caramel malt backbone. Some earthy hop flavors and a faint touch of pine come through for the finish. A minimal residual bitterness lingers with along with even fainter hints of caramel malt. The slightest bit of alcohol heat lingers also.

P- Low carbonation and medium weight body that is smooth and somewhat oily. The alcohol can be detected here more than in the taste (which is still present but minimal and unobtrusive).

O-This is a nice DIPA that has a surprisingly mild character (especially with a name like MAXIMUS). This would be a nice intro DIPA...if there is such a thing. I like this one and will have it again.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-11-2008 21:13:40

12oz bottle scored via trade.  Pours a totally transparent, copper, orange amber with a lacing, slightly creamy, slightly off white head.  Unique aroma, oranges, lemons, cantaloupe, biscuit dough.  Flavor is fruity, oranges, lemons, melons, caramel, crackers.  Full bodied, dry finish.  A different take on a double IPA.

The beer pours a nice color, bright, dark amber with good highlights. It’s a good looking beer with a good head. It smells of some good hops, but it’s a little underwhelming as a DIPA. The hops are enjoyably bitter with citrus and pine flavors. There’s some balancing malt, but it’s just not strong enough.
Too Piney for my taste.... Copper colored with a minimal head, mildly malty aroma, not pungently hoppy in the American IPA vein... Medium to medium full bodied, somewhat lively...

12 oz. bottle.  Pours an amber tinted gold with even off-white froth layer.  Sweet hoppy aroma, very resiny and floral, notes of sour diesel, pine.  Flavor is pretty much an explosion of hops in the mouth, much more citrus / grapefruit noticeable, but still retaining the sweet resiny aspect, with the citrus coming out more on the finish.  Full bodied but not syrupy, however somewhat sour profile, very bitter.  If you love hops you will love this beer, and regardless it’s a pretty nice mention.
nice amber pour, decent head nose is pine and grapefruit, get a bit of booze as well. Flavour carries through very hoppy very bitter a touch of malt.

Bottle.  Pours a bright orangish-yellow with a white head.  Nice little islands.  Strong pine scent with some citrus.  Taste is similar - pine, grepefruit, hoppy.  Not too extremely bitter, really meshes well with the semi-sweetness in the background.  Good beer.

This is a great IPA you could definitely have a few of. somegting I would reccomend for a hot day. The body is not as heavy as some others in the dbl category. great citrus hop with rich malt balance. Great beer.
Had this from the bottle, smells quite fruity, and looks orange-red-ish. Wasn’t able to get a good head while pouring and tastes very hoppy, and a little bitter.

.5 inch white head holds in aroma. Amber color, relatively clear... inviting look.   Bitter with relatively clean finish.   Full body.   Not as much taste / aroma as expected given the name and strength.

12oz bottle. Pours a crystal clear, orange colored body with a golden-copper hue. Finger-width, creamy, off-white head that dissipates quickly and leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is caramel malt cookies and lots of hops. Some brown sugar, bread, and a touch of buttery crystal. The hops are piney and orangey with some resin, syrup, and chewy toast. Flavor is similar. Lots of thick, caramel cookies and chewy crystals with a hint of toast. Big on the pines, sweeter oranges, resins, and somewhat sticky florals. Finishes with a good amount of sweet bitterness and a lengthy aftertaste. Medium body with a somewhat lively carbonation. Overall, a decent DIPA. Lots of malts and sweet hops with a higher level of bitterness. I found this less than exciting, but it was enjoyable and filled with balanced flavor.

Props to shakespeare33 for hooking me up with this one.  Lagunitas went in an interesting direction with their DIPA, much more character and personality than their traditional IPA.  Smells of sweet caramel, and syrupy hoppiness, like Dogfish Head but not as intense.  Pours a deep golden amber, so fresh and so clean.  Palate shot is a respectable hoppy bitterness, but with balance.  I typically look for a hop overload with bite but I’m digging the subtle strength of the Maximus.  Less San Diego citrus hop domination, more English/East Coast, malt and caramel sweetness.  I dig this better than 90 Min or Hop Juice, etc...well balanced, tasty and robust without overdoing it.  Bet its great on cask.

sixer from my man eddie down at express liquor in Pacific Beach.. Pours a delicious honey suckle amber orange with a french vanilla head... the smell is not overly hopped out but rather some sweetness touches my nostrils and coaxed another wiff outta me..  is it vanilla I smell on the back end? First sip is good.. it really reminds me of softer version of the elder, I know the degree is less on this one but that same almost ETOH malty sweetness is infused on the back of each sip (I understand some of you russian river folks might think thats blasphemy) but I write what I feel!! ..  You can tell this guy has a powerful engine but he’d rather cruise the block and pick up chicks, and hey, what part of that dont ALL of us enjoy!!  The hops are there early, some floral but its the malts that settle this DIPA in and make it very enjoyable. Wish it had a little more punch and the lower degree of difficulty does play a part in my rating, but still, this DIPA is like eddie murray, can hit from both sides of the plate and in all directions!!... I like the IPA and quite frankly this DIPA is better...
12 oz bottle - pours a hazy orange with a little head that left decent lacing - floral aroma - medium body and bitter taste (though not overly bitter) - lively carbonation - overall a very good DIPA

Pretty orange-copper color with a fizzy-frothy head brought on by swirling. Aroma quite hoppy with notes of citrus, caramel, pine, and grass. Flavor has the same notes as the aroma; very hoppy. Mouthfeel medium-thick; slightly creamy and sticky on the lips. Overall very solid; a little heavy on alcohol and hops but very solid.

Serving: 12 oz. bottle from Fire Works.
It pours a clear amber orange with a small foamy white head.  Big tropical and citrus notes hit you in the nose.  Some tangerine and papaya for sure.  The taste is a mix of pineapple, fruit juice, grapefruit  peel, lots of pale malt sweetness.  A little short in the body department though.  Medium-light mouthfeel with medium carbonation and a long bitter finish.   It’s a real punisher with the hops but an elixer for all the hop heads.

From a 22oz bottle... 

Pours a gorgeous dark orange color, with a huge amount of head. The look is very hazy and cloudy, which in turn makes it look thick and hearty. Looks perfect actually. Leaves a huge swath of lace. 

The scent is a heavy bitter-hop smell. Very very bitter indeed. But there is also a sweet, flowery secondary aroma that comes off. It’s nicely balanced by a dry malt, and the pale malt aroma comes in nicely. 

Majorly, massively bitter hop flavor. It’s halfway between a regular IPA and an Imperial IPA. Quite bitter, with a sweeter, estery aftertaste. Tastes more Imperial as it warms. 

It feels thick and even a bit bubbly. Leaves a bitter film at the very end. Boy does that bitterness keep a’comin’. A strong Imperial IPA, yet quite drinkable; a feat in itself.
A superb IPA. well rounded in every way, bitter, malt alcohol balance. Perfect for the summer.

Bottled@The 1st Vaasa CS/ES beer session (thanks JS). Deep orange colour with small slightly off-white head. Aroma is bigtime pine, fruits, some slight grassyness as well. Flavour is quite much the same. Big time hoppyness, but still in a quite good balance.
Pours amber with a white head. Aroma is caramel, citrus and grapefruit. Flavour follows the nose.

12oz bottle. For some reason I wasn’t all that impressed with the regular Lagunitas IPA but this version is not bad at all. Pours a hazy golden color with a white head and decent lacing. Alcohol is "only" 7.5 so it’s on the low side for an imperial which results in a very drinkable IPA. In addition to the citrus and pine there is a nice sweetness to this one.
Golden orange. Nice citrus and pine scents, with a hoppy, bit bitter flavor. I was a little worried looking at it bc it looked a bit soapy, but it was actually a good feel, and tasty!

Buddy brought this over while we were brewing. Poured a Golden color. Slightly dark for a traditional IPA, but not terrible. Smells malty for an IPA. Well balanced. Hop character wasn’t overpowering, but a great malt back ground. I could drink more of these.

Beautiful pine aroma when opening bottle.  Balanced by a background malt. Thin head, perfect amber in color.  Bursts with flavor - none too bitter.
Nicely carbonated.  Very easy on the toungue for this style of beer.  Smoothly bitter - if that means anything.  A tasty treat that doesn’t rely on high ABV and bitterness as a selling point.

Pours a medium golden color with medium bubbles and a small white head.  This beer has a nice aroma of citrus, hops and fresh cut grass.  The flavor of this beer is nicely hopped, but there is a surprising malty sweetness as well that adds some nice balance to the overall flavor.  The aftertaste, however, is all hops.  This beer is fairly easy to drink and feels smooth in the mouth.  This is a very solid IPA.  It is a nice medium ground between a lightly flavored traditional IPA and an overly hopped California or double IPA.

Bottle 12oz. - Poured amber color with medium white head.
Aroma - piney and citrus hops with nice sweet malt mixed in!
Flavor - ultra smooth yet crisp piney hop taste with a nice balance of malt.
Palate - medium bodied with slick smooth texture. Finish is bitter and has little afteraste.
Overall - nice IPA. Really does’nt seem like a IIPA to me but still a great tasteing beer!!

Pours deep orange with white head, aroma is full of citrusy hops.  Taste up front is grapefruit, orange, and zesty hops with a tiny caramel malt middle with a bitter finish.  Very nice, more like a flavorful single IPA but good!

Purchased at Winslow’s Tavern, Greenville, NC

One of the better beers I’ve had.  Terrific.

Apparently all of those that rated this beer so highly have little experience with IPAs or DIPAs. IPAs are designed to be a vehicle for IBUs and this beer has just too much malt giving it a sickly sweetness that just doesn’t fit the style and doesn’t work as an enjoyable beer. On a positive note I would rather drink this than battery acid...I think.

I saw some 12oz bottles of Maximus for the first time and thought what the hell. The color was a clear orange with a decent white head. The smell had a caramel aspect to it but no hops that I could detect. The taste was very balanced, almost too balanced for an IPA. I don;t think this beer was hoppy at all. The alcohol was very well hidden. At $9 a sixer I would never purchase this again. I keep buying Lagunitas beers and being disappointed. I think the only one I like is Gnarleywine. Thumbs down on Maximus.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-20-2007 15:56:1
Pours clear copper with a small white head. Citrus and noticeable bready sweetness. Easy drinking IPA.

12oz bottle 

Appearance: Golden with a small white head, no lacing 

Aroma: Sweet malts, bready, pine 

Taste: Malts, pine in the finish 

OK IPA, but not that great. The finish is sticky sweet.

12-0z bottle. Poured a beautiful golden amber with a touch of cloudiness. Thick off-white head. Not billowing but persistent. Left plenty of lacing on the glass. Bold aroma carried pine and citrus. Rich malty flavor with notes of honey. Hops came on strong but the lingering maltiness balanced it well. LONG finish. The flavor lasted and lasted. Rich and sticky on the palate, too. This is an excellent and substantial brew that satisfies those that crave hoppy goodness yet want something creamy and substantial. Drinkable as far as a double goes! An excellent brew.

Not as hoppy as Stone’s Ruination or Avery Maharajah... I’d recommend this first to anybody moving into DIPA territory. I’d say it’s in-between a normal IPA and a double.
 Orange to amber in glass. Decent amount of  sticky head. 
 Taste is comparable more to pine sap than pine needles (for a change).  Mid-level carbonation.
 Sour aftertaste and long finish.
Bottle. Orange colour with nice lasting white head. Aroma and flvour of hops, fruit (citrus) and honey.

Chose a large snifter to enjoy this bottle of Lagunitas brew at Brixie’s in Brookfield, IL. Displayed a clear, golden amber tone, with thick, off white foam to the head, and clingy sheeting as lacing. The aroma was heavy, perfumy citrus, with some secondary pine, and caramelly malt and fruit sweetness. The flavor added a rich malt presence, substantial and supportive hop bitterness, malty sweetness, and light alcohol. I have always been a fan of the standard IPA, and the big brother is no exception.

Bottle->tulip: Pours a rocky, white, diminishing head that exhibits good lacing atop a carbonated, clear, amber body.  Aroma grains and hops, perhaps with some honey notes in there.  Medium bodied, long on the palate, mildly bitter, finishing astringently.

Golden copper color.  Dense meringue head that fades but laces exceptionally well.  Floral hop nose with grapefruit and other citrus.  Taste is citrus, floral, and moderately piney hops.  There’s a good amount of malt to hold up all of the hop flavors.  Nice oily mouthfeel.  It’s been a long time since I’ve had this and am really enjoying the reunion.

Pours a orange-amber haze with a thin head.  Has an aroma of hops, caramel and malt.  Very smooth and creamy.  Sweet and malty up front, bitter on the back end.  A decent body for the alcohol level.  Reminds me of the DFH 120 in terms of color and body.  But not in terms of sweetness and obviously abv.  Leaves a decent amount of lacing.  At 72.41 IBU’s, there are more bitter IPAs out there.  The bitterness does not dominate, nor does the malt-sweetness.  A good balance, good flavor.

Nice hoppy beer from lagunitas. I have to say that I’m liking the draft beers from Lag way better than their bottled offerings. This one I had bottled and it was just ok. Decently floral IPA that’s not as clean as it could be. Not too crisp, and there’s a skunk to it that I was not too big a fan of. I would buy it again though.
From a bottle poured brown with a fair amount of head.  Nice piney hoppy flavor with a lasting aftertaste.

12 oz bottle pours reddish amber with some white head into a tulip.  Aroma of an extra load of the typical Lagunitas hop-bomb grapefruit, caramel malts, floral/honey sweetness, bit of pine.  Taste is essentially the same as the nose: caramel malts and pine/grapefruit, bit of breadiness, finishing with some floral sweetness and an ever so slight touch of alcohol.  Medium to full bodied with light to medium carbonation and a soft, puffy mouthfeel.  Good stuff.
Hoppy, but not overpowering. Sweet finish. Smells delicious and the beer has a deep, but bright, red/orange hue. I drank from a bottle, but I bet it would be better on tap.

Bomber from Hall’s in Colleyville.  Clear orange/amber pour with 1 inch of off-white head that leaves some lacing.  Citrus, hay, grass aromas combined with a faint honeysuckle sweetness.  Good, short-lasting, citrus/resin bitter with an appropriate level of opposing sweetness.  No alcohol presence noted.  Like most other Lagunitas beers I’ve had, balance seems to be en vogue.  Not a hop-bomb, but a really easy to drink DIPA(?).

Golden honey in color with a minimal white head. Smells of sweet lemony orange citrus with a slight honey (maybe even molasses) undertone. Starts mildly sweet with a hop finish, but the sweetness balances the hops so the finish is not bitter. Slight alcohol finish on the nose.

Pours golden orange with a billowy head and heavy lacing.  Aroma is fruity and strong, big citric notes with an underlying syrup sweetness.   Flavor is similar in progression, though the middle possesses a bitter, somewhat chalky moment.  More balanced than the lesser pales of this brewery.
Pours a nice golden / orange color with wonderful white head and then followed with nice lacing.  Good overall aroma and strong taste of sweet hops.  This one is strong. Great brew.

Lagunitas Brewing Company--Maximus IPA Maximus Ale--Limited Release 2008--12 oz.	Bottle--8.40% ABV--72.41 IBU’s.  (4.5 / 5.0)	IPA--Imperial.  Mild lace head.  Clear thin bright amber color.  Huge floral hop front.  Earthy piney notes.  Hot dry sweet earthy hop infused crisp caramel body.  Big earthy spicy pine citrus hot hop spice end.Huge Hops!  IBU’s?  A touch unbalanced.  Sampled 4/11/2008. 6-Pack--$9.99.

Maximus IPA Maximus Ale--Unlimited Release  2009--12 oz. Bottle 72.41 IBU’s
Dense lacy rocky big white head.Clear thin bright amber red color.Malty floral hop front.Creamy cloying sweet rich caramel fruit dough body.Lingering sweet malt hop spice mild hot end.Rich Unusualy Sweet Malty Lagunitas IPA.Tasty, but sweet, not dry.

Clear amber pour with a half finger white head. Aroma is citrus, caramel, earth, and grass with some light resinous qualities. Flavor is juicy orange, grapefruit and lemon with malt notes of caramel- borderline toffee. On the sweet side, but still maintains an excellent balance. Palate is medium to full bodied with medium effervescence and a sticky smacking finish. Well put together and highly quaffable.
Clear amber pour white head hoppy piney citrus sweet aroma .... sweet malty start little lacing sweet hop little spice at the end a quality brew through and through from laguitas

An old love returns. I hadn’t had one of these for a couple of years when my pal Chip bought me one after work on Friday, which, in turn, compelled me to stop for a six-pack on my way home. Pours an orange-yellow beer under a half inch head of white foam. Nose is citrus hops over a sweet malt. And the taste follows directly behind. The hops in this are just right with a balance of citrus and piney resin all borne on a solid, broad, just-barely sweet malt. Finish is just dry enough that the malt sweetness doesn’t linger past its welcome. And the finish hints at some sort of spice.  Mighty fine beer.

Orange color, with some bubbles and a frothy white head. Citrus, flowers, and hops all over the place in the aroma. Tastes almost more like a normal IPA than a double, but it seems almost more full bodied. A bunch of hops and tons of citrus. Really nice body and a really good balance of all the flavors. Easy to drink in virtually any situation, but with the comparatively high alcohol content, that can turn a little crazy.

A: Nice golden hue with hints of red showing thru. It pours with a big rocky white head that dies down to a half finger. There is nice sheet lace noted.

S: It has a big pine aroma. There are some undertones of malt and grapefruit, but pine is front and center here.

T: Bold hop character which comes at you mostly pine. Some C hops are used as there is some grapefruit as well. There is a nice malt backbone to balance things out a bit and make this one extra enjoyable.

M: Medium in body, smooth with good carbonation.

On break from study for exams, Dead Ship of Fools on the radio loud and a smoke. Clear darker orange with medium white head. Aroma of sweet pineapple, citrus and other fruits with less noticeable sweet caramel. Flavor is sweet hoppy with that sticky sugary feel that turns very bitter/dry by contrast. Still easy but interesting. Beer leaves very dry sticky feel on tongue. Satisfying! but circumstances were good.

A nice change from the current streak of winter beers. Pours a clear orange with a nice beige head, with plenty of lacing as it goes down. Very strong citrus aroma with floral undertones. Flavor is "grapefruity", spicy--strongly ginger, nice and not overly complicated. Finishes sweet at first, a nice change from most DIPAs, but hits with a good bit of bitterness just as it goes down. Good and strong (but didn’t remove my enamel, thankfully).
Copper, amber colored brew. Nice hopped aroma. Flavor is also very hoppy. Some Citrus and pine, very drinkable. Not that intense as I expected. Still very enjoyable.
Rodman’s in DC. Smells like all Lagunitas beers: like wet dog. Nice head and a dark gold body. Taste is citrus/cereal with a hoppy finish.

Bottle.  Pours a hazy copper with a decent, pillowy, clingy, white head that lasts.  Taste is of malt, caramel, citrus, hops and some pine.  A little dry and bitter.  Similar aroma.  Creamy body.  Well balanced.  Rather smooth and easy to drink.  An enjoyable beer that is worth picking up again.

Enjoyed from a 12oz bottle in a pub glass.  The beer pours a burnished deep golden color, with a small-but-thick white head.  The nose gives some citrusy hop notes, as well as some more danky Simcoe-like aromas.  There is also some strong malt notes, perhaps high crystal, which counter the hops.  The palate is floral up front, again showing some citus notes, malt-driven in the middle, and then assertively bitter in the swallow and finish.
