A slight fruit character is noticeable from the yeast, but it is fairly restrained, and only seems to compliment the rest of the beer’s flavors.  Overall, nicely done.

Luxurious clear amber color with generous white head. Beautiful.

Nose is mixed citrus and pine, with a clean/sterile component that is nice.

Palate is assertively piney and dry, with citrusy hops and mild toasty malt in the background.  Alcohol is apparent.

Finish is quite long.

For the style this is a very, very good beer but a little too much pine & alcohol warmth for my preference, as it interferes some with the drinkability for me.
Nice copper, reddish color.  The aroma and flavor are over the regular IPA, it is noticeably more bitter, with more citrus and piney notes.

Pours light copper with white head and good lacing.  Aroma is of hops and caramel.  Excellent hop and sweet citrus flavor nicely balanced with malt.  Not as bitter as the commercial description may lead you to believe, but definitely a very good beer.
Hazy amber in color with a slight head that quickly disapears.  Aroma of citrus, caramel and hops.  Flavor is pine needles with a touch of citrus and finishes long with the hops

(Bottle, Monk’s Café, Wallingatan, Stockholm) Amber colour with frothy, beige head. Fruity, malty nose with citrus, apricots, a hint of pine needles and caramel malt to match the fruity hops. Fruity, hoppy taste with notes of orange, dried apricots, some grapefruit and pine needles. Solid caramel malt to balance the generous hop character. Nice, tasty and very well balanced.
Pretty good, and a little unexpected. I expected a lot of hop character but the intense citrus taste was a little bit of a surprise. It was really hoppy and was actally pretty refreshing.
Bottle, 12 fl. oz. Pours a golden beer with an orange/offwhite head.The aroma is hops with citrus. The flavor is likewise hops with citrus. The palate is bitter. Overall a simple but good beer.
When you have finished a grapefruit that is covered in honey and you squeeze it into your mouth, this is what you taste with the Maximus IPA.  Love the big piney hop notes and creamy malt texture.
22 oz bottle.  Pours amber in colour, with decent head.  Aroma and flavour are intensely hoppy, primarily floral/herbal in nature.  One kick ass IIPA.

12oz bottles from a sixer from Whole Foods. Another kick ass IIPA from Lagunitas. Strong grapefruit and pine nose. big malt heavy bottom that is almost chewable it’s so dense. but it has to be, to hold it’s own against the huge PNW hop bite. Quite easy to drink over and over again.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a clear golden copper with a finger or two of dissipating head that laces nicely as it goes.  Aroma of hops, spice and citrus, with a hint of floral.  Initial taste is interestingly smooth, with the bitterness coming on the finish.  Up front it’s caramel sweetness, breadiness, citrus, and then bitter hop finish.  Nice IPA... very nice.  Lagunitas doesn’t do a wide range of stuff... but it does what it does do well... Go ahead and diagram that last sentence...
Bottle. 25.4 oz. Pours cloudy amber, with a thick, off-white head. Aroma of hops, spice, malt, and citrus. Full body with a crisp finish. Excellent IPA.

12 oz bottle.  Pours orange amber with an off-white head.  Sweet and hoppy citrus and caramel aroma.  Flavor has citrusy hops, sweet caramel, and slight grassy hops, with biscuit coming up toward the finish, then moving into a mild bitterness.  Slight alcohol tingle.  A very well-balanced combination of flavors; I’m very happy with this one.  Not really an IIPA though, just seems like an IPA to me.
Pours a copper color with a white head.  Aroma is malty, crystal malts, with lots of citrus hops.  Flavor is malty, caramel, citrus, and a nice juicy citrus hop finish.
Bottle. Pours a clear amber body with small white lacing. Aroma is floral, citrus and pine hop. Taste is nice hop complexity. Flavorful and nice drinkability.

Poured a clear, dark orange/copper with a tall creamy light tan head. There were some carbonation bubbles rising up in the glass. There was a strong grapefruit aroma and later a little bit of a pine scent as well. The beer retained the head for a good while and it left nice lacing. There was an excellent grapefruit flavor and a good hops bite right from the first sip. A nice background sweetness balanced the hops. The finish was a nice bitter hops with some citrus flavor lingering on. This was very refreshing to drink. Good bit of hops, but not overpowering. Excellent!
22oz - Orange liquid under off white head, certainly looks the part.  Orange peel nose.  Swwet malt immediately offset by hops.  Nice interplay, different in a way from most DIPAs.  Good not great

It poured a clear golden liquid with a medium sized white foam that left very little lacing. It had a medium heavy smell of hops, fruits, caramell and bread. It tasted mostly of fruity and flowery hops and just a bit of grassy hops. Also sweet of butter scotch and caramell. It was smooth with a medium-full thickness and tickled the top of my mouth. Also had an odd kind of funky taste, not sure what that was. Edit: Re-rated after a tasting from Systembolaget. Increased score by 0,2

Pours a nice golden color with not much head.  Aroma is of hops, some honey and grass.  Taste is pretty smooth for the hoppyness with good complexity.  Has big hop flavor, but without being overly abrasive.  I was a little surprised at how good it is.

Thanks, Florian’s in Truckee, California!  Shiny copper with a nice off-white head.

Aroma is sharp, sweet grapefruit.  Big-time caramel malt going on here, which keeps this from being the typical hop-bomb.  Nicely balanced, just a bit sweet.

Pretty strong carbonation in this one, somewhat masks the 7.5% ABV.
Bottle from the Gingerman in Fort Worth.  Sweet smell, lots of hops, really nice.
US trip Aug/Sept 2009 - Nice zesty grapefruit, slightly flabby with malt weight but hop bitterness cleans the whole thing up nicely.
22 oz. Bottle. Pours a cloudy amber color. Light white head. Pleaseant aroma of hops and malt.  Taste is well balanced between hops and malt. Good beer. Recommended.

Poured from a bottle, like a hops lollipop.  Beautimous appearance, pushing a sweet, sugary smell into my nasal passages...like a &#40sugar&#41 frosted pinecone.  Taste belies the sweet smell, giving the lucky imbiber a hit of hoppy glory.  It hurts so good.  This is a fantastic beer from a solid brewery.

Slightly hazy golden with a thick long lasting white creamy head. Light nose of hops on the fruity side &#40apricot, nectarine&#41, delicate but appealing. Full bodied with a terrific mid-palate saturated by a massive dose of hops that leads to an evrlasting finale of sundried apricots. Un délice...
Tasted side by side with 3 floyds Alpha King, it outclassed it by miles in every aspect.
Blond-Amber with thin, white head.  Citrus, orange, grapefruit, and mild grassy aroma.  Grapefruit, caramel, and mild grass flavours.  Balanced with medium dry-hop finish.

12 oz botte from BarleyWine. Clear, deep reddish colour, nice head with good retention. Smell is choco-orange, tangerine, with a solid malty backbone. The malt gives off sweet notes after the hoppy aroma. Taste is hoppy and malty, well balanced with a subte bitter finish. Very yummy, would love to try again.

12 oz bottle.  Crystal clear topaz with a bone head; lots of lacy sheets.  Nose is orange peel, tangerine and mango with hints of banana.  Creamy, tangy and spicy with some nice hop resins.  Taste is orange juice concentrate, maple, caramel and pine.  A sweet treat with a subtle bitter finish.
12 oz bottle poured into a tulip glass. light citrus/ apricot flavor. an overall average tasting IPA.

12 oz bottle served in a tulip glass.  Pour was deep bronze with one finger of white head.  Nose is hops, malt, and caramel.  Taste is light citrus, hops, caramel, big malt and notes of apricot.  I enjoyed this much more than their regular IPA.  I thought that would be rather pleasant with more sweetness, and that’s just what this delivered.  A very enjoyable brew.

Poured from the 12oz bottle into a plastic cup: It’s like almost a DIPA, but not quite there(?). Sweet malts, caramel, brown sugar, grapefruit, faint pine notes... Drinkability: a bit too sweet to binge on. Rebuy: prolly. #098 on 22082009, DG.

22 oz bottle. Golden/amber with a fast dissipating off white head. Aroma is citrus, floral and caramel. The flavor is bitter and supported by a big malt base to balance out the beer nicely. The mouth feel is slightly syrupy and thick with good carbonation to balance it out and a long smooth bitter finish. The hops are subdued a bit but that could be due to age. Another great beer from Lagunitas.

Lagunitas Maximus is a hazy deep golden ale with a lot of particles floating in it.  It has a huge, dense, creamy, lumpy off-white head that shows outstanding retention and lacing.  It has a resinous, citrus aroma that’s fruity and spicy.  It’s medium bodied, creamy and smooth with a clean finish.  There’s something lightly syrupy about it all the way through.  It’s pretty well balanced and quite sweet.  There’s a resiny and citrusy bitterness that keeps it in balance, but it’s still just a touch too sweet.  I’m pretty certain I got an old bottle.

Appearance:  Pours a clear amber with a fluffy beige head.

Aroma:  Light grapefruit and pine.

Taste:  Candied grapefruit, turbinado sugar syrup, finishing with earthy bitter hops.

Mouthfeel:  Thick.

Overall:  A bit too malt forward for my liking. May not have been a fresh bottle, or perhaps this is something border-lining a Double IPA.

I was hammered at my brother’s bachelor party the first time I tried this, so now I’m trying it again while coherent... the hop aroma is slightly subdued for the style and mixed with malts and hints of candied prunes, raisins, molasses, etc. (an interesting mix). The flavor isn’t quite as bold as I usually like from this style, but all in all it’s pretty tasty.
12oz bottle. Pours amber-orange with a lingering head and good lacing. Very nice aroma of citrus and pine hops. Pleasant hop flavor, as well. An enjoyable IPA.
Drank this after the stoudts and it in my opinion is better...pours orangeish with light creamy head. smells of fruits and hops. Taste is a good blend of sweet/bitter.
Pours amber orange with a small off white head. Very fresh aroma of honey and grapefruit. Taste is caramel, grass grapefruit. It’s a little watery with a dry bitter finish.

Bouteille de 650 ml acheté le 9 juillet 2009, à Charles Street Liquors à Boston. Cuivre claire, petit collet. Arome d’houblon sucré licoreux, petits fruits muries. Goût de céréal mi-sucré, houblon un peu amère et assez alcoolisé, finition sucré amère. Une très bonne IPA, mais je n’irais pas le nommé une double!

(Bottled) Almost clear copper-amber with a small head. Aroma of piney hops and strawberry fruitiness. Flavor is quite fruity with moderate bitterness, lots of exotic-fruity aroma hops, and slightly sweet malty backbone. Medium body, very soft carbonation. A clean and well-made IPA, but maybe not so clearly on the Double IPA side.

Pours an off-white lacing head with an amber-golden body.  Smells of mellow floral, citrus, and resin hops.  Flavor is the same as the aroma.  Finish is bitter and sticky.  Mellow and sweet, not sure if the bottle has some age.
Bottled, piny spicy aroma, some citrus, maybe orange, nice malty feel, terrific IPA.

Similar alc. content to sumpin sumpin which I just tried, but this one is called an IIPA.  This one is clear and orange.  Pine nose.  Very nice malty mouthfeel.  This one favors the malt a bit more than some, but is nicely balanced.   Nice beer.

Clear copper body with a small white head that leaves some stringy lace. Grapefruit nose with hop flowers and slightly caramelized sugar. Clean sweetness upfront, with grapefruit flavors and cereal malt on the finish. Well balanced for the most part. Full body with soft carbonation and the slightest hint of alcohol.

Bottle from Perry’s in Hayward.  Yes, there’s also one in Hayward.  Nose is sour hops, slightly underripe orange, grass.  Flavor is the same.  Must say, malt is very jagged in this one - very gritty and imbalanced.

Poured out a brew that is more orange than brown and pretty clear with some light floating sediment and a light, off white cap and minor lacing. Decent wafts of ample grapefruit that mix well with the malts. Very appealing. Melon as well. Good spice in the background. Tasty stuff overall. A bit too much of noticable alcohol, some yeast, some pepper, very nice malts and barely average hops. Fairly smooth mouth feel, light medium bodied, spicy finish that overtakes the bitterness. Malts in the middle. Decent burn. Ok but forgettable.

Bottle. Pours a clear copper with a one to two finger creamy, tan, rocky head that leaves very good lacing. Aroma is herbal (fresh, wet) hops, white pepper, strawberry cheesecake, Grand Marnier. Taste is same as above plus some spicy alcohol. Has a syrupy, medicinal quality like Grand Marnier or orange liquor. Cardboardy, dry, Brazil nut finish. I gave it sub par scores because this is much closer to a well-hopped barleywine like SN Bigfoot instead of an IIPA.

Bottle.
Quite possibly one of the best Imperial IPA’s I’ve ever had. Wonderfull aroma and flavor of hops. Lots of malt and more hops. I keep stirring the glass to get the aroma, instead of drinking it.

This beer pours a copper color with a thick one finger gold head.  A delicious nose of sweet fruit, floral notes, and caramel.  Flavor offers a quite complex hop profile.  Some nice spice notes, as well.  Caramel is very much in the background.  This beer bumps up against the  Barleywine category.

This is the best IPA I have yet to have!  The aroma is just sweet, tantalizing, goodness that embodies all the an IPA should offer,  The hop presence is strong, but not too strong, and it hits the pallate like a gentle rolling cascade of goodness.  I could swim in this beer.

Clear amber pour, medium white head that leaves abundant lace.  Floral, slightly citric hops very present in the nose, also some sweet, honeyed malt elements.  Aroma does rapidly attenuate after a couple sniffs.  Flavor hops grapefruit-hops aromatic and bitterness very well balanced with lightly caramelized malts. Very smooth, pleasant drinking. Understated for the style but I like it. Only flaw is that it the bitters turn a bit metallic on the linger.

05-JUN-2009.
Bottle @home.
It runs out of the bottle on opening.
Nice orangy look with off-white head. Hops are very present on the nose, especially when it is still very cold. When it warms up the malt becomes more noticable, and it also changes somewhat from an IPA to something more barley wine like. Actually it reminds me a lot of the Olde Gnarley Wine, just not quite as sweet and strong.
Very delicious beer. Maybe a bit to sweet for an IPA, but I like that.
Not overly bitter, just very creamy and pleasant.

12 ounce bottle from local liquor shop.  This was marked down to $1.39 and still says "Limited Release" -- it might be old??  Pours a golden orange with thin white head.  Hoppy aroma includes pineapple and a fair amount of booze.  Flavor has some citrusy/pineapple-type hops.  It’s bitter, but the booze taste dominates.  Yeah, this does not taste as fresh as I would expect.  It’s probably just old -- will try to re-rate with a fresh bottle.

12 oz bottle via Hagen. Pours a near clear copper with a massive beige head that lingers. Nose is strong citrus hops..grapefruit, pine and orange. Taste starts and ends sweet actually, with lingering resiny pineapple/pine syrup  in the aftertaste. In between there is lots of orange, tangerine and grapefruit. Body is full. Carbonation is light/medium. I would prefer less malt and more hops, as this is  more barleywine tasting than IIPA tasting...

650ml bottle. As one of the first double IPA’s I’ve tried, it was good, but the malt covered up much of the hoppiness. While the bottle stated 70+ IBU it felt more like it was in the 50’s because of the large amount of malt in the beer. I feel like a double IPA is supposed to be unbalanced, and when you try to balance out the extreme hoppiness with extreme maltiness you lose the appeal.

A very good beer and a good value as well for a 1.5 IPA.  Very full of floral hops on the nose, the pour was clear amber.  I was very impressed over the amount of hops that came through the nice amount of malt in the body.  A very nicely hopped beer in the citrus realm.  I would not put this in the same league as Dreadnaught or 90 Min. or some of the other legends, but this beer was nice, very easy in consumption.
Clear orange.  Hoppy aroma but well balanced.  Lots of sweet hops with another style added for depth.  Ooo lots of edge of the tongue bitterness that fades into a solid finish.  Lovely

clear  amber 
sizeable lasting cotton candy head
floral nose with pineapple
long clean hop finish
good bitter sweet flavor
body not too heavy to drink in summertime

Tasting at DØE, Aarhus Syd, DK.
Bottled, 170609.
Orange with white head. Aroma of malt and alcohol. Flavor is more malt and alcohol, hop spices and caramel
Bottle. orange clear pour with a medium head. clean but surprisingly mild hop aroma for a self proclaimed imperial IPA. Still, pretty solid.

Bottle. A nice clear light copper color pour with a big foamy off white head, some soft carbonation,loads of sticky lace left on the glass. Aroma of sweet tangerine with soft piny notes. Flavor is nice , full body, malty sweet ,with some nice orange,and citrus flavors , slightly floral and spicy pretty strait forward. A slightly oily texture but not in a bad way, a long slightly bitter hop aftertaste, very drinkable.

BOTTLE: I love this beer - pours orange with a white head, tons of floral hop, malt, and caramel on the nose, more of the same on taste. Creamy mouthfeel, almost of a syrupy, wine-like taste. Very bold flavor, excellent!

"I must say at the start of this review I am not a fan of this brewery don’t know why I’m just not. Beer pours a hazy dark brown with only a small covering of bubbles coating the surface that disappeared to a small bubble ring around the edge of the glass, lots of columns of carbonation are making their way to the top of my glass though, this brew looks pretty standard. Aroma is pretty simple grapefruit hops, with a touch of malt, its crisp, clean and smells somehow cold, it’s not too bad. Taste is more than acceptable grape fruit hops, very sweet with a floral aspect, and is good and malty I’m very surprised in fact this seems to be high quality for Lagunitas. Strange every third sip or so I swear I’m tasting some melon, why? This IIPA seems pretty slandered nothing really stands out about it, but it of high quality and had desant enjoyment. Done while playing cards with beercronic and his wife."
I don’t get the high rating. It tastes like their boring IPA tripled up. Bitter upon bitter upon bitter. No complexity. Not horrible. Not memorable. Improves as it warms and fruitiness is released.

Pours a nice amber orange with very thick off-white head.  Aroma strong of floral hops, almost overdone, pine, strong malt, and spice.  Flavor matches, but the floral hops just dominates it and I am not a fan of that.  Definitely take a Hop Stoopid over this one.

(bottle from Springs Liquor Outlet in Colorado Springs). Pours a clear copper color. Small off white head which diminishes quickly. Spare lacing. Heavy hop, flower like aroma with light citrus. Oily texture. Moderate carbonation. Avg duration. Light bitterness.
12 oz bottle... amber pour... pinelands aroma (nj folks will know).... malt start with a mellow hops finish... excellent...
Solid, but I def prefer the Hop Stoopid.  This had a little bit of a subdued hop punch for a DIPA.  The name "Maximus" might be overdoing it a bit.  Overall, nice brew.
Bottle. Pours a clear copper color with a tan head. Aroma of pine and malt. Has a creamy mouth-feel. Starts a nice sweet taste, then the hops hit. Has a nice bitter pine finish

mild sweetness is balanced out hoppiness - smells like orange and tastes like resin - very little sour - alcohol doesn’t really come through - aftertaste is pretty much a slow fading of standard taste. Friends, I want to tell you - I like this junk.

12 oz. bottle served in tulip- poured transparent faded orange, lively carbonation of small bubbles, clump of pea size white bubbles atop the liquid surface for a head.  Aroma of pine, resin, and malt.  Hits the mouth with nice medium body, malt is there but seems to be washed away a little too quickly by the hopwave of this brew, holds up fine in the middle, finish has a pleasant acidic hop burn.  Good stuff.

Pours a sexeh golden-orange color with tons of carbonation dancing around inside the glass.

Smells of Pine trees, hops, orange peels, and utter satisfaction.

Taste is great, very hop forward, but not over-the-top. The body is just perfect to get the hops on your taste buds and then washes them away.
Pours a clear copper color with no head. Aroma is citrus hops and a nice earthiness. Taste is caramel and earthy hops rather than citrus. Full-bodied and smooth. Very drinkable and enjoyable.

12 oz bottle purchased at Corral Liquors, Granite City, Il.
 Pours golden amber with a medium beige head.
 Rich, strong hop flavor with a slight alcohol burn.
 Pretty good, but for a ’Maximus’ I thought there would be more character.

Most of the time I have this it is just a little over the top. Not sure if a clean palate would help or hurt it. A lot of hops, pine and citrus and a big malt presence with all the alcohol. Maybe it is just resinous for me and too sticky. Pretty good overall.
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are rich hops, flowers and citrus. Some caramel and malt as well. Very good balance.

Pours hazy golden amber with a thin cream colored head.  Aroma is of nice citrusy slightly piny hops.  Flavor is big bittersweet citrusy hops with a big lasting finish and a little bit of malt to balance it out.  Very good.

approx 0.65 litres bottle, according to my google translation of ancient measuring system used on bottle ;-).
lovely deep orange with a smooth thick yellow/light orange head.
pleasantly mild hoppy aroma, somewhere between pine/grape and yellow fruits. some malts and some salt can also be detected.
flavor is very malty, very hoppy, quite dry (comes almost as an acid note), salt licorice. both malt and hops are powerfull. the balance is okay. quite sweet brew. i like it a lot. good DIPA, one of the sweeter ones. i’ve tasted.

Bottle.  Pours amber with a nice off-white one-finger head and decent retention.  Aroma is really piney with sweet caramel malt also noticeable.  Flavor is very sweet malt up front and citrusy hop bitterness.  Think I had an old bottle because hops had faded a little bit.  Nice medium palate with hop oils and a dry finish.  Above average for the style.

bottle.
Pours a bright, clear light copper color, half inch of tight off white head that sticks around and leaves plenty of lace.  Aroma of light, crisp grapefruit and sweet oranges.  Flavor starts with sharp grainy bitterness, sharp lemons and grapefruit, some pine needles.  Not much malt or sweetness to speak of- some thin grainy sweetness in the background that stays there. Palate is even and full, lightly crisp and dry finish.  Solid DIPA, though would be helped by some more depth to the hop character.

Awesome beer. Hoppy but sweet, much better tha the Pils from lagunitas, just a really good IPA. Alchol flavor is very present for a 7.5 abv beer. smooth and very tasty nonetheless. Highly recommended.

Gold/orange pour with light white head and lace. Aroma of light citrus and evergreen. Flavor is more citrus with a semi sweet malt kicker. Abv hidden really well at 7.5. Nice lingering medium/hard bitter. Well balance. Just not a lot of hops in the nose for me but a very good beer.
Poured golden yellow, floral, malty, citrus, little piney hops, little fuity, little honey.
was expecting better from lagunitas.  name says mazimus but not very extreme. pours nice pale color nice white head smells kinda weak and taste is good but not "maximus"
A strong Ipa flavor, with sweet bubblegum coriander and a non-hop tasting causticness in addition to the great I2PA flavor.

Bottled. My bottle had leaked due to cork opening a little bit by rough contact with other bottles in the parcel on way to Finland. I tasted it straight away as I opened the parcel and realized what had happened. It was fine except that the bottle had lost all the carbonation making it kind of flat. Also, no foam formed while pooring. So it was a little bit real ale -like. Anyhow, pours copper-brownish. Aroma of exotic fruit, mango and pineapple, and slightly bitter hoppiness. Hoppy flavor is deliciously fruity and malty sweet. Hoppiness was kind of lame to me, maybe due to leaking.

Pleasant aroma of hops and pine.  Strong body witch may over bearing in its citrusy overtones coupled with a fine hoppy sensation.  Carbonation was not to be expected.  Overall, I might think about possibly drinking this beer in future, hopefully on tap instead.
Another great IPA option from this brewery. Amber color. More pine flavors. Clean and crisp.

Bottled (CK). 
Clear amber-copper color, small white head.  Strong aroma of pineapple and hops. Quite sweet and malty flavor with lots of pineapple and resiny notes. Some citrus in the finish too. Not really powerful for IIPA. And seems that I am not a fan of pineapple and hop combination -to me this looks a bit overrated here.

Bomber. Pours a nice coppery-orange color with a one-finger white head. Strong aroma of citrus, including grapefruit and pineapple. Flavor is smooth and sweet at first, with a good amount of malt to balance the large quantity of hops. Finish is slightly sticky and resinous, followed by delicious bitterness. Great IPA at a good price - would definitely buy again.

Bottle pours a copper color similar to the IPA.  Foamy white head and excellent lacing along the side of the glass.  Aroma is hoppy with notes of honey, grapefruit and pineapple.  Flavor is sweet and malty up front and bitter and hoppy on the back end.

Pours a nice copper-orange color with a foamy white head.  Aroma is floral and bitter citrus hops and some sweet malts.  Oily mouthfeel, balanced taste between sweet malts and bitter citrus hops.  Nice beer, and great for the price.

Bomber. Pours clear light amber with a smallish white head. Aroma is lots of citrus hops, malts with light-fruit and honey character, and some wood. Flavor is a nice mix of citrus hops, pine, somewhat sweet and fruity malts, and a grapefruit finish. That’s all quite good as far as it goes-- an IIPA with a lot of nice mix of hop and malt character with citrus fruitiness. But then it has a weird aspirin-pill medicinal-bitterness aftertaste a few seconds later, which is weird and not that pleasant. Still, not bad on the whole, and cheap.

Bottle.  Pours a clear, amber color with a large, frothy white head.  Lacing is strong.  Aromas of hops, spruce, grapefruit, and some roasted malts.  Nice start on the palate with a smooth initial feel followed by a nice bitter finish.  Creamy throughout which is a surprise for an IPA.  Flavors of hops, hay, then a nice hoppy finish.  Great beer.

Bottle, after a couple months in a fridge. Pours light and rich amber with a medium and lasting white head. Aroma of citrusy hops, some malt. Flavors are the same. I’d had a bottle before that was fresher which had a strong hop presence, but after a couple months of rest the hops had settled and a nice maltiness set in, with no sign of stale hops or anything else undesirable. Very tasty.
Bottle. Pours amber with big white head. Aroma is surprisingly sweet, with citrus and bread notes. Flavor is hoppy and citrusy, but very sweet. Mouthfeel is a little light and dry.

Bottle. Poured a beautiful deep amber with a tiny head. Aroma of oranges. Disappointingly dry and bitter flavor compared to favored IPAs such as Stoudts and Dogfish Head, with accents of oranges and grapefruit. Tangy but dry mouthfeel which finished very bitter. Better than many, not as good as many others.

Bottle pours an orange amber with a big, big head.  The aroma is of sweet malt and a citrus and bread like.  The flavor is  quite hop forward but very sweet, with some orange like sweetness and peal to attempt to balance.  The palate is very much there.  There is somewhat of an abrasive aspirin like bitterness that I can’t quite overlook.  This is a bit of a mess...

Much better beer than their traditional IPA... Aroma of hops and a flavor with a nice balance of bitterness and sweetness, however, the beer does well in highlighting the hoppy flavor much more subtlely than the Hop Stoopid, their more ostentatious IPA... Nice tasting IPA

22oz bottle.  Copper amber pour with a big off-white head.  Sweet grainy aroma with bread and hops.  Sweet malt flavor up front with a bready hop finish.  Either this was an old bottle, or it’s just not very good.  The sweetness way overpowered the hops.

WAY TOO SWEET! couldnt finish the whole thing because of how sweet the finish is. started off fine, a little malty for how i like imperial IPA’s, but not bad. but the aftertaste and the finish was no good, dissapointing because of their regular IPA.
not as much of a hop aroma as expected. looks a little thin, taste is extremely sweet, almost like a barleywine with an alcoholic aftertaste, not very much hops.disappointing.
Again not a fan of IPAs, but at least this one had more flavor then just a kick in the teeth of hops.  If you love IPAs its a must have.

22 oz bottle.  Small aroma of pine and hops.  Poured a bright copper with a small quickly vanishing white head.  Flavor began to approach DIPA standard and held it’s ground throughout.  A little rough on the palate, but not unexpected.  Overall a workmanlike ale.

22 oz. Bottle. 3/1/09. Hazy straw color with an ok head that thins to a white cover. Smells of resinous hops that is a little thin but still nice. Tastes of sticky hops and malt that lingers for a short time. Good imperial but could be more hefty.

Dégusté avec Agaguk et Pyrozoid.  Apparence or limpide avec une belle petite mousse blanche qui colle tres bien au verre.  Aromes de pin, gingembre, zeste d’orange et un poivre leger mais intéressant.  Tres bonne amertume, leger cote sucré corps crémeux et velouté.... finition sec.  Gout tres houblonné, zest et poivré.  Bonne biere...

600ml bottle shared with Pyrozoid and French Tickler.  clear light brown appearance and a thick off white head.  Aroma: pine, ginger, hops, orange peal and caramel.  Flavor: hops, light peppery taste, ginger, pine, wood chips and orange zest.  Palate: medium body soft carbonation, creamy and oily and a hoppy peperry finish.

Bouteille de 600 ml. Dégusté avec french tickler et Agaguk. Bière de couleur caramel avec un très bon collet beige pale moyennement collant.  Odeur d’épinettes, épices, oranges, sucre, miel et sel. Gout de très sucré, miel, caramel, sucre d’orge et un peu la poire.

22 oz. bomber, 2006 vintage. Probably the oldest IIPA I’ve had. Still has some nice PNW hop in its nose, but now almost overwhelmed by caramel malt. Cloudy caramel colored IPA body. Thin white head. Taste starts with hop note of pineapple backed by tangy orange. Relaxing alcoholic malt, thick with a hint of toffee, rum and whiskey. Warmth and hoppiness expands as I work down the bottle. Well-aged ale even starts to finish with hints of 7-up. That’s a good thing.

bomber.  avg creamy/rocky off-white head into clear cooper body with minimal lacing present.  aromas of strong caramel and mod citrus hops  oily mouthfeel that coats.  too much sweetness in flavor for me.

Ryan/Casey’s. Bright orange body with rocky tan head. And a hoppy nose I can smell from far off. Strong taste of hops, slightly bitter. Texture is quite oily. Strong bitter finish. Nice stuff. That said, I’m beginning to feel that all American beers are starting to taste the same...

Red-orange amber with a whitish short-lived head. Lots of spotty lace. orange zest and Pez,slight grass, rather refreshing aroma; just a little plain hop aroma. Sharp hoppy bitter in the middle with almost enough candy-like malt to  balance this hop mini-monster. This style of all-hop IPA is well represented here, and the finish is a pleasant bitter dwindle

22oz. from Trinity Liquors in Spring Hill, FL. Pours a nice amber with a red tint...no cloudiness..thin tan head, alot of lacing. Aroma is not as strong as I was expecting...Nice pine, citrus, and grass. Flavor is some pine, quite a bit of citrus and malt up front. Not real bitter at first but the bitterness hits pretty hard a few seconds after you swallow it. Really nice bitter aftertaste. Medium mouthfeel...Nice warming feeling. I really like this one...a very nice balanced IIPA.

Poured at the gulfstream beerfest.  I have had this a few times, but finally I am getting around to rating it.  A very nice gold color and a medium white head.  The hops are big and citrus with some pine notes as well.  Flavor hits hard with hops.  Pretty damn bitter.  I must say that there are some caramel malts present in the beer, but the hops dominate in this brew.

Bottle.  Pours a bright golden color and big bright white head. Smells that great hoppy, piny scent. Flavor is surprisingly big and strong and deep.  Did not know until now that this is an imperial IPA.  Very huge and complex IPA flavor, so I guess it would make sense.  Great bargain.

A- Large, white, frothy head that sustains; fair lacing throughout; clear body with an orange/amber hue; small, lively particles

S- Nose is full of citrus hoppiness; strong grapefruit tones; subtle malt aroma; light bread smell gradually appears

T- Citrus hops initially, lightly acidic; quickly dissipates and leaves a malty feel followed by a short bitter finish

M- Medium body; watery texture; good carbonation

D- Strong but short hoppy finish makes this quite a drinkable ale; I join with other reviewers’ doubts of this being a true DIPA, it just is a little too simple with rather underwhelming hops compared to other DIPAs
Pours dark golden color with minimal white head. Nose of fresh hops and grass. Very bitter with a dry finish.

Picked up a single 22-oz bomber at Johns Marketplace in Portland, OR. Pours a semi-clear copper amber brew with a fast dissolving off-white head. Aroma of raisin, grapefruit, a hint of floral hops, some pine, toffee and caramel. Taste is medium to full bodied, average carbonation with flavors of tangerine, grapefruit, some caramel and light spice. Finish has a lingering semi-sweet grapefruit and bitterness. An average IIPA overall.

On cask at Toad.
Brassy color with no head. 
Large but mellow floral hop aroma that carries into flavor. Sweet and thick malty base with flavor of shellac in aftertaste.
The appearance gives this one away.  It is a light amber color and offered little head or lacing.  The over all flavor is OK, but this beer lacks the punch I expected from a "pumped up IPA".

Beer trade with nearbeer. Aroma: Lovely hints of quinces and hop resin. Pleasant malt background. Flavor and palate: Very nicely balanced. Dry bitter finish. Overall impression: A very nice Imperial IPA. Thanks a lot nearbeer!

courtesy of Allen - clear amber colour with a fair off-white head; aroma of quinces and cream; good malt body and with a regular carbonation; solid bitterness before a long aftertaste of quinces, apricot and cream - a very nice one which brings some balance between malt and hops

Light copper orange with a thin whipped milk white cover.  Lightly syrupy, sticky, sappy pine hop aroma, some toffee and caramel malt.  Taste is more pine hops over a thin caramel body with a slight alcohol bite.

Bomber from Barley Wine in Copenhagen.  I had been craving  something hoppy all evening and finally I get around to opening this.  Clear copper amber colour with a lasting ivory head.  Big syrupy piney hoppy nose.  Spicey hop with some kind of tangeriney citrus fruit too.  I’d been saving this for 5 months to have on a special evening when I could really appreciate it and you know what?  It hasn’t let me down.  I love this brewery and this is another more than solid beer.  They just take the styles and do it so much better.  Just so remarkably fresh in its flavours.  I mean I love the pale ale and this is just as good.  God I love the hops on this.  But the mouthfeel is deep and full as well.  Really good carbonation.  Beats stuff like Great Divide in my opinion.  Less malty syrupy and more on the hop side without being stupidly hoppy.  No alcohol unpleasantness at all.  Bit of heat on end, but not excessive.  The pale ale I think is perfect.  This is almost as good but not quite as the pale ale I would drink all night, but a bomber of this is probably sufficient, but I would still want a bottle every night.  Exceptional.  It’s the mouthfeel that I just find so good.  God that really is hoppy.  Just what I wanted.  I’m burping hop.  Lovely. The carbonation is both soft and insistent at the same time.
At Volo. Golden colour with a small head.  Caramel and pine nose with alcohol there too. Flavour: Toffee, sugar, alcohol and malt, the hops are present but overwhelmed by the alcohol. Not bad though.
A very strong IPA on flavor. Strong hop flavor what help to hide the high level of alcool. Really loved it but 1 bottle it’s more than enough, after it’s too much. Will buy it again for sure.
Bottle. Poured orange with an orange tinted head. Aromas of caramel, pine, and floral. The flavor had floral malts and caramel. Medium body, medium bitterness, creamy texture. A nice DIPA.

Re-rate 6/5/11: Bottle at a tasting. Thanks Dagan. Clear deep golden-amber color with a small white head. Aroma of piney and resinous hops and some alcohol. Bitter flavor of resunous hops with some sweetish caramel and malt and a bit of alcohol. Medium-full-bodied. Decent feels a bit too heavy. 7/3/7/3/13=3.3



(10/31/08) Draught sample at Blue Palms in Hollywood (thanks Brian for the free beer!). Clear deep golden color with a big white head. Aroma of grapefruit and some pine notes. Hoppy flavor with pine, some resin and a bit of citrus in a bitter finish. Medium-bodied. 7/4/7/3/14=3.5
Very floral malty smell. Taste is sweeter than most IPA’s, slightly bitter, good mouthfeel. Malts, hops and orange rind stand out for me.
Big hop aroma and big hop flavor.  Grapefruit and lots of citrus, some, plants, and flowers.  Full palate, well balanced and full of flavor.

Pours a deep red amber with a one finger off white head. Good amount of sticky lacings. Aroma is mainly sweet caramel malts, some floral hops.
Taste is very sweet malts almost candy like with just a touch of hop bitterness. If I didn’t know better I would judge this an Impy Red or something else on the sweet side. The bottle date indicated it was over three months old. Maybe improper storage killed the hop flavors. I will see if I can find a fresher sample and if it is better I will edit my review. For now though it is not a beer I would recommend to a friend.

Pours a clear blood orange amber with a shallow off white yellow head. Aroma is of caramel, toffee, citrus and pine, a bit of grass, strawberry salt water taffey. Hop aromas are overpowered by the sweet fruitiness. Flavor is caramel, toasted grain, burnt sugar and some citrus and grassy hops, finishing off with spicy/grassy hops and burnt sugar. I had thought maybe I got a bad sixer of their IPA that I had earlier, I had commented that it may be a good beer as a double (thinking I had a bad pack and that it would taste worlds better than what I got fresh)....I was wrong. The Maximus looks fine but is really weak and disappointing, this tastes more like an extremely under hopped IPA or hoppy American Amber either way doesn’t fit the style and isn’t very good.

Lagunitas Maximus delivers a floral hop experience. The aroma boasts lively hops as does the taste in this orange-gold colored Imperial IPA. Low carbonation and round body. As a sip hits your palette you are greeted with fresh and crisp feeling that disperses into a hop festival. The bitterness lingers in the aftertaste. Somehow this beer maintains good character - it doesn’t have many other distinct flavors besides some maltiness, but at the same time, the bitter hoppiness isn’t overdone. A great beer.

Bomber poured into a pint glass. Deep golden orange color, with quite a bit of yeast floating around. Big tan head, very sticky. Aroma is sweet and caramel malty, with juicy citrus that tends towards sweet rather than sharp/bitter. As a fan of dry and bitter IPAs, this isn‘t looking good so far. Flavor confirms my suspicions, as this beer is kind of a gooey mess of crystal malt and candied fruit. Totally disregards the tenets of attenuation and drinkability.
Very rich, sweet IPA; almost Belgian sweet. Pours caramel amber with a candy aroma. A very satisfying buy!
Perfect head, poured a nice amber. Great taste, Loved the hops and after taste. This is def one the best beers ive ever had
Bottle.  Pours an orange amber body with a white head.  Hop notes of pine, earth, and grass.   Malty caramel body.  Decent.

Pours with a large, off-white foamy head and good lacing. Clear, penny colored body. Aroma of pine, brown sugar, butter, dark fruits. Seems like this bottle might be aged a bit too much for a DIPA. Taste is a bit weak with crystal malt, raisins and hops. Watery mouthfeel and light bubbles. Good price though at 3.99 for a 22oz bottle.

650 ml bottle.  Pours a clear copper with a nice off-white head.  Good pine and citrus in the nose.  Solid malt base offset by a goodly amount of hop bitterness.  Decent balance.  Tad sweet in the finish with a hint of lingering bitterness.

22 oz. bottle.  Orange honey color.  Clear.  Quick bright head settles to dense and creamy, then dissipates to a sticky looking slick.  Smell is supersweet sugar pine.  Candy and hops.  Super thick in the mouth.  Sugar sweet at first to bitter hops to just bitter. Almost aspirin like, but not in a bad way. Im wondering how fresh this bottle is.  Id better try a couple more later this week.  Used to be my all time fav.  100th rating.

Bottle.  Pours a clear deep orange to amber color with a medium white head.  Lovely floral hop notes with a thick malt backbone, and possibly a hint of pineapple.  Medium thick body with a good amount of fine carbonation leading into a deep bitter finish.
An attractive dark amber glow with a creamy head.  Noticeable whiffs of citrus and malt.   Good hops and malt notes, with a fine clean finish.

Poured from a 22-oz bottle into a glass.  Pours an orange-gold, really nice coloring.

A very solid IPA.  Hoppy, but not overpowering.  Caramel malt on the finish.  Very good - about what I’d expect from Lagunitas.  I could see myself drinking a few of these.
22 oz. bottle.  Good aroma and drinkability.  Kind of a caramelly finish.  Not terribly bitter.

Bottle.
Aromatic hops, caramel, honey. Intense sweetness. A little burned sugar.
Full bodied. More of a Barley Wine than an IPA IMHO.

Pours dark/deep copper with frothy off white head.  Smells piney and citrusy.  Plenty of sugary sweet malts present in the nose as well.  Tastes bittersweet with overpowering hops, and thick full flavor of malts.  Balanced, and nice , as it has a very full flavor and warms all the way down with the medicinal alcohol.  Piney and citrusy, yet bread grains and thick cereal malts battle to the end.  Very nice.
Bottle. Pours a dark orange brown. Smelled  pretty piney, with floral and malty tints. Tasted mainly hoppy, piney, with definite malt notes, slightly boozy. Really solid IPA especially for the price.

Bottle.  Now this is more like it . . . you go, Barry!  Pours orange yellow with a medium head.  Aroma heavy on flowers, ripe orange, and malt.  Flavor is classic Lagunitas:  heavy on the malt, but you can tell that some quality hops are present as well.  Overall, I prefer Maximus to Lagunitas many ASA-style “red” beers.  Yes, it was too malty for me, and yes, I STILL do not think Lagunitas’ beers have a very desirable palate, but at least the flavor on this one was tasty all the way down.
Crushed with Jakebra.  A mother of a IPA.  Warms as it goes down.  Yum hops on the nose, same in the flavor.  Very sweet but balanced finish.  Kick-ass IPA.

poured a copper/amber colour with a creamy off white head that laced well.
Aroma was awesome citrus-pine. Plenty of caramel maltiness backing that up. A slightly sticky sweet piney alc. finish.

Clear red body with a disappating white head.  Floral hops balanced with caramel malts.  Easier drinking compared to many in the IPA family.  Not as hoppy given this is a west coast brewer.  I think this might fit better into the American Strong Ale category.  A solid brew, just isn’t so memorable.

Beautiful clear golden pour, thick white head.  Aroma is similar to other west coast IPA’s, citrus and floral hops.  Flavor is lightly hoppy and bitter of same citrus and floral notes.  Great all around brew.

In Bostom after game four of the ALCS (Tampa Bay). 

Lagunitas Maximus Imperial IPA is a deep amber color with creamy khaki head. The aroma and flavor are both sweet and bitter with malty bases. This is a fantastic beer with a serious bite.
[Bottle] Pours clear deep gold with a small off white head. Huge pine and grapefruit nose with a touch of malt. Flavor is slightly bitter, piney and citric, with a medium mouthfeel.
Big hop but a slightly sweat aroma. Golden amber color. Big hops but well balanced flavor, with an alomost creamy texture.

Bottle thanks to mar.  Nice amber pour, thick sustained head, really nice lacing.  Aroma of pine, hops, honey and malt.  Nice and hoppy flavor but not overwhelming.  Reminds me a bit of two hearted.  Nice sweet undercurrent... almost like a hint of coca cola.  Smooth, not too bitter.. really nice IIPA, one of my favorites.
Pours out orangey with a nice citrus smell that hits your sinuses like a freight train. The hops hit you from the first sip and don’t stop til the very last drop. Another winner from Lagunitas.

Orange with a beautiful reddish hue...thin white head with minimal lacing.  Aroma is faint, especially for a IIPA.  Flavor is sweet, with an iced-tea quality.  Too malty for the style...enjoyed the price, not the beer.

22 oz bottle from Mohegan.....Oh what a brew ! Orange/copper color with decent pour characteristics.  Has a serious fruity/caramel/toffee sort of flavor with similar aroma.  It’s great, will drink it again, esp if found in the taps of a Westchester pub!
Orange color with little head.  Aroma is dark fruit, hops.  Taste is the same with some bitterness.  Mouthfeel is good- some lingering.  Not as smooth for lower ABV (among DIPAs).

(Bottle).  Grassy, semi-sweet citrus aroma.  Hazy copper-amber body, off-white head.  Semi-sweet hoppy taste, mildly bitter rather brief finish.  Ok, but can’t hold a candle to DFH 90-Minute, or to Stone Ruination.

Bottle, bought @ Vinens Verden, Odense.

Pours lightly coppery golden with a great, creamy, small, off-white head. Aroma is hoppy, but with quite a malty balance. Slightly weak mouthfeel, but the ABV is a bit low. Super dry flavour, though, good hoppiness. Dryness, but not that much character, actually. Disappointing.

Nice looking sunshine yellow with a creamy, pillowy head. A nice lacing remains on the glass.

Fresh hoppy aromas of fresh cut grass, grapefruit, citrus and pine. I’m not always good at separating out the individual aromas, but this seems to hit them all!

Great taste. Bitter, as expected, but also fresh and slightly sweet to balance.

Creamy mouthfeel. Goes down very easily!

Overall a nice beer, and recommended.

22 oz. bomber from Binny’s (Orland Park, IL). Pours a fiery orange hazy hue with notes of grapefruity red prominent and a sign of the tastes to come. Small to medium head that dissipates significantly but still manages to lace anok amount. Aromas are largely citrus, strong grapefruit and lighter caramel malt notes that are pretty great. Taste is similar, large bitterness up front with grapefruit and lemony prominance, middle body shows signs of caramel and biscuity malts, moves quickly back to grapefruit and bitter hop notes. Finishes with a crisp bitterness, but not astringent. Fairly smooth for the style. Pretty great! Cheers!

I got this because every single beer I’ve had from Lagunitas has been amazing, and this is no different! It pours a darker amber, with a retaining off white head. The aroma is classic IPA with some citrusy notes, and some alcohol on the nose. The flavor follows suit with huge hopps and a slight bite of alcohol on the finish. This is definitely one of the better IPA’s I’ve had in a while, being very well balanced and drinkable. Cheers!

Fishing for Coho on Thorne Island in Alaska (pop. 115) and miraculously the general store had a healthy stock of Maximus to go with your typical macro sewer water.  Now I know why.  Paired with a fresh catch of Silver Salmon, the bitter fruits reveal themselves nicely with a dry hoppy finish.

Ordinary in the glass, with a golden hue and some soapy lacing.  Hop aromas dominate -- apricot, grapefruit.  Same on the tongue.  Good heft a balance, with lots of good caramel malts coming to the show.  Overall, a sipper that contains nice floral, pit fruit notes throughout.

Very flowery hops with a nice aroma and great flavor.  The hoppyness is well balanced and not very bitter.  The cereal grains are very nice and balance the beer well.  Very nice hoppy fruit flavor balanced with grain.  This has to be the most enjoyable IPA I have had!

Wowza. Aroma is sweetly hoppy. Flavor is, at first a rush of hops, but then you get a lot of that sweet malt flavor. Unlike any IPA Ive ever had. Very nice. Sweet with good strong hop flavor. Nice balance. I recommend.
Bottle. Unclear amber-like. Sweet and grassy nose. Flavour is kind of caramel sweet with a dry bitter finish. A very simple and boring beer
1 ptin 6 oz. bottle purchased at Central Market in Mill Creek.  Pours a beautiful amber color, with a hoppy/citrus aroma.  Flavor:  The same as the aroma, with just the right amount of bitterness.

1pt 6oz bottle from Weavers Discount Liquors, Elkton, MD...amber pour, white head...very floral aroma with a touch of orange (tangerine?)...flavor has a decent hoppy bitterness with a touch of alcohol...good stuff.
Pours amber with thick off white head.  This one is past it’s prime so the hops are mild and not that noticeable as expected.  More malty flavor due to it’s age.  Will try again.
Pours clear golden with a small head. Dried apricot, honeyed-malt-sweetness in the aroma. Flavor is similar. Malt and hops intertwine. Nice hop presence.

Bottle pours clear golden with very little head, no lacing. Aroma is pine. First taste is sweet sugar but hops quickly take over. The finish is pine hops with little sweetness left on the lips. Not really a DIPA but good none the less.

Bottle.  Honey-brown pour with large, thick, off-white head.  Toffee and citrusy hops on the nose.  Remarkably robust on the palate.  I expected the complex hops bouquet, but I didn’t expect the magnificent, toasty malt.  There are flavors uncharacteristic for the style - like cane syrup - but this is a remarkably good beer. Long, lingering bitter finish.

Its a hop attack!  If you are an IPA fan than this beer is for you plus you get the added benefit of the high ABV.  Hops provide a clove, bitter, taste and finishes with a coated dark overtones of grain.

Pours amber with a small, white head. Strong hop aroma, with some caramel malt backing. But this beer is all about the hops. The flavor is very hoppy, backed with the smallest amount of caramel malt.  Nice mouthfeel, long hoppy finish. Lingering bitterness.

2008 Bottle - Pours lt amber with a small off white head, aroma is clove honey, dried fruit, sugar...flavour is less bitter than most Lagunitas, but still with a bite, heavy malt, flavour lasts for a while, decent...

First off, it’s Lag, so I’m expecting something overdone, as with most all their beers, total personality burst. Twist off somewhat shorter bottle.  Flowery perfumy hop and weird fruit olfactory. Look is slightly darker than yer ubiquitous pale yellow but it’s still in that class. Very thin head wth a fine foam blanket. Little detectable carbonation on the palate during the initial swig. Starts off fairly fruity then morphs into a grating bitter chewing on green grapefruit rinds handsoap terribleness. Every taste is the same; first candy aroma then fruit commencement in mouth and finally a  back of throat old dandelion greens sensation. wew.  I must say however, since it has so much personality, I never would have guessed it was almost 8%!  Freakish oily bastard taste hides overly alkied brew. Exceptionally annoying and intimidating. Yukky back of throat gathering lingering biting bitter to the breakingpoint. On style, try it hop head!

Bottle. Pours a hazy reddish-amber with a white ring. Aroma is bitter and hoppy, with a hint of sweeter fruits and some herbs and spices. Taste is sharp and bitter, of hops and herbs that picks up a dryer hoppiness as it goes. Lingering bitterness. Quite tasty double IPA.

nice amber color with a cream head that dissipates into a thin head.  huge notes of oranges and fresh hops.  very easy on the palate with a malty flavor that finishes with a great slightly bitter hop note.

Lovely orange hued beer with white head. Hoppy nose and a bit of citrus. Some sweetness in there, probable higher ending gravity/ higher mash temp than my preference for a 2IPA. Shades of sauterne-like marmalade on the palate. Not intensely hopped, and the malt tends to dominate. Bloody good beer, I just prefer a drier, hoppier 2IPA myself.

In the bottle from an undisclosed location.


Pours dark amber, almost red, with a small off-white head and clear as can be.  Little to no lacing.  Good bitterness.  Not super powerful.  I would expect a little more bitterness and flavor from an Imperial.  Stronger than the standard Lagunitas IPA, but not by much.  Good malt structure and hop profile.  Citrus and spicy cinnamon notes.  Signature Lagunitas IPA "soy sauce" flavor.  Original and enjoyable but not my first choice.

Wow, pours my favorite color for an IPA.  A nice caramel color with big floral bouquet.  flavor is spot on, the hops attack your tongue but in a good way.  Nice notes of sweet caramel and spicy hops.  Really a perfect representation of the glorious IPA.

22 oz. bottle. Pours a lovely light tan head, nice golden color, nose was resinous, piney, and very slightly floral,  initial taste not particularly big, finishing with nice hop spice and then bitterness, with a superb mouth feel. The nose was perhaps a bit monochromatic, and a bit short on floral aroma.

Pours an enticing dark gold, smells of a bit of hops but not as much as I expected, relatively weak on the nose which surprises me as most IIPAs I’ve tried have a great nose. Looking down the ratings already here, it seems like I’m the only one who will score this weak on aroma- maybe my nose is too stuffed? Really just a bland bit of hoppy aroma, nothing special. The label lists 72.41 IBUs, pretty low for a 2IPA. First sip... wow, lots of hop punch, but balanced with a citric sweetness and some malt towards the end. Finishes long, honey/malty, and bitter. Perfect mouthfeel- sticky malt with adequate carbonation. Really, really enjoyable IPA, the best new IPA I’ve tried in months. I want to give this a higher rating but the nose just wasn’t there for me. Either way, excellent IIPA, a far better effort than Lagunitas’ regular IPA. Recommended for sure.

Last few days served in shaker at Mellow Mushroom and at home from bottle in a flared pilsner glass.  Has unclear, brown color and orange head.  Aroma is sweet hops as is flavor.  Great taste throughout.

Tasty looking amber pour with a creamy tan head that lasts and laces nicely.  Aroma of caramel malt, pine sap and grapefruit rind.  Big hoppy flavor, lots of citrus and pine, and a smooth malt balance.  Thick and sticky on the palate, with a long bitter finish.  Yummy!

Bottle (65 cl) from Ölbutikken, Copenhagen, Denmark. Clear amber with medium off-white head. A bit sugary malt aroma with citrus and pine hops. Slick mouthfeel. A bit sweetish with a nice hop bite. Quite good.

Pours out a nice copper color with a decent white head.  aroma is grassy, citrusy and very hoppy.  Flavor was big on hops and rather sticky.  I certainly enjoyed this one and am glad to see these beers in NC

Pours a deep orange/copper with a big white head.  Aroma of citris and pine.  Taste is resiny hops and big bitterness throughout with a touch of malt.  The bitterness is a bit harsh in the aftertaste.
pours a copper orange with a nice frothy white head. Aroma of citrusy hops, malt, pine,. Flavor is citrus, hops, pine, big malt backbone to balance it out. Nice IIPA. Very Tasty.
Pours an orange amber with a nice head. Big aroma of pine and citrus, some malt aroma as well. Strong bitterness. thanks OG

Rich, brassy pour with a full foam cap and lacing.  This beer has a powerfully appealing aroma of fir trees, flowers, honey, and orange - but that is the best thing about it.  The flavor is mostly resiny hops that get a little harsh in the finish.  This is a rugged IPA that is potent and penetrating.  In my opinion, it could use a little more balance, some more sweetness and smoothing - but it is still good.

12 oz bottle fro premier gourmet. pours clear orange with a small off white head. aromas are big sticky caramel malts. very deep and sweet with almost no hops. the same huge malts dominate the flavour. the hops come in for a long bitter finish. chewy mouthfeel and very big flavour. more of an american barleywine. id love to try a superfresh sample.

Poured clear orange with a two finger head and very good lacing. Strong citrus hops aromas that featured grape and grapefruit as well as some pine. Taste followed suit, with a bit of orange and caramel thrown in. Well carbonated, thick and full bodied, with a strong grapefruit aftertaste that didn’t thrill me. Otherwise, an excellent beer.
From a 22 oz bottle.  Orange-brown pour with a one inch cream-colored head.  Strong citrus aroma.  Thick, slightly sweet body with a bitter, acidic aftertaste.  A Decent effort.

From bottle... poured orange with small white head. Beautiful citrus hoppy aroma. Initial taste had very high alcohol prominence, but that faded as it went away to a bitter, grapefruit tase. Very warming finish. Pretty good.
Tasted on vacation in CA.  Very crisp and clean tasting beer, light bitter aftertaste, well balanced with aroma, even a hint of orange in there somewhere.  Easy to enjoy.
draft. aromas of peach. evergreen and herbal hops(EKG?), grapefruit on the finish, lush body.

[1606-20080816] 12floz bottle. Grainy hops aroma has a bit of citrus peel. Clear, orange amber body with a quick creamy light tan head. Hoppy sweet yeast flavour has orange peel notes. Medium body. Nice hoppy brew.

(@ Cole’s IPA Festival; Buffalo, NY)

Draft at Mad Mex, 8/10/08.  Pours orange with a white head and good lacing.  Nose is grapefruit, pine, sweet caramel and bubblegum.  Taste is moderate bitter with grapefruit, pine and resiny, sugary caramel.  Nice IIPA.

fresh bright hop aroma with sticky tropical notes of pineapple and mango. oranged body, foamy head, good lacing. beautiful and happy in my mouth. the added intensity of ingredients amplifies everything to a balanced heightened sensation experience.
Bottle. Pours amber with thin white head. Gorgeously strong hoppy aroma. Taste is slightly too sweet and body is too thick for the style.
Deep clear amber with short lasting head. Strong hoppy aroma with some caramel and pines. Flavour is bitter and bitter finish.
Bottle. Pours amber with an off white head. Sweet and hoppy aroma with floral and pine. Flavor has a very nice grassy and floral hop profile with not quite enough malt. Nice bitter finish.
An excellent double IPA. Has the traditional lagunitas taste and is very flavorful. Not comparable back to back with the avery maharaja but it was very good.
Dark copper colour with large white head.Aroma is strong and fruity of Grapefruits ,bitter and well balanced with heavy finish and full body aswell well done.

12oz bottle - 8.3% alc. Maximus. The name says it all. So much malt combined with even more hops. In the end, it creates a slightly thick and sticky, but amazingly enjoyable DIPA. Going down, the malt initially win the battle until, shortly thereafter, the hops perform a covert sneak-attack on the palate. This beer is definitely one to check out. I heard the Maximus in the bomber is not as good, if it wasn’t for the case of 12ozers in my basement, I’d like to pick one up for comparison. Overall: WOW! I don’t care if its 11 in the morning, I can’t wait!

22 oz bottle.  Aroma of grapefruit and a little malt.  Sweet malty flavor at the beginning, which yields to a grapefruity hoppy bittness with some grassy notes.  I liked the flavor balance and complexity  Burnt orange color with thin, yet persistant head.  Decent lacing on the glass.  Nice, unique brew that proves you don’t have to hit people over the head with a bunch of hops to make an enjoyable IPA.
Flavor is citrus hops, resiny mouthfeel, not as itense as i thought it was going to be, but very good
Bottle. Dark copper color with a slight head. Strong hop aroma. Thick to the palate. Flavor is a very hoppy start mildly bitter middle and a sweet finish.

Had this on draft the other night at Cobblestones in York, PA. This is probably the most over the top IPA I have ever had. It tasted like I was simply drinking liquid hops. There was no balance to it at all. Its smell and taste very fresh however so if hops are your thing then by all means find some.

Hazy copper pour, a bit of head but not much.  Bitter scent of hops and something smoked.  Taste of hops and spices (coreander and cinnamon).  A nice sweet rise in the middle and a dry finish.  Probably the best IPA I have had.

Appearance: Nice clear copper, small off-white head that lasts.

Aroma:  Beautiful hops aroma.  More piney/resiny than I would say citrus.. but the citrus is there, very subtle.  Simcoe? Malt there, but takes a backseat.

Flavor: Delicious bitterness and hop flavor to match the aroma exactly.  In fact, the definition for aroma is exactly the same as this + some strong, clean bitterness

Mouthfeel: Light to medium body, fully carbed.

Overall: Excellent IIPA.  Very standard, nothing out of the ordinary, but no present flaws.  WOuld drink often.

Bottle from Kensington Wine Market in Calgary. Pure copper in colour with a very dense, long lasting cream coloured head and high carbonation. Aroma has a lot of grapefruit, followed by a little pine, florals that build up too be huge the more you inhale and a faint smell of old books (pleasant and not the typical oxidative smell of cardboard though). Taste starts with a huge, sweet malt backbone leading into a good amount of bitterness. Not extremely complex. I did get a little bit of a fishy taste that could be a little dimethyl sulfide...would have rated higher if not present. Palate is medium bodied and resiny.
6pack from knightly sprits in o-town. Thanks again Alan!  Clear copper pour with a fluffy white head and picture esque lace.  Pine hops aroma.  Strong but not cloying, lots of hops balanced this out.

Has a grassy aroma, a little earthy with a mild citrus.  It pours beutifully, with a thick head that settles down, clear, copper/orange color.  Nothing outstanding with the flavor, aboot a normal IPA, a little grassy.  Bitter on the palate and finishes with th grassy flavor.  Overall, it is not one of my favorite IPA’s, but not bad.

Bottle. Nice aroma of pine, citrus, caramel malt. Flavor keeps some strong, fruity malt, but the hops are a little less pointed in the mouth and turn to more general spiciness/bitterness. Still, not oppressively bitter, and has a particular, bitter finish that can be a blessing or a curse. Very nice.

Bottle.  Pours orange with a thick white head and leaves nice, thick lacing.  Aroma of rich bready/cookie malt and flowery hops.  Flavor of lots of hop spices, bitter hops.  The flavor is very muddied and it was hard to pick out anything specific.  This beer has a spicy bite to it.  Mouthfeel is thick and heavy.  An ok IIPA but not very well balanced and too heavy for my liking.
POured a nice amber color with a small off white head. Aroma was very nose bitting bitter hops, mainly citrusy/pineapple notes. Flavor was also very much the same, not too smooth, just very bitter

22oz bottle, shared by Omar.  Thanks, man!  Pours a bright, bold, slightly hazy orange color; light khaki head with great retention and medium-bubbled lacing; really nice looking pour.  Solid amounts of citrus, earthy bitterness, and crystal malts in the aroma; kind of basic; minimal astringency.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: chewy candy sugar, citrus / earthy bitterness (nothing astringent or rough), and just loads of crystal malts; relaxed carbonation; basic, typical Lagunitas ASA boredom.  Ok and fairly drinkable, but not really worth the alcohol; doesn’t provide a fair amount of complexity.  Lengthy, mildly bitter finish: candy sugar, crystal malts, and bitter citrus.

A caramel  and citrus aroma, orange and brown in color, darker than most IPA’s, has a deeper almost malty flavor, more than most IPA’s with a decent hoppy bitter finish.  I say it is what Anchor Steam would taste like if it were an IPA
Fine coloring and head. Aroma is fine if a little weak for the style. Really good overall for the price. Hits all the notes at the right times. Oily.
Pours from 22 oz bomber medium copper, aroma of floral pine resins, malted hops and caramel.  Flavour is of a modest IIPA, resins and a grapefruit character come through on top of the bitterness.
Bomber poured amber with a nice head.  Good hoppy aroma.  Flavor starts off sweet with a nice dry bitter finish.  This is a solid easy to drink beer.
Bomber. Pours golden amber with small off-white head.  Piney hop aroma follows through in flavor.  Hop nuggets were actually floating in the beer.  Cloying finish.

12 oz. bottle courtesy of drewbeerme.  Pours a clear amber color with a big creamy head that leaves some lacing.  The aroma is resiny citrus, floral, moderately sweet, and some caramel malt.  The flavor leans more toward the hoppy side of things.  It opens with some citrus and a hint at sweetness, but becomes more bitter mid-palate through to the finish.  Maybe a hint of pine is sneaking in as well.  The malt is present, but does not stand up to the hops.  Thick and chewy going down.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a copper color with a light to medium head.  Pretty hoppy and medium bodied.  Citrus and floral flavors predominate.  Hits pretty hard on the back of the palate.  Pretty tasty brew.
650ml bottle at Beer Bistro in Toronto. Amber with white head. Floral, mango, malty aroma. Bittersweet taste of hops, malts, and mango. Very smooth mild taste. Completely hides the alcohol.

on draft...  excellent IIPA... nice deep golden / amber color with a good white head.  solid hop filled aroma... medium to full body with near sticky hop notes on the palate.  piney hops are most prevalent... even over the palate and a nice bitter finish... this one is a borderline IPA and IIPA.... it is kind of caught in the middle somewhere.... a bit more hops would truly make this one stand out more.  for the price, you can’t beat Lagunitas... they make some excellent beer at affordable prices.  Maximus is another example of a true go to beer that will never disappoint.

12oz. Bottle:  Aroma of caramel, malts, hops, biscuit, resin, and a hint of alpha acid.    
Poured amber in color with a medium-sized off-white head that diminished but lasted.  Clear.  Sparkling.  Very good lacing.  Flavor is lightly sweet and medium to heavily bitter.  Tastes of hops, resin, caramel, malts, and more hops.  Medium body.  Oily, then sticky texture.  Soft carbonation.  Hoppy, lightly dry finish.

12oz bottle, pours like... an IPA! thin head, amber color, smells of a variety of citrus, pine, etc... It’s all been stated before. Tastes very good, nicely balanced, but stronger and more alcohol taste than DFH 90 Minute that was drank previously in the day.

Pours an attractive clear copper hue with a two finger creamy head. The nose is nicely balanced with pineapple and floral hop & caramel malt. The front falvor is more toward th hop influence, but there is a caramel malt mid that then reverts back to the dry hoppy, bitter finish.

Bottle.  Pours a clear amber brown with a diminishing head that leaves nice lacing in the class.  Thick, grassy cascade hop aroma.  Initial sweetness is balanced by tremendous bitterness, all inside a viscous body.  The finish is lingering and pleasant.

12oz bottle: Pours a slight hazy amber with a 1-2 finger head of ivory foam. The aroma is pure IPA with mostly piney notes.The flavor continues the aroma with some malt sweetness and notable hop bitterness. The pine flavors come through again with only a hint of citrus. The mouth feel is smooth with less coating than i would expect in a double IPA. Overall this is a solid beer but this is a crowded category with many great examples.

magnum bottle, came out of the bottle as a classic IPA does - nice amber hue, thin head which dissipated in snifter quite quickly. Aroma of piney hops that follows through on the palate with a mild carbonation full of piney turned sweet hops with kudos to a malt backbone. Second time tasting, second time enjoyed.
Deliciously hoppy.  Aroma is very sweet, somewhat syrupy.  Color is a bright orange, has a thin head.  Flavour is bitter, sharp, sweet.  Mouthfeel is smooth with a strong bitter finish.

ABV: 7.5%
RateBeer rating: 95
Calories: estimated at 400 C
Volume: 22 fl oz
Glass: concave shaker, snifter, tulip
Purchased at: Circle Liquors Super Saver, Pennington, NJ
Price: $4.49
Consumed at: home with a dinner of spicy pork and beans.

First Impression: great aroma, good taste, nice color and presence. Good price. Aroma is pine, flowers, lime and grapefruit. Visuals are everything a great IPA should be. Copper body, highly carbonated, nice lacing, off white head. Taste is hoppy, pine, lighter texture, not overwhelming - very nice. Palate is fluid, sweet & bitter taste buds active, medium length finish. Very enjoyable. Second Impression - a very nice example of IPA, for a good price.

Aroma: 8 out of 10

Visuals: 5 out of 5

Taste: 8 out of 10

Palate: 4 out of 5

Overall: 17 out of 20
Address :

Found a bottle in the grocery store singles section. Nice amber with orange hues. Good hop nose. Nice sweetness quickly tempered and beat down with a hop awesomeness. 

I’m so glad I picked this up.
Rather hazy amber-orange, diminishing head.  Very hoppy on the nose, with grass-clippings and citrus.  Thick body, moderately sweet, with a wonderfully bitter ending.

22oz bottle, pours clear orange/amber with a foamy, creamy off-white head that lasts and leaves some nice lacing.  Aroma of pine, caramel malt, and citrus hops...very nice aroma.  Taste was a bit sweet, citrusy, and hoppy.  Not as hoppy as I expected, which I’m OK with, as I’m not a huge hop-head.  Mouthfeel is a bit thin and watery, not as rich as I expected.  Quenching, though.  Overall, a very good IPA.

12 oz 
aroma of sweet hoppy goodness, and hop flavor that is strong but not too bitter. nice carbonation and decent mouthfeel, more bitter aftertaste that requires another sip to cool it down.

Orange/copper without much of a head, but it is there.  Nice citrusy hops on the nose, but they werent as strong as I was expecting.  Body is quenching but not a complete thunderfunking slam of hops in my mouth- which ordinarily is ok for me but I was in the mood for my face to be melted.  That said, this was still a well constructed and balanced brew, worth returning to.

From a 22 oz. bottle purchased locally. Aroma is full of fruity and citrus hops, some pineapple. Color is a honey golden amber with a thick head that stays. Very clear. Slightly sweet at first, but completely overtaken by the hop bitterness. More pineapple, citrus hop flavor. Finish is dry with a lingering bitterness. Light for the strength, and not overly sweet. A great Double IPA.

This beer pours and orange-amber colour, with a finger sized white head thats hopping with citrusy hops. I will agree with other posts however that its not as Maximus full of hops as I imagined, yet still very good. Lots of citrus fruit, grapefruit and lemons.

Sample at Barley’s Smokehouse. This beer is a hazy light amber color with a thin light beige head that diminishes quickly. Spotty lacing. The aroma is hoppy with some caramel malt. Medium-bodied and moderately bitter with hops and spice flavors, along with some sweet malt and grapefruit underneath. The finish is fruity and hoppy with a lightly bitter aftertaste. Does not pack as much punch as I would expect in a IIPA. Slightly above average overall.

Pours a clear, light orange color with a decent, frothy, barely off-white head.  Aroma is hops, slightly musky.  Beer goes down as the head sticks to my upper lip... hoppy, but leaves a tame aftertaste.  Light/medium body.  Something feels and tastes lacking.  Not sure what it is.  With a name like "IPA Maximus" I was expecting a bit more.  But still, not bad for an IPA.

Bomber.  Pours a crystal clear amber with three finger off-white head and a bunch of carbonation with nice lacing.  Nose is floral hops, tangerine and pine.  Palate is floral, citrus, sweet malts and a non-lingering dry bitter pine finish.  Medium mouth feel - not a bad DIPA – one of the better Lagunitas beers I’ve had.

Max pours copper with small yellow-white head. Nose is strong with a beautiful balance, and the flavor follows as such, but neither is complex. Overall, perhaps a little watery and flat, but still enjoyable.

A golden/copper clear beer with a small white head that disappears. Aroma is great, citrusy (grapefruit) and floral hops. The taste is a bit thin, as is the mouthfeel, not as hoppy or bitter as I would like.
12 ounce bottle purchased at Total Wine Fort Lauderdale, FL for $1.99 Very good!

Bottle. Pours amber with a medium white head. Flowery, fruity, hoppy aroma with notes of exotic fruit, grass, pine, and grapefruit. Flavour is the same but has a good malty base that adds toffee and caramel. Long bitter flavour.

Draught: Beautiful creamy head atop a smoky peach color. Unbelievable aroma! Peaches and pine and maybe a little orange citrus. Very floral as well. Flavor is fruity orange but not oversweet. Nice oily texture coats the entire mouth. Peachy finish stretches out and does not want to let go. Wonderful double.
Pours a dark amber colour with excellent white head.... tastes strongly of malt with a fruity hoppiness, not too thick lick many double IPAs... a brilliant concoction indeed!
bottle, malty girl scout cookie nose, excellent grapefruit , lemon, spice flavor, finishes a little thin or would be great

Bomber w/ Simon.  This was overwhelming overshadowed by the previous M.S. IPA we just had.  Nicely balanced - caramel malts mix nicely w/ the mild hop profile.  Really not all that bitter or in your face...In comparison to what’s out there, this is mellow, drinkable, and overall good - but nothing great.

Re-rate:  Copper colored with a moderate sized head.  Big caramel malt profile under a sharp pine hop bite.  Catty and oily with firm bitterness.  A little heavy but still a very nice beer  Original Rating:  I have noticed, for the most part, Lagunitas offers some real nice big beers for less than some of their competitors. No different here. Pours a amber-copper color with a nice initial sticky head and pretty good retention. Aroma is mostly floral grapefruit hops but there’s also some caramel malt and pine. The flavor consists of a lot of citrus grapefruit hops with sweet malt underneath. Finishes a bit bitter and dry. They are able to provide a lot of flavor with a relatively low abv for a IIPA. And again, there’s real good value here. I’ll be getting this again.

Clear reddish amber with large off white head. Sweet and hoppy aroma with notes of caramel, pine and grapefruits. Flavor is sweet with plenty of hops, caramel and grapefuit notes. Good mouthfeel and a solid bitter finish. Nice.

Pours amber brown and clear with a cream colored head.  Nutty and hoppy aroma.  Super-hoppy and bitter taste with hints of nuts and carmel. Finishes with a kick of spicy hops at the back of the throat. Overall, a good IPA but the palate lacks to the smoothness of other IPAs.

Pours a hazy amber with bubbly carbination.  2 fingers rich cream head.  Moderate lacing.  Strong hop aroma, with grapefruit, citrus and malt.  Wonderfully bitter up front followed by nice warm alcohol.  Taste lingers quite awhile on the  tongue but is fairly short elsewhere.

Brown bottle, 1 pint 6 ounces, purchased at deVine Wines and Spirits, savoured on May 19 2008; eye: copper, slightly hazy, lots of creamy white head that disappears almost completely, a bit of lacing, slight effervescence; nose: lots of hops (pine), grapefruit, light grain; mouth: hosp (pine), grapefruit, a bit of caramel, Cointreau, well-balanced finale in hops and caramelized malt, lightly sweet, mildly bitter, medium body, slightly creamy texture, not much carbonation, light astringency; overall: quite nice

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 1 pinte 6 onces, 7,5 %, achetée chez deVine Wines and Spirits, savourée le 19 mai 2008; œil : cuivrée, très légèrement voilée, mousse blanche crémeuse abondante qui disparaît presque complètement, un peu de dentelle, très légère effervescence; nez : beaucoup de houblon (pin), pamplemousse, léger grain; bouche : houblon (pin), pamplemousse, un peu de caramel, Cointreau, finale bien équilibrée en houblon et malt caramélisé, légèrement sucrée, moyennement amère, corps moyen, texture légèrement crémeuse, peu carbonatée, légère astringence; en résumé : très bien
Amber, with a very thich head. Medium carbonation, very hoppy, little hint of malt and yeast. Slight fruity touch with some spices. Dry taste that leaves a tingy sensation on the palate.

Pours amber and clear with a white head, plently of lacing.  Aroma of big citrus hops, grapefruit, orange, and herbs.  Some floral hops as well.  Taste is very hoppy with some light malt backing.  Finishes with huge hop bitterness.  Mouth is pretty stickey.  Very nice IIPA.
nice hoppy nose that does not seem to translate to taste well....copper color and a decent iipa but it will not remove the enamel from your teeth

Bomber: Pours a viscous amber with a rocky yeasty head that sticks to the glass in long strings.  The first brew of my summer vacation.  Nose is heavy whole hops with a carmelized malt backup.  Body is medium and well toned.  It is long lasting and crisp with citrus undertones.  Malts and hops are balanced and that ssayin something since there is so much of both.  A very easy drinking brew at 11PM.  Lets see what the next two and a half weeks bring me for new beers.
Bottle: Poured a copper with an off white head. The aroma is sweet citrus and apricot with slight hops. Taste is gritty grapefruit citrus with hops.

On tap. Floral hop notes, grapefruit and apricot, fresh and vibrant. Medium sweetness and light grain. Nice aroma. Orange-amber clear with thin off-hite lacing head.
