Medium heavy body with medium carbonation; fizzy burning on tongue. Starts with nice sugary sweetness, apricot nectar and mild resin. Super balance and not overwhelming in sweetness or bitterness. Nice sweet-bitter finish and fairly clean, considering. Really drankable IIPA.

pours a dense tan head.  Aroma is piney citrus. Mouthfeel has a veryfull creamyness but still feels bright ands refreshing. Flavor is typical of a very good IPA - grapefruit and pine but unusual in its caramel malt flavor -great balance to the sharp citrus hop profile. Delicious.

Vibrant copper pour.  Nice head.  Grapefruit aroma.  The taste is slightly medicinal which is what you would expect from a Double IPA.  The alcohol is there but at 8.4% it is fairly well hidden.  Good value and a good beer.

The aroma is a nice piney hop scent, surprisingly not at all overwhelming.  A little grapefruit aroma in there too.  Appearance is mostly golden, without the reddish tint you see in many IPA’s.  Nice refreshing flavor, hoppy, again not too much so.  Medium mouthfell, with slight stickyness.  Palate has a citrusy hoppy feel.  Good IPA overall, though I liked the regualr Lagunitas IPA just as much.  Like most Lagunitas, it is affordable.  It has good value given the good quality of the beer.
Just an awesome IPA here.  Very serioius hops and flavor throughout.  Surprisingly not overwhelming.  Nicely balanced.

This beefed up version of the 22oz. Maximus has a bit more hops and in turn a bit more ABV. than the original.  The six pack carrier say 7.5% but the bottle says 8.4%.  My guess is that they didn’t update the six pack carrier this year.  

On the beer side.  This is one of the best deals price wise for a six pack of a great imperial I.P.A.  It’s kind of hard to believe that  a six pack of this cost only a dollar or two more than a good 22oz. Imperial.

22 oz bottle...Poured a beautiful golden yellow...the initial head had a yellow tint to it, but it evened out to a thick, rich, frothy white head that provided snake like lacing to the last drop. Aromas of citrus, florals, a little pine. Taste was very mild and balance which was very surprising. Great mix of hops, malts, some light citrus (sour orange/grapefruit), a little sweetness, and some pine. The palate was medium bodied w/ just the right amount of carbonation. The alcohol was well hidden, which would mean this can be a very dangerous session beer. I will definitely buy this again...
Bottle, at the WBF in Raleigh.  Copper, beige head.  Very nice hop aroma, citrus, pine, and caramel.  Flavor is similar, very tasty.

12 oz. Clear copper with a very small head that tries to persist. Aroma of honey, resin, tea leaf, grapefruit, and slight cocoa. Flavor of earthy tea leaf, honey, evergreen resin, toasty nut, cocoa, and grapefruit. Near the end of the glass, the taste becomes mostly just resin and grapefruit though. Light-medium body is soft and dry.

Bottle, Kegs & Barrels in McKinney, TX.
Pours a nice orange copper with off-white head with good retention. Aroma of nice grape fruit. Flavor was sweet with nice hoppy flavor and nice bitterness in the end. Palat is medium-full mouth feel with medium carbonation. Good IPA.

This was pretty standard for a Double IPA, no big surprises.  Its a little unbalanced but I knew it would be going in.  By the taste I would have guessed it be a regular IPA, not quite thick and sticky enough to be of the double variety.  Up against some of the real DIPAs this seems like water.

Bottle:  Beautiful copper color with a small lingering white head...decent lacing.  Solid nose on this...pretty much a citrus-hop bomb.  Some notes of light malts, soft spice tones and candied sugar tend to pop up erratically.  Very crisp and biting mouth feel leads to a solid floral and resin hop base with some of the mild citrus (pineapple and orange rind) coming through on the finish along with the light malt.  Solid brew, but seems to fall b/t an IPA and a IIPA.
From a bottle.  Pours a capper color.  Aromas of piney and citrus hops.  More citrusy, piney hops in the taste with some caramel malt.  Very dry finish.  Good double IPA.

A yellow tinted caramel beer. Pours with a 2.4 inch head, (yes, 2.4 inch) that just won’t quit. Super bitter, hop aroma. Taste is like pure hop bliss, It’s perfect. It’s a lot, but not too much, and definitely enough. Texture is medium, and full. After taste is bitter, which if you’re drinking this, you know how good it is then.

22 fl oz bottle, comes as Lagunitas Limited Release IPA Maximus Ale. Pours hazy orange with a huge off-white head. Pinewood needle aroma, dry and quite inviting. Flavour is light acidic pine wood - dry wooden hops note following. Mild sweet caramel malt base appears before the finish. Dry wooden finish. Nice one! Goes great with barbeque.

Bottle. Tasty balance of sweet malt and bitter hops, though this double IPA leans toward the bitter side. Golden orange body with a nice looking off-white head. The initial pour yielded an aroma that was full of pineapple and orange along with notes of pine, resin and grapefruit. Just a hint of doughy yeast. The flavor is moderately to heavily sweet and moderately bitter. The finish remains moderately bitter with a moderate amount of acidity. Medium body with lively carbonation. Soft texture that is slightly sticky. Enjoyable.

The beer pours a penny copper amber with a pale white head. The head is mostly lasting. The nose is a strong mix of bitter floral hops and citrus notes. The front of the beer is surprisingly smooth, the middle is where the action begins. The middle of the beer is full of sweet bitter hops the finish is full of floral hoppyness. The after taste is very staying.

Bottle. Pours a transparent golden copper with a lasting pale head with some decent lacing. The aroma is heavy in grapefruit and pine. Lots of botanic notes mixed in as well as some subtle sweet carmelly notes. Hops instantly bites your tongue as the brew enters the mouth with pine, grapefruit, and tons of grass as its initial flavours. The mouth feel is light and citrusy which adds to the slight sourness noticeable as the brew sits on the tongue. Some mild sweetness is barely noticeable. As the brew passes, bitterness explodes along with the pine flavours. Other flavours become a bit subdued. Surprisingly enough, the caramelly notes, even though subtle, still are pretty noticeable even with the intensification of the hops qualities. It’s pretty balanced up until the finish. The hops are pretty overwhelming. However, I actually enjoy the blast of hoppy bitterness.

Initially a very hoppy aroma and not much else - as it warmed the malt came through with caramel and vanilla.  Bright rusty orange, not much head.  Really well balanced within the style.  Big hops, not very sweet, crackery.  Not as much mouthfeel as I was expecting, in fact a little thin.  No complexity in the palate or aftertaste, but it’s pretty crisp.  My bottle said "Limited Release" and it was 8.4% ABV, which was well masked.  I’m appealing to the sysadmins regarding the bundling of Limited v. Unlimited Release.  Market Square Liquors.

12 oz bottle from Total Wine in Jacksonville, FL.  Pours a nice golden copper color with a white head. Nice aromas of hops and pine. Flavor is hoppy with plenty of malt.  Bitter hops finish, but a great beer none the less.
Lovely C hop aroma. Underbalanced with big grapefruit hops. Big bitter finish. Malt just doesn’t stand up, but I don’t really care. Love it.

hazy apricot color, fluffy head.  aroma of pine and grapefruit.  creamy grapefruit flavor, with a nicely hoppy bitterness in the palate.  medium bodied.  overall, a decent beer, if a bit mild for my idea of a double ipa.

50cl bottle from Carrollwood Liquors (Florida). Pours a hazy amber color with a thick, creamy white head. Smells strongly o ripe citrus and grapefruit, hints of lemon and spice. Strong citrus and grapefruit overtimes, hoppy with a slight spicey flavor. Notes of apricot and other fruits. Seems a little watery throughout and especially on the finish, but overall a nice Imperial IPA.
kick ass!! I love the Lagunitas Maximus. Incredibly crisp and citric. reall strong finish

Poured a dark orange with a small head. A bit watery if that is the right way to describe it for a IIPA but the flavor was very good. Tasted very citrusy with lemons and oranges and some other sweet flavors I couldn’t quite make out. Pretty good beer would definitely drink it again, but doesn’t have anything that makes it special.

Sampled in the presentation tent at WBF Raleigh. Light amber color with medium head. Nicely balanced sweet citrus hop aroma. Nice hop malt balance in the taste, though it falls short a bit at the back end before making one final comeback. Interesting.

Bottle 65 cl. Average beige bubbly head that mostly lasted. Clear sparkling body with a pale amber looking color. Good display of lacework. Aromas of sweet flower, pine, citrus, grapefruit, apricot and light malt. Over the palate came nice sweet fruity notes with well balanced hoppy crisp and fresh feel. Medium bodied with an average carbonation and dry mild oily texture. Moderated bitter and sweet in a very balanced way. Dry bitter flowery finish. Quit different notes of hops and very drinkable.

Pours a nice golden copper with a thick off white head.  Leaves plenty of lacing throughout the session.  Nice aroma of hops and pine.  Flavor is pretty balanced for such a hoppy beer.  Plenty of malt to keep things in check.  Nice and resinous...sticky on the lips.  Bitter hops finish.  Very nice beer.
Lagunitas Maximus is an orangish color IIPA that is pretty good but not one of my favorite Imperials.

Nice looking sunshine yellow with a creamy, pillowy head. A nice lacing remains on the glass.

Fresh hoppy aromas of fresh cut grass, grapefruit, citrus and pine. I’m not always good at separating out the individual aromas, but this seems to hit them all!

Great taste. Bitter, as expected, but also fresh and slightly sweet to balance.

Creamy mouthfeel. Goes down very easily!

Overall a nice beer, and recommended.

Bottle.  Poured a clear golden-copper color with a thick off-white head that left some nice spotty lacing.  Aroma of light citrus, some earthy hops, and a light pine.  Light caramel malt on entry leads into a sweet citrus flavor with a moderate hoppiness with a light earthy-leafiness.  Smooth, lightly bitter finish with some decent bite.  Not bad, pretty solid IPA.  I would like to try it really fresh.
Bottle, pours a clear orange with an offwhite head.  Aroma is sweet and hoppy!  Flavor is bitter and dry hops.  What a great deal for this beer only $3.50.  This is a classic great Double IPA
Nice and hoppy! I like this beer with its golden color and white lacing, to its hops in the nose and its amazing bitter taste...whats not to like!
bottle.  pours with a slight cream colored head.  aroma notes of citrus and pine.  First taste wonderful grapefruit notes.  Finish was little to hot with alcohol.
The Maximus name fits this 2XIPA, crammed with hops.  More than just the standard C-hops, over the top bitterness.   Thick bodied beer, one to savor not guzzle.

The color was golden/orange.  The head was creamy, thin, and white.  The aroma was apricot, citris, and hops.  The flavor was fermenting fruit, apricot, and hops.  The palate was medium-bodied.  The finish was warm.

Finally in NC.  Porus a copper amber with a sticky offwhite head. The pour is obviously more viscous than an average brew. The aroma is very intensely hoppy, resinous, citrusy, zesty. The flavor is also very intense, hoppy, waxy, bitter, citrusy, resinous, piney, earthy as well. Very nice hop flavor. Waxy bitter mouthfeel. very nice flavorful DIPA.
bottle.  Gooey hop laced ale w/ just enough malts to keep you drinking.  Syrupy tongue touched by a hint of alcohol & a slightly sharp pine/grapefruit linger.  Very nicely done, a real drinker.

Medium to dark orange pour with small off-white head.  Surprising nose at first--all I got was a deep astringent smell, but I could tell something was behind it... piney resin, malt, and faint grapefruit skin. Seemed overly resiny and perhaps sweet to me, not allowing the citrus of the hops to come out.  Still, I’m intrigued as this was a pretty distinctive brew to me.  Subsequent tastings may change my mind.  My bottle was 8.4%, not 7.5%, by the way, and the alcohol was definitely present on the palate.

Note: second tasting revealing more citrus and better balance, though overall impression was a little astringent.  I bumped it up a point.
I love this beer.  It’s big on aroma and flavor.  A creamy body and a really rich hop finish. Mmmmm, beeer.

Poured at Firkin Fest at Triple Rock, a hazy gold with ecru head, aromas of floral piney hops and a touch of malt sweetness.  The flavor comes in with a punch of caramel sweetness which quickly turns into a drying floral hop bitterness carrying pine and citrusy gratefruit notes.  Nice balance that is enhance by the small cask experience.  Good beer.

old rating:
7/4/7/3/14 - 3.5

pours a clear burnt orange with a large yellowish head, very good lacing.

smell of grapefruit, hops, touch of caramel.

taste is creamy, hoppy, caramel, touch of citrus, a bit sweet, some roasted nuts in the back, end is a little bitter with a thick mouth-feel.

Wonderfully balanced and rich DIPA. Golden amber with a thick white head. Massive hop nose with piney and citrusy notes. Devilish hops up front with a subdued malt sweetness balancing things out. Very, very nice.

Bottle. Light to moderate malt aromas of cookie and caramel, heavy smells of pine and grapefruit for the hops, light broth for the yeast, and currant and date in the background. Head is small and white with fair lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is murky orange tan. Flavor is lightly sweet and acidic to start and the long finish is lightly acidic and moderately bitter. Palate is medium, oily and the carbonation is lively. A very nicely balanced DIPA with no negative characteristics

What ever hops these guys use I love them.  Great piney aroma and flavor are the signature of the Lagunitas hop brews.  I always tend to head for the hoppy beers but these guys got it!!!  Great balance overall and I love the pine aroma and flavor.

660ml bottle, bright golden color, with a frothy white head, sweet toasted malt and nice floral hop nose, of coniferous, cedary, piney accents, with some orange, candied apricot notes, hint of toffee in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a toasty, caramelized malt, juicy flowery hop character of pine niddle, leafiness, cedary, coniferous, a bit resiny too, with a mild fruity accent of citrus, candied orange peel and manderine, with an intense hoppy warmth muothfeel, leading towards a good leafy hop dry bitterness finish.
the pour is coppery orange,thin white head.aroma is very hoppy,and citrusy.this is in my opinion,the best bang for your buck,iipa

22oz.  Poured hazy darkish orange with a white head.  Nose was mostly hops and citrus, body followed with some more concentrated flavors and the slight notion of vanilla.  Pretty enjoyable but nothing too crazy.

Pours a reddish-copper color into a snifter.  Small head of off-white foam that quickly dissipates.  This beer has a distinct piney-citrusy aroma that tastes like leaves a bit of piting pine in my mouth at the finish.  This is the best Lagunitas beer I’ve tasted to date; still kind of mellow for a double IPA.  Would definitely drink again.  Good stuff.
12 oz. pours clear and copper with small head. mild citrus aroma with a bit of caramel. mouthful is bright with citrus and a smooth malt. finnish is crisp with little linger. great ipa.

22 oz bottle.  Pours a clear golden-amber color with a slight white head.  Aroma is very present, grapefruit/citrus and hops.  Flavor is a very fruity, with tart hops and some grapefruit notes.  Maximus finishes with a banana flavor and a hoppy aftertaste.   One of the fruitiest IPA’s I’ve had, and I mean that in a good way.  This is a very complex brew, something I’d recommend without hesitation.

Nice looking beer. Has a very nice head, and a transparent caramel/gold color. The head doesn’t fade away very fast. Very piney aroma. My word this beer is aromatic. There is also a citrus hop aroma that I can smell. I have had a lot of IPAs and I truly believe that this is the only one that I have smelled where the hop aromas are seperated. The other IPAs you have to try very hard to smell the different hops used, but this is obvious. There is also a slight sweet aroma in this beer, bringing out the malty flavour. The citrus hop and the pine hop are coming through in the flavor, and the malty flavour is also there. The hops are everywhere in this beer. It is very good. The beer is not as creamy as I would like it to be, but it is very good. I am surprised by how good this is. Fairly impressed with the hop profile, but the palate is not up to par with everything else.

This beer is exactly what they said.  If you have had the Lagunitas IPA before, then this is pretty much a hoppier version of the same beer.  It’s malty and sweet, and dangerously drinkable for 8.5%.  The hops and malt are pretty evenly matched.  The malt finally gives way to the a slightly bitter hops finish.  The heavy malt presence reminded me of the Hop Devil.

Bottle. Pours a dark amber with thin head. Wonderful floral aroma of grape, pineapple, spruce and hops. Taste is maltier and a bit caramel-sweet, dryer, but tasty, finish with quite a sting of alcohol.
Bottle pours out an amber topped with a off white cream head. A very nice aroma of citrus hops. Tast more of the hops along with a little sweet caramel. Very nice brew to drink any time.

Good sweet malt, honey, and hops aromas with pineapple notes.  Rose orange colors with a whitish head.  Flavors are the same as the aroma with a good balance of sweet and bitter.  Mild palate.  Fruity and sweet with a good hoppy backbone.  Very enjoyable and drinkable.

22oz bottle.   Clear orange-amber with a small creamy head.   Fruity and floral aroma with tobacco, mango, grapefruit.   Pretty mellow flavor for a dipa, but drinkable as well.   Creamy and citric, with light prolonged bitterness.   medium body comes off a little thin for the strength.   Small bubbles.   Not enough flavor for a double for me, but their regular IPA is more drinkable and comes off as hoppier for me too.
Pours orangish color with big, rocky off white head. Citrusy hop aroma. Sweet flavor with lots of hops and some malts to balance it out. Overall a decent IIPA, very good for the price.

Pours orange/amber with no bubbles and a medium off-white foamy head.  Nice fresh hop aroma with citrus, mango and peach.   Pretty salty stuff with a somewhat weak body.  Still the flavor is impressive.  Tropical fruits emerge and it gets quite juicy.  Some tingle in the mouth from the hops.   Not the greatest double... but pretty damn good.

big nose on this.... very sweet with a side of hops.  pour is brown golden with a bubbly head that retains fairly well and laces the glass.  The front end on this is sweet, and the sweetness is immediately thinned out by the perfect shot of hops.  medium big body and really a not too overpowering aftertaste.  I could say that the commercial description makes sense because it is awfully similar to the regular IPA, but bigger.  and thats why i gotta say I like it that much more because of it.  Beautiful Job.  Little too sweet, but easily one of my favorites.  If you could find the medium of this and Stone’s Ruination, I’d be all over it.
Hazy orange with a high head. Powerfull aromatic hops all the way through: grape and lemon with some alcohol to notice. Too much I’m afraid.

750 ml bottle, RBNAG07. Amber colour. Lightly cloudy. Tall fine-laced light beige head. Oily sweet malty nose. Drying hoppy aroma with a slight medicinal aroma. Smooth texture cut by rich and sharp hops. Bitter hops nicely balanced by sweetish malts.

Nice amber poor with decent head.  Smell of pine and some citrus.  Has a good flavor but not very intense for a double IPA in my opinion.  I like it but if I want extreem hops there are two or three others I would go to.  Dont get me wrong I like it.  Its somewere between a double and regular IPA.
Pours a dark amber.  Smells is simple and full of hops and spices.  The flavor is bitter yet sweet.  Overall a nice balance and is very drinkable.
A Tasting at Three Cellars Milwaukee.  A “softer” IPA if you will very nice beer.
At Three Cellars tasting. Light orange with pine and sweet hop aroma. Nicely balanced with sweet malt followed by citric hop finish. Good stuff!

Big Bottle. Poured a clear medium amber. Creamy, light-khaki colored thin head stayed around for some time. Excellent carbonation. Aroma was of hops, plain and simple. Tase was hoppy with a very, very light, almost nonexistent hint of malt. Aftertaste was also very pleasant. Definitely a repeat buy.
wonderful IPA, nice palate and head, tremendously balanced and drinkable - hops are not overpowering but delicious
tasty beer.  nothing real special, piney hop flavor, a little sweet at the end.  very drinkable for a beer of 7.5%.
Very tasty beer.  Has a nice piney and citrus aroma.  Finished very clean and is easy drinking.
Great looking beer.  Piney hops over a rather sweet malt base.  Pretty tasty.

2-21-08 bottle.  


Clear orange amber in color with a nice fluffy white "IPA head". Aroma is sweet hops, but weak overall.  Flavor is decent.  Not as hoppy and balanced as I had hoped for.  Mouthfeel is actually quite smooth and complements the flavor nicely.  Overall, a bit weak and boring but drinkable nonetheless.
Poured amber with a fluffy off white head. Aroma of pine and hops. Lots of hops flavor up front with some pine. Finished clean and sort of wet. Not bad at all.

Bottle from Aggie Liquor in Davis.  This one is a mix between Stone IPA and Green Flash Imperial IPA with a mostly smooth palate.  On one end, you have a complex, hoppy flavors of Grapefruit and citrus that hits you immediately, but it’s also rich and smooth to boot.  There was a slight aftertaste, which is my only ding on the rating.  Still, very good.
Bottle. Orange/amber color, small white head. Creamy, fruity, hoppy aroma, some vanilla, some grapfruit. Quite hoppy, grassy perfume flavor, fruity notes, dry, bitter and with some fruit.

Poured a copper color and the smell of hops exploded out of the bottle. Flavors of citrus, mainly grapefruit dominated the taste. The hops are mostly tasted in the aftertaste which brought down my rating a bit. Better control of the hops would make this a great beer.

A rather boring IIPA. Aroma was decent. Earthy hops with some caramel in the background. Pour was a medium clear gold with a one finger off white head. Taste was very sweet. Sticky caramel malt with a medium mouthfeel and the hops don’t come in until the aftertaste. As it warms the hops come out more but are still in the backseat.

On cask at Redlight. Mmmmm, been waiting for this. Pumps out of the tap a hazy amber with a thin white head. Temperature was a slight chill, really a perfect temp. The aroma was a huge bouquet of grapefruit and pine. The taste is spicy, hoppy with a grapefruit like tang to it from the huge amount of hops. A little thinner body than I expected. Finishes with a dry bitter citrus finish. Because of the cask temp, I made sure to go extra slow drinking this, because it goes down WAYYYY to easy.

Cask @ Redllight. Mmm. Sweet but understated hop aroma. Grapefruit rind and a little candied apricot, maybe some sweaty shirts. Very clean flavor up front, with light bready malts followed by a dose of prickly grapefruit hops. The low carbonation gives this an easy feel without lacking anything. Hoppy finish lingers with plenty of resins. Hints of white pepper and tobacco also in the finish. Deep copper color, poured with a modest had but leaves sheets of symmetrical lace.This one just disappears from the glass.

Wow, what an underrated IPA.  Pours a beautiful reddish golden color. filtered.  Head is slightly orange with a good consistency.  Very tastey head.  Great mouth-feel and bang of hops.  A very good well rounded IPA.  The raging hops calm for a flowery aftertaste.  I drank a Two Hearted Ale right after and it seemed to bring out all of the flaws of the Bells.  Not even in the same ball park as other Imperials.  Thou shalt not drink IPA with less then 7% or more then 9%

Nice fresh DIPA, although it wasn’t as thick as some, which helps the fresh-ness come through.  Lots of grapefruit in the whole bottle.  Mild and drinkable through all the hops, which gets it another point or two.  Balance is very good.

bottles from Beerlando and Liquid solutions.  This one from L.S.


Pours clear amber with a nice offwhite and lasting head in a tulip.  Smell is caramel mostly and a slighty hoppy twinge to it, but it is very understated for a double IPA.  Perhaps the hops have just faded.  Flavors of caramel and tea like hops.  Mild bitterness, thin, yet syrupy sweet at times.  Decent, I guess, but needs more hops, unless this is an old bottle...

bomber from grape & gourmet. aroma is very hoppy with hints of pine, pistachio, and fruit and almost sweet. the color is a light amber with very good lacing. flavor is impressive with a great balance of hops and malt with a smooth aftertaste. perfect amount of alcohol. overall, a very quality beer.

This is a good IPA..... Right up there with Lost Coast and LaConner in IPA’s from breweries whose name starts with the letter  L......

Clear yellow gold color like Apple cider.  
Aroma of soap, cut grass, white wine and apples.


Dry and medium astringent like white wine.   Warming mouth that seems to melt away.....Very Nice palate.

Flavor fruity up front, then strong piney citrus hops balanced nicely by malt.  finshes with pancakes + Jam.

Bomber.  Clear mid-orange color.  Citrus hop aroma.  Great hop flavor of pine, tangerines, and grapefruit.  Nice sweet malt backbone complements the hops, great balance.  Nothing overwhelms, perfect mouthfeel and great flavor.  Good stuff!

1/3/08 @ the Tour @ the Brewery with Bikesandbeer, 8th Brewery of the trip, 1st of 3 of the day.  Bomber @ the Brewery.  Pours orange with an off white tan ring.  Nose was dead on this bottle.  Taste is sweet, piney, hoppy and mellow.

Bottle.  Caramel orange coloring.  Icy, static surface foam.  Buttery, hoppy, pear, paint-thinner.  Bitterness assaults the tongue and stays prominently present throughout.  Tangy, ammonia, nectarine combination . . . a very odd mix.  Like drinking a very pleasing household cleaner.  Strangely, I like it.

22 oz bottle.  Hazy orange pour.  Aroma is strong citrus, very grassy.  Taste is a nice mix of bitterness and citrus which trails off at the end.  Think Great Divide Hercules at 70% strength.  Very similar compositions.

~Golden amber colour. Nice white head.
~The aroma is great! Nice strong grassy hops. Makes my mouth water.
I could sniff this all day. I wish they made a cologne.
~Bittersweet flavor with emphasis on the earthy hops. A bit of citrus.
Not as hoppy as I had expected from the scent.
~Palate is a little thick and chewy.
~A well done brew, but I am still waiting for the king brew of IPA’s to 
grace my lips. This is my favorite IPA to date.

Bottle, 7.5%. Nice, sweet and caramelly hop aroma. Clear copper colour, small white head. The flavour is quite sweet, caramelly. Grassy from the hops with a good, cleansing bitterness. The finish has a little teaish hoppiness along with a good alcohol note. Quite flavourful but still well-balanced. 8 4 8 4 19



Bottle, 8.2%. Good grapefruity hop aroma. Clear copper colour. Small stable white head. The flavour starts off sweetish with a good caramelly hop note. Mild hop bite. Teaish finish.  8 4 8 4 18

A well done double IPA. Big and beautiful fruit and resiny hops. Refreshing, although thick. Drinkable with nice balance making this more tahn one dimensional. Does not leave an overly bitter hop bite, just a nice warm, lingering fruitiness.

Sampled at Sexual Chocolate Day. I’d had this beer previously but hadn’t enjoyed it this much. A very big floral nose gives a strong first impression. The mouthfeel is very thick and satisfying, abetted by the creamy head. Nice zingy hops dominate, with some almost peppery sharpness in there. Good stuff.

Sampled on-tap. Pours a basically clear orange/brown/amber. Nose is strong piney hops. Flavor is very hopped but let’s say it’s one step below a hop bomb. Long lasting aftertaste. Strong pine character. Feel is a bit syrupy on the liquid and good on the bubble. Drinkable, yes. But this one is kind of thick and might turn people off a bit with it’s unique characteristics.

In the bomber bottle from Total Beverage. Pours amber with a large off white head of considerable staying power. Nice grapefruit citrus hop aroma. Flavor is sweet enough to balance out the hop load, so this actually ends up a surprisingly smooth beer to drink instead of the hop bomb that I was expecting.
in bottle, thanks to sledge jr. A delightfully hoppy beer with a quick flash of floral, followed by grassy citrusness.  palate is excellent, due to fine malt content. Truly enjoyable.

An easy red amber color with medium white head.  Sharp hops and floral cirtus scents.  Earthy bitterness and light body without much structure.  Good carbonation and lower alcohol round out the finish.
My current favorite. Perfect harmony between hops and malt. Beautiful nose - citrus and flowers. Quite bitter, but not overdone.

Pours a deep honey orange color with a semi thick frothy white head that laces the glass. Smells of hoppy citrus but also a bit flowery as well. The hoppy taste is not overly bitter it is more subdued, somewhat sweet. A bit more grassy on the taste than on the nose. Has the mouthfeel of a much higher ABV IPA like Dreadnaught or Stone 10th. Kind of thick, carbonation is a bit on the low side, more heavy sweet than bitter. This is a great session DiPA at 7.5% ABV not too high, not too low.
Amber color with a quality white head.  Nice floral aroma, sweet flavor that complements the bitterness.  Nicely balanced and pretty good overall.

Bottle.  Pours a good golden amber, with an ok white head.  Aroma, hop heavy and tending towards the floral side, with a bit of citrus to balance.  Flavor is of good hops, heavy again on the floral with citrus to mellow it a bit.  Medium body, light on the tongue, but full in the mouth.  Good hop bitter finish.  Great IPA.

Nothing special; A very strong India pale ale, both in flavor and in buzz-factor. Basically tastes like grapefruit juice and vodka. Release should be limited, contrary to "Unlimited Release" decree on bottle.
barely qualifying as a double, and therefore a very drinkable brew.  strong hops nose not much body, long bitter tail.

Pleasant surprise all-around here.  Beautiful golden red color with a fast head.  Sweet floral aroma of tart cherries, apple, orange.  Sweet crisp greeting with some expected citrus, barely noticeable alcohol, and bitter but relatively clean aftertaste.

bottle....been in the fridge for a few months so it’s probably not at its freshest....poured a semi-transparent orange brown with a frothy white to off white head....floral and citrus notes in the nose combines with some malts but not too much....flavor of crisp citrus hops with a bitterness that lingers a bit in the finish but it’s not obtrusive in any way.  not too much in the way of malts and overall it is quite dry.....way better than the Oddysey just tried and is a bargain DIIPA for the price.

Lagunitas Maximus IPA
Pours an orange-amber color, fizzy white head.  Aromas of apple, pear, hops.  First sip reveals more pear, sour blueberry, lingering and savory hops.

22 oz. bomber.  waxy pineapple on nosing. good clarity in pint glass, nice head, lacing sticks to glass and on palate nice clean hop flavors, excellent balance and long, long, long clean bitter finish. very good ipa, this bottle doesnt stand a chance. actually enjoyed this more than the two-hearted. will look into others styles from this brewery. could be new go to ipa!! outstanding
pours a clear brown gold with full white head.  very floral citrus hop aroma.  hoppy mild citrus, floral front with bitter dry finish.  good.
Wanted to try this, especially given the price (nice and cheap).  Poured a nice golden color.  Taste is light tropical and citrus.  Fairly light flavor for a double IPA.  Very drinkable.

I will call this one the Workin’ Man’s IPA since the price is usually about 3.99 for a 22oz.  Can’t go wrong w/that!  Good hoppy IPA for the HOPHEAD!  Pours with a nice fluffy head and light amber colored body!  Sweet!
Very good IPA for the price.  Pours a light copper color with a nice head.  If your short on cash grab this one and try it out, you might just get hooked.

bottle: pours a clean cooper orange with a white head some lacing. aroam is grapefruit peel citrus hops a little bitter. little ot no malt adn a small peppery aroma. flavour is a bitter hops again no malt anywhere. finishes with more hop bitterness that lingers as an affter taste also some peppery flavour. good hop but no malt at all to balance it out.

Clear sparkling amber, creamy off white head.  Hop blast of pink grapefruit and candied orangey pine that rest on a soft sweet malt undertone.  Bitter piney citrus flavors warm to nutty earth-like notes.  Hop loaded from start to finish.  Medium bodied, medium carbonation, bitter finish (as expected).  A well made strong (not double) IPA in my book.  Price can’t be beat either at $4 / bomber….

My New Years beer.. opened 10 minutes to midnight, finished 30 minutes thereafter. Extremely over hopped, and not in a good way. Matches your Dogfish Head in the extreme hop category, but it was so overpowering that that the subtletry is gone. A little chewy malt, that if you let it sit on your mouth a while an let the hops wash over, you can get. Not thin on the tongue, bridging on chewy. Golden orange/yellow color when poured. Little fizzy, but since this is not a winter beer, it was not what I wanted after-all, I’ll re-visit this after the second bottle, but style-wise, as the D-IPA, it is at least representative. (Bottle Pour 12/31/2007 -1/1/2008)
Bottle. An unclear orange beer with an orange head. The aroma is sweet hoppy and grassy. The flavor is sweet hoppy with a dry hoppy end. Quite simple, but nice. Kind of lacking.

22oz, paid 3.99 for it though and at that price this is a steal.. tastes like an IPA looks dark amber like an IPA and has lots of hops like an IPA seems to me Lagunitas has really hit the mark with this one.. only quirk... low ABV :D
Nice golden color, small white head.  Nice hops flavor with a littlle less bitterness than you get in some others, which was nice.  Very nice brew.
Very well balanced brew. Typical West Coast hop profile. Very easy to drink....too many.

Bottle, 22oz. (RBNAG 07) An orange-golden, slightly hazy beer, poured with an off-white head. Sweetish nose with all the joys of American hops dominating. The same goes for the flavor, lots of pine, resin, citrus and fruityness, as well as a lot of sweetness, but far from overpowering the hops. Full body, and so hoppy it almost feels a bit astringent in the mouth. A lovely beer, but maybe a bit too hoppy, meaning that it is more a hop juice than a beer. (071103)
Nice honey aroma, and amazingly balanced flavor with a long finish. Easily one of my favorite beers this year.
Very piney/citrus aroma and taste.  Beautiful golden amber, medium lace, and small soft head.  Nice hoppy beer.

Wonderful piney grapefruit hop aroma, even on the second whiff, thick mouth feel that tremendous high powered malt hop blend. not quite as wide and bold as Dogfish head, but still a classic taste. falls apart a little at the end and becomes a little alcohol y, but still a great brew
A hazy amber, small head. Hop smell. Big citrus flavor is a sweet bitter finish. Spicy. Very good at $4.00.
22oz bottle. Pours amber with orange highlights. Aroma is light grapefruit. Taste is nice on the tounge. very nice IPA and the price is nice.

Here is a DIPA for the ages! Everything about this ale is superb, from the citrus aroma to the perfectly balanced aftertaste. In between are a nice copper/orange color, a beautiful off-white head with excellent lacing and a taste that tells you it’s a DIPA - not by its strength but by its depth. Mouthfeel is opulent. All this combines to perfectly integrate the higher alcohol content. Definitely a keeper.

I might not be the world’s biggest Lagunitas, but I gotta call it like I taste it and this is one tasty DIPA. Quite excellent really in every phase, and easily one of the top 25 DIPA’s out there I think. Aroma is a really nice 1-2 punch of piney and citrusy hop goodness, but it’s more than just that. There a lingering perfumey character that is really noticeable and a touch of malty sweetness. Appearance is a solidy, hazy medium orange in color with a beautiful, thick and creamy off-white head that had some great staying power. Looked quite beautiful the entire time with suprising lacing after every sip. Mouthfeel was sily smooth. No harshness here, no overcarbonation. Flavors were well integrated with a pleasant hop/malt combo that was neither overwhelming or too subtle. I think this was about as balanced as I like my DIPA’s to be and still have enough hop profile to please me. Orange, tangerine, and grapefruit are really at the forefront with this beer. Very nice and I think this is something that I know I can go to on a regular basis now. If you see it, don’t expect to be blasted by a ton of hoppage. What you get with this one is a signifigant difference than some DIPA’s, which is to say it’s balanced. Highly recommended.

Surprised to find I hadn’t rated this one.  Nice amber color with a medium head.  Aroma is very citrus-hop centric with a nice bit of malty sweetness coming through.  Flavor is a nice grapefruit/citrus/sweet bready malt combo that works well all around.  Nice tingly, hoppy mouthfeel.  More like a stronger IPA than a DIPA, but who cares?  Similar to Kill Ugly Radio in many ways.  Solid DIPA!

650ml bottle from Bevmo. Pours a rich copper color with a one finger white head that has good retention time. The aroma is ripe with citrus--mostly grapefruit and oranges--and a touch of caramel. The flavor mirrors the aroma with a fair amount of biter hops added. The hops dominate but are not overbearing, as there are plenty of  superbly balanced sweet caramel malts. The mouthfeel is smooth, silky and full with perfect carbonation. The finish is short and clean. The alcohol is well integrated. Overall: This is one of the great IPA’s. Recommended

Pours crystal clear with a firm head. Aroma is huge cascade, with some hints of crystal malt.
Flavor is big hops upfront but with a strong malt backing, lots of crystal, yet fairly light body. Alcohol is apparent, but not aggressive or overwhelming.
Definitely one of the top IPAs out there.

More of an IPA than a DIPA, but a fine tasting brew nonetheless.  Nice balance, wonderful hop aroma escapes the glass, taste is balanced between bitterness and sweet malt.  Super balance, and a great IPA.

Gold with a pillow of white head formation on top.  The aroma is gorgeously strong of flowery fresh hops with a layer of citrus hiding behind.  It delightfully adds to the anticipation of tasting the beer bellow.  The flavor is surprisingly light on bitter hoppiness upfront.  While the hops are clearly noticeable, the bitterness is well masked by the citrus and sweetness.  The body is easy to cut through and the alcohol is deceptively tame making this a dangerous IPA in the wrong hands.  I could drink this all night.
Bottle at RBNAG 07. Golden / orange colour with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, hop, citrus. flavour is sweet, hop, citrus, hay. nice beer.

Bottled. Pours honey-colored, off-white head. Nose is hops, resin, citrus, and pine. Flavor is surpirsingly sweet, with hop resin, grapefruit, and pine notes. Finishes with a nice hop bite. Sticky mouthfeel.

golden amber appearance with slight white head and very slight carbonation.  flavor is well balanced with both a strong malt character and pronounced hop presence.  no hint of the 7.5 percent alcohol.  only knock would be the extreme balance makes the beer somewhat unremarkable despite how impressive that balance may be

Bomber, pours a clear golden orange with a large white head, great lacing.  Aroma is piney hops, with some grass and citrus.  Flavor is similar with more pine and grass, and a fairly subtle bite.  On the milder end for a DIPA, but pleasant and enjoyable all the same.

Bomber pours a crystal clear copper with lasting off white head and spotty lacing. Nice aroma mixture of pine hops and mild sweet malts plus crystal malts. The taste is similar with up front pine and grassy hop bitterness followed by mild sweet malts and a dash of earthiness. Midway grapefruit hop bitterness takes over. The malts and hops meet at the finish on equal terms creating nice balance. The after taste is mild with lingering hop bitterness.

Bomber. Pours a nice amber color.Aroma is hops and citrus. Taste is hops and citrus with some fruits. Very smooth very for a double. You no not get huge dose of hops like a double. Still a very good beer with good drinkablitiy
660ml bottle @ RBNAG’07. Hazy orange body with a medium beige head. Aroma is really lovely citrus hoppy and hay. Flavor is sweet warming hoppy, lots of hops but no extreme impression. Very nice.

22oz bottle.  Pours a clear honey golden color with a nice compact, creamy white head and good lacing.  Aroma is earthy, pungent hops.  A bit spicy with a strong malt background.  Taste is balanced with a vanilla like malt presence and bitter hops.  Don’t know how old this is but it doesn’t taste super fresh.  Still it’s drinking quite nicely and is a nice, drinkable, balanced example of the style if not a hop bomb that I prefer.
[ Thanks to fonefan ] Cobber of color with a beige head. An aroma of hops, grass, liqurice and malt. A flavor of grapefruit, hops, malty notes and liqurice.

Pine and a bit of citrus in the aroma. Hops that smack you in the face. This brewery does no wrong for me. Not available in Missouri, but supposedly available just over the Illinois border. Excellent double IPA without the heavy malts that many have.

Dense one finger beige head over an unclear copper colored body. Moderate (for the style) fruity and grassy hop aroma. Whiffs of caramel and earth. Sweetish malts and a fair amount of bittering hops in the flavor. Clean mouthfeel. Medium body. Long bitterness in the finish. Nice. (Bottle @ RBNAG’07)

Pours a hazy amber colour with a large rocky-frothy off white head. Aroma is fruity, with lots of hops. Initial taste is soft fruity and sweet malts. Mouthfeel is a soft carbonation with a bitter hop that coats the entire palate. Head retention is good and the lacing the glass looks absolutely excellent, completely slapped and pasted over. Long, good finish.  Wonderful!

Bottle. Unclear medium orange color with a average, frothy / creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, beige head. Aroma is moderate to light heavy hoppy, grass, pine, citrus, light to moderate malty, caramel. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. (271007)

Pillowy whitehead that stands the test of time. Lovely lace and a big floral hop aroma. In a nutshell a classic California hoppy IPA that is very resinous. The palate is dry and bitter with tropical fruit and orange scented hops. The finish is long and hoppy with a dash of malt to keep this beer honest.

Once again, this style fails to appease me.  I was dissapointed because Lagunitas classic IPA is one of the best.  However, this one, with only hints of the original, is overpowered by the grapefruity hops.  If you like a sour and bitter ale, this is for you.

Sampled bottle, RBNAG 2007 in Grimstad. ABV was 7.5%. Amber to orange colour, decent head. Nice hoppy aroma, not as strong as expected. Distinctly hoppy flavour throughout, but not really that extreme. Good beer.

Pours a hazy large particulated amber colour with a large rocky-frothy off white head.  Aroma is fruity, with lots of hops. Initial taste is soft fruity and sweet malts. Mouthfeel is a soft carbonation. Moving into a bitter hop that coats the entire palate. Light red berried candy also lingers in the background palate. Head retention is good and the lacing the glass looks absolutely excellent, completely slapped and pasted over. Palate duration is also good. Overall enjoyable.
66 cl bottle. Copper color, off-white head. Hops and fruit. Very sweet. (RBNAG’07 in Grimstad Nov. 3th.)

The aroma is super hoppy with pine and a biscuit maltiness. The appearance is amber with a foamy head. The flavor is like the aroma. It’s rather bitter. The palate is smooth. Overall this is a good beer but not the best IIPA that I have had.

Small white head. Hazy orange body with yeast particles. Deep sweet firm straw and malt aroma with fruity medicinal notes. Honeyish. Dry sweetish straw and malts taste with medicinal notes. Clean, sharp mouthfeel. Very nice! (0.66l bottle at RBNAG’07.)
This beer was REALLY sweet for an IPA.  It tasted like it was loaded with sugar and hops.  It wasn’t bad, however it was a little too sweet for my liking.

Pours cloudy burnt orange with small creamy head. Aroma is very malty sweet- sort of honey like- plus woody, resinous hops. Flavor is very malty, woody, and syrupy sweet like apricot as well as citrusy orange. Ends with sappy, woody bitterness and smooth, creamy palate. Not my favorite type of hopping, but good nonetheless....not sure if the hopping matched the malt increase for this IIPA tho.

Bottle. Pours a light amber with a nice fluffy head, decent lacing. Aroma of caramel malt and citrus hops. Very citrusy start, has a little more malt sweetness in the middle than I am used to for an IIPA, but it finishes with a nice bit of hoppy dryness. This is a very solid beer, but not quite a Double in my opinion, sort of bigger than an IPA but not big enough to be a Double/Imperial. Semantics of IPA-IIPA aside,  it is very enjoyable indeed, growing on me more as I work my way through the 22oz bottle. I see many more in my future.

Aroma is flowery hops.  Clear orange amber hue with an averaged sized head that left good lacing.  Flavor starts fresh and ends bitter.  Palate is watery and alcohol.  A very good brew but alcohol is way to apparent for only 7.5% ABV.

Poured a nice copper color with average sized head.  The floral aromas are strong with some citrus notes.  The flavor was nice, a little mellow for an IIPA though.  Had bright grapefruit and pine flavors, with a nice caramel hint.  The dry biscuity flavor is nice on the frontend and blends well with the respectable bitterness on the back. Overall, I did like the flavor and strength of this IIPA, but didn’t care for the structure or overall flavor of these hops...There seemed to be too much going on, with little impact of a certain variety of hops.  Very drinkable Imperial with good complexity and flavor, but really wasn’t impressed with overall taste.

Poured a bright, clear copper-orange color. Created a tight and dense 1/2" white head with decent retention and some wispy lacing. Slightly muted but pleasant aromatic notes of feshly cut oranges, grapefruit and pineapple. Smells of pine, biscuits and malts linger in the bcakground. Palate is fairly full and fluffy with a slight oily texture. Taste starts out with a nice citrus peel blast of bitter high alpha acid hops; crisp and lip-smacking. Soon to follow is a smooth tongue coating of subtly sweet caramel candy malt and tropical fruits to balance things out. Finish is slightly dry and bittersweet. Alcohol is faintly perceived in the background. Overall a solid and sessionable DIPA.

This one’s ridiculously good, mayhaps the best I2PA I’ve had.  Definitely better than the Ruination IPA I had the other night, which is 4.3-4.4 quality.  Lagunitas has this hop thing down just about as well as Stone.
My second Lagunitas brew....and again I’m fully impressed.   Clean, cereal taste, mostly clear light pale yellow body.  Similar to their Kil Ugly Radio IPA....not quite as Hoppy.  Full bodied, tasty.

22 oz bottle from bottletrek.com.  All I can really say is, "damn good".   Pours orange with a creamy  head and tons of sticky lacing.  Big citrus and floral aroma with a subtle maltiness.  Flavor is very similiar, but very well balanced between malt and hops.   Lasting bitterness, oily mouthfeel and alcohol is barely detectible.  This is a awesome West Coast IIPA.   Must be put in your regular rotation.

liquorloft tallahassee.Very much like there single IPA, spicy hops blended on top of citrus. very nice malt backbone. nose is strong citrus hops and malt. lasting bitter finish but not as bitter as other styles.
Bottle. Sweet malty aroma with no head. The taste is malty with nice sweetness and good citrus hop bitterness. Got MUCH better as it warmed. Very good brew. Thanks to whoever sent me this.

Orange-copper with good, creamy off-white head / Pine & citrus nose / Medium body with big fruit balancing big hops, with biting hop finish / Flavors of pine, grapefruit, orange, resin, and lemon, with candied sugar finish.

Orange amber with a good head. Malty caramel & fine hop aroma. Flowery & piney. Very fresh & crisp. Fruity & elegant.

 Rerate July 09: Very sweet malty profile. Caramel and bread. Ok hops as well but way too sweet malty.

Bomber:  Aroma is a nice citrus hop texture, not as much as I expected from a double IPA.  With a pine note lingering together makes the actual scent of this brew really well balanced in my opinion.  Appearance is a light copper with a foamy white head that has some retention.  Taste has got a pungent hop front. Big on hops, not much malt characteristics, with a pine note and fruity undertones, and a real earthy flavor to this brew.  Palate is bitter with the hop texture coming through.  Overall, It’s OK.  It really did not impress or dissuade me at all.  It’s kind of just OK, above average, but just OK.
Great color in the glass with nice head retention. Nose is subdued but present. Well balanced between malt and hop. Nice every day I.P.A.

Aroma of spiced hops.  Palate is thin.  Little or no head.  What I like about this beer is its fairly clean, and has a solid citrus-herbal hop presence.  But what I don’t like is the body is a little watery, and the finish seems off to me.  Its almost a weak sweetness/bitterness that reminds me of eating an orange after brushing my teeth.  I’ve noticed this is some microbrew IPAs.  I would like the beer to be a little more solid, with better body, especially if its supposed to be an IIPA.  But overall, I find it enjoyable and pretty tasty.

Had this beer on 7/27/2004.  Aroma is fresh and full of hops.  Color is a deep orange/gold with fair carbonation and a nice tight head.  Taste is bitter, sweet and almost fruity.  Starting with a medium body it goes down with a smooth feel and a mild bite.  Finish comes in with a sweet malt flavor that has a fruity flavor to it.  Then a sharp bitterness with a mild hop flavor floats in on the end.  As you drink a bit more of it the fruit flavor fades and the bitterness seems to build.  Well balanced but it needs a bit more hop flavor.

Lots of fruit that just pops out at you. I think it could be a little bit more balanced flavor wise, but my buddy who does not drink IPA’s loved it, so go figure. Overall a great so-cal IPA with lots of hops and lots of citrus flavors. Nice change-up if your used to drinking Stone or Bear Republic.
Grapefruit aroma and taste to start, but ends with nice hop bitterness. Medium body. Copper color and clear.

Bomber.  Pours a cloudy coppery orange with a thick white head.  Excellent lacing on the glass.  Extreme floral notes with a bit of citrus.  The flavor was initially bitter, but with a nice malt balance. Plenty of citrus in the flavor.  Medium mouthfeel.  Very well done brew.

Pours a hazy, straw color into the tulip with a two inch white head.  A sticky lace coated the glass.  The scent was flowery hops, citrus and spice.  A very bitter beer with a harsh play on the palate.
Well done IPA, more like a 1 1/2 IPA. Sweetness, sourness, and bite are all there. Just noticed this is classified as a double IPA, which is probably more appropriate. Nice.

A decent Double IPA - very hoppy, with some citrus, not much pine, and caramel maltiness. On second analysis - this stuff is DANK Like Indica IPA, this stuff tastes like you’re eating a bong hit, in a good way :)
NIce and overly hoppy.  Just like a double IPA should be.  Grapefruit and caramel.

Pours a coppery orange color with a thin wispy white head. The aroma is of piney hops, citrus fruits, grapefruit, and some malts. The hops hit you first, but not overpowering and are followed with a slightly sweet malt backbone. There was a good amount of grapefruit flavor, some floral notes, and malt sweetness. There wasn’t as much hops as I would of thought, but it was still good. It was medium to full bodied with a hop bitterness finish to it. Pretty solid for an IPA, but not enough hops to be a double.

Copper beer with a frothy off-white head that leaves some lacing. Big American hop aroma, with citrus, pine, pineapple, peach and roses. The little malt sweetness is quickly taken over by intense hop flavour, and bitterness, but the sweetness is definitely there. A think mouthfeel that is a bit overdone for my liking.
Very tasty IPA. Pours out dark amber. Very hoppy with a smooth finish. Tasty beer.

22oz Bomber

Deep golden color with a thin head.  This had a strong hops aroma from the start.  Loved the flavor and with a strong hops presnece.  The beer was deep in flavor and the malts used also came through which can be hard for strong IPA’s  Has some dry after affects but this was good and very tasty.  Great Beer.

Clear amber/bronze and 3cm of dense off white foam that settles slowly to a thin layer. Aroma of resinous, piney, herbal, and lightly citrusy hops with some lightly sweet malt in the background. Flavor has clear grapefruit, adds some vegetation, floral notes, and more sweetness. Medium/full body, balanced carbonation, lightly resinous. Solid.

From the bomber ... Pleasantly orange, quietly active wtih a nice solid poofy head of lacey foam. The aroma is beautiful ... woodsy, piney, airy, and citricly fruity.  From the first sip, my tummy is a happy tummy ... warming and smooth, this carries a rich resiny hop character.  The bitter finish is just right, but this could do with a tad more balance. (#3093, 9/16/2007)
Bottle. Mild for a double IPA. very well balanced hop / malt profile. considerable hop profile but still reasonable easy drinkable. very nice.

Nov. 2005 - Beer poured with nice color and moderate head. Appearance and taste was of citrusy/piney hops. There were some nice maltiness there, but not really enough. Mouthfeel was kinda oily. The alcohol taste was prevalent and overly bitter. Good, but not great

Clear, firey orange body with a small white head that settles to a thin film.  Minimal spotty lacing noted.  The aroma shows big and buttery, toffee malts, brown sugar, and ample tangerine and pine hops.  The flavor is again very malty up front.  Heavily buttered toffee, biscuit, and caramel comprise the malt base.  Hops of the grapefruit variety are moderately strong, but far from overpowering.  Excellent balance.   Mildly astringency in the long, bitter finish, but not enough to get worked up over.  Substantial body makes for a medium-full mouthfeel.  Slightly sticky though not overly cloying.  Nice brew.

Bottle sampled. Pours a copper color with a nice white head. Nice hoppy aroma of pine, grapefruit, and sweet malts. Flavor is well balanced with caramel, citrus, grapefruit and some malt sweetness with a strong and clean finish. A very good double ipa.

On tap a Toranado SF, 24 Aug 07.  Light in color without much head.Agressive hoppy aroma, Flavor was big and hoppy, citrus dominated with a little bit of sweet malt thrown in to ballence it out. Not a bad brew, but not as refined as Id like

Hazy orange color; Sweet, but not overly so; caramel notes, quite bitter, with grapefruit and orange; bitter hop finish;  great balance and a nearly perfect palate.  this has been my go-to beer for a few months now.    K-7.5

22 ounce bottle in pint glass.  Bright copper with flat head and nice lace.  Fresh hop aroma with malty undertones.  Nicely balanced flavor with malty start and medium bitter finish.  Medium-full body, medium carbo.  Very slight alcohol.  A tasty if not distinctive brew.  Very good.

Rerated because I always thought it was better in 12 ounce bottles.

Bottle, pours a cloudy golden color, with a thin head. Nice and hoppy, maybe a touch of light malts, and some nice cream.Hops are mostly citrus with only small amounts of pine. A good IIPA but not a great one.

Date: 08/21/1998

Mode: Draft

Source: Toronado, San Francisco



hazy dark yellow, thin white head, thick alce, strong citrus hop aroma, big body, lots of hop flavor, slight sweetness, strong grapefruit essence, relativeitly light lingering bitterness, very simular to a rogue brutal bitter

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Date: 09/03/2006

Mode: bottle

Score: iiii to iii



clear amber, whispy white head, touch of lace, creamy body, big sweet grapefruit aroma and flavor, nice sticky sweetness with a touch of pine, as good as it ever was but the bar has risen in the 8 years since I last tried it

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Date: 12/27/2006

Mode: draft

Source: taco mac woodstock



very consistant bottle or draft

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Date: 05/02/2007

Mode: draft

Source: taco mac john’s creek



lots of flavor even in a frozen glass, 



Aroma: 8/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 8/10; Overall: 16/20

Rating: 3.9/5.0
Drinkability: 8/10

Score: ***/4

Hazy orange look with a small tan head. Extremly creamy aroma, thick caramel and a good amount of grassy hobs with notes of grapefruit. Flavor is pretty intense and very broad and balanced. At first the malt blend is dominating, but after abit, a dry bitterness takes over. Finish is also dry. In no way an extreme double IPA, but very solid and ejoyable

Syrupy pine, caramel, citrusy.  Pours pale amber with a white head.  Caramel, citrus hops, some pine resins, a very spicy character peppery, very smooth.  Not so hoppy after having the Hop Stoopid, but its still good.

Pours an orange cloudy color, with a nice white head. Aroma was hoppy with some citrus and spice, not too strong. Flavor was pretty nice and smooth for an IPA, a little bitter, but not too much. I didn’t find this to be really special, but it’s still a good beer.

Haven’t had a bottle of these in years. My tasting notes are full of accolades, though. I wrote, "singular in body, flavor, nose, and appearance this IPA satisfies all the senses, the palate, the brain, and the mind." Whoa! How many did I drink? Ahhh, but that was in the good old days before my senses were jaded by gigahop assaults. Now that my hop horizons have expanded, I’ll have to revisit this one. Tough competition out there!

Bottle. Pours copper orange with a fairly thick head. Retention is decent. Smells like cane sugar, orange peel, and grapefruit, which is also pretty much how it tastes. While not too complex, the flavor is strong, clean, and appropriately hoppy.
All in all a good beer, if not quite as interesting or satifying as a Stone brew.

Bottle. Pours copper with two finger head - good retention with lacing all around the sides. Aroma is apricot, sticy caramel malt, berries, pineapple, light pine scents and alcohol. Flavor is slightly sweet almost syrupy- strawberry, pine. Some bitterness in the back and sides of the mouth. Lingering pine resin hoppy aftertaste. Palate is round, creamy maltiness.

22 oz bottle, no freshness date.


Clear amber with tight, sticky, tan head. Thick lace.


Grapefruit hops and caramel aroma. 


Flavor mirors aroma, light citrus, light pine, sweet caramel.


Nicely balanced, but I expected more, especialy after the description.

Golder orange with a decent white head. Smells nice a hppy and with a slight caramel undertone. Has a nicey piney, citrus, grassy hop bite. Slight sweet malt but this beer is mainly hops. It’s actually a good mix with the hop. The malt is there, but not overly sweet or noticeable compared to the hops. So, if you like a good amount of hops and lower malt ratio for an "IIPA" then this might be a good choice.

Pours a bubbly copper with a thin white head.  Fruity, hoppy aroma, some grapefruit and malts.  Tastes od sweet malts, cinnamon and mild hops.  Not as hoppy as I’d thought, especially for a double IPA.  Very bitter aftertaste, but it stood out more becuase the huge hops werent there to back it up.  Definitely has a big malt presence and was slightly sweet on the palate.  Needs a little more crispness.  This would be a decent regular IPA, but for a double it lacks firepower.

22oz bottle.  Pours a clear copper with noticeable carbonation.  Bountiful aroma of hops.  Really nice smell.  First taste is a feel of that carbonation, which quickly gives way to some nice hoppiness, though it doesn’t stack up to some of the best IIPAs (e.g. Ruination). It was a nice beer all the way through, but I was left hoping for a wee bit more.
22 oz. bottle - pours clear orange with no head; aromas a malty and thick; flavors are equally malty; a decent, but not fantastic DIPA

Hazy orangish color - medium fluffy head.  Aroma is sweetly hoppy with notes of citurs.  Full rich flavor, malty base that is followed by a creamy finish.  Hoppiness permeates thoughout.  Nice Imperial IPA.
Orangy in colour, a little hazy.  Light orangy head.  Hoppy and earthy/grassy in smell.  Flavour is sweet, hoppy with a light bitter aftertaste.  Simple, smooth and consistent.
all the good taste and character from their ipa with an added alcohol punch. i suppose the occasion might arise for this one from time to time.

22oz bottle. Pours a clear copper with a one finger white head that fades and leaves some lacing. Aroma of pine hops, citrus hops, and sweet malt. Taste is the same as aroma. Medium-full resiny mouthfeel with a well balanced bitterness. Not very complex but damn tasty.

This bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a small sized head of foamy finely sized tan colored bubbles that were mostly lasting and left behind a slightly hazy typically carbonated dark orange colored body. The mild aroma was hoppy and floral. The excellent mouth feel was very tingly at the start and at the finish. The thick very yummy flavor contained notes of strong soft hops. A wonderful best in class brew.

12 oz. bottle from Gregis.  Pour is clear orange amber with a very big, thick off white head.  Aroma is pine and citrus hops.  Taste is big resinous pine and orange citrus.  Very bitter finish.  Overall a nice IPA.

Got a bomber from Binny’s.  Ended up trying this at a little warmer that what I would like, but I don’t think it will affect my rating.  Quite a bit of head, hazy copper color.  Full bodied, leaving a slick palate.  High malt profile, nice bittering on the back end; no bee-sting nectar but still good.  Tons of lacing which caked in rings down the glass.  Faint aroma on this. This is good for sipping or slamming, so the drinkability is high on this.  High alcohol content is not noticable.  I actually thought this was their IPA (first offering I’ve tried from these guys.)  But it is thier IIPA, they state it’s their IPA upgraded about 30%. Good but not overwhelming.  Then I thought why does it have to be big; it’s very smooth, so my criticalness ended up melting away.

Clear copper orange body, medium creamy beige head. MF- chewy, resiny. A tad restrained in the hops department for the style; grapefruit, pine, soapy/sticky, hardly any sweetness. Short finish. Similar in flavor to Alpha King, but with a more oily texture. Well-rounded and never harsh. Not the most groundbreaking IIPA in the world, but still definitely good and great for the price($9 / 6).
Orange colour, firm white head. Aroma: lots of hops and florals. Flavour: bitter, lots of hops and the dryness hits you in the face.

Aroma is very hoppy, mainly the fruity ones, grapefruits. Orange coloured with a lasting, off-white head. Taste is a bit sweet and offcourse quite bitter. Very hoppy, mainly the fruity ones but there is  pine and flower as well. Big knock-out this one.  Don’t let it be your first beer of the evening.

Bottle. Pours a nice copper, with a big, shiny, off-white head. Aroma is, of course, tons of hops, grapefruit and pineapple being the most prominent. Flavor is textbook Double IPA, strong maltiness, and aggressive hops of all sorts. This beer, however, manages to be noticeably aggressive, and suitable for rapid consumption simultaneously.

Pint bottle.  Pours copper orange with a beige head that quickly recedes to a film.  Strong aroma of American hops, and maybe a little malt and spice underneath.  I’m not sure.  Taste is more balanced than I expected, as the hops initially wait in the background, allowing sweet caramel malt to make its presence felt.  Then the hops step forward, overwhelming the malt with orange, pine needles, and spice.  The bitterness lingers through and beyond the finish.  Alcohol is well hidden; you feel it more than you taste it.  Creamy mouthfeel.  Good.
Pours a beautiful rusty orange color with a small frothy head. This beer has a strong earthy/piney flavor along with the typical hoppiness IPAs are known for.
Pours a nice light amber color. Tastes very smooth and good with a different bitter after taste.

Wow! This is one smooth Double IPA. Hoppiness and clean finish is unique and refreshing. 

My Local keg supplier is currently unable to get kegs of Ruination. I have only tasted in bottles and can’t wait to taste it on tap.

Bottle from Corral Liquors in Granite City, IL. Pours a clear orange with a creamy, off-white head. Sweet toasty malts and both spicy and citric hops with a light alcohol note in the background. Medium-bodied and slick, it is moderately carbonated and finishes bitter and dry. The flavor is of sweet caramel and citrus upon hitting the tongue, dry and quite bitter at the swallow. Light alcohol presents itself upon exhale and the aftertaste is a long, lingering, resiny, hop bitterness that squeezes the back of your tongue. This one is a hop bomb, and while I love bitter/hoppy beers, I was left wanting more from the malts to help balance things out.

22oz. bottle poured into a glass with a tapered stem and large bowl.  This glass makes this beer look really nice, very amber in the stem but a beautiful reddish-orange in the bowl.  Very little head but quite a bit of nice lacing.  Strong grapefruit flavor with a good amount of hops.  Sweet.  Nice mouthfeel.  Good bang-for-your buck with this brew.  Not the first time I’ve bought it and certainly won’t be the last.

Nice to see this one in six packs now.  Great aroma.  Along with Victory Hop Wallop, this is one of the best DIPA aromas I’ve smelled from the bottle.  Smells like lots of Centennial hops to me.   Very light, golden color.  Great SRM for a DIPA. A slight bit more heavy in the mouthfeel than I would want for a full pint.  Just a little more attenuation would make this closer to perfect.   good 8oz pour of this is excellent.  A very nice brew.

Bottle.  Poured a clear amber color with a medium white head.  Good lacing.  Aroma of citrus and pine, with a little caramel to it.  Flavor is citrus with a strong bitter finish.  A pretty good double IPA, but nothing I need to go out of my way to get.
Looks like most ipa’s.  Heavy ipa taste at first followed by a remarkably neat finish.  went well with parmesan cracker bread.

Had this one bottled in Chicago Heights, Illinois.  Wow.  This was crazy good.  Clear, light orange pour with all kind of things happening in the nose.  As one might expect from a IIPA it was very heavy on piney, floral and citrusy hops, which carried neatly into the flavor, dominated by grapefruit, rose and black tea.  Finished strong and clean. Wow.  An almost perfect beer.

Bottled. Thanks Marsiblursi. 
Clear amber colour. Black currant, berry jam and tea are all very prominent in flavour. Jam-like flavour profile(no, not Zinfandel Wine) with tea here as well and a good bitter finish. Every thing about this beer is of a plain IPA. Aroma hops, flavouring hops and bitterness. 7, 5 would always be on the edge as I see it.  Very much house character, with the tea.

First rating
Initial Rating Date: 7/1/2007
Bottle, thanks Marsiblursi!
Clear brown color, tan head. Hoppy fruity chocolate scent. Hoppy nd grainy taste. Smooth mouthfeel. Medium bitterness.
7/3/8/3/14=3.5

Rerate
Sampled draught at CBC, blue session, Saturday afternoon May 4, 2013.
Clear golden color, yellow head. Sweet, caramel, hoppy scent. Caramel, bitter, hoppy taste. Medium mouthfeel, medium high bitterness.
7/4/7/3/14=3.5

pours a light copper with a nose of orange skin and sweet malts. flavor is quite rich with notes of orange and pekoe black tea. nice balance and not overly hoppy. not really the big dipa i was expecting but an easy drinker...

Bottle. Nose is fruity hops, citrus but also some peach and a touch of pine. Clear orange beer with a minimal white head. Strong fullbodied palate carrying an initial bitterness that settles nicely into an aftertaste of grapefruit.

(Bottle) Pours amber. Friuty aroma with oranges and apricots. Hops also brings black tea,light pine and something floral. A bit sweet. Hints of crushed tomatoes. Fruity and medium hoppy flavour with black tea, oranges, apricots and some toffee. Light spicy. Medium bitter. A bit to thin mouthfeel and body. Also a bit to sweet. Ok IPA, bad DIPA.

Flaske: Flot karakterisk farve for en IPA, god duft af humle og citrus. Smagen var ikke så overvældende som jeg havde regnet med. Nok fordi den ikke var helt frisk hvilket gjorde den mere balanceret i min mening. God bitterhed på tungen

WOW!!!!  Very hoppy, awesome!  I love the beer and I haven’t even tasted it yet!  Ok, now it’s time to taste it...before that, it’s like a nice light amber color.  Ok, now, it’s time to taste, Hoppy, smooth, sweet, awesome!!!!!  I can def drink a six pack of this, Ver Good!!!!!!
nice orange amber color with slight carbination. not much on the aroma front but what you would expect. nice hops and citrus, grapefruit taste, well balanced and one of the better ipa’s i have tried

Pours a clear dark orange with a nice thick white head. Aroma is hoppy but mildly so, not as "in your face" as expected. Taste however is alot of piney grapefruit hop flavorl  that we all know and love. This beer capitalizes even more on its already appealing aroma. This sort of reminds me of the flavor of Pliny the Younger or Dreadnaught but just not quite making the cut. Still an GREAT beer and wish I could get this bottled where I live, it would become one of my regulars.
The hops sting your tongue, then then quickly disappear without lingering.  Light and refreshing.  Near perfect for hops without that gross mouth resin feel afterwards.

22 oz. bottle. Poured a cloudy orange/gold color with a little white head. The aroma is very hoppy and hints of pine. Nice lacing on this one with taste that is sweet with a moderate dry finish. A very balenced IPA.
Ppurs a good looking orangish gold hue with a light lacy head. Nose of fresh hops, and tastes like it too. Citrusy, crisp clean finish. An excellent IPA.

Nice copper-coloured beer with lingering head. Hoppy, nearly oily aroma with nice malt backbone. The flavour is of sweet malt and citrusy, flowery hops. Moderately bitter and not that dry.
A fine, elegant and well-made ipa. Balanced and just very ipaish.
Pine and citrus hop flavors with a solid presence of sweet malt, I thought this had a surprisingly complex flavor. Enjoyable.

22oz bottle poured into a pint glass.  This beer pours a clear amber/orange with a thick foamy beige head that lasts.  Some nice heavy lacing is left behind.  The aroma is very citrusy along with a good dose of toffee and caramel.  The flavor is mainly grapefruit and caramel.  The are also notes of pine and bread.  Flavor is well balanced.  Finish is lightly bitter and quick.  The mouthfeel is just slightly oily/resiny with a bit of carbonation.  Medium-bodied.  Very well done.  My only complaint might be that this beer may not be strong enough to hold up against other double IPAs.
The Dan Journal #19.  tasted 5/30/06.  22oz bomber.  Hazy and amber brown.  Biscuit and piney hops.  Spicy.  Bitter spices and off-dry.  Caramel malts.  Dry and good.

Golden coloured with a white head. Grapefruit and a bit of pine like aroma. The tatse is mostly hops but they aren’t huge and explosive like I would expect an IIPA. There is some good bitterness though. Overall pretty good, but not great.

Not being privey to many Yankee IIPA’s, comparisons are few and far beetween. This one just seemed a little to soft and restrined compared with other tried in the past. No tounge fuzzing bitterness, and the hop aroma seemed a little one dimensional

22 oz bottle. Pours fairly light orange/copper with minimal white head. Decent aroma of sweet hops (grapefruit/the usual) with some malt to back it up. Same for the palate. A tad thin. Not a creamy as I like my IIPA’s Decent balance between hops and malt. Average IIPA, but still better that your everyday beer.

Rated 3/8/07:  Was able to get a couple 12 oz bottles from one of my regular stops. While I find this to be a nicely crafted IPA, it doesn’t appeal very highly to me. Hearty hop presence but they seem to act more as a bittering agent thus lacking in the flavoring department. Thick golden copper pour with a one and a half finger head and thick lacing, looks solid. Thicker mouthful than the standard IPA it came across as chewy which I liked but the finish is a touch soapy. Aroma is bitter with a lackluster citrus scent, malt is bready. Flavor is pretty good but like I said before I look forward to a more floral citrus bouquet in my IPA’s, this one is malty and bitter. Resinous and thick I like the malt content but long for more grapefruit and pine flavors.

bottle- clear, copper color. piney pnw hops that smell great. Taste is very imperial like, with caramel malts dominating a bit. Still some bitterness, but nothing drastic. Pretty well balanced. Given other brews available in this style, I would not go back to this as an option anytime soon. draft- 06/08- enjoyed this quite a bit more on draft as the hop flavor really shined. re-rate bottle- 07/08- again,, liked this considerably more than the earlier rating stated. would absolutely go to this again.

Appearance: Pours a clear, light copper color with a white-colored head.

Smell: Sharp, sweet pine hop aroma with notes of caramel.

Taste: Firm citrus, grapefruit flavors with a small amount of caramel left to balance out the hops. Hints of bread dough. Very dry, bitter finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Thin, but a bit oily, as well.

Drinkability: This one wasn’t for me. Thin to a fault, and the malt flavor could be more distinct.

22 oz bomber shared with rebelbeerguy. Poured a hazy orangeish/amber with a small off white head. Aroma was flowers, pine and some caramel malt in the background. Flavor was a little weak compared to the aroma but pleasant none the less. Pretty good beer all around.
Clear orange color, short head. Aroma of sweet malt, grapefruit, hop, some candy sugar, pines. Quite bitter taste, moderate sweet, fruity as well. Quite complex. Not just hoppy. Very nice stuff.

Amber in color big malty hop aroma followed by citrus aromas.  Super sweet for a DIPA, not at all bitter.  Malty sweetness, lightly carbonated.  Highly drinkable, unusually so for a DIPA.  Yummy and enjoyable in quantity.

Orange/amber in color, fairly good sized foamy white head that lingers. Aroma is citris, caramel an date/raisin fruitiness. Nice big hop punch folwed by somewhat of a chewy caramel flavor. Medium body which is not typical of most DIPAs. Also a bit of warmth detected in the finish. Overall a very good beer.
Poured from a bottle. Orange amber in color, average off white head. Nose is awesome. Lots of citrus, sweet malt and piney hops. A little soapy and sticky,  but still an awesome DIPA. I

FAR sweeter than any IPA or double IPA i have ever tried, with a fair amount of fruitiness..  A great beer, but definately not what I was looking for in the style.  An extremely sweet burnt raisin and caramel flavor with a peppery hop bite, but little bitterness, followed with a very pronounced, almost porter-like roastedness.

Mostly a sweet malt aroma, a hint of hops peaks through the orange colored beer. Flavor is a sweet caramel malt blast, some malty fruitiness, followed by piney and peppery hops. This is a pretty heavy brew because of the pronounced maltiness. Not too resiny, although a peppery bite hangs around for a minute. Not my favorite IIPA, but a nice beer nonetheless.

An intense IPA. Amber with beige head. Not very impressive visually but the nose was strong hops, grapefruit, alcohol. Great mouthfeel. Rich and thick. Flavor had kick to it. Hops bitterness in a good way. Fruity. Grapefruit juicy. Kick ass IPA.
on tap @ Coles Buffalo NY. Not bad heavy on the citrus. Grapefruit bomb. decent hop bitterness. @ 7.5 wont kill you like some DIPA’s
Bottled. Amber-orangey colour with a rich white foam. grapefruity hop aroma with notes of pine-cones. Citrousy fresh flavour with a long bitter grapefruity finish. Simple but tasty.

If you like this style you will easily enjoy this drop. Colour wasn’t that flash to me but that is ok, hops are all you notice - a little more malt for the backbone would be nice, alcohol was good, so this was easily drinkable but not outstanding.

Very nice hop aroma. Light bodied, but slightly oily. Slightly sweet with strong, but mild alcohol note that slowly reveals dark fruits. Finishes with a chorus of flavors. Lots of interesting, unexpected effects. A masterful IIPA.
not bad for an IPA, smells delicious, nice hoppy aroma, pours a deep orange lot o head, nice and bitter.

Whoa!!!!!!!!!!!!   This stuff is heavy and a  little too heavy for my taste.  It  wears me down; it tastes good, but be careful cause this will create regrets in the morning.  Citrusy hops with unfiltered yeasts, tates sweet and well balanced, but wears down the session drinker.

Bottle.  Pours a fairly standard copper color with a nice three-finger white head that leaves behind jagged lacing down the glass.  Slightly cloudy though.  The initial aroma is a super sweet citrus fruit, like a tangerine or a clementine.  Very nice.  As it opens up the piney hops come out to play giving it a fairly standard aroma, but I bumped it up a point for making me think about clementines.  The flavor is a nice blend of citrus fruit, piney hops, floral hops and even a bit of caramel.  A bit hop-heavy as the malt backbone can’t quite support the bitter finish, but an enjoyable beer nonetheless.  Best beer I’ve had from this brewery.

It has a nice smooth somewhat creamy mouthfeel and the flavor accentuates towards floral bouquet with some piney resin qualities.
