In the aftertaste, there is an odd orange-like tone bursting out along with the alcohol content which seems hidden at first. It seems to pair well with pizza. It seems a bit unbalanced to appreciate the bitterness, but I enjoyed it nevertheless.

Pours a clear, copper color with an off-white, average-sized, creamy head;  a small, frothy, persistant layer remains with lots of tight lacing.  Nose is simple but substantial with pink grapefruit and spicy resins and a bit of floral; malts are faint but keeping the nose from being all hops with bready notes and light caramel.  Flavor is the nose would have suggested; pink grapefruit and pine resins remain dominant with a balancing malt base of caramels and bread tones.  Palate is slightly sticky, somewhat creamy, moderately carbonated, and medium in body witha minimal alcohol presence.  Finishes with the citrus notes remaining and floral and herbal bitterness notes exposing the more the moderate bitterness.  Fairly simple but well put together IIPA.  Nice balance of malt background, hop bitterness, and hop flavors.  Nothing earth-shattering, but quite enjoyable.

This beer is fuckin awesome. Very floral and "dank" when I first smelled it(dank means "marijuana like" for all you squares who are too fuckin old to know any cool shit). Hoppy and botanical taste with not too much of the lemon and grapefruit that certain IPAs possess. I tend to think that too much citrus is fucking sickening at times...I mean seriously, if you want citrus go buy your self a faggoty 6-pack of Corona Light and stick a half shriveled lime in it...cause after all that is what living is all about...right? Corona Light...it’s a way of life...if you are a fuckin yuppie.
This is a good IPA, piny taste. Was definitley lacking in aroma when compared with some other IPAs. Very citrusy. Was cloudy in appearance.

Nice orange smell, but very faint. Thin to no head. Copper color and clear. Very flowery flavor with plenty of hoppy bite. It falls down on palate: for one thing its a bit sticky, like even noticeably on your lips; another problem is a weird lavender-like smoothness that is not pleasant. I’ve noticed the latter charachteristic in a few brews (Redhook Long Hammer comes to mind as does Deschutes Inversion). I don’t understand the cause (or if it’s by design). Maybe I’m not describing it correctly; certainly a smooth feeling can be pleasant but this type of smooth is lavenderish and fuzzy. (For pleasant smooth, see Stone Ruination)

Has a beautiful citrus hop bouquet, which is almost immediately smoothed over with some sweet malty notes. Almost seems more of an ASA than IIPA, but whatever you call it, it’s delicious. Immensely drinkable.
22 oz bottle. Massive hop blast.  Alcohol unnoticeable.  For a mid-priced IIPA/DIPA,  definitely worth it.  Very warming to the gullet.

Bomber in Atlanta, cold in a flute. AP26/07



App.:  Medium-deep amber, clear, decent off-white head.
  
Aroma:  Typical American IPA – lots of C-hops, grapefruit peppery and resinous, backed by caramel, toffee and treacle malts.
  
Palate:  Medium body and lively carbonation.
  
Flav.:  Peppery, resinous and citrus hops, much like the nose; some malt sweetness, bracingly bitter but in a good way.



Might lean a little too much towards hops, but I can accept that..



Re-rated June 12/08.



1 pint 6 fluid oz bottle from Sherbrooke Liquor, served cold ina  wine glass.



App.: Slightly hazy, orange-amber, small off-white head with a yellow-green hue.
  
Aroma:  Oh-so-familiar brown sugar, rye bread crust and grapefruit-pine hops, oranges and peaches/apricots, peppery.
  
Palate:  Slightly syrupy, medium+ body, moderate but soft carbonation.
  
Flav.:  much like the nose – rye bread smothered in Seville orange marmalade, some raisins, apricots and peaches, other vague fruitiness; somewhat sweet and quite bitter; the bitterness sticks around for a bit and there is a slightly fruity and peppery finish.



Quite true to the style for American IPA.  Enjoyable.  Same rating.
Lighter copper,. thin head.  Nose is fruity pine, plenty of caramel,cotton candy.  Flavor is bitter caramel, some dusty malt, orange/lemon.  Some caramel in the very bitter finish.
Sunset orange amber with a medium but heavy head. Caramel malts and orange hoppyness a bit of hay and earth. The palate is resiny and just a tad light. Finishes with pines and oranges.

On tap in the Horse & Plow
Pours a blazing orange with a thick, creamy white head. Huge citrus hops on the nose with grapefruit and pine. Great bitterness with the usual West Coast IPA charactoristics. Finishes with a mild alcohol burn. For such a big beer, it’s very light and crisp. So heavy on the hops, maybe a one or two maximum for Maximus.

Courtesy of After4ever - thank you Tom! The color is very beautiful warm amber and the head is huge and creamy. The aroma is alluring with it’s hoppy notes of pine and resin. The flavour has a wonderful malty caramel foundation with a nice smooth, grassy and piny bitterness and notes of citrus (mostly orange). It’s really nice! 2052

Pours a medium-to-dark amber with a white head.  Light aroma of floral hops with a hint of penicillin.  In the mouth, it has spiky carbonation and medium body.  Taste was relatively dry, with solid floral hops giving away to moderate bitterness.
A decent IPA, but not among the best.  Perfume like some what floral aroma, medium bodied palate, but the taste was not as bitter as I expect from an Imperial IPA.
This is pretty hoppy.  Maybe too much of a good thing.  The experience of a 22ozer was a little bit much for one person.

22 oz bottle. Poured a clear orange color. Head was thick, white, and reduced to a thin film. There was some decent lace on the glass at the end. Aroma was of light flowery hops. Medium bodied and slightly sweet on the tongue. Citrusy hop dominated flavor, but not over the top. There was also a touch of biscuity malt. Mild hop bitterness at the end. Decent.

Fantastic aroma, and very indicative of a west coast style hopping.  Caramel sweet malt, and nice PNW hops make this a good beer.  Nothing I would consider overwhelmingly aggro, but a good, dryish DIPA.

Bottle.  Golden brown pour with a one finger, frothy head.  Aromas are slightly sweet with a little bit of a pineapple hops character.  Body is pretty heavy on malt for an IPA but the hops comes through nicely in the finish.  Kind of a kinder/gentler IPA, so to speak.  Caramel malt sweetness is lovely, as is the pine finish.  Mouthfeel is slick and kind of heavy.  In spite of decided lack of a strong and bitter hops blast I’m enjoying this quite a bit.  Very well balanced.

I’m on a Beer streak, y’all. The hits keep comin’. What can I say? I really might have to change my name to "The Great BEER Magnet". It’s like that. Not too strong, and nowhere near weak...this stuff is "juuuust right", like the porridge.

watered iced tea look, golden-honey brown.  Head is yellow tinged, like smoker’s teeth, and huge, long-lasting.  Smells of pine needles & pine apple. Taste is large and sweet, mildly acidic from citrus hops. Not bitter though, lots of malt here, barley, a little oily. After is vegetable hops.

Bottle. Very small ivory head that quickly dissipated, virtually no lacing, transparent, visible carbonation, and an orange hue with golden highlights. Malty, some caramel, citrus, grapefruit, hops and a hint of pine. Flavor was lightly bitter, malty hoppy, grapefruit, some pine and the ABV was well hidden. Lingering hoppy aftertaste. Dry and slightly tingly mouthfeel. Light-medium body. Not over-the-top hops. Definitely worth a try if this one comes your way!

Re-Rate 3/6/08
citrus and pine hop aroma ... sweet citrus rind, concentrated orange and medium pine resin ... very nice balance of pine and citrus with a good amount of light sweetness ... maybe its the new batch or maybe its the timing of my growing appreciation of craft beer over the last year, but this is better than I remember

1st Rating (4.1)
slightly hazy copper, small head...strong hop aroma, citrus and malt...great crisp hoopy taste..very refreshing..great IPA
bottle . . pours copper with light whitehead . . aroma is citrus, floral, hops, sweet . . taste is hoppy, FRESH, clean, grapefruit, bitter . . aftertaste is a bit bitter but NICE beer . . !!

Copper color, some haze.  Blood orange aroma, tang of grapefruit.  Some crystal flavor layered over further hints of citrus and some musty attic malt taste.  Somewhat reserved palate.  A quiet outdoor campfire, nicely subdued.
pours a nice bright orange with a little head.   nice citrusy nose.  beautiful bitterness.  just the right amount of hops. wonderful stuff.

12 oz bottle from Liquid Solutions pours a hazy copper-orange with a great hop/malt aroma.  Small white head.  Flavor is a very good balance of wonderfully bitter hops and a lot of malt.  I love this IPA.

Dang, this is a bitter beer.  Wonderful hoppiness and clarity.  See through it like a window.  The amount of alcohol is great when you want to get a buzz off only a couple of drinks.  Great lacing, carbonation bite, and smooth finish with great taste.  Had a big bottle a while ago, now picked up a 6 pack- Same as before if not better.  Top notch IPA-  I only wish I could figure out the recipe so I can make a clone.  A hop head delight.

Bouteille de 12 oz achetée chez Oak Tree Discount (South Plainfield, NJ). Arôme: Odeur d’agrumes et de pin. Apparence: La couleur est orangée avec une faible densité de bulle. Présence d’un mince col mousseux et d’une fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût d’agrumes et de pin avec une pointe de caramel. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement huileuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Présence d’agrumes en arrière goût. (Rating #958)

nice copper pour with small head, lacing lasted for the whole beer. Lots of malt is there, with some nice hoppiness, but more subdued than expected. a little of an alcohol bite, but not too bad. Decent, but could us some balance.

Copper Coloring with White Ring.  Wet Hop, Sweet Malt Aroma.  Sweet Malt Foundation...Alot of Wet Hop Flavor..Dry Hopped Aftertaste..Caramel Malt Balances Out the Brew...but Certainly a Hop Lovers Beer.

This is a good DIPA.  There isn’t much that stands out about it, however.  It’s overall quality has been evidenced in countless other IPA’s.  The best thing I can say about it is that it had a slight kick indicative of a higher alcohol level.

Good foamy head at the pour, nice amber color to it, with piny aroma. The hops are there, but I was expecting more from a "Maximus" IPA. Some grapefruit and orange citrus in the flavor, semi-balanced overall with an average finish on the palate. Nothing spectacular but worth a try if you’re a hop freak.

Pours a reddish ambery with a light tan head.  Aroma is slight citrus, pine and a bit of alcohol.  Taste is citrus hops, pine, alcohol and some caramel malt.  Nothing meshes well with this beer.  The hop presence is understated.  That malt doesn’t add any real balance to the mix.  The alcohol presence is way too high for a beer that is only 7.5% abv.  This was a train wreck of an IPA.  Glad I only got a single bottle of this.
Cirrus cloudy head, pillowy silk mouth.  Nice hops in the nose, great chops in the blows.  Drink this sh!t to get sh!tf@ced!

Pours a hazy golden with a small head that leaves adequate lacing. Aroma is very aggressively hopped. Notes of cirus are mostly grapefruit and orange. Chemical odors protrude. Leafy and with prickly alcohol. Flavor is unimpressive and at times annoying: bitter hoppiness clashes distinctly with toasty malts that seem only half extracted, raw. Finishes bitter and moderately dry. Not very good at all. There is a big difference between pleasant hops and nasty bitterness that is crossed over like it’s unimportant to differentiate between the two. The hops never seem fresh, but the beer undoubtedly is. Extreme hoppiness can’t mask these egregious flaws.

Now that is an Imperial IPA!  Pours dark tan brown with a frothy head. Has an incredibly strong hoppy flavor and scent. Mouthfeel is smooth and goes down with a little bit of an aftertaste but a good one in that.

Wow... a nice strong IIPA, big hop nose, light carbonation, somewhat cloudy tan color, with almost no head.  The flavor is a nice balance of various hops running across the mouth, jumping down your throat, and having a party.  This comes close to the Ruination in its ability to prevent tasting other beers.  This is one I’m going to drink as much as I can while it’s available.
12 oz. limited release bottle 2007. Spring like grassy aroma. Hoppy with an exceptional bouquet and bitting bitter finish. Charming IPA in a nice and balanced range for a West Coast.

Re-rate; Wow this stuff has taken a turn for the ugly since it went to ’unlimited release’. Sweet and astringent, super piney and resinous.  Ugh, I hope they don’t fuck up Hop Stoopid when it goes to wide release but I’m guessing it will happen.
Pours cloudy orange with off-white head.  Nice orange citrus aroma with some pine zest.  Hoppy through and through with the citrus and pine.

On tap at the brewery’s loft / tasting room.  Thick and delicious without tasting like hop resin.  After reading a few other reviews that suggested this beer tastes like tea, I now know why I sometimes think my tea tastes like beer.

22oz from matt at Capone’s. Pours slightly cloudy orange with a thick beige head. I smell oranges and a slight pine aroma. The hops hit you early and at the very end. In between it is all grapefruit and orange-zest. A very drinkable beer, except for the bitter in the aftertaste. I can still taste it in top of my throat. This makes it slightly less refreshing than other IPAs I have reviewed. Still a very well rounded brew.

[b][i]650ml bomber, shared with VeloVampire[/b][/i] - pours a deep amber/golden shade, with a relatively small white head. Aroma is at first a big of citrusy, orangey hops, but then mellows a bit and you get a big dose of sweet malt as well. Mouthfeel is very buttery. Flavour is extremely well balanced, with lots of sweet, caramel malt and citrusy/piney hops in the mouth. The piney character of the hopping comes out mostly in the nicely bitter finish. Has a somewhat tea-like character. Much bigger malt presence in this one than most other dIPA’s. Really nice.

650 ml bottle, shared with StompBrockmore - pours a foxy amber with a small off white head.  Big fruit aroma, as in grapefruit, along with some light apple and honey as well.  Taste is bitter sticky herbal hops, more grapefruit, sweet malt and a tannin quality, almost like a black tea.  Very nice carbonation.  Well-balanced.  Nice stuff.

I swore years ago i would give this beer another shot before rating it as it was one of my first IPAs and i wasn’t prepared for the hoppy flavors.  well, we now get Lagunitas in Illinois and i finally made good on that promise.  this beer was just as hoppy as i remembered it, but it was delightful this time round since i now have the palate appreciative and not afraid of hops.  lots and lots of west coast pine-y hops in this one.  some carmel, grapefruit, and lemon, and orange on the flavor as well.  yummers.

Pours a murky golden orange with a thick somewhat offwhite head that sticks around for a long time.  The aroma is citrusy hops with an underlying malt prescence that gives the impression of balance.  On the palate, balance, there is.  Very nice with a citrusy hop flavor backed my a toffee-like malty sweetness.  Finishes clean.  Many IIPAs end up being too big for their own good.  This one allows the enjoyment of the extremity of IPAs without the probolems of having too much malt and alcohol.  Very nice.

One of my favorite non double/triple/imperial IPA’s.  Clipper City Loose Cannon has been my go to everyday drink all night IPA aside from Alpha King, Belle’s etc..., but this takes the cake.  I am with my other OHIO bro on here from West Chester, It has all the right notes a good IPA should have and better.  It is a bad ass brew!!!!!!!!!

This is a beer site, and I’m tired of talking about beer the way wine people talk about wine.  Who cares how it smells, what color it is and all that jazz.  Bottom Line, this beer Rocks!  It is truly the gladiator of IPAs in my opinion... Maximus, Maximus, Maximus....Rose petals fall around the 6 pack, and the king...gives the thumbs up!

pours a copper golden color with a seafoamy yellow head, it is quite translucent.  smells citrusy hops some caramel or toffee scent lemons, grass, tastes unexpectadly sweet up front, malts caramel and toffee like in the nose, finishes with a good dose of hops. definately an amazing brew. love it. cheers pops!

Poured a Orangish gold color with a dirty white head.  Nose was that of earthy crunchy nutty fruity flowery smell.  much alcohol, am I tasting the hops and malts, I need educated feel free to email me on this one. Emails are welcomed.   Very good relaxing beer.

Pour a clear deep golden copper with an ample frothy off-white head.  Some citursy hops come through in the aroma and, to a lesser degree, some pine.  Nose is also a little sweet.  Palate is slick and just a tad sticky.  Medium carbonation.  Nice hop bitterness and grapefruit hop flavor.  Just enough malty sweetness to be balanced.
apparently i was drunk when i jotted notes on this.  but what i get is that it had a nice hoppy floral nose and a similar flavor.  it was good shit

Bottle... Poured a red/amber color with a foamy head that lasted with nice lacing.  Malty, hoppy aroma, the usual for an IPA w/ the usual palate, mildy carbonated.  Flavors of hops, caramel, alcohol, grainy and mild hops.  Finishes with a lasting appeal.

Bottle. Pours a beautiful amber color.  Smells earthy with a strong aroma of wood--like cedar. Taste is expectedly hoppy for something called ’maximus’. Spicy in the mouth. Taste is strong, dry, and has a medium/long finish. I can’t shake the wood taste. Jeeez.
nice copper color minimal head, hoppy citrus aroma, flavor has  lots of piney hops with some citrus on the finish. decent

Big bottle. Pours a very nice hazt deep golden colour with a big long lasting rocky white head. Sweet very hoppy aroma. Flavour is sweet with a lot of hops, very fruity, citrus. Dry fruity finish. Very tasty brew!
Gold color with a thin head.  Pretty decent citrus hop aroma.  Definite citrus hop taste with ample pine hop.  Strong dry malt.  It reminded me of Bells Hopslam, but not as grand.
Coppery color with off white head. Aroma is almost minimally hoppy for an IIPA, and the same goes for the flavor. Mediocre at best.
Pours a nice golden caramel amber.  Nice soft malt and sweet citrus hops on the nose.  Nice creamy mouthfeel with hints of citrus hops as well as a nice floral finishing bitterness.
massive floral hops on this pale honey pour.  Liquified flower shop in this unusally creamy beer.  Hops not over the top like so many IPAs.

drank out of jesus’s grail, this ipa has a light lasting foamy head, malty and citrusy aroma taste is light hops periody malt a little taint as well. goes in sweet ends dry, a decent beer. drinkable just not amazing nor one of the better ipas ive had

Ah, a very nice offering from Lagunitas, who are known for their specialties and their occasional duds.  This is as advertised, a highly hopped IPA that has a good bite and lingering hop flavor on the palate.  Not sure if I’d call it a double IPA, but it’s much better than their standard IPA, if not just for the fresh taste alone.  Glad I picked up a 6’er.
Hazy orange color with a beige head. Aroma of pine and citrus hops. Flavor of grapefruit hops. Not very malty, and pretty mild for a 2IPA, but its really good.

on cask at the Night of the Living Ales 07. i’ve not been a big fan of this beer or brewery for that matter but found the cask version quite tasty. nice pnw hop balanced well.3.6. 



2008 vintage, 12oz bottle, 8.0%abv version. pours clear golden with white head. nose is piney and citrus hops but a big grainy malt aroma coming through and this really isn’t that hoppy. was isn’t that hoppy also, an earthy grainy flavor with some grapefruit hop notes. this is more like a single ipa or a 1.5 ipa. calling it maximus is a bit of a joke. 3.2.
Bottle.  Strong hop aroma and some malt.  It felt a little too carbonated on the palate.  Good hop flavor with nice bitterness, but could use some malt for balance.

Poured a reddish orange; medium head.  Aroma of grapefruit, citrus and orange.  Nice, light oily mouthfeel.  Pretty subdued for a DIPA, but still tasty.  Pretty good balance, with a caramel malt flavor.  About average for the style.
This is an outstanding beer!  It has an aroma off of its orange glow that really spikes with different layers of complexity...fruits, herbs, and a nice sense of hops.
Bottle.  Pours with reddish/orangeish color and lots of head.  Pleasant bitter smell, and the hops predominate but not too overpowering like some other IPA’s.  Great balance, IMO.

Aroma of an almost lipton iced tea mix smell and a small amount of malt on the nose. Pours a clear copper color. Taste is less sweet than other IPAs and has a nice bitter hop tastes Creamy mouth feel and lasting finish.

A dark orange appearance with a beige head. The aroma is full of pine, grapefruit, and oranges. I catch a little perfume in there as well. This wasnt as BIG as some IPAs Ive had which isnt always bad. A well balanced beer with more grapefruit and oranges showing up in the flavor. The finish was quite bitter. Top notch IIPA in my book.
Draft at the Bistro’s 7th DIPA Fest: Nose of citrus hops; Hazy copper samll off-white head; flavor of citrusy hop bitterness; not that good!
Light amber/orange color. A little sweet a little citrus. A little weak for a double but still quite good.
Bottled. Hazy orange with creamy white head. Aroma of citrus and resin. Sweet with a nice hop finish. A good brew, but a little too sweet for my taste.

(Bottle) Pours a orangy amber color with a nice white head. Nice full palate, and full hoppy aroma. Smooth, creamy mouthfeel. Lots of hops in here, but nothing abrasive or harsh. Seemed very similar to their regular IPA, just hoppier.

Feb. 4, 2007; 22 oz. "bomber" purchased for $3.99 at Chanatry’s Market, Utica NY.  Amber pour; thin, quickly-dissipating head.  Minimal lacing.  Aroma is tastefully muted, but just as neatly balanced as the outstanding round, full-bodied -- and eminently smooth -- flavor & palate.



Like Lagunitas’ excellent flagship IPA, this Imperial weighs in at the lighter end of the scale for its style (7.5% ABV, 72 IBU), thankfully eschewing over-the-top "novelty drink" status. The result is the most "drinkable" -- almost session-worthy -- IIPA I’ve yet tried.



Life is wonderful when people make beer like this.

22oz from Liqourama:  I’m sorry, I thought this was a wonderful beer.  It was a beautiful amber color with a nice frothy head, with smell of pine, citrus and caramel.  The taste was of the same.  Lots of hops, malt.  Carbination was at minimum, and it is very smooth.  I would love to have more.

I love the beautiful look of this beer.  Its really cloudy with a dark orange hus and off white lasting head.  The aroma is that of a good IPA, citrus and sweet.  I think overall this is a supper yummy beer.  I don’t like to rate based on category, but this is not an imperial/double IPA.  My girlfriend, who is not a bitter fan, didn’t even think this was bitter.  I didn’t either.

aroma is all citrus, and hops!
one of the better IIPA’s i’ve had. i havent had many, but man this is great stuff! love it! flavour is all citrus, and bitterness

22 oz bottle. Perfect execution of the IIPA/DIPA. Not over the top like some of the great ones out there, approachable yet assertive at the same time. Cloudy orange/copper color, great head, First you start with the citrus/frutal grapefruit, pineapple gifts of the generous hopping no doubt. Finishes nicely wiht what i’ll describe as a smoky/peaty taste. 
I like it . A good introductory beer for anyone that wants to start with imperial IPAs.

I wanted to try an IPA, but didn’t know where to go. So I chose this one, based on the good things I’ve herad about it. Man, it was good. Smell is really strong and faintly of orange. Pours a dark amber color with no head to speak of. Taste is very strong, so you know what your drinking. Would buy this IPA again.

Clear copper body topped by a medium off-white head.  This is a very clean IIPA.  The relatively low abv is well hidden so the beer feels like an intense IPA rather than an IIPA.  Grainy malts, peppery hops, low sweetness, oily body.  Very hoppy with medium bitterness.  Excellent, trully a maxi-must.

Bomber. Oily-looking pour coalesces into a cloudy copper/orange hue. Uninspiring beige head nonetheless leaves a legacy of creamy swirls on the surface of the beer and glass. Upfront woody, grapefruity hop nose; pineapple/tangerine, caramel malt, diacetyl, and plastic mingle in its wake. Sappy and sugary on the tongue, woody and herbal with a huge pine/rosemary character. The fiinish is abuzz with charred sugar, orangey hop spice, and warming ethanol. Moderately full palate; gritty. Ashtray and pithy bitter aftertaste. Woefully identical to any grapefruit-and sugar "C-hop" double IPA.

Pours a cloudy orangish hue with a lasting white head.  Obvious hoppy aroma, some pine, light floral, although I detect sweet glazed donuts... ?  Anyway, body is light for the style, not thick or viscous like other 2IPA’s.  Real citrus bite to this one.  A decent beer, not too complex, not overloaded with hops, just easy drinking and tasty.

Bomber.  Pours a hazy copper with a thick, creamy off-white head that last and laces the glass.  Aroma is a blend of citrus, pine and resiny, with a hint of malty sweetness.  Palate is medium, carbonation is medium, with very fine bubbles adding a light prickly sensation.  Flavor is a very good balance of hoppiness and malty sweetness.  For an imperial, you could complain that it’s not hoppy enough, but I find the balance very pleasing, much like that of DFH’s 90 minute IPA.  Good hoppiness, but not overly bitter or astringent.  Overall, a very enjoyable beer, one of the better ones I’ve had from Lagunitas.  Definitely recommend.

Re-Rate..Pours clear orange/amber with a small light tan head. Strong piny and citric hop aroma with a semi-sweet toasty caramel malt overtone. Big piny hops upfront that slowly lead into a roasted malt, and caramel finish. Medium sticky palate with a bit of spice and bitterness. Well-balanced and enjoyable. (Original rating. 8 4 7 3 16, either way a 3.8)
22 oz bottle. Pours cloudy copper color with minimal off white head. Aroma of hops and taste of piney hops with lite bitter after taste.
Bomber. Hazy light orange color. Perfect crisp, hop aroma. This is an intense hop beer. The alcohol is hard to detect, especially for a beer with a slightly higher percentage than many beers.

22oz bottle. Pours hazy light orange.  Wonderfully pungent, fresh hoppy aroma with a flavor to match. Possibly the most refreshing, thirst-quenching beer I’ve ever tasted. Very clean and crisp. The hops reign supreme here, and mighty tasty they are! Citrus flavors add to the  surprisingly light-bodied, almost briskness of this beer. Dense, tight, wispy lacing that just coats the glass. 7.5% alcohol is virtually undetectable. This beer strikes me as kind of simple for a 2IPA, but in a refreshingly straight-forward, uncluttered, GOOD way. This is a beer that knows what it wants to be and succeeds with clarity of purpose. I can’t wait ’til summer to have this to cool down and chill out with. Excellent!

THis hazy orange ale poured with a decent off-white head. There is a nice blend of malt and hops, resulting in a pleasant balanced flavor that is initially slightly sweet, then a slightly bitter. There are noticeable citrus and pine characteristics. Overall, a pretty good quaff.
22oz bottle.  Orangein color.  Citrus aroma.  Kinda watery for a DIPA.  More like an IPA  Taste of cascade hops.  Not very impressed.

pours a dark orange with a one finger off white, light tan head. a little cloudy as well. aroma is orange peel hops with a little sweet malt. flavor is orange peel hops with a little sweet malt and an oily feel in the mouth. medium body with descent lacing. little bread aroma as it warms and also in the flavor. kind of an in between of an ipa and 2ipa, but definetly good, not the best i have had of course, but definetly for hop heads like myself. theres a little carbonation and has a little spicey bite at the end.

Bottle sampled from the Mad Indian collection, cheers bro. Pours with an orange copperish beautiful color, with a large off white head. Aroma of hops, pine, and sweet malts. The flavor is well blended, sweet, bitter, citrus, and slight trace of caramel. Decent body, alcohol is masked well. Good brew.

Worthy Bomber.  Super, strong citrus and hops nose, sweet and orangey.  Clear orange pour with a foamy beige head.  Sticky and bitter, loads of hops and piney resin.  Lots of citrus with a touch of biscuit.  Fullish mf, dry and resinous hoppy aftertaste, warms long into the night.  Nice!
Thanks to Ramenen. Bottle: True IPA but a bit one dimensional, alcohol level well hidden. Nice specimen but not best in its class.
Tried it after Goose Island Double IPA.  Felt a bit flat, and too bitter at the end.  Lacked more flavors, you could only taste the hops.

Bottled. Shared with Stegosaurus. Orange/copper pour with nice white head. Hop and pine aromoa instantly punch you in the face. The first milli second of taste is strong over bearing hops but it instantly mellows out to a more enjoyable balance. Body was a little thin but I enjoyed this brew alot.
Copper body, off-white head, PNW hop nose. Well-balanced IPA. Why does the brewer think this is some how "maximal"; it is hardly exceptional in its gravity, IBUs or ABV! Nice beer, though.

Bottle. So, it almost 8.am and I just finished writing my 5th semester project, which is to be handed in at 1.pm today, after an all-night effort. What better way to celebrate for a hophead like myself than with my very first double IPA?! Pours a hazy orange-amber with a nice, but diminishing off-white/yellowish head. Some lacing. Soft hoppy and malty aroma. Notes of rye. Flavour is bitter hoppy and malty. A bit candy-like. Licorice bitterness in the finish. Nice body. This was nice, but I had hoped for more – especially bitterness-wise. 20-12-06.

Bottle courtesy of Hogtownharry: Poured a beige/yellow color ale with a medium bubbly head with average retention. Aroma of C-hops is quite powerful with lots of citrus and floral notes. Taste is quite bitter with huge citrus and floral hops with a big grassy feel. Malt is more subdued then I would have liked it with limited caramel. Body is about average with medium carbonation. Good take on the style but it is missing something (malt?) to make it truly great.

Pine and pineapple.  Slightly peppery and spicy.  Sweet malt balances this well.  Rather than a balanced beer where both things even each other out, this is a whole lot of hops, but then some good malt to provide contrast (if that makes any sense).  Alcohol is a bit low for a double, but the flavor is big enough to justify it.

Hazy orange body, fast away off white head; Spritzy, peachy, malty, nothing special nose; Soft textured body, to little carbonation, bitter sweet body; Medium sized bitter sweet finish, peachy aromas. Not my kind of IPA, unclear and unbalanced.

Bottle from santa: Pours a nice copper color with a nice, slightly off white head. Smell is seems pleasant, some pine, citrus, and maybe some caramel hidden in the back. Taste is piney, with a hint of citrus. In no way is this IPA overpowering. It’s well balanced and very well done.

Not too sweet and undercarbonated like other Impy IPA. Great flavour and dry without any overbearing, unseemly bite. Clearly an IPA but a steadier experince from nose to finish like some of the great dry pale ales are.  Great especially give the affordabe price. Only drawback is an odd aftertaste.

Bottle.   Pours hazy copper color with a big white head that stick around a while.   Aroma is floral hops, pine, citrus.   Flavor is some malt, grapefruit, pine.   Palate is medium bodied, with some stickiness.   I would have rated it higher  but it’s more of an IPA than IIPA.
Hoppy and malty.  Some odd malt flavors.  A little too sweet.  The hops are nice and hide the alcohol decently.

22 oz. bottle.  Pours a coppery orange with a pale yellow-white head that held up quite well.  Very nice lacing.  Wonderful aroma of pine and grapefruits.  These same traits come out in the flavor as well along with some caramel sweetness.  Dry, bitter finish but not excessively so.  This is a real nice IPA.

22 oz bomber shared with kdrobb2k.  Pours a light orange coppery color with a nice white frosting for a head.  Aroma is piney hoppy with grapefruit overtones.  Flavor is piney as well with grapefruit flavor.  Excellent west coast style IPA.
Very dark cloudy orange, not real hoppy aroma. Head is very dry and hoppy. The beer is also excellently dry and hoppy, but smooth in the finish to not kill your taste buds. Great.

Pours a very clear orange with a thick off-white head. Aroma is malty, with a touch of floral hops, and loads of citrus hops - some grapefruit, sweet (mandarin) orange, apricot. The flavor is more of the same - amazing fresh citrus and hop taste, sweet malts than balance the hops quite well,  and hints of caramel and honey on the middle of the tongue from those sweet malts. The finish is bitter, grapefruity, and somewhat dry with a long, cloying, hoppy after-taste. The mouthfeel is very nice - smooth and velvety. The carbonation is just right - it isn’t sharp on the tongue, but does present itself by subtly tickling the middle and back of the tongue. A rather good IPA.

22oz bottle-pours a thick to rocky light tan head that laces with gold color.  Aroma is lots of sweet citrus hops, zesty, with some bitterness, secondary medium malt.  Taste is lots of sweet citrus hops-grapefruit, bitter, a bit raw, zesty, pine, secondary medium malt.  Mild/OK carbonation.

Pour is orange with a small white head that thined out to large bubbles.  Aroma is a nice helping of pine/citrus hops.  Very clean and refreshing.  Flavor is also a very nice crisp hop with a malty biscutness.  Looks great smells better and taste even better.  No real alcohol presence but I know its there.  Pretty darn good beer.

Pours deep red-orange with some pink highlights. Small, diminishing cream-colored head.

The aroma is promising with lots of fir-tree hops and a fair amount of balancing caramel maltiness. The nose also picks up definite orange presence and suggestions of a perfume that I might as well call papaya.

The flavor profile is uncomplicated: bitter. There’s a little acidity, some halfhearted attempt at balancing sweetness, but not much. Just bitter. And some alcohol. I think the palate’s a bit on the thin side and there’s definitely some metallic tinge to the finish, which is fine. 

I’ve had a lot of this style lately and this one doesn’t hold muster. Seems nice up front, but doesn’t back it up in the mouth.
bomber.  Amber in color.  Aroma is citrus hops and malt.  Taste is citrus and malt with a powerful piney bitterness.

So breaks the fast ...lagunitas...ya I need this lagunitas...mild foam ..copper colored... loose lacing....up front grapefruit and lemon peel...finish is bitter with a piney aftertaste..not my favorite IPA, but well crafted.
Bottled. Golden coloured with a rather large head. A bit malty and very hoppy. Slightly perfumed but alltogether a pretty good body. Hints of pines and soap.

Pours a pale amber with a marginal fluffy white head.  Aroma dominated by floral hops.  Smooth, clean, crisp and hoppy taste.  Sweet maltiness and citrus notes come through as well.  Well balanced; not too much alcohol noted.  Very good.

Orange-amber in colour, creamy beige tinged head, great lacing with about 1cm of sediment in the bottom of my glass.  The aroma is of piney hops, caramel malts, some light alcohol, orange and grapefruit.  The flavour is quite piney, lots of caramel sweetness, some orange citrus, earthy.  Thick and chewy mouthfeel, medium body, medium/high carbonation.  Finishes long with some alcohol warmth and lots of hops.  Pretty good, I was surprised by the large amount of sediment.


650ml bottle from Premier Gourmet in Buffalo, New York.  No Best Before date.

650ml brown bottle. Deep gold colour, full thick, white head, lots of sticky clinging foam. At first pine jumps out in the aroma, then lighter citrus notes, lemon and grapefruit, malt is barely there. Slight initial fruiiness, sweet orange, light caramel malt sweetness in the middle, finishes with abundant pine/grapefruit hop flavours, bittereness is moderate in intensity but long lasting. Medium creamy body, cabonation is light and soft. Alcohol is not noticable at all. This was my first Imperial/Double IPA, it was not quite as bold as I was expecting, but I was not disappointed. Rather I found it strong, hoppy and flavourful without being imposing. Will be returning to this beer often.

Pours copper with a dense off-white head that gives very nice lacing.  The aroma has lots of floral and grapefruit hops with some spiciness and only enough malt to lightly balance the hops. Medium body with some fairly sharp carbonation.  The taste starts with woody hops that are not harsh like many along with the floral and grapefruit traits on the aroma.  The finish has lots of woody / piney hops with a touch of tree bark.  This tastes to me like a middle ground between IPAs and IIPAs - solid effort.

The Maximus is indeed a beer to be reckoned with. It pours a medium amber color, crested by an average, fizzy off-white head. A mostly diminishing head leaves fair lacing in its wake, as your eyes peer down into the sparkling body below. Aroma is of moderate flowery hops and light yeast, with a presence of alcohol. Initial taste is moderately sweet, which caught us off guard, but we were slapped back into reality with a moderately bitter finish. Medium on the mouth, it has a watery texture with soft carbonation. A moderate alcohol tinge is left behind to remind you that this is not a light beer. Dog gone good!

12oz Bottle. Pours orange with a creamt off white head. Piney hop and rich malty aroma. Initial flavor of toffee, caramel, toasted malt. The middle is bitter and piney. Fruity and juicy hop finish, with more malt and some hints of  alcohol. Not bad. One of the more maltier beers from Lagunita. I drank this twice, once in a bomber and the other in a twelve ounce bottle. The bomber was better IMO. This is probably my favorite beer from them, and I would have no problem buying this again, especially at the price they charge for it.
Wow... I’ve died and gone to hop heaven. Great hop bite with a hint of maltiness. Alcohol is subtle but noticeable. Very, very good.
bottle. golden color. large head. nice hops in aroma and taste. soft and creamy hops. not bad at all.
hoppy aroma.  orange colored.  large frothy, off-white head.  very nice hop and malt blend.  very good IIPA.  i’ll have another.

22 oz. bottle on 10/20/06. Gold pour with a large off white head. Fresh grainy aroma with nice citrus notes. Medium body with just the right carbonation, and a slightly resinous mouthfeel. Good sweet caramel backbone that is beautifully balnced with spice and citrus hop flavors that brings it to a pleasing dry finish.

Aroma is floral, pine and citrus hops with a deep caramel malt sweetness beneath. Body is a murky orange/caramel color and holds  a creamy and lassting white head. Bitter piney hop fore with some milder grapefruit notes and a big dollop od syrupy caramel sweetness that runs through all flavor ranges. Decent as this style goes, but the hops become distracting to my palate after a short time.

Dark amber with a nice white head which fades a bit while drinking. Aroma is of pine. Flavor is pine and citrus hops with a decent malt backbone. Definitely a beer for hopheads, but remains drinkable. Might not be the most complex or interesting IIPA, but it is quite enjoyable for the hopheads out there.

Bottle 65 cl. Clear dark amber colour with a decent off-white head. Fruity (oranges/grapes) and malty aroma. Sweet flavour and thick palate. Mandatory dry and very bitter finish. Not the most sophisticated I2PA...
Bottle. Citric, piney and orangepeel hop aroma. Amber, golden, creamy head. Quite dry pine, grassy hops dominate. Puckering dry finish. Grassy and orangepeel aftertaste. Quite extreme.

Pours orange with a dirty white head. Aroma is big bready malts, carmel, and toasted notes. Flavor is sweet bready malts. Dry bitter finish. The body is pretty thick initially, but seems to get more watery with each sip.

Bottle.  Pours deep copper color, with a medium white head.  Hops in the aroma, piney and citrusy.  Taste is somewhat subdued for an IIPA, citrus and pine hops with some cookie malt. Decent bitterness right from the start.   It’s ok.

This beer starts with a deep, brassy hue capped by a moderate and white frothy head.  Hops are at the forefront in the aroma with big elements of spruce, grapefruit and orange.  The malts are subdued, merely a touch of cookies and light caramel.  Beginning with a light caramel sweetness, a bold hoppy prelude and strong fruity acidity, there is a slow malt fade as the finish reveals a sharp and striking hop bite.  The finish is off-dry, the texture managing a certain slickness despite the bustliing carbonation.  I could easily do without the caramel presence and a drier finish, but this is still a very effective hop vehicle and a good (non-barleywine!) DIPA.

Poured from a 22 oz. bomber into my Duvel glass a hazy orange/amber color with a medium white head. Aroma of piney hops. Big beer flavor you’d expect from a 2IPA and then some. Full of hop bitterness from start to finish, a hop lovers delight. Backed by a mild malty sweetness to balance the flavors rather nicely. The hops left my taste buds tingling for quite a while afterward. This is one nice big beer. If you like hops, try it.

Pours light golden with a mostly receding off-white head. Aroma of orange hop resins. Taste is aggressive with hop resins that are fruity and piney. Notes of toffee, grapefruit, and pine. Mouthfeel is medium bodied and resinous with lively carbonation.

The flavor had some similarities to an amber ale...very strong malt presence and sweetened with carmel.  Aroma was piney and some notes of grapefruit. Alcohol was somewhat noticable but not overwhelming. 7.5% got to me pretty well.  Palate was the best part....well balance of dryness and biterness.

Amber, with a thick tan head.  Sweet hoppy aroma, almost like the sweetness in fruit or flower’s aroma.  Medium body with a bigger malt flavor than anticipated.  A bit sweet and lingering in the finish.

22oz - Aroma is fresh floral and grapefruit hops with a little malt tossed in for good measure.  Pours transparent orange with a small head and great lacing.  Flavor matches aroma.  Palate is crisp and tart.  Very tasty IIPA.

Lighter amber color, kind of a vibrant oragne color; only slightly hazey.  Lively carbonation with a lasting pale yellow head that stays around and leaves a generous amount of lacing.  Aroma is 
subtle, but complex with hints of citrus.  Flavor is sweet citrus (not overpowering) and the bitterness is good, but subdued at first and slowly builds up through the sweetness. The 72.41 IBU doesn’t nail you all at once.  The bitterness lingers through the finish and becomes a little dry.  Alcohol is very well integrated with only a hint in the flavor toward the end.  Gets better and better the more you drink.  Lagunitas is another brewery that is quickly gaining my favor!

12 oz bottle (7.5% alcohol), $ from Belmont Party Supply.

Clear orange colour.  Off white head with broad lacing.  Big aroma.  Hoppy and malty flavour, like a true IPA.  Lingering finish, you don’t want it to leave.  It’s warm and humid with thundershowers, like a Mashonaland afternoon.  Perfect day for a Lagunitas Maximus.  This is from the bottle.  I’ve had it on draft at my local and it’s even better

Had never heard of Lagunitas, and just picked this up at Green’s. Damn glad I did. Poured to the expected golden orange with thick off-white head that stuck around for the whole glass, and left excellent lacing. Aroma was very hoppy citrus, mostly grapefruit and lemons, and taste was more of the same. Palate was very bitter and dry, but with a hint of sweet malt. I had the bomber, and drank it slowly, so that at the end, I was beginning to feel the effects of the 7.5% alcohol. This was a mosyt excellent beer, and I hope to try more.
Bottle. Good citrus aroma, a decent blend of lemon and lime. Very orangey look with thin head. Good taste with slight alcohol hit. Decently smooth and very drinkabale. Good balance. Pretty good IIPA.
Orange body with a large, light orange head.   Flavor is intensely hoppy with a nice hint of sweet caramel malt.  Nice, fruity aroma is not overwhelmed by the intense hops experienced in the taste.

it smells frothy, like fresh rain in a hop field, citrus behind. deep gold approaching orange. thin head. the top of my mouth tastes citrus, while the bottom is kind of piney and a little sour. sleek across the tongue. A delicate balance to work a body light as this with the strength of hops and alcohol. & at $2.50 a bomber on sale, where in the ratings does value figure in?

An observation about beer is that fruit flies in the area will quickly appear when a good beer is opened, and this one made them fly in immediately.
Pours a large, long lasting, creamy head over a copper colored body. 
Light doughy malt and pine resin hop aroma.
Well balanced flavor with a long dry finish. A good one.

Was pysched that Lagunitas beers finally showed up in Georgia.  Kind of a let-down, though.  Heavy hop aroma with orange, resin.  Creamy head that mostly lasted.  Expected much more hoppiness as this is 72 IBU’s.  This was more like a West Coast IPA, rather than a DIPA.  The palate was surprisingly soft.

Dark tan with a burnt orange glow, crystal clear.  Medium white head with find bubbles.  A very pretty beer.  Spicy, citrus aroma.  Full bodied, bitter.  Grapefruit, citrus dominate the flavor.  Nice malt balance though, some caramel and plum in there.  Another winner from Lagunitas at a reasonable price.  Here’s to feeling good all the time.

Bomber.  Clear caramelly/amber with a short, well-retained cap of white head... some spotty lacing.  The aroma found bunches of hops (fresh grapefruit and pine needles primarily)... also some candy corn and caramel backing.  Flavor had a lot of bitter pine resin and citrus more as a highlight... sticky caramel backing.  Balance felt only ok.. a bit syrupy on the palate at times.  Solid beer.

Bomber.  Clear orange color with a thick offwhite-cream head, mostly lasting and producing bands of lacing.  Aroma of floral, citrus and piney hops with some faint cheesy yeast.  Big woody pine and grapefruit rind hop flavor, with a luscious caramel malt foundation.  I can understand the comments about oversweetness of the malt, but I think there’s enough hoppiness to make it a fairly good balance in the end.  Smooth palate. Lots of hops on the finish, with a resiny aftertaste.  Wouldn’t necessarily consider this an imperial, but rather a "Big IPA."  Great stuff regardless.

Very nice beer - not sure for  a double IPA, however.  Caramel malt and light hops  in the nose.  An exquisite blend of bittersweetness.  Nice copper color.   Just a  little sweet for what I was expecting from a I-IPA. That said, very nice brew.
Tap. Pours with a copper to orange color and medium head. Aromas of fruit and flowers. Pretty intense hops flavors, very bitter and a little bit unbalanced. Finish is comparatively mild, but lasts.

Pours an amber color with a decent sized white head.  Aroma of piney hops, caramel malt, and citrus.  Taste is much sweeter than I expected.  Flavors of caramel, honey, malt, citrus, and pine.  I can even taste a little warming alcohol.  Tastes good, but strange to have an IIPA with more sweet malt then hops in the flavor.  Fairly thin for the style.

This is quite the sessionable little DIPA. Pours bright copper with an almost-tan head that starts foamy and holds as a thick film. The nose finds a Christmas Tree of piney aromas with a backdrop of roasty malts and mild honey notes. Peppery alcohol chimes in late. Flavor seems well balanced albeit a bit thin. Hops are in check as sweet malts overtake, but a bitter, piney finish lingers. I can’t see the IBUs in this being too far above 90. It’s a nice brew but it seems that the hops were used more for aroma than flavor.


Puchased at United Liquors, Frankfort, IL 60423

Dark orange/copper pour with a nice sized tan head which lingers.  Hoppy with citrus and floral notes.  Nice active carbonation and high hop bitterness.  Somewhat sweet but with a nice bready malt middle.  Resinous finish, hops linger for quite some time.  Pretty good double.  No hint of alcohol.  Liked it.
12oz bottle poured an orange color with a small head. Aromas of caramel malts and piney hops. Taste is bitter with a good malt balance and a dry finish. A good IPA just not the best double.

Pours a clear orange color with a steady big head: I love it. The smell is worth drooling over: some fresh flowers, orange, tangerine and other citric fruits. Flavor is mostly in line with the hop aroma, soft flower flavor, but when I say that it doesn’t give this beer justice. Great lacing down the glass. There’s something about this beer that makes "MAXIMUS" appropriate.

This is not a one-dimensional IPA.  There are some real nice toasted malt and caramel notes.  The hops don’t overpower the aroma , although there are a lot of carpet-y arrangements.  Nice carbonation and very refreshing aftertaste make this a solid deluxe IPA.  I’d definitely buy it again.  I’d like to try it on tap.

Clear amber color with a big offwhite head. Big ups to Tom for this tasty double.  Big piney, hopy aromas.  Nice malt that just coats your mouth enough.  Slightly creamy and nice slight bitter finish.  Very smooth.

Bomber.  Awesome piney hop aroma and even better thick, foggy caramel color.  A bit fizzy at the end, great balance to the bitterness.  I’ve been drinking the regular IPA but will search this one out now.

Pours an amber color with a medium off-white head.  Aroma is of citrus and pine hops, and caramel.  Flavor is the same with a decent bitter finish.  Much better then their regular IPA, not that the regular IPA is bad because it’s pretty good.  Definately a decent double IPA.

Bomber from the Foodery in Philly.  Wonderfully bright grapefruit and piney aroma.  Bracing hoppy flavor with more grapefruit and a toffee/caramel note.  Enough malt to provide a reasonably good balance but the hops tend to get the best of the glass every now and then.  Silky and creamy mouthfeel and a crisp, dry and very bitter finish (maybe just a tad too bitter every few sips).  But for the occassional balance issues, this would be a great IIPA but it’s still quite good and worth more than just a try.

Nose of pine & resin, brown sugar, alcohol & flowers.  Pours a sparkling clover honey. 
The light frothy off-white head is fully diminishing with minimal lacing.  The robust flavor
has a wonderful citric start leading to moderate alcohol warmth at the middle; and resolves
into a rich bitter finish.  The medium palate is dry and soft.

Thanks to after4ever for the sample. Pours a cloudy orange amber with a straw head. The aroma is lightly sweet, with citrus and floral/grassy notes. The body is medium and creamy, even a bit sticky.  The taste starts toffee sweet, with the same notes as the smell… then hops really kick in. The finish is clean and bitter.
Bottle 650ml - Alone - hhmmmmm lovely. Clear amber - off-white head. Malty, sweet, very hoppy, grass, pine, citrus, resin, bitterness, honey.

Pours a clear copper orange with a mod-large light yellow head.  Aroma of caramel malts, grain, sticky resiny pine hops and a little grapefruit.  As far as aromas go, this blows their IPA out of the water.  This does have some balance, though it leans toward the hops a fair amount, as expected.  The taste is mainly grapefruit and pine, with some caramel backing it up.  A slight bit of peanuts as well?  Light-mod carbonation, medium body.  Very nice.  Right on the average of 3.75.

Bomber. Light copper with a raging dirty blonde head: it froths all the way to the bottom of the glass when poured from a height of a couple of inches. Maybe the best-smelling IPA this summer; rich with bitter floral hops--a real earthy snap there. Thick sweet bread dough notes underneath. Creamy body with some carb tingle but perfectly balanced. Plenty of sweet malt there, but mostly a beautifully modulated hop ride: floral and tangy on the palate, crisp and clean on the finish. Great stuff. Other than the ABV, one of the best drink-all-day beers around.
UPDATE: Draft at the Parkway’s Day of IPAs. KInd of a snooze on draft, at least with this first sample today.

Poured a hazy straw yellow mice fluffy white head. Aromas were grapfruit hop and citrus. Flavor reflected the aroma with grapfruit and citrus with a piny like flavor as well as a earthy note. well balanced flavor quite simple and good

12 oz. bottle- color of Honey, with a lingering off white  head - nose of  hopps , grapefruit , some lemon / lime , and  floral – taste of bitter hops , citrus , sweet , and malts – not that hoppy for a double but a good taste for a ipa - body is silky , low acidity , and medium to low carbonation – aftertaste of citrus , grapefruit , and semi sweet
Excellent stuff. Poured orange with a big white head. Aroma was terrific pine and rind. Flavor was an assault of tart, spicy, floral hops and a good amount of sticky sweet candy malt.

Medium amber in color, thick whiteish head.  Great malty and hops aroma with a subtle sweetness.  Taste is much more intense with hops (powerful hops), citrus, and florals.  A crisp and dry finish.  Well balanced flavor and one of my favorite IIPA’s from now on.

22 oz bottle. Poured clear light orange with a white foamy head. Aroma is my favorite in this, like putting your head in a hopsack, with pine being predominant. A little bit of bitterness at the end, but not what I would really expect of an imperial, but very nice.

Wow, I love this! I have been drinking IPA all week as their has been a local "festival" of sorts. This Maximus is a bottle. Very fresh, full and balanced. Lots of citrus, pine and floral flavors. I wish this wasn’t a limited release.

Cloudy orange amber,small beige head. Small scarce bead.Scotch alcohol nose.Starts malty,medium strength lasting hop finish,molasses notes. Medium alcohol heat. Thick and chewy
Not one of my favorites
poured an orange-amber hue with a frothy white head mostly pine notes on the aroma, but a touch of sweet oranges.  Flavor was hoppy yet fruity.  dry finish.

Clear orange color, with a small/medium white head.  A great aroma!!  I would love to have a shampoo that smells like this I think.  Its just a soft and malty, lightly fruity, almost sugary, flowery, hoppy aroma.  The flavour is similar. Sweet, big hops, even some caramel, with a bitter finish.  Almost creamy in consistency.

Pours a rich brownish gold with a thin though smooth and dense white head.  A tiny whirlwind of bubbles coming up to the surface of the beer from the dimple at the bottom of my glass.  The nose is really remarkable.  Big juicy citrus/ grapefruit hops and light sweet malt with hints of peach and bootleather.  The mouthfeel is soft and gentle, reminding me of a beer on cask more than a bottle.  Still obvious small bubbles.  A good bit of light viscosity as well, with a slight alcohol warming.  The flavors are more subdued and rounded than the aroma, though still rather bold.  A big sweet wall of malt up front with light sweetness and more brown sugar and even slightly caramel-like flavors coming through.  As the beer warmed these flavors became closer to molasses at the dark end.  The hops are certainly assertive and blend in a very nice way, though it comes off as slightly soapy at first.  Predominantly floral, with that grapefruit seed-like bitterness and something a bit piney.  There’s something slightly spicey or peppery about this beer, accentuated by the taste of alcohol.  The lingering bitterness comes on quick with the first flavors leaving the mouth rather quickly.  Big bitterness of the grapefruit seed sort with spicy overtones.  Really well executed IPA.  I thought this was a bit too sweet and rich at first, but now I’m sure this is a well balanced beer indeed.

A quality IPA. DIPA may be a little stretch. Color is a light orange and the beer has lasting aroma. No noticeable head. First sip explodes of hoppy bitterness, nice tingle. Long lasting bitterness and very drinkable.......careful. Excellent IPA.

From a 22 oz. brown bomber bottle with a humorous(?) blurb along the right side of front label, no bottled/freshness date.

Made a good appearance, poured a slightly hazy reddish amber hued orange with a foamy head that settled into a thin lacing, good carbonation.

Had a hoppy nose, pine, grapefruit and floral, fruity esters and a very light caramel maltiness.

Crisp, softly slick and hop textured, smooth medium bodied mouthfeel, good DIPA drinkability.

Nice hop taste, piney, grapefruit zest and a tad bit spicy oily, a sweet maltiness that lies underneath the hops, a vague carameliness as well, and a hop resiny finish.

A nice summer seasonal from Lagunitas, tasty and balanced, not the taste bud killer one might except from a DIPA, very enjoyable on a hot summer evening.

Aroma was hppy, some caramel.  Flavor was nice typical double IPA, some citrus, pine etc.  Nice looking, orange, with nice lacing.  IIPA’s are almost never bad, this wasn’t the best I’ve had, but still a pretty good beer.

Amber color; generous and creamy head. Nice aroma of malt and hops, some fruits and resins. Good malty body, with a light liquorice taste, and an interesting bitterness, without being exaggerated; the hops are quite resiny; in the final the bitterness raisies. Mild emotions.

This is a good IPA.  An orangey colour, it pours with a good head that sticks around awhile.  Nice sweet, hoppy nose, which also describes the taste.  It is a well balanced IPA, though a bit on the strong side.  Overall a good choice if you want to try a new IPA.

22 oz bottle.  Maximus is a pretty standard, solid hoppy IPA.  This is so much better than the regular IPA.  But, to call this an imperial IPA is a bit of a stretch in my opinion.  Still, this is one of Lagunitas’ better offerings and a solid west coast IPA.

Maximus is a nice IPA. As others have noted, it is not over the top--especially in this style. The hop aromas are wonderful--as with most IPA’s. The head is very good, hanging around for awhile. The flavor is less hoppy than most IPA’s out there--which makes this an interesting change of pace in the style. The sweetness of this beer is the suprise in my opinion. A slight hint of sweetness peaks through the hop flavor to catch you off guard--in a good way. The finish is nice and clean. A very easy to drink IPA. "

Bomber poured light copper with a 2 finger head. Nice lacing to the end. Sweet hoppy aroma. Hop taste with a hint of pine. I wasn’t getting the citrus/grapefruit that others were. Very good but not mind blowing. Also not enough balls for a IIPA.

65 cl bottle. Yeast at the bottom. Cloudy orange colour with a nice creamy head. Very pleasant hoppy citrus aroma. Nice tasty flavour of a lot of hops, speciely citrus and grapefruit, ends up warming from the alcohol. Very nice.

Extremely sweet aroma of citrus hops and molasses.  Fairly well balanced with bitter hop finish and malty undertones.  Extremely hoppy on several levels.  Good example of a West Coast IPA though not strong enough for an Imperial.
I liked this a lot.  Lots of citrus hops and some sweet swedish fish flavor.  Good beer and i think it was like $4 for a bomber.

Bomber ..	Citusry, apricot, light malts, (very slight aroma - head’s in the way)	Clear copper. Nice long lasting head, lots of small bubbles, good lacing	Malty start w/ a long hoppy(bitter) finish.  Good balance	Medium-full body, medium carbonation, a bit sticky at the end	A tasty, big beer.  A nice balance with an emphasis on hops.  Good beer

22 ounce bottle from BeerandBlues2.  Poured into my Duvel tulip.  Poured on the lighter side of copper with a billowing, resinous, slightly darker than white head.  Very nice lacing.  Gobs and gobs of pine and citrus in the aroma.  If you get your nose deep enough you get friggin’ Pine-Sol.  The flavor is pretty underwhelming.  Not really imperial at all.  Yeah there’s citrus and pine and its a great drink, just not what I look for.  I guess its the price you pay for being a style guy.  The palate is fine.  Sweet and resinous.  I’d really drink this any time, but its not imperial.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a dark copper with virtually no head and minimal lacing.  Nose is hoppy; dominated by west coat hops (cascade?).   Flavor is pretty boring for an IIPA.  Not much going on here...

22 oz Bottle: Pours a deep golden color with an off white head that remains atop for most of the whole beer and leaves sticky foamy residue all along the side of my shaker glass.  Lemon, other citrus, pine, grass, citrus, caramel, wheat ... with the pine and lemon really jumping out at you.  The flavor is sweet initially with a hop power bomb in the middle another sweet malt flavor and hop bitterness to finish off.  An interesting balance.  Some grapefruit, pine, citrus/lemon, caramel flavors.  The caramel is suprisingly strong in the flavor.  Some bitterness as it warms in standard IIPA fashion, although it gives the impression of a heavily carbonated beer (although there are some seriously small bubbles floating to the top, its not an overly carbonated beer).

220z. Bottle:  Clear copper color with a cream colored head and sticky lacing.  Aromas of pine needles, grass & junipers.  Powerful bitter, hoppy taste of graprfruit rinds.  Thick and smooth body with average carbonation.  It leaves a nice bitter aftertaste lingering for sometime.  Delicious.
Yiha 500. Pours a clear brown with a tanned head. Quite bitter. Hoppy aromas of resin, pine and grapefruit. Full bodied. Not overwhelming hoppy and bitter finish. Average IIPA.
22oz bottle.  Rich amber color and long lasting head. A little piney on the tongue and quite hoppy on the aroma but certainly not as bitter as one would expect from an IIPA

Poured an amber-orange color with a small head and minimal lacing. The aroma was light pines with some citrus and grapefruit aromas. The flavor was of mild alcohol, dominated by citrus and some grapefruit hoppy flavors. Light pine hops underneath. The mouthfeel was moderate with light carbonation. A nice beer. Re-rated in 3/3, no changes.

bottle.  frothy, tawny head that laced nicely.  really good color and appearance, more orange than anything else.  Very hoppy, with molassess/horseblancket taste that gradually transformed to a slightly too medicinal sourness.  Over all a great and complex beer.
Not much you can say baout this beer other then it is good.  There are many beers like it, but this one is mine.  It goes well with movies and food.  Gawd bless my beer.

Resin and grapefruit aroma (and malt). Gold tending towards reddish amber (top to bottom under halogen), maybe a ruby hint towards the bottom. Medium feel, malt to start, moving to hops, to grapefruit, to hops. Grapefruit noticeable at the finish. Swish and it’s chewable. Swish and an apricot component appears. And it’s 78 ibu. Nicely astringent when all is done. Pine in the burp. Really, really, great.

A great double IPA from Lagunitas!  I really enjoyed the immense hoppiness from this beer, the hoppiness contributed to my happiness, you could say.  Found it well-balanced, aromatic, yet did not remove the enamel from my teeth, I am pleased to report.  All things considered, an enjoyable beer that should not to be followed by something tamer, such as a regular IPA...

Bottled.  Pours a rich, dark copper color with an ivory head.  Good hoppy aroma with notes on grapefruit, grass and oranges.  Nice malt balance to blend with a good hoppiness.  More grassy notes as well as tons of grapefruit and lemon flavors.  Dry, bitter finish.  This beer is a bit tame by most west-coast IIPA standards but it’s still a fantastic beer.

Sessionable Imperial.  Strong grapefruit and pine nose.   big malt heavy bottom that is almost chewable it’s so dense.  but it has to be, to hold it’s own against the huge PNW hop bite.   Quite easy to drink over and over again.
A strong IPA dark orange in colour.  This is the finest of the Lagunitas beers in my opinion.  Heavy malt character and slight fruitiness, with a strong bitter hoppiness.

A crisp IPA that stands out from the crowd. The body was dark orange. The aroma was caramel and grapefruit with not much else. Nice strong aroma. The taste was bitter with grapefruit and peanut shells. There is also some caramel. Finishes clean. Nicely done.

From a 22oz bottle.
Aroma of yes, big hops, but also off-smells of boiled cabbage with a whiff of burning transformer. The flavor is malt-heavy, offering plenty of bitter hop oils but bringing with it the vegetal flavors of kitchen peelings compost and rather unpleasant (in a beer) iron-pot balti flavors.  In mouthfeel, the beer seems to split two styles; it’s two thick to be a thirst-quenching IPA and too thin to be a mouthwarming sipping IIPA.

6 ounces into the bottle, I’m left underwhelmed and wondering what to do with the remaining 16 ounces.

Golden witha tal head, deflates into an aroma of pine and a light citrus,  Subtle spearmint.  Nice and sweet,of honey and fruits, and frankly not that bitter in the mouth.  After some warming and waiting (in the mouth and the glass) the hops start to come through.  Seems to be an american hop, centenital or warrior.  Very drinkable but very sweet for the style, and thin on the back of the tounge.  Worth a revisit to further explore this beer.
Rich hoppy IPA with more malt than is typical for a CA IPA.  Nice flavor complexity in both nose and mouth.  Dark (for an IPA) pour, big head, med-full body.

Poured an effervescent amber with a small semi-creamy off-white head.  Wonderful aroma of floral essences, citrus and pine hops and a touch of candy sugar.  Flavor is hoppy with lots of nice citrus and pine flavor, rather dry.  Light sweetness underneath the hops.  Very nice and tasty west coast double IPA from a brewery I’m coming to respect more and more.

This beer looked absolutely beautiful in the glass, red/brown amber, with a nice head and lace.  Orange sweetness with lots of citrusy hops, long-lasting orangey bitterness.  Fairly well-balanced, fruity but with a subdued hop nose.  A little sticky, with a slight alcohol warmth.  Thick mouthfeel with a lot of bubbles.

22oz bottle: Pours a golden amber brownish color, big bubbles.  Big white head, somewhat lasting.  Strong hop aroma-citrus, bitter, sweet.  Semi-bitter, semi-sreet taste, small sour hops aftertaste, pretty smooth.

Bottle. Pours a bright copper with just a perfuntory head.  Very hoppy on the nose.  That hop profile continues on into the  mouth with some sweet, caramel that attempts to ward off the hop attack.  I prefer my 2IPA’s with more of a stand-off between the two.  This was more of an IPA IMHO.
Now this is an IPA ! Thin head on a orange body. Obvious hoppy flavour,  a bbit sweet, interesting fruity hints, including some lemon, quite a beer !
Copper color with no head.  Nice hop aroma.  Lots of hop flavor and bitterness.  No lingering bitterness.  Medium body.  Nice beer.
Bottle.  Pours orange with some reddish hues.  More of a floral hop profile with the standard pine and citrus notes in the background.  Balanced nicely.  Good double but by no means huge.

Pours a hazy deep orange color with a nice amount of foamy white head.  Aroma is very hoppy: slight pine and honey maple, grapefruit, and kiwi.  Flavor is kinda syrupy, sweet and heavy on the palate, piney and very citric, warming finish. Overall, very very enjoyable.

bottle.  amber pour with huge frothy off white colored head.  nice floral, fruit, hops and lemongrass.  full bodied. great hops with bitterness in the aftertaste.  Amazing white grapefruit tartness.  very impressed.

Bottled.  Clear, light amber solor with a small-med offwhite head.  Body is sparkling, lace is in sheets and rings...beautiful.  Mouth is medium with lots of soft, creamy carb giving it a full feel.  Lightly dry finish.  Some syrupy and watery characters.  Aroma is fruity and sweet with noticeable pollen.  Light honey, floral, touch of white bread, peachy for fruit.  Flavor is honeycomb, brown sugar, pollen, touch of honey, pine, grapefruit, some flavor that tastes like a fruity alcohol left in a wooden barrel until it went sour.  Fruitiness is peach/apricot.  Warmth is felt rather than tasted--alcohol is invisible.  This stuff is well rounded and developed--as a woman, the voluptuous, developed version of the girl--version of the regular IPA.  Very drinkable--sessionable even, although it’s a bit high ABV...but so what?
Grapefruity/pine aroma. Taste is a little soapy, though has a nice amount of hopping. No malts to be found. Typical West Coast IIPA though doesn’t have quite enough of the major hops to be top-notch.

Pine, bready caramel, fairly bright and fresh with some grapefruit and mango notes.  Orange with a tall, white head.  Sweet, chewy toasted caramel witha nice spruce and fruity orange and flowery rose flavor.  Not very bitter.  Medium-full body, oily texture.  Thanks to Brigadier for sharing.

12oz. bottle.  Deep golden color with a medium sized white head.  Pine, resin, lysol aromatics.  Acrid/floral and fruity/resinous hop flavors over fairly sweet malt.  Some alcohol heat and a chemical spiciness in the finish with a lasting bitterness.  Mouthfeel is heavy medium, fairly dry.
Bottle. White creamy head. Unclear amber. Aroma of oranges and hops. Lovely hops flavor.

Real clear, dark orange pour.  Nice hoppy, spruce pine aroma typical of IPAs, which sweetened with some swishing.  I expected much more bitterness, but what I got was ground up kiwi seeds.  There was a hidden fruit in the body, like a fig of sorts.  Other than these minute standouts, this was a pretty typical IPA.  Not terribly different.  The finish is merely bitter and doesn’t grow into anything else of interest.  This only gets a 3.5 because I’m a big fan of IPAs.

Nice, clear amber body with a creamy, off-white head. Some lacing. The aroma is grapefruit and pine. Moderade bitterness, good caramel backbone (especially at the end), nice g-fruit hop flavor.  Finish is slightly soapy.

Pours a pale copper golden, with a thin tuft of white head. Nose is nutty and malty sweet with no real hop action. Flavor is pretty tame. Some honey like sweetness and a mild residual bitterness. I guess the bar has been set way too high on double ipa’s for some brewers.

a little activity inside after the slow pour and then a mild amber sand stone color emerges with little head carring a verry jumpy taste with a bold brite aromma and a small after taster of pine trees.

12 oz bottle, sixer. Cloudy golden pour, vicious chunky head that quickly faded.  Very piney aroma, marked orange tones.  Smooth and almost like it wants to be a little sweet with a kick in the ass of hops, hops are mostly sticky pine, but short aftertaste, fruity hops tones.  Nice and even body.  Not at all harsh, just very abrupt and punchy.  Indeed, much better than I anticipated.

12oz bottle pours amber with a nice fluffy white head that didn’t stay long..  Aromas of pine, grapefruit, caramel malts, and some nce sweet blends of those.  Flavor is nice full bodied caramel with an assault of pine and grapefruit.   Finish is some caramel sweetness but mostly the bitter pine and grapefruit hops..Not bad!

22 oz bottle from trade with acertain



Shared with malachi and hezron.  I was looking forward to this one.  It poured with a rich white had.  The liquid underneath was an opaque golden with visible carbonation.  Hints of grapefruit, pine needles and a general flowery bouquet wafted out of the glass towards my nose.  My first impression upon taking a sip was of caramel or toffee dipped pine with a nice balance of bitterness and hops.  The finish was great; my only complaint being that it could have lasted a little longer.  I look forward to getting my hands on another bottle - this is an IPA I could drink regularly.

Pours with a thick white head that fades in a few minutes to a smaller head.  Surprisingly clear for such a big beer.  Tons of hop noteswith a little citrus.  Good stong hoppy flavor, and a thick mouth feel.  Does it’s job, but then I like big beers.

Smells of lots of hops, of the Cascade variety.  Pours a ligher shade of amber than I would have expected - filtered and see-thru.  The head on this sucka is Maximus.  Tastes like a good IPA should.  You get that local brew pub hoppiness in this widly distributed brew. Nice. The taste left on the palate is plesent and dosen’t annoy.  Thank God this is an UNLIMITED release!
Pours a clear copper color with a small head.Great pine/citrus hop aroma.A nice balance of hop and malt with a great bitter finish.Only downfall is the body is a little thin.

Picked this beer up on a business trip to Arizona.
It pours a dark orange/amber with a solid head and steady lacing. 
The smell is good and balanced hops. Not over the top at all, but delicate and citrusy. It’s got a subtle yeastiness in the smell that’s like a good fresh bread. 
The taste is subtle at first, light green hops, a good bit of sweet/sour bitters. Nothing mind blowing, but a beer doesn’t need to be "huge" to be damn good. I would put this in the just write catagory. Not a landmark beer, but if you see one out and about, dont hesitate to pick one up!

Amended: I let this big bitch warm up...HOLY DAMN this is a different beer! drink at 55-60 degrees and this beer is awesome!

Dark, gold color with a nice hoppy smell.  Very nice taste of a sweetness but it had more of a malt flavor to it.  Nice bitter finish at the end.  I wouldnt say it doggone good like it says on the bottle.  Just good for an Imperial IPA.

Nice head, strong hop aroma.  22 oz. $3.39 at Fred Meyer.  What a deal.  Even though hop flavor is strong too much maltiness seeps through for my idea of an imperial.  Very good though, strong bitter aftertaste that lingers.

(03.17.06) One pint, 6 oz brown bottle purchased from Liquorama.com.  7.5% ABV. IBU 72.41, OG 1.080. Pours clear orange with tiny white head. Soft carbonation. Sweet malt and hop in the nose. Full bodied IPA that starts with moderate malt sweetness and intense citrus (grapefruit)/pine resin flavors.  Hop flavors and bitterness increases in the middle. Finishes with lingering hop flavor and bitterness with soap-like flavor fade.  An  unbalanced beer,  this aggressive hoppy beer will leave the inside of your mouth feeling raw.  Diehard hopheads will love this beer. Not for the timid.

Can you have too much of a good thing? I think so, after having tasted this beer. Maybe its because I found it unbalanced or poorly integrated or whatever adjective you want to choose, but this had all the rich colour and powerful green hop aroma I expected, however the palate was overpowered by bitter hop flavour, leaving it a bit harsh. Heavy mouthfeel, but not smooth as you’d expect. It was still good, but it just didn’t strike me as it did some of the other raters.

Clear amber with a solid, rocky head. Intense citrus and flowery aromas. Sweet caramel flavours, blending harmoniously with citrus and flowers, eventually ending drier. Medium bodied. A California IPA that manages to be more well-balanced and harmonious  than most.

Grapevin Mkt. $4.59  22oz.  Yum yum gushing flavors and abundant cascades bring to the front of the nose all that is west-coast wonderful. Caramel and tangerines and medium bodied barley satisfy my five mile thirst. A bargain I’ll seek out again.
Pours red-orange with a nice fluffy creamy head. Pleasant piney grapefruit aroma. Nice hoppy kick, but drinks pretty smoothly. Decent beer.

22oz. bomber. Clear amber color with a small white head. Citrus hop aroma with some sweet toasted malts to balance things out. Flavor was more hop heavy than the aroma. Big citrus hops with a bit of pine also. Some sweet malt in the background.

Amber color. Sweet hop aroma, with some underlying citrus and pine notes. Flavor matches the aroma, a little on the sweet side than what I was expecting. Hoppy finish, but still somewhat on the sweet side. Solid beer, but nothing special.

Bottle 22 oz.  An excellent IPA.  Glowing amber/orange color, slight white head, with a slightly sweet hoppy nose.  Not too overpowering, but plenty of that nice bitter hoppy flavor.  Overall, an above average IPA, that I would recommend if you can find it.

Quite dissapointing aroma, it was very light with some solvent and alcohol and a mild hop note.  There is little in the way of hops in the flavor as well.  On a good note, for such a strong beer this is extremely smooth and balanced beer.   It is very drinkable but not the hop bomb I expect from a double IPA.

On tap.  Deep orange color with no head when it arrived.  Nose is heavy on the hops, bitter citrus and candied orange.  Flavor follows with great body.  Had this a lot from bottle as well, and it still rates highly.  Great IIPA.
A very hoppy armoma of fruit and floral scents greets the nose.  The color is a rich dark amber with a tan head.  Flavor is strongly of grapefruit and finishes with a decent hoppy bitterness.

A very nice hoppy IIPA. Not too overly agressive but still has some good kick. But, all of the sweet and bitter flavors blend together extremely well for a beer that has a lot going on but still goes down well.

Pour thick cloudy dark amber with a thinwhite head. Big Floral/Hop aroma. Lots of hops in flavor but not overpowering which is nice. A touch of malt but the hops are stronger. Theres a little alcohol bite which is pretty well balanced with the hops.

Overall a pretty good IPA. Pretty well balanced and refreshing. Cheers to Lagunitas for this one.

This is a new beer to me. Sampled from a 22 oz brown bottle this beer poured a bright orange-caramel color with a large soapy light tan head that leaves good lacing. The aroma was tangy with moderate piney hops and fruity hops. The flavor is tangy and sweet with moderate piney and fruity  hops and a bit of perfume. Long tangy hoppy finish.  Medium body. Tasty.

Rich, coppery amber coloring with practically no head, but a few very large bubbles are coating the surface.  Some grapefruit and red pine greets my nostrils, but with a mild manner.  An underlying sweetness escapes from beneath the light hops aromas.  Texture is actually quite carbonated and far less sticky than expected.  The bubbles create a bigger tingling sensation on the tongue than the hops.  Slightly sweet, and not nearly as hoppy as expected.  The finish comes quickly and a little brash, as a touch of metallic alcohol bites through.  Not bad overall; I can see this being a nice, fairly light summertime IPA.
