"Poured an amber color with a small head and a little lacing. Aroma was of pine and citrus and could pick out the grapefruit. Flavor was of grapefruit and hops. Light mouthfeel. "

A "baby step IPA" is how soem might describe this.  I mispoured this and wound up with sedimnet in the glass, which did not make for a great experience, but I think this is a good one, and I would definitely try it again.

Cherry and citrus aromas are very evident.  A nice gold body for this IPA, very good for it’s style. Very minimal white head, even when poured rough.  A little bit thin on the taste, but good hops and some orange.  Malts are very evident in the ending, which partially negates the bitterness that I have come to expect from IPAs.
hazy orange color with a creamy white head. Aroma of hops with some malty hints. Citrus bitter flavor with some light malt in the background.
Pours cloudy orange with a medium white creamy head. Fresh hoppy aroma with some citric orange notes as well as pine like notes. Medium hoppy taste with a good blending of malts and hops. Dry body.

22-oz. bottle.  Pours a coppery orange sunset with tiny bubbles quickly rising to form a rocky, frothy off-white head, good lacing.  Orange citrus rind and pine aromatic bouquet with traces of yeast (sweat) and malt (meal).  Heavily bitter, moderately acidic citrus rind, pine and resinous flavor that scorches the taste buds almost to the point of hiding the medium sweetness and malt, yeast notes.  Medium bodied and spicy, lively carbonated palate.

here’s a murky cognac colored pour with plenty of scree suspended throughout. given enough time-- an epoch or two in geological terms-- these chunks are abundant enough that they would likely coalesce into a new continent to rise from the tempestuous waters. needless to say, i couldn’t wait for that.  the head was there to enjoy immediately: a sticky head of pug-beige that bloomed and slowly receded like hot breath on a cold window. amid vanilla wafers, spent tea leaves and a note of alcohol, the hops express themselves in voices like orange marmalade and crushed spring pine needles. and those voices are hip, energetic and synchronous, daddy-o. they could form a girl band and sign a motown recording contract while most people are still padding around in their underwear, scratching their ass and nursing a hangover. neatly balanced caramelly sweet malts and a strong bitterness across the tongue, like you’d tried to lick the rust off an old packard fender.  easy carb, full bodied-- not a hop cannon that demolishes everything, but a scatter gun that nails the waffle malts, the oak-like alcoholic overtones, and the lingering bitterness . lingering? you betcha: my saliva was still measuring about 40 IBUs twelve hours after drinking. ah che wa wa.
Hazy orange colour with a small fast disappearing head. Lots of hops in the aroma, hints of resin too. Hoppy flavor with some malty notes. Hints of resin too. Floral hoppy and long aftertaste.

LTD sampled 6-2-2008: Pours copper w/ a tall lasting head. Good lacing. Strong bitter sweet aromas. Full nctar w/ good carbonation. A fat malty sweetness pushes bright, fresh citrus candy forward. The hop component grabs my tongue and ties it in a knot while the malty goodness tries to soothe my wounds. The finish is bittered well w/ a malty sweetness hanging in the wind. 

Maximus Regular: Pours a golden copper color w/ a full, semi creamy froth. Good hangtime. Residual lacing is clasic w/ a full down comforter and snail tracks. Aroma of fresh hopsy pine sap and thick malts. Nice! Full nectar w/ ample residual nectar. Ths is a malty version w/ a mild sweetness balanced by a moderate grapefruit rind hop profile. Flavors are integrated well w/ a touch of perfume. Fat caramel malts, punchy hops, what more could you ask for ? The finish is long and leaves a mild sweetness on the palate as well as abundant grapefruit bittering.
 Flavors are more pronounced as it warms. Not as hoppy as the commercial description suggests and a little light on the alcohol for it’s style. All in all a rather enjoyable beer that leans slightly out of style. If this brew was the typical 9 or 10 abv with this same balance, it would be a classic brew indeed.

Slightly hazy light amber pour.  Nose is crisp citrus, C-hop, honey, spice.  In the mouth it is a crisp, clean flavor, lots of bitterness and floral.  Very nice.  Aftertaste is a soft bitterness and honey.

Poured into a snifter.  Head quickly dissipates to multi-sized bubbles.  Extreme tingly hop notes. Hazy golden color with little active carbonation.  Lively taste with lingering bitter hop finish.  Very nice.
Hazy orange beer with a white head. Hoppy floral aroma with a malty caramel sweet background. Malty, light toffee sweet flavor with a fruity hoppyness.

(bottle - 22 oz) Clear reddish and coppery color with a soapy yet lasting slightly off-white head. Heavy floral and hop aroma with a slight undertone of caramel malts. The taste begins with a smooth and peppery hop taste and goes to a floral middle and slightly sweet middle with a peppery and floral finish. Leaves a nice and bitter aftertaste.
(On bottle)Impressive title, but kind of a quiet drink. Has a good hopping, nice berrÿ/sugarish aroma and a full malty finish, but not enough to be a real kicker.
Hazy amber with a thick, tanned head. Very hoppy aroma (well, of course... it’s an IIPA..) with hints citrus, grass and flowers. The bitter finish lasts...

Bottle. Copper colored with creamy white head dragging fine laze. Aroma is "typical American IPA": Cat pee, citrus etc. Flavor is malty with hints of apricot, strawberry. Finishes with intense sharp and pleasant bitterness. Gets a bit watery in the end, but nonetheless very good.
Pours a deep dark orangish amber color.  Aromas of big hop action, sweet malts, and more hops.  Flavor has some caramel malty tastes with nice grapefruit and floral hop taste.
Clear copper with a light tan head. Piney c-hop nose, fairly sweet, really resiny. Sweet, but not overly so--nice caramel notes, quite bitter, with grapefruit and orange.
It wasn’t a BAD beer.  but it just felt like something was missing.  i felt it was decent, but it lacked anything really special.  like a good guitar solo with no emotion.  good, but not great.

Decent head with good carbonation.  Lasts for quite a while.  Lighter than expected aroma with some cherry, citrus and floral hops.  Medium orange in color.  Plentiful hops and bitterness in the flavor.  Some floral.  Could use some more malts for balance.  Bitter dry finish.  Very crisp with a lingering hops aftertaste.  Decent but there are many better IIPA’s out there.  Mine seemed to be a little lacking in the hops department compared to some other reviewers.  Second try the hops are more pronounced and juicy.
This was all hps, Top to bottom. Poured a dark tan body with lots of grapefruit and hops in the nose, and in the aftertaste. It was even better in summer.

One of those beers I was shocked that hasnt been rated.  Almost a semi dark amber color. Very enticing hop and pine aroma. Leads to a big citrus flavor. I think the hop character was nicley subdued.  Like the three bears it was just right. Mouthfeel is smooth with a nice touch of malt. Ends with a nice lingering bitter taste, outstanding.
this was an excellent example of an imperial ipa.  althought it loses points for not being stronger in alcohol.  Great balanced hops flavor start to finish

Mostly diminishing, creamy, off-white head.  Extremely hazy amber/brown color which I can’t see through even when put up to light.  Aroma could be stronger for such a big beer.  I detect a small amount of piney hops which is accompanied by a medium maltiness, and a hint of orange citrus.  The flavor has a light orange citrus sweetness.  The bitterness is very strong, which I very much like, but doesn’t have that piney bite which makes it well balanced.  Body is more thick than watery, but not as thick as I would prefer.  Overall, a execelent IPA, but I would call it a one and a half IPA.
Bottled. Pours a dark golden with a white head. Aroma is very hoppy, slightly malty. Taste is malty, and very hoppy. Long bitter aftertaste

(Bottle 65 cl) Beautiful, clear amber with a creamy, thick head leaving some lacework. Distinct aroma hops in the nose. Flavour of sweet caramel malt with a very solid, hoppy finish. A very typical Double IPA with a routinely touch. 221005

22 oz bomber.  Golden orange beer, thick, fluffy tan head and sticky lace.  Hoppy aroma, fresh, lightly grassy, moderate resinousness and a massive sweet citrusy aroma.  Orange and a bit of juiciness.  Some pale malt aroma backs up all of the hops, but doesn’t interfere with it.  Flavour is quite a bit sweeter than the aroma would suggest.  Light caramel, cookie dough and biscuity malts underneath a juicy citrus hop flavour.  Moderate bitterness up front but presents a lingering bitter palate.  Nice, easy-drinking beer.
Bottle. Light hazy amber colour with a medium tan head. Sweet very floral, fruity, hoppy aroma and a sweet very hoppy, bitter taste. Medium body and a sweet bitter dry finish.
Amber color. Small head. Strong, hoppy, fruity aroma. Very hoppy flavor. Some fruits and a very bitter palate.

Pine and citrus aroma (not as much citrus as other offerings - kind of muffled.)  The taste has the grapefruit rind.  More rind then grapefruit so it has a bitter component fue to extra hops (I guess).  Dry but well balanced not too hoppy for an IPA above average.

Sampled @ GABF- Pours a clear golden color, small white head. Aroma is citrusy, lemons and such fruit. Flavor is somewhat thin, astringent body with pine needles and light fruit notes. A slightly floral dry finish.

Draft at The Ginger Man, NY. Clear amber color with a moderate white head that diminished slowly with good lacing. Good hoppy and pine aroma. Medium body with a dry texture. Full well balanced flavor with a moderate bitter finsh of good duration.

This IPA is definitely different, as someone suggested, from the offerings of Stone.  But in it’s own way this one is just as good!  It smells sweet, piney and grassy or citrusy.  Not a lot of head when poured, but what is there lingers on and on.  The color is pretty typical, though a bit more amber and hazy than some.  The taste is initially sweet, then hoppy, bitter, and resinous or piney, whichever adjective one prefers.  The palate is medium-thick, a bit sticky, but not overpowering.  The finish is clean and bitter, with some lingering floral notes.  I like it, and I’ll try it again when I find it on the shelf!

Thanks Secret Santa!  Pours to a thick frothy white head atop a hazy amber body.  Nice lacing.  The aroma is resin and lemongrass and something floral but strange.  The flavor is lemongrass, caramel, strange yet good floral hops.  The palate is fresh and not overly oily.  Smooth, medium-light, chewy body.
(Draught - Toronado) Nice amber with a small white head. Lovely pine hops aroma. Abundants hops flavor, but enough malt to balance.

Bottled.
Clear amber coloured with an off white head.
Aroma of hops, pine needles and caramel.
Flavour of pine needles, hops, fruits and spices.

GABF ’05.  Clear amber body under a thin white head.  PNW hop nose.  Big, hoppy flavor: resinous pine sap plus grapefruit flesh.  Very fresh tasting.  Pretty normal caramel backing but the freshness and zipiness make this a winner.

Golden color white head great lacing.  Hoppy aroma grapefruit some lemon grass and very light carmel.  Palate is lightly creamy but not big.  Flavor is even bitter citrus and grass some lemon rind and carmel.  Could be better but pretty good.. a bit small.

Exactly the kind of Imperial I would expect from Lagunitas.  Looks and smells like any good IPA.  The taste is what separates this brew.  Hops are definietly there, but there is a lot of fruits and citrus, with a little malt and possibly mint.  This could be in its own category.  Highly recommend.

This doesn’t have the power-punch of hops or intense bitterness as some other double IPA’s like Stone Brewery’s Bastard & Ruination offerings, but that’s not necessarily a bad thing.  A couple of Stone’s beers are too bitter and a little unrefined for my tastes.  Lagunitas Maximus is just a much more balanced double IPA.  The hops are readily apparent in flavor, but they don’t overwhelm.  Creamy citrus is and some malty sugar is introduced with each sip, but not spoiled by an aftertaste that is too bitter. Essentially, it boils down to individual tastes; this has a lot of character and balance for a double IPA, but not the extreme hoppiness of some competitors.

Aroma had pine, ctirus, graitfruit and caramel.  Taste had citrus and graitfruit hops.  Very well balanced but kind of one dimensional.  Very malty palate.  This to me is more like a single IPA.  Very nice brew.

All the IPA aromas floral, pine and also some sweet malts. Copper color body and small off white head and lot of lacing. Citrus hop flavor that IPA’s are known for along with some sweetness. Dry fruity aftertaste on palate a good brew.

this iiis a tasty ....brew!" Great proud orange hue, with a big bold head that laces to the max! the smell makes u think back, oooh ya! Sweet bitter taste that is cleaner than there regular ipa, This brew’s a party in my mouth and everyones invited!

Pours amber-orange with a large pearl head. Decent lacing. Smells like a hop sandwich. Very citrusy flavor, with a piney finish. Not as extreme as other Double IPAs, but creamy in the mouth and fairly delicious.

Awesome summer beer, period. This beer has got it all, plenty of bitterness and hop aroma to keep things interesting, plenty of alc to keep you happy, plenty of malt to back up those to. But how do they keep it so damn easy drinking?!!!
[bottle] Pours dark copper - flavors are strong pine at first, then grapefruit and smooth malts. Strong bitterness lingers.. this is excellent.

the beer poured a rich copper color and i have no idea about the head or lacing (wasn’t paying attention and it was poured into the biggest chimay glass ever!)  flavor is easy with hints of pine, hops and malt (which creates a nice balance).  very slight citrus/bitter flavor towards the end as well.  i enjoyed this more than their ipa.

Translucent copper in color with a few miniscule bubble cloisters for the head.  Consecutive pours yield somewhat of an icy head.  Island party of sugar sweetened grapefruit, pineapple and papaya enzyme for the aroma, joining forces with orange extract and fresh honey.  Flavor creates a nice encasement that seems to kick-start the saliva glands into overdrive, and then knock it back down to a dry, chafing finish.  Oily, honey dipped hop pellets with borderline sour grapefruit characteristics.  Some hovering citric oranges and lemon juice in both flavor and the causal palate response.  Traces of dactylic alcohol, which seems improbable while looking at the stats.  Admirable sweet malts give a honeysuckle composure, finishing with a bitterness that seems to dangle from the larynx.  Well done.

Sampled from magnum bottle. Maximus pours clear copper with a dense, frothy, off-white head with sheets of lacing. A great looking beer. Its aroma is bursting with American hops, but the malts are present and accounted for as well. Flavor is nicely bitter, but a big malt presence adequately disguises the 72.41 IBUs. Caramel and peppery, piney hops dominate the flavor. Its nice, but really simple. Full-bodied, moderately-carbonated with a lingering, bitter finish. Very well made!

It’s a modest, creamy, yellowish head sitting atop this deep orange IIPA, but it manages to do some serious lacing as you drink.  There’s a sturdy pine and grapefruit hop scent emanating from the ale with a bit of caramel malt oozing through.  Medium-bodied and slightly oily, it delivers a solid hop bitterness atop a sturdy malt backbone.  The finish is surprisingly abrupt, leaving only a light bitterness in its wake.  Pretty decent over all.

Liquid Solutions

Very cloudy orange with an ok head that didn’t last.  Floaties in there too.  I think my bottle was a little overaged.  Aromas were great.  Very sweet vanilla/caramel along with the expected hops.  Flavors were quite hoppy.  Somewhat viscous with a decent IPA finish.  I think I may have to re-rate this one in the future someday.

On tap at the Northside Restaraunt.  Pours a cloudy dark orange amber with an average size off white head.  Strong aroma of pine, floral hops and citrus.  Flavor is dry hopped, floral, some citrus and pine.  As expected very hoppy, not as nicely balanced as some other IIPA’s I’ve had, but still great. 8-4-7-4-17

Re-rate from a bottle...Pours a translucent golden amber with a smaller bubbly off white head that left some light lacing.  Aroma of citrus, pine, floral, caramel malt  Flavor of floral hop flavor, pine, light grapefruit and some caramel malt.  Kind of thin and really not as great as I once remember.  Still a solid beer.
Pours light light orange with an average white head. Aroma is citrus, grapefruit hops. Taste is sharp grapefruit hops. Light body. Nicely hopped. Reminds me of Mojo ipa, somewhat.

Deep orange gold with some white head. Big citrus hops in the nose mixed with caramel. Taste is more of the same. Needs more complexity however. Smooth and light body for the style. Drinkable but forgettable.

22 oz. bomber courtesy of Saarlander via our latest trade.  big citrus aroma hits you up front.  pour is a nice amber with a white head, fading to a ring of lace.  this is more of a big IPA, not really an IIPA.  caramel malt flavor is present but overpowered by the hops.  a nice beer and will look forward to drinking it again.  just doesn’t seem like an Imperial.

22 oz. bottle.  A hazy, amber/copper pour with floaties and a smallish tan head that leaves rings of lace.  Usual I2PA aroma with tons of hops and citrus fruits and some hints of pine and caramel.  A little smoother and a lighter body than expected.  Hints of caramel at the start and a nicely bitter finish that hangs on for quite some time.  Just not as full-bodied and flavor-packed as the better I2PAs.
Floral dank hops in the nose, very fruit and sweet smelling as well.  Flavor had strong hop kick and was quite dry.  Decent carbonation created a nice lively mouthfeel.  Could use more balance.
Bomber. Pours orange color w/ off white head. Nose is hopps and sweet alcohol. Taste is light w/ some alcohol finish and some light hopps. Small bitterness in the end.

not quite up to the standards of the better IIPA’s.  good though.  had this side by side with two brothers hop juice and the hop juice won out.  it was interesting how different the hoppyness was between the two this was milder and a lot less resiny.  the two brothers won out, but this was acceptable.

Not hugely bitter. Actually, pretty corn syrup like. More of an imperial amber than I2PA, in my opinion. Not very good for an I2PA, but okay.

update: on tap it’s far superior to the bottle.

Had Hercules, enjoyed this one much more. Sweet Tea, lemon, hoppy and very very good. Underrated in my opinion. If you haven’t had this one you’re missing out. Big flavor, very drinkable. Very satisfying beer.

Near clear amber with a moderate head, decent lacing and retention. Aroma is grapefruit, grass, pine, etc etc with caramel and sugar backing. Not extremely pronounced though. Some alcohol as well. Medium bodied with a somewhat bitter and alcoholic finish. Would have preferred more hop flavors and bitterness.

Cloudy amber w/ thin finger of creamy tan foam. Lots of sediment. Good lace. Big, hoppy (pine, mint, grapefruit), surprisingly malty (carmel, toffee, cookie dough) aroma. Thick, sticky feel.  Heavily bitter flavour w/ lots of sweet malt to support. Long, dry, leafy, peppery finish.

gold with lots of floaties, big foamy off white head.  fruity citrus and earthy aroma with apricot and pine.  flavour is sweet, toasty and caramely with tangy citrus and pine.  earthy finish with lasty grapefruit.  not as bitter as you’d expect.

Lots of citrus in the nose, almost banking on sweet fruit (peach) and cherry.  Nice bitter start that continues with a great hop balance throughout.  Definitely not over the top though - balanced decently with a malty backbone.  In today’s world of extreme hop juice though, this should be bottled as their IPA and their IPA should be bottled as a Pale Ale.  Solid, but definitely mild for an IIPA.

Bottle. Pours a orange gold color with very little head. Aroma is citrusy and floral. Taste is pretty malty for an IPA though the hops are present, especially in the finish. Finish is sweet and bitter with a lingering grapefruit aftertaste.  Tasty!

22 oz. bottle.  Poured a nice orange-tan color with a whitish-tan head.  Aroma is piney and fresh but not overboard with hoppiness (knows its bounds).  Tastes maltier than many IPAs, but the hops dominate.  Alcohol is hiddden in aroma and taste.  Overall, a very good brew.  Not a double IPA, but somewhere in between a regular IPA and a double IPA.

Pour is bright orangey amber with a big tan head...smell is soap and grapefruit...taste is very sweet...citrus, sugar...very malty doughy...hops come out in the bitter finish with a smallish alcoholic kick and sweetness...

Courtesy of Pailhead. Re-rate bottle from Larry Pitonka. Orange/amber with nice off-white head. Nice hoppy aroma of pine and bitter citrus. Flavor has lots harsh bitter pine, and faint citrus up front. Flavor turns to a very astringent bitterness, slightly cardboardy in the finish. IMO would score much better  with some more malt for balance. But that’s just my preference. Re-rate didn’t change overall. Bumped up palate 1 point and knocked down aroma 1 point.
Damn nice beer.  Definitely has the hop thing going on, but with a nice complex malt background as well.  Not something I’d drink all the time, but a nice IIPA.
O n cask @ the Falling Rock poured a clear copper with an off white head. Body was a little thin. Aromas of carmel and light citrus. Flavors of bitter carmel and citrus with a dry finish.
Golden yellow with a citrusy-piney aroma. Bitter upfront with a floral taste, and some sweetness in the finish.

something special for my 400th. A bomber of this sought after impy IPA. Poured a murkey orange-gold with a creamy off white cap. Moderately carbonated. Aromas of sweet bread and grapefruit. Lots of chewy malts in this like sticky sweet cookie dough meets pine-citrus hopping in near balance...like the ad sez: " a raging mouthful of malt and hops". The finish is slow and erodes into not quite the promised  enamel melting bittering but was a pleasant bittering with an astringent- metalic aftertaste. This what Liberaty ale on steroids would taste like....I lile the well balanced hop and malt wallop of this big APA and I’ll buy it often.

Very slightly hazy amber pour. Big small beaded off white  lasting head. Chocolate, vanilla, pine, leathery tobacco nose. Uncrazilly hopped. Very toasty and breadlike. Sweet but not syruppy. Clean and lots of bright peach, caramel and minerally. Alcohol is more pronounced than expected. Very floral and the sweetness comes out as it warms.

light amber color with medium sized white head. Aroma is dry, faintly hoppy, slightly metallic, notes of caramel and oak. Flavor is malty, dry, slightly bitter in the finish. Overall it is good, but not quite great.

Bottle at Volo. Golden-amber colour with a small but persistant head. Aroma of rich, syrupy hops, with a woody/grassy backnote. Flavour is fresh & hoppy, with a bit of caramel sweetness, and a citric finish. Hides the alcohol very well, making it a dangerous one, especially when you’re drinking a whole bomber bottle by yourself...

Pours a dark copper with an off white creamy head that sticks around.  Smells of citrus and grass.  Tastes of brown sugar and caramel. Not as hoppy as I’d lik out of a IIPA but still nice.  Warming alcohol finish.

Bottle:  Courtesy of beerguy101.  Citrusy (orange) and hoppy aroma but not as strong as most IIPA’s.  Pours a mostly transparent orange with a touch of haze.  Very small white head that is just barely a thin layer for a head.  Flavor is very citrusy, but more actual citrus than citrus hoppy.  Citrus hops come in the finish, but not as strong as I expect from an IIPA.

bottle poured dark orange amber with a good head a lacing.
Big aroma of hops and citrus with 
Flavor is all citrus and hops with a great bitter citrus finish.
alcohol is very well hidden.
Awesome IPA!

Fresh, clean aroma, sweet malty, woody, oil scented nose. Smallish but nice creamy top, snowy amber. Strong high hoppy front, full-bodied ale but still you were able notice potent alcohol presence .As time goes by this trace gets more and more pronounced. More than I wished for.
Big bottle.  Dark hazy orange ale, no head, little lace.  Another classic DIPA - powerful hops, lighter on the malt than some.  Kinda close to Stoudt’s DIPA.
Dark golden with an off-white, disappearing head. Sweet with a dominant, flowery hop nose. The taste is rather piny from the hops with alcoholic notes and a perfumy aftertaste. Dry.

bottle. orange body with a medium short lasting head. citrus hop aroma with a slight sweetness overall.. sweet sharp hoppiness. it’s very hoppy and there isn’t a whole lot of balance. lots of citrus orange rind flavour. Mediocre IIPA.

22oz Bottle.  Pours orange colorwith decent white head.  Nice grapefruity hoppy aroma.  Decent flavor - sweet malts and citrusy hops.  Good malty citrusy flavor and mouthfeel with a good bitter finish.  Body was thin for me - I was expecting more of a big IIPA, and this is more like a kicked-up IPA.  Good beer tho.

Bottle. Shared with Tupalev at Volo post Ireland victory. Golden orange body, moderate white head. Very resiny, slightly piney aroma. Didn’t pick out as much complexity out of the aroma as I might have out of a snifter or my usual Unibroue glass. Mental note for future ratings. Surprisingly well balanced.  Fairly bitter, leafy hops with very slight citrus and resin. Medium palate. Quite quaffable for a strongish beer, alcohol doesn’t make itself known until its too late.

Better than average beer, perhaps the near-room temperature on a very humid day did not do it justice. Had at Volo Cafe. Bomber needed to and was shared. Good retained head. Floral hoppy, initially grapefruity aroma. Smooth

Bottle at cafe volo- Sparkling amber body, orange hues. head is thin and beige. Some lacing here. Aromas are hoppy, piney, bready, caramel. Taste is citrus and hops bitterness, with some grapefruit and pine for good measure. Slight burn, and an alcohol bite in the finish. GLad I got to try this one. Shared with Radek and Dougshoemaker. Cheers!

(22oz bottle) Sampled at Cafe Volo, Toronto. Pours a large, frothy, almonde head with a deep orange body. Nose is very hoppy, leafy-fresh with undertones of citrus. This is a very bitter hop flavour with a mild bite of alcohol. I was expecting another level of dimension but its not there. This is a fine beer but not worth the extra $$$ over Hairy Eyes which seemed like a bargain.

Bomber. Pours a fairly dark  orange. Aroma is sweet and malty with a hoppy presence. Lots of malt up front giving way to some hoppy bitterness towards the finish of this brew. Nice strong presence from both the malt and the hops. Throw in a little sweetness for good measure.

Poured a copper color with a small white head.  Aroma of hops and alcohol with malt to back it up.  I was suprised to smell alc with this low of an ABV.    malty flavor with hops running through it.  Nice bitter finish.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry at Bar Volo. Pours a hazy amber with a frothy average white head. Earthy aroma heavy on the hops with some citrus. Flavour wasn’t as hoppy as I expected -- bitter, spicy and a bit malty.  I found I could taste the alcohol a bit too much. May have been served a little too warm. A good IPA, I would definitely get it again, but ultimately I was a little dissapointed.

Bottle (650ml) At Volo, shared with blankboy.  Pours golden, clear, lots of bubbles.  Head slightly off-white, quick diminishing.  Flavour mild to start, then the hops kick in - heavy hop on palate and linger.  Again, I’m not a big hop-head, but if you are, you’ll be happy with this.  I don’t get much maltiness in this one, or citrus either for that matter.
Aroma of peach nectar.  Appears crystal clear copper-orange.  Flavor is bitter hops over sweet peach/apricot.  Palate medium-light, nice.

22 oz bottle.  Bright clear orange, thick fully lasting puffy head, substantial lacing...resin dominant in the pungent, earthy hop aroma profile, perhaps some leather and grapefruit...ample body presents a challenging amount of wet piney PNW hops, low to moderate sweetness, intense bitterness late along with an odd and perhaps misplaced licorice-anise undertone...it’s interesting, different from other IIPAs I’ve had recently, but doesn’t totally come off for me.

650ml bottle, Volo.  Orange Pour.  Thick bubbly white head that faded quickly.  Strong earthy hops in aroma - a really wonderful not over the top aroma here.  Very strong malt taste, all hopped up and sharp, yet I found it a bit subdued given its reputation.  Medium to full bodied.  It does at limes, taste a little thin and watery (hard to do with this much going on), but only slightly.  This is an excellent strong, sweet hoppy beer that I would gladly have again. Another thanks to Ralph at Volo for taking a chance (red tape and cost only 2 difficulties I’m sure) and bringing this in.

22 oz bottle.  Hazy orange with a big frothy, long lasting head.  Scent was a bit on the weak side but wow, what flavor.  Big hoppy jolt of grapefruit, orange peel, pine and freshly brewed tea.  The special thing about this beer is the huge bitter finish that lasts and last.  Super IPA!!

22oz bottle. Served at 51.3°, to start, in my NB worthy glass. I popped the cap and it started to bubble over so I poured it ASAP. The beer is hazy orange with a good deal of finely ground pepper sized floaties and a hazy white head. The aroma is primarily orange and floral,  with some grapefruit and a nice wildflower honey backing. Really nice smell, very inviting. The taste is sweet orange blossom honey to start with then comes on the herbal bitterness that finishes dry and bitter, but not overly so. The mouthfeel is good, but not overly full. This is a great drinking DIPA with nice citrus flavors and some good west coast bitterness. Addendum: The hops are potent, instead of decreasing when the beer warms up they just keep on coming strong. They are puckering and make my cheeks tingle.  THIS IS A VERY GOOD BEER, I MUST JUST BE VERY CRITICAL NOW WITH THE IIPA’S SINCE I HAVE HAD MOST ALL OF THE VERY BEST

22oz bottle. Loved this bottle.  To  me, this is how a DIPA should drink...the beer had some sweetness, but the hops overran it and it did finish bitter.  I get so dissapointed with a sweet DIPA...yeah, it needs some sweetness for balance...and this one had enough for balance.  along with a solid bitterness. Head and heels above the one bottle of the "regular" IPA from them...this one provided the juice...hops were piney, pine tar, resin...not really the big citrus fruit, although a bit of that was there...I’d have liked more, but the balance of bitter/sweet was just about perfect for me...lean on the bitter, don’t stomp with it...this one leans.

Couleur ambrée tirant vers l’orangée, grosse mousse blanche mi-persistante.  Arômes proposant le zeste d’orange, le persil et la terre.  Manque vraiment de malt et de caramel pour venir contrebalancer l’amertume qui semble être amer juste pour l’être, sans aucune bonne raison.  Corps de densité semi mince, faible carbonatation semblant trop effacé pour le style.  Finale amère et presque  astringente et un brin oxydée.  Décevant sur toute la ligne.

Aroma is a  lighter than anticipated orange hops, hazy orange colour, small off-white foamy head. Flavour is hoppy, with some malt background, giving a nice balance to this medium bodied beer. Terrific! 

 Thanks again to Ralph @ Volo for being bold enough to bring these beers to Toronto!

Had this in Malibu at a canyon side B&B prior to my graduation.  The aroma was had to get at due to the wind, but a brief trip indoors allowed for the discovery of full sweet malt and lightly crisp citrus hops.  The brew was relatively nice looking, having an amber appearance, heavy carbonation, and a frothy head.  The taste was sweet malt, including caramel and toasted malt.  Some nice crisp citrus hops (orange and grapefruit are pronounced) but overall they are subdued for a 2IPA.  A good brew overall and a nice drink. Glad I tried it.  Don’t know if I would seek this out for the style though

This drink wallops the hell out of your mouth with orange and grapefruit and juniper berry flavours.  Bitter to the core.  I don’t think I’ve had such an overwhelming hoppy drink in as long as I can remember.  An EXTREME double to say the least.

From notes taken at the Southwest Beer Festival in Scottsdale, Arizona. The conditions were hard to take notes in but these are the ratings and they stand. Good stuff. Well hopped with a good balance. Nice bitterness. People at the tent were cool.
a very cloudy beer, yeast sediment is highly visible.  hoppy, malty and full bodied.

Great beer, but not what I wanted out of the style.  It’s a bit too sweet and not enough bitter in my opinion.  Very similar to Hercules, if I remember correctly.  Solid none the less.  Thanks again to thefatmanrocks for sending this as a surprise, alongside two Double Bastards in a trade.

Cloudy orange. HUGE puffy white head. First impression is how malty this. I expected it to have more of a hoppy bite, especially for an IIPA.  TONS of sediment. Too much so for my liking but nevertheless this is really drinkable brew that I’d happily drink again simply b/c it’s got a good flavor and is well balanced.

Sweet orange and hop juice nose, some fruity/grape and pineapple hints; full, round body and sweetness with a fresh citrus hop finish, chewy and sticky palate; I think the sweetness really holds up the substantial hoppiness of this brew; if you like their IPA, you’ll really like this. I’m so impressed with this brewer: Great Brew!

This has actually a musty caramelly malty aroma with some hints of citrus orange and grapefruit mixed in.  This does not smell like your typical west coast IPA.  Mildly hazy copper color with a small light tan/yellow head.  Burnt toast flavors in the end.  Almost like a burnt popcorn.  Whoa.  Some bitter hops, but definitely an overburnt flavor to finish.  I don’t know if this was brewer’s intention or a bad offering.  Theres a slight vinous sour character to start.  This bottle might be off...

Bright amber/orange pour, with a thin coating of lace that clings faithfully to the glass. Hard candy sweet, with a light aroma of citrus, fruity hops. Hoppiness is very subtle with this one, giving the malts a nice showcase. Toffee, caramel, hard fruits, and a pleasant peppery finish. Somewhat grassy. Full and rich mouthfeel. A grand imperial, great job Lagunitas!

Whoa, this is a good one.  Sip it slowly and let it trickle down your throat for maximum enjoyment.  The hops are very prevalent and satisfying.  A tinge of citrus tickles the taste buds, and the malt graces the tongue in the finish.  If you like this style, you’ll love this brew.

Hazy orange body with small particles.  A foamy white head and spiderweb lacing all the way down.  Citrusy hop aroma with a slight twinge of sweet malts.  Slight bitter taste like grapefruit rind, but not over powering.  A sweet malty carmel taste near the end.  Slighty thick and clingy in the mouth.
perfect balance between malt and hops, very hoppy but not overpowering like many IPA’s. nice head good lacing, all around a great brew

Bottle. (bought on 10/7/04) Paired with Basque Shepherds Cheese.  Pours a heavy golden/amber, with some floaters, and a thin but dense creamy white head.  Nice stream of bubbles emanates from the beverage.  Aroma is pale/caramel malts nice balanced with sweet honey coated citrus hops. Less overwhelming in the hops department that I expected from the beer, but very good nonetheless.  Nice sweet ripe hops flavor.  Great medium body and high drink ability.

A good IPA with an interesting yeast character in addition to the typical aromatic, citrusy bitterness.  Malt character is excentuated by the alcohol content.  A pleasant beer overall which most closely resembles an extra hopped American strong ale.

4/9/05: Bottle
Flowery hop nose.  Body is a golden orange color and head is off white.  Medium lace.  Flavor is hoppy and plays with honey, lemon and tea.  Clean finish.

Bottle from LoweredSixth.  Nice copper orange color with a dense off-white head which lingers and coats the side of the glass with lacing.  Aroma is nicely floaral and citric.  A touch of caramel malt sweetness pulls through also.  Very nice job with balancing malt sweetness and hop bitterness.  Body is a touch watery.  Taste is initially malty and balanced which gives way to a slow hop bitter buildup and finish.  Nice.

From BA warriorsoul, this came in a 22 oz. brown bomber with a paragraph of musings on the edge of the label.  The beer was poured into my trusty tulip, and looked very nice, with an orange body that contained a touch of haze.  The head was perfectly proportioned at two fingers thick with a rocky, foamy, creamy appearance.  Patches of clumpy lace clung to the side of the glass as the beer was consumed.

The aroma was grassy and herbal, and not as overwhelmingly hoppy as I had presumed it would be.  The alcohol was poking its head through the hops as well.

The taste was where the hops showed up in a more assertive way.  The bitterness was up front and center, but as the tongue adjusted, biscuit like caramel malt made an appearance.  The finish was grapefruit and floral with a peppery tang.

Medium mouthfeel was closer to a single IPA than a DIPA I think.  The body lacked the heft that other beers from the style typically possess.  Nonetheless, the beer was mouth coating and satisfying.  Aftertaste was bitter and dry, but a little short lived. Definitely a notch above the run of the mill IPA, and very drinkable, but not quite a DIPA

Clear, golden pour.  Typical Lagunitas style slw of west coast hops, with strong hop presence offset against malt.  Alcohol was too visible, destroyed the balance.  I very much prefer their Hairy Eyeball if I need a strong IPA.  Disappointed by this one.
So not  an Imperial IPA. Nice beer very drinkable not a standout in any area. I hope they really ramp this one up.
Bottle: Clear orange-amber with a small white head.  Aroma: sweet honey, hops, fruit.  Taste: sweet malt, citrus, lemon, grapefruit.  Has a crisp, bitter finish.
Smells of nutmeg, homemade chicken soup, resin, and caramel.  Tastes malty....nutmeg notes (lots in the aftertaste), also some sourness in the swallow.  Spicy, not hoppy at all.  Strange.

Steady IIPA, pour was a very pretty golden copper color, with a mild white head.   Nose was very piney, with some citrus and something I cannot determine yet.  Taste is quite bitter loaded with hops, and finished off with a descent malt touch.

Dark copper in colour with aromas of Cascade and grassy hops. The flavors are mellow for an IIPA, medium bitterness with a whole lot of syrupy malt. The finish is powder dry and has a biscuit quality (which I’ve experienced with some Irish ales). I liked that quality, but I could see others not appreciating it. This is kind of a baby-step IIPA, but still a quality beer.

Bottle Pours a clear copper color with a modest but fine and creamy off-white head.  This settles out fairly quickly leaving that thin white ring that produces a thin, sheet of lacing. The aromas are mainly a soft pale grain maltiness and a hopps that is not to sharp of edgy.   Flavor is a bit sweet, honey maybe, and again the hops, while prominant are not overly bitter.  Very smooth and fairly heavy feel for the style.
Pleasantly bitter and slightly chalky aftertaste.
A strong hoppy opening within the light amber brew. Fairly balanced through the middle but a bit bitter on the finish.

pours light amber with a white head. aroma is sub par.. tastes piney, citrusy, pretty much like a regular IPA but a little stronger. I can think of many other ipa’s i’d rather have, but this is still pretty good. far from the "raging mouthfull of hops" that it claims

Aroma is not pleasant. I would probably prefer to take a whiff of a dirty sock. Clear copper in color. Sparse, slow visible carbonation. Excellent lace, but small head. Interesting flavor. Sweet, a little cloying with a solid alcohol profile. Nice overall, but would be hard to drink in quantity due to the cloying quality. A big beer. Hints of being really good, but doesn’t quite cut it.

Pours Golden orange color with nice head that stick to the edge of the glass. Hoppy Aroma.  Taste of caramel and alcool rounded with citrus hops.  Bitterness ok but not as powerfull as other double IPA I have tasted.  Overall it is well balance and  pleasent to drink.

Very nice, in fact, it seemed much better than the last time i tried it.
Not the most bitter beers in the world, it actually had pretty good balance despite the name.
Highlly recomended!

floral hoppy aroma, pine, also some baking soda. Pours a light copper brown, nice foamy head. Hop bitterness lingers but with a name like Maximus not as hoppy as I expected. Sweetish for the style. Enjoyable but not at the top of the heap.
Pours hazy golden orange color with little head.  Aroma of citrus hops but it’s faint.. great malty taste with a hoppy addition and a slight alcohol finish..

beer pours a hazy golden-amber with a well-formed white head that laces well. aroma is the usual American, citrusy hops (although a bit less pungent than I would expect in a double IPA), backed up by some toasty malt and, unfortunately, some diacetyl (butter). flavor is more of the same, with the hops again being somewhat understated for the style (especially flavor-wise), and their flavor getting somewhat covered up by the diacetyl. plus, the bitterness carries quite a bit of astringency. even without the "d", this is an underflavored (hop-wise) double IPA at best-hardly a "maximus". back to the drawing board

Pours a very foggy, dark orange body with a thick, sticky head.  Strong piey aroma with maybe a little carmel.  Great balance between the sweet malt flavor and the bitter piney hop finish.  Good stuff.
A really fine California IPA that shows up front hops balanced toward the sweet side with bitterness and fills the mouth with overwhelming hope and honey notes

It tastes like a pumped up Lagunitas IPA rather than an original creation. A touch of IIPA syrup in the flavour and body. Hops did not seem overly strong as even my swill drinking buddy enjoyed it without exclamation.

Pours slightly turbid deep copper with a white head and significant hop floaties (I threw an ounce away, damn it!).  Aroma of big resiny hops, pine, citrus, malt, and slight fine cognac.  Great aroma.  Tastes hoppy, malty, with some fruit and a well balanced, very complex finish.  As it warmed, some syrupy apricot and caramel made themselves known.  This one is heavily hopped (and dry hopped) yet very well balanced, with more fruit/resin/biscuit at the esophageal space.  This one is up there with Hercules and Marin White Knuckle as the cream of the lower-upper tier of Impy IPAs.  I kicked myself hard for not buying 6 of these.
Draft: Orangish, nice white head, citrus and hop aroma, flavor of sweet citrus, medium bitterness, intensely flavorful, freakin good.  Quite easy to drink many of these at once

A cloudy amber-orange color, the head a light tan with some noticeable lacing. The nose is of floral hops, citrusy, light hints of malts too. Well the beginning is sweet----yep,  definitely malty sweet.  A strong departure from the Moylander I just tried.  This isn’t bad, just different.  The mouthfeel is very thick, much more so than the Moylander.  The finish, is all ’Hops’, somewhat dry, a bit acidic, with a nice bitter aftertaste. Another fine example of this great style.
Light hazy gold with restrained hops aroma, very pleasant. Good solid sweet malts with hops comming well in final, but not in your face. Alcohol very present, but  overall  pleasant. (Sept. 2004)

Bright orange color with no real head.  Sharp mouthfeel when cold.  Light flavor, not a very strong IIPA.  Bitter aftertaste.  Pretty damn good, but more of what I would expect from a IPA not a double IPA.
Thanks, EDA.  Golden clear with a little white head. Aroma is hoppy. Flavor is hoppy. Finish is dry.  Drinkable.  Piney citrusy aroma. Nicely balanced. Finish is bitter. Medium bodied. Nice beer.
Thanks, EDA. Golden clear, white head. Hoppy aroma and flavor. Slightly thin. Dry finish. Lacking a bit when comared to the 50 other IPA’s I drank today...

Clear copper with a frothy white head.  Nose is mostly malt, not the hop explosion I expected.  Mildly piney, but still a bit mixed with cooked caramel. Good hop flavor off the bat, but kind of a thin feel in the mouth.   Certainly a very bitter aftertaste.

Wonderful piney grapefruit hop aroma, even on the second whiff, thick mouthfeel that tremendous high powered malt hop blend. not quite as wide and bold as Dogfishhead, but still a classic taste. falls apart a little at the end and becomes a little alcoholy, but still a great brew

22oz bomber. This pours a hazy amber orange color with a good sized off-white head that dropped down to a coat of bubbles after a few sips. It left good lacing around the glass as it was consumed. Hops fill the nose of this one as citrus and floral hops pretty much take over the smell. Notes of malt sweetness can also be detected through the hoppiness. The taste is lead with a bit of a sharp bitterness that is balanced of by the malty sweetness soon after. Notes of citrus fruits can be detected and there are also slight traces of alcohol. Mouthfeel is very full and creamy and it is very drinkable. Not as bitter and hoppy as most DIPA’s but a good and balanced beer none the less. Definitely give this one a shot.

orange body with a foamy white head that didnt stick around for long.wonderful aroma of hops,malts,and flowers.
the flavor is outstanding.very smooth for a double ipa.
tastes of hops,flowers,and a beautiful carmel finish.gimme more please!

Hazy orange beer with a foamy off-white head. Nice complex aroma of flower hop, fruit and toffee. Flavor is nice with lots of fruit, oranges, flower and bitter hops and a long lasting finish with hints of citrus and a tone of alcohol. Yummi!
An unclear orange beer with an orange head. The aroma is sweet hoppy and grassy. The flavor is sweet hoppy with a dry hoppy end. Quite simple, but nice.

Bottled. Orange-amber, big fluffy head. Orangey nose. Sweet and boldly malty with soft, but syrupy and fatty mouthfeel. Like sweetened, concentrated orange juice, but with very bitter finish. Too sticky.
Slightly cloudy honey color - smells like sweet hops.  Decent head- strong initial taste of hops and slightly bitter.  Decent IPA
Not as hoppy as I hoped. However, it is a good beer. Lacks more of everything. The balance is good between the ingredients. We just want more of it all. A beer for the masses!

Bottled: Golden coloured. Light beige head. Hops, sugar and herbs in the aroma. Flaovur is fruity, hoppy and has light spices. Is nicely bitter in the end. Lacks a little power in aroma and flavour to live up to some of the greats of the style.

Delicious, slightly creamy texture.  The malt and hops blend nicely at the middle and end to form a very  pleasant finish.  Somewhat yeasty, hops definately linger.  I could (and will) drink a lot of this!  22oz for just $ 3.19

Hazy copper colour with a nice light beige head. Aroma of malt and alcohol with a sharp pine scent. Flavor reveals the similar qualities to the aroma, just a bit more subdued, the malts show up much more in the flavor. Lingering hop flavor. Tasty.

A deep orange amber ale with a dense, creamy, white head.  The aroma is an engulfing embrace of resiny, piney, grapefruity hop sitting on top of a sweet malt pillow.  Flavor is intensely fruity, almost bubblegummy malt blended with the same hops as the aroma though subdued against the big malt.  Where hops dominate in the aroma I find the malt dominates the beginning of the flavor profile then the hops take over but they are less descript than the aroma.  Acidity and an alcohol induced menthol hop flavor make a nice, long finish to this beer.

Oh yeah. I dig this color of a used copper kettle.

Smells of new leather, fresh cut alfalfa, sage scrub, a couple warm caramels on the dash board.

Not as big as Arrogant Bastard which I just reviewed, but equally balanced. My tongue is on this roller coaster: Caramel, green rose (hop flowers), caramel corn, wet grass, caramel apple (granny smith), juniper, toffee, orange rind. Oh god, dry, dry, dry, make it stop! I want to do it again!

I love IPA’s because they’re so good with food. They compliment dishes like chicken piccata, tomato sauces, anything with herbs-right. But an IPA like this can stand up to substantial dishes like this rabbit, andouille-n-roasted green chile gumbo I made tonight. It’d be great with green chile, Mexican.... Alone, as a quaffing brew, this is a bit sharp on the bitterings, but pair it with food and>brewhaha>this is a king of refreshment.

orangey amber in color, offwhite head, very foamy, almost rocky.  draping lace pattern all around the glass.  pine, orange, marzipan aroma, hop too.  surprisingly light mouthfeel, fairly thin and low carbonation.  citrusy sweet malt start - pink grapefruit with a bit of honey.  mild hoppy finish - for a double IPA.  actually this is a great single IPA in my opinion, more of a sesh IIPA.

Rustic Orange. Great Head. 

Biscuit malt, spicy sweetness, caramel, pine and grapefruit in the nose.

Pretty delicious. West Coast hoppiness. Juicy. Light fruitiness. Great hop flavor with sharp and pungent pine and citrus notes. 

Full in the mouth. 

I want another.

Ahhh west coast hop monsters.  This fits right in with the crowd, but it’s a hell of a crowd!  Big hop aroma, bitter citrus flavor, good mouthfeel, nicely intoxicating.  Bonus- 2.99 at Hi Times!  Woot!  (this is my third rating tonite, I’m losing my edge :P)

Aroma is obviouslly hoppy, with nutmeg, and pumpkin.  Nice amber body, with lasting frothy white head.  Not an overhopped IPA, pretty darn good, would be excellent if you have a cold (for some reasons IPA’s make me feel a lot better).

Easily the best IPA available in Arizona.  "Head" and shoulders better than the dull, mono-dimensional brews from Ale Smith and Stone that have better reviews.  I can only assume that not many people have had the chance to enjoy this wonderful concoction.

orangey amber nadda on the head.But boy the nose of this brew is ohhh so nice.most IPA’s I it is like grapefruit but this offers something completely different.Sure you have the Grapefruit hop blast but then it is almost like the person sitting next to you is drinkingorange spice tea and to aroma from that mixes in.The falavors aren’t quite as intriquing but still a very nice blend of flavors vs the norm.Nice body and a lasting tasty finish.Thanks to loweredsixth for bringing this back to me.
Poured a medium to dark amber with a large off white head. Some floaties. Strong aromas and tastes of pine, citris (oranges)  and a little grassy. Nice bitter finish. Light malts. I liked this one.

Grassy, lemony, slightly woody and caramel aroma. Some strange antiseptic hints. Orange color with a small tight white head and lively carbonation. Lagunitas is one of the few breweries that regularly has pieces of hops in its beer. I don’t know if this is meant to be or is a quality control issue but it doesn’t bother me a bit. I am more interested in flavor than esthetics. Sharp, slightly acidic flavor passes quickly over a mild malt middle to a bitter finish. Relatively complex, puckering hop flavor profile. Especially good for the price of less than $3 per bomber but somewhat unbalanced.

A plump malt cookie keeling over with an obvious alcohol breath...Green bitterness overwhelms the back of the orangey hop kiss and almost makes the tongue recoil...A little cream cannot add to the unidimensionality and stands there as the taster slowly gets acquainted with the quenching but punching hops...

Sweet orange, cookie-like yeast and marzipan in the aroma. Pale copper coloured with plenty of yeast in suspension. Off-white head recedes to thin cover. Agressively bitter and very strongly alcoholic. Seems like there’s not enough malt to balance. Smooth in the mouth but fairly simple. Low carbonation. A bit of a one-dimensional hop monster. Bottle enjoyed with beerbuzzmontreal, lubiere, MartinT and Rastacouere.

Murky amber, tons of floaties, nice 1cm head. Big aroma of herbal oranges. Light earth components and something lactic, not unlike meringous. Straightforward malt introduction, sweet, a bit maple-like, but then strikes the unforgiveable, harsh floral/grapefruity citric bitterness. Low to medium carbonation, medium bodied. Extreme stuff and I’m not huge on the style, but still one of lagunitas’ best by my standards.

Cloudy amber color with lots of sediment, thin white head and few lacing. Aroma of piney, green, spicy hops with alcohol and citrus. Flavor of hops, spices, alcohol and citrus. Everlasting bitter finish. Light to medium body, creamy texture, soft carbonation.

This brew pours a glowing amber with a tall white head. Tons of citrus hops in the nose and a very well balanced smooth taste. Slightly sweet malt start finished off by a great citrusy bitter end with tons of hops.

22 oz. bottle.  Nice head over amber, golden color.  Aroma is hoppy with hints of citrus and apple (would have liked more aroma though).  The flavor is fairly bitter but good amounts of flavor hops are also present.  It has enough malt to back up the alcohol content so it is a nicely balanced beer.  There is some sort of spicy flavor probably just from the yeast strain.  Lagunitas simply makes great beer and has made quite a presence in the microbrew industry.  I stocked up on a few bottles of this stuff since it is a seasonal.

A well designed body with lot of floaty junk just hanging out in the glass. Aroma is a fresh hops and pine perfumes.  Not a real noticable fruity side although it sends me signals of apricot.  The alcohol percent is up so you get that malty background while your drinking.

This IPA had one of the most unique smells of any IPA Ive had.  Of course it had that awesome hoppy aroma- maybe some simcoe or ammarillo or somehting real fruity and pungent.  Plus it had a wierd sweet aroma almost like cotton candy- wierd but good nonetheless.  FLavor was also sweet and malty with a perfect amount of hops up front and in the finish.  Nice bitterness lasting on the tongue.  Very cloudy hazy orange color but looks real good.

bottle from Happy deli NYC
ntce orange amber color,
strong hop aroma as well as flavor.some citrius in therecloudy.full mouthfeel smooth pretty good
i imagine this would have been better on tap. amber, aroma was more subdued than expected and quite citric. a little flat, peach nectar texture, hint of white grape, finish of aluminium roofing

This IPA is just fantastic. A mouthful of hops in every sip. Perfect amber-caramel color...and those little yeasties floating around....awesome! The finish sits around and just lets you enjoy it. 72 IBU...gotta love that.

Nice tan head that hangs. Hazy copper color. Piney hop nose, pleasent fruityness. Medium body, lightly oily. Nice hop juice! Solid toasty malt background. Finish is dry, fruity, hop-a-licious! Yeaya! Thanks to snowtiger for this one!

Cloudy, amber orange appearance that threw off a lot of sediment.  Aroma was dominated by citrusy, resinous hops as was the taste.  The small malt presence added a bit of a caramel flavor for a short while, but then was overwhelmed by the hoppiess.  Full-bodied wih a biting, bitter finish.

This one pours amber to orange with a medium creamy white head. Leaves quite good lacing in the glass. Aroma is very fresh, good piney hops, citrus and a nice malt background. Flavor is very full on the hop profile, very refreshing, nice malts and a good alcohol burn. The end is finished with a nice earthy bitterness. Very full bodied and very drinkable.

The Maximus pours a cloudy copper-orange with some big floaties in it (tons in the second half of the bomber pour).  It has a big pillowy off-white head that has great retention and lacing.



Its aroma is piney, floral hops with some citrus notes and some light malt.  Not as strong smelling as I would expect.



Its flavor is strong on the hops (spicy, piney and resiny) with a pretty strong bitter taste throughout.  It has some sweet and citrusy malt initially.  At first the hops dominated, then the sweetness became a little cloying, but as it warmed it balanced out fairly nicely.  The mouthfeel is a little thinner than I expected, with a sticky lingering bitterness.



Overall, this is a nice solid DIPA.

hop smell is very powerful, i can smell it across the table from me.. pours out amber colored with a thick and creamy looking tan colored head.  smells floral hoppy and has a hint of pine.  taste is good, very good mouthfeel and easy to drink.  has a good lasting bitterness in the aftertaste.  a good iipa, but i cant wait for my yulesmith and great divide to get here!

Pours a copper color with a small head and a fair amount of lace.  Aroma of citrus and pine.  Sweet and sticky hops, caramel, and a fair amount of alcohol here.  Tastes like hop oil.  It’s like a super dank bud.

Bottle. Golden amber beer with a decent white head. Citrus and pine aroma. Big pine/grapefruit flavor. Lingering bitterness. Malt is there, but the bodu is slightly lighter that many other beers of this type. Nice hop tingling.

Nice red/orange body. Small fizzy almost white head. Aroma is very pleasing, yet light. Seems like sweaty subdued hops that give way to a nice caramel malt. Taste is a sour cascade type of thing. Pleasing mouthfeel, and overall very good, but flavor is slightly lacking.

22 oz. Bottle.   Red and gold color.  Not quite amber, not quite orange.  Unique color and nice to just look at.  White head looked like a small cauliflower.  Lots of faint aromas, but hops dominated.  Despite the high alcoholic content it drank very well.  The last drop was as good as the first drop.  This one is a real winner.  Since I first rated this I have had a chance to rate many more beers and ales, and so I decided to go back and have another 22 oz bottle. I simply have to raise my rating a little.   What makes this so very good in my opinion is great balance.
Orangeish brown color with a medium white head. Fresh hoppy aroam with hints of caramel malt. Toffee malt flavor with a big bitter hoppiness. Slight toastiness as well. Dry citric hop finish.

pours almost orange with a thick white head that laces down the glass. smells of sweet applesauce. taste is of earthy fruit. there is some malt flavor to balance this out, leaves a pleasant finish of roasted apples.

Bottle. Nice pour, orangey with a thick one finger head. Nose is fruity-notes of apple, corriander, grapes, and hops come through. First taste is easy to describe: hoppy and bitter (YUM). The hops overpower the other flavors, so they are hard to pull out. The best part is the finish-very clean and smooth. Overall a good IPA, very enjoyable.
Poured a deep amber, nice head that left a lot of lacing. Strong aroma of hops with a little citrus. Went down really good.
Medium amber with a nice-sized head. Smells more malty than hoppy, but it’s clean and crisp. Taste is super-hoppy with only a slight grapefruit and pine flavor. Great mouthfeel!
Pretty good. Nice full sharp hoppy nose with just an undertone of malts. Enjoyable and surprisingly easily drinkable.

An intense IPA.  Amber with beige head.  Not very impressive visually but the nose was strong hops, grapefruit, alcohol.  Great mouthfeel.  Rich and thick.  Flavor had kick to it.  Hops bitterness in a good way.  Fruity.  Grapefruit juicy.  Kick ass IPA.
Nice golden body with nice head and good lacing. The flavor is very balanced. It has a nice hoppines with a good malt background. Very pleasurable beer.

Foggy orange appearance, lacey white head, citrus hops aroma, intense hop flavor, apple, grapefruit, surpisingly sweet, mmmm so bitter, the palate is great, preftect carbonation, malty finish, this is just what i need to simmer down after a 48 hour architecture binge, this beer is heaven compared to what ive just been through and will likely recieve a higher rating because of it

Bomber. 05.24.04  Honey gold color.  Medium head, much lacing.  Pretty beer, nice, lingering carbonation.  C-hops and sugar on the nose.  Lots of sugar, infused honey, sugar.  Otherwise, it’s a pretty run of the mill IPA, sort of an oily, resiny attempt at 90 Min.  Prominent, but not greatly balanced hops make this I2PA less than great.
Bottle. Really dissapointing. Just really tinny, rusty American hops, no length too the flavour. Typical pine/grapefruit.

Golden amber body with a chunky white head.  Arome of pineapple and sweet malt, some citrus as well.  Flavor is mostly sweet citrusy hops, not very bitter but with a noticeable alcohol tinge.  Finishes dry and sweet.  Good.

Pours amber with a rocky off-white head. The first glass of the bomber is clear amber while the second glass has a good amount of floaties. Aroma is malty, bready and yeasty. Taste is nicely bitter and sweet with a ton of hops with grapefruit, citrus, vanilla and pine. Chewy, earthy and spicy. Good malt backing. Nice lacing on the glass. Mouthfeel is perfect; full, round and creamy. Good stuff.

This is an interesting brew. The sediments in the bottle make me froth at the mouth. They taste like little hop sprites. Pours with a giant head. Uncontrollable. Color is light copper amberish. Head dissipates. Smells Florally and piney...mostly piney. Mouthfeel is nice and thick due to the alcohol. As others have noted it looks too pale to be 7.5% but definitely is. Pine tar lays out flat on the back of my tounge, with strangely enough a swiss cheese bitterness. aftertaste is astringent like rubbing alcohol...not that I’ve drunk that before though...right. Good brew. Don’t think I could drink more than one in one sitting though. Ruination still dominates.
G-rat
This is a solid IPA.  Very strong hop character along with some citrus flavor.  Wow, large head initially then diminishes with good lacing.
(Bottle)  Pours a clear amber color with a small, quickly diminishing head.  Has a refreshing aroma of spruce, grapefruit, and orange peel.  Creamy palate and a hoppy flavor.

This IIPA pours with an amber orange body topped by a thick, off-white head with lots of lacing.  The aroma is slightly sweet and malty with a very slight hop note and a touch of lemon.  Not the aroma I was expecting.  The flavor is slightly sweet yet mostly bitter, piney and hoppy with a slight grapefruit note and a good amount of malt.  The finish is very bitter and piney.  Full bodied, slightly warming and slightly dry.
A thick golden color with robust head. A good flavor with plenty of hops that don’t overwhelm the taste. Not the best Double IPA, but tasty.  A little expensive.

22 oz bottle:   poured into a shaker.  really nice deep golden color with a modest creamy head.    doesnt smell as hoppy as i expected but, pretty nice.  feels goon in my mouth- thick creamy and alittle sticky.  tastes pretty malty and very hoppy.  its a really mellow double ipa but i like it alot still.

Pretty tasty little beer. Surprisingly pale for a beer ringing in at almost 8%. It’s a light amber, very clear on the first pour, with an excellent eggshell head that’s the perfect consistency. It lingers nicely as well. The aroma is intensely hoppy, as is the flavor, but the beer isn’t overly bitter. In fact, if it’s overly anything, it’s overly sweet. The sweetness definitely turns it into a slow sipper.

Big white head, dark orange color. Aroma: fresh, floral, fruity, hoppy. This is self-hyped as highly hopped, hence the boastful name, but on first sip, I’m not overwhelmed. First impression: a more alcoholic extra pale ale, but not the hoppiest of IPAs by a long shot. Smooth palate, medium body, easy-drinking.But overall, a disappointment.
murky copper color, crisp malt and awesome hop presence.....................
Damn i love this brew. Hoppy, great aroma, perfectly balanced, the English troops in India would have loved this.

Nice and resinous, but MAXIMUS? Not exactly sure what I was expecting... not exactly disappointed, but neither was I blown away. Was thinking that perhaps I was going to be treated to a relative to a double IPA. Seemed like a far off cousin that didn't study the lessons all too well and mumbled through the good bits. Still enjoy this brewery, so don't take it the wrong way.
Re-rate - While my opinion might not be vastly different, I think I was a bit harsh. Either that or the hop rate was upped. Rather nice and while perhaps not too complex, the focus on hops bolstered by some good malt makes this a rather enjoyable brew.

Bought in the 22 oz brown bomber.
Poured into my pint glass, it appears to be a dark orangey brown, darker than the usual IPA..nice persistent creamy white head, attractive looking carbonation.
The aroma? well two words, spicy and hops!
Taste surprisingly is almost balanced..at forst there is an exspansive malty sweetness..then the hop monster takes over at the back of the tongue..very dry with hints of alcohol.
Very intresting and nice on the palate.
Quite a drinkable ale..IMO..not bad.

Thanks to Eyedrinkale for sending me this Imperial Bomber a few months ago! 

 Pours with the orangey glow of a Halloween pumpkin, and a huge chunky cream colored head sitting atop. The aroma is a mass of caramelized grapefruit, guava, tangerine zests and a note of brown sugar. 

The flavor brings exceptionally dry notes of pinesap and spruce chips, and I’m talking about some spicy cedar like notes as well. I note some mild cigar tobacco… and large suggestions of a planter filled with developed mid-simmer marigolds. Big musty hops and caramel malt all the way through. This is a pretty tasty Imperial IPA… I just wish I hadn’t waited to drink it… I think it would have been even more alluring fresh!

22 oz bottle-pours a very nice orange hue-farily clear appearance.  minimal white head around rim of snifter.  Fairly strong grapefruit/pineapple aroma that reminds me of Goose Island Imperial IPA, but not as sweet as the GI.  Very piney flavor that didn't have the malts to back it up.  slightly astringent/metallic bite on the tongue.  Good Imperial IPA, but there are much better from CA.  Thanks to Loweredsixth for sending it and whaleman for letting us sample.

Deep golden-orange body with some apparent viscosity, mild carbonation, and a velvety off-white head. Nice lacing in my New Belgium snifter. Nice fresh grapefruit hop in the nose plus some malty, stone fruit action underneath. Piney bittering hops. Bitterness is actually understated but flavor is still mostly hops and therefore this is a bit one-dimensional. Additional qualities in the flavor emerge very reluctantly but do finally come out. Thanks to loweredsixth for sending two bottles my way.
Whaleman 2004: Pours orange with an offwhite head. Streaming carbonation. Not as big hopped as I thought. Light pine and citurs notes with a little soap? Enjoyable.

Cloudy and honey in colour with a huge head that leaves elegant lacing on the glass. Nose is floral and citrus with some malts. Opens sweet, middle is well balanced progressing to a hoppy bitter aftertaste. Well balanced and drinkable.

Awesome head and even better remaining lace. Pours a nice deep yellow/orange hue. Smells of oranges, dandolines and hops. Taste is very floral with just a bit of sweet malt to balance, finishing with a nice hoppy smack. Mouthfeel is medium with a nice slick oily caress. Very balanced, if not a bit pretentious, but I admire the intent. A very bold, citrusy hop blend. A great American IPA, with a fiesty attitude.

A solid IPA.  Nice appearance, good lacing on the glass and good carbonation level.  Hops dominate, but it's well-balanced.  As with most Lagunitas brews, a solid beer for the money and would recommend.

Decent flavor, ultra hoppy.
But it seriously looked like coors or something (very yellow, very pale, not hazy at all), had barely any aroma, and felt awfully thin in the mouth.  Overall not too terribly impressed, not very balanced.

Poured reddish orange with a medium white head. Aroma is very hoppy and citrusy with orange peel and grapefruit. Also there is a faint pine hint in there. Taste is also dominated by the citrus flavors. It's very hoppy with lighter malt notes. Some bitterness along with more orange round out the finish.

slow rising tiny bubbles, amber hued golden body.  dense, but dissipating white head clung on throughout.  fruity, ripe, tart and piney/  resinous hop character.  bready and biscuty with floral undertones.  Soft, full.  sweet and fruity frontdries out giving way to a bitter and fairly alcoholic finish.  crackery malts as well

This beer poured a cloudy orange with a medium white head.  I found that much of the yeast remained suspended in the glass.  The aroma was obviously of hops and the taste was the same, finishing somewhat dry and wanting for more.  This was worth it and I would recommend this brew  for anyone looking for a good IPA.

22 oz. brown bomber bottle. No freshness date or bottling date noticed. Poured out a brilliant, orangish / copper color, with a small, white head. The head was almost non-existent, but it left a really decent lacing down the sides of the glass. Aromas are kind of vague, let's see what I can pick out of it. Prime pale ale malts are here, along with slight hops in the background. Not much in the way of hops aromas. Maybe I got a stale bottle? Hard to say.
Tastes are of malty goodness, and slight hops bitterness. Other than that, there's no real discernable tastes here either. If this beer is 7.5% ABV, it sure hides it well. Unoffensive as far as tastes go, but finishes sweet. Almost cloying in nature. A good IPA, but not a double IPA, at least not to me it isn't. Bonus points for appearance, because of it's absolute clarity.

Mostly translucent amber-orange body with frothy white head.  Grapefruit fills the room upon opening.  Nice sweet flavor up front.  Light carbonation.  Syrupy-sticky texture with chalky sour milk finish.  Should make my regular rotation judging by how fast I finished it.

acquired from cquiroga. hazy copper color with a nice light beige head. aroma is astringent and sharp with pine. flavor reveals the similar qualities to the aroma, just a bit more subdued, the malts show up much more in the flavor. brown sugar quality to the flavor. the hops linger too, so this beer is damn nice..thanks to cquiroga for this one.

Medium to light orange, decent head.  Bitter but pleasant aroma.  Hop blast with a focus on the bitterness.  Malts are strong, trying to balance the hops, but they just can't do it.  Almost like a tannin driven Zinfandel that hasn't mellowed yet.
Beutiful orange/gold color with a light lacy head. Smells like fresh hops, and tastes like it too. Citrusy, crisp clean finish.

creamy pine floral sweet yet hop deluxe. plain fruit citrus, sticky pine aftertaste. i think this is the nearest (emphasis on NOT being dreadnaught) i've gotten to dreadnaught. this is excellent, yes, but it lacks. it feels thick, but the intention is not as thick it could be. i need something thicker. i need a larger soul. i've been spoiled, that's why. UPDATE 9/24/04: it's been awhile! thanks KEVIN!!! this is really just a hopped up IPA of their own... there's definitely a weak IIPA going on. rather than being seduced by the sirus of fruits and other sweets, i'm given a quasi-stinging tropical floor cleaner. it's not bad, though. i'm just elaborating on what i sense because i've never sensed a beer as it truly is. the head is marshmallowy and like a cloud, sparkly, and white. the body is golden brown. it's just... i don't know. it's good. i downrated a point, yet i think i actually enjoy this more than what i've remembered it to be. hmm. and i've nothing to say about the malts and yeast. hmm.

Pours a crystal clear darker amber color with a frothy white head and boy does the lace look good.  Oh yeah, it's got that hop kick, floral, bitter and some citrus coming out. A nice background of malts is present as well.  Initial taste. Nice. Malt and hop work together to make my taste buds sing praise. Floral hops, citrus hops, and some bitter hops roll around the tongue. Palate and body are nice. It has the up front hops that one would expect but it's got that malt backing that makes this style stand out. Very nice, not the best, but it's in the same league

(22 oz bottle, $4) Compared to others in the Double IPA class, this is a bit on the light side, but definitely more hoppy than standard IPAs.  In comparison to the other flavors in this beer, it’s extremely bitter, and at 72 IBUs is pretty bitter in its own right.  Lightly sweet and moderately fruity.  The subtle, bready maltiness is nearly lost behind the strong hoppiness.  The nose is reasonably balanced, lightly malty, but not strongly hoppy either, but for a Double IPA, the nose is rather tame.  Lighter palate than most other Double IPAs, with a long lasting, crisp, bitter finish.  Golden orange in color with a substantial amount of massive chunks of sediment, most of which is too heavy to be suspended in the beer.  Large, off white head has very good retention and exhibits a pentiful amount of spiderweb lacing.

Bottle pours an amber color with a frothy white head.    Lacing is wonderful.   Aroma of hops and flowers.   Taste is a sweet bitterness, but not dry.   Brief maltiness quickly gives way to the piney hops.   Mouthfeel is adequate.   Finish lasts and is quite bitter.   Not overly hoppy, well balanced, finish is smooth, with some bitterness.   Definately an enjoyable IIPA.   Yes, very good!

A very large light tan head erupts from this amber bodied brew. The aroma of hops is quite evident even without getting your nose down in the glass. Piney hops dominate the aroma but there is a good bit of sweet malt in there also. As for the flavor, it is piney hops with a smooth mildly sweet malt core. Sure the beer is bitter, but not nearly as bitter as some of the other IIPAs out there. Body is medium-full with a rather lively bit of carbonation. I remember having this beer years ago and not being able to believe how hoppy it was, how times and palates have changed.

Nose strings with moderate citrus hops.  Pours with a medium white frothy head, which mostly diminished, lacing is good. Appearance is amber and glows a translucent orange under the lamp. Flavor begins with lightly sweet malts and transitions to moderate bitter hops which lingers for a minute or so, well balance IPA. Body is moderate between gum and water textures, carbonization is low. Finish is well balanced hops and malt. Excellent IPA.
Golden with a big foamy sticky head. Nice grass and hops aroma. Kind of sweet, weak hoppiness but still a nice brew.
Big fresh hop and piny nose, hazy orange color and a lathery head. Decent malt body to support the heavy hopping. Meaty and a very full body.

...And this is how we go IPA without going over the top.

Pours a clear honey color. Nice head and nice lace.

Smells oh-so-hoppy, with a hint of the sweetness of the malt.

Tastes quite good! It's not the most complex beer I've ever had, but a very well balanced. The hops are heavenly but there's just enough fruity hops to keep it from going over the top. The hops are flavorful but not overly bitter.

Mouthfeel is full and creamy, yet crisp and clean.

This has got to be one of the most drinkable IPAs I've had. Most are too hoppy for me to enjoy one after the other, but I wish I'd picked up a few more of these.

2003 bottle. Interesting experience I had.  I try it at about 55 degrees and it seems exceedingly bitter, overhopped, out of balance.  I let it warm up to about 60-63 and all of a sudden there is ample sweet malt to balance it out.  Still, nothing out of the ordinary here, well made, PNW alpha hops, pale malt.  Very bitter.  Nice appearance, duller amber-red, small amount of head, tons of sediment that hangs in suspension throughout.  Typical bitter hop smell, mildly citric. Not overly complex in aroma, average complexity in flavor.
Bottle, nice clear pour with a reddish copper color. Big head, pine aroma to go with the hops. Not as hoppy as the name, more bitter than anything.

Smelled delicously hoppy but not as strong as the ruination.  It wasn't really anything special to look at; looked sort of like an amber ale :| good flavor though of predominant hops and slight citrus with a thick sort of smooth bitterness.

overall a little dissapointing.  Pours a light amber with nice white head.  The flavor is where I get stuck.  All the good floral and citrusy flavors of IPA that I like are missing here.  The first impact with my tongue tasted good, but going down, it had an all to powerful obtrusive bite... not a good one.

sweetish nose, loaded with crystal.  Golden color with a small head.  Intensely hoppy with an overpowering skunky hop flavor.  A good body but simply unbalanced and bitter.  Covers up the alcohol very well, lots of sediment.

Pours cloudy amber with thick white head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is cascade hops (serious hops here) with some malty tones as well. But mainly just hops. This has one of the most bitter finishes I've ever tasted.  There is a pause and then the hops kick in with attitude.  Packs quite a bitter kick in the end.  Alcohol is apparent in the taste after a few swigs.  This is one dramatically unbalanced beer -- all hops and bitter, very little malts.  I like it!
Pours a nice ruddy golden brown with a lacy head and floaters (yeast).  Sweet and hoppy aroma.  Flavor is full.  Sweet start that opens up into a sharp, yet subtle taste.  Mildly hoppy finish.

Pours crystal clear and an orange copper color.  Nice big head initially that dissipates to a small even head with excellent lacing.  Aroma is very, very fresh hops  (this reminds me of the Sierra Nevada Harvest Ale) with a decent amount of malt thrown in.  Flavor is full and sweet up front with the hop bitterness kicking in later than expected.  Finishes quite smooth.  Not really as hoppy as expected for a double.
very nice yellow&orange color and white head. goes down very smooth. crisp, mild taste which was scrumptious. good beer!
Aged about a year: Nice golden color. Light citrus scent. Definately bitter, but I think that age might have mellowed this a bit. Pine flavor.    An interesting, almost minty aftertaste. Enjoyable.

A hazy copper color, pours a bit on the thick side with an off cream to tan colored head that is fairly thick and lasting.  A hoppy aroma with notes of fruit and citrus, perhaps some aromas of a blooming field of some type of flower.  A full mouth-feel, quite thick for an IPA, even for a strong one.  This was yester-years American Barley-Wine.  The hops are there, but not as up front as I was expecting.  A sort of orange-nectar hop flavor.  This beer is quite malty as well.
